2601 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Macomb


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Niagara County


9 Misc. 2d 1027; 174 N.Y.S.2d 330; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3717



March 13, 1958 



DISPOSITION: The conviction is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of a Court of Special Sessions in the town of Niagara, Niagara County (New York), which convicted him of violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14, prohibiting a driver from operating a truck with an overload on the rear axle.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14 prohibited truck drivers from operating their vehicles when the vehicles carried too much weight on the rear axle. Defendant was convicted in a nonjury trial for operating his truck in violation of the statute. On appeal, he argued that N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 388 required the prosecutor to make an opening statement. The court observed that the purpose of the statute was to ensure that a jury received a preview of the issues to further their understanding. In a nonjury case, an opening statement could be omitted. Defendant also argued that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14 was unconstitutional. The court summarily cited to another case in which the constitutionality of the statute had been upheld.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for driving a truck with too much weight on the rear axle.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- overloaded truck -- defendant properly convicted of violating Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 14, subd. 8) in operating truck with overload on rear axle -- no opening statement necessary (Code Crim. Pro., § 388) where case tried before Justice of Peace -- sufficient showing that truck was operated on highway -- proper to use scales tested two months before defendant's arrest.

1. Defendant was properly convicted of violating the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 14, subd. 8) in that he operated a truck with an overload of 7,300 pounds on the rear axle.

2. Since the case was tried by a Justice of the Peace without a jury, it was not necessary that there be an opening statement (Code Crim. Pro., § 388).

3. There was sufficient showing that the truck was operated on a highway.

4. The scales used were tested two months before defendant was arrested. The period [***2] of two months is not excessive.

 

2602 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kramer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


10 Misc. 2d 473; 175 N.Y.S.2d 508; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3758



March 4, 1958 



DISPOSITION: The appellant having raised no valid ground for reversal, the judgment of conviction is affirmed.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Nassau County District Court (New York), which convicted her of willful violation of the terms of a lease in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 2040.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was the superintendent of an apartment building, and the complaining witness, a tenant of the building, alleged that defendant entered the tenant's apartment without permission and disarranged the furniture in order to paint the apartment. The tenant claimed that defendant acted with the intent to cause the tenant discomfort so that the tenant would vacate the premises. On appeal from the judgment of conviction, the court affirmed, finding that § 2040 did not offend due process because the term "interferes with quiet enjoyment" was sufficiently clear in its ordinary meaning to give warning of the proscribed activity. The court held that an amendment to the information against defendant was permissible because the original information sufficiently stated the matters upon which defendant was to be tried. The amendment merely strengthened the information. The court noted that the trial court had jurisdiction to try defendant and that the failure to inform defendant at her arraignment of her right of removal was not a defect that would invalidate the subsequent proceedings. She had pleaded not guilty and had proceeded to trial without objection.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of conviction.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- willful violation of terms of lease -- judgment of Nassau County District Court convicting defendant, superintendent of apartment house, for violation of section 2040 of Penal Law (willful violation of terms of lease) for twice entering apartment of complainant-tenant without permission, affirmed.

1. The judgment of the Nassau County District Court convicting defendant, superintendent of an apartment house, for a violation of section 2040 of the Penal Law (willful violation of the terms of a lease) in twice entering complainant-tenant's apartment without permission and in order to cause the tenant discomfort and in disarranging tenant's furniture preparatory to painting, should be affirmed.

2. The term "interferes with quiet enjoyment" in section 2040 of the Penal Law is not indefinite and is sufficiently clear in its ordinary meaning to give warning to the prospective [***2] wrongdoer that his contemplated act is proscribed.

3. The court can properly permit the amendment of an information even though the amendment affects a matter of substance. In this case, however, the original information sufficiently stated the matters upon which the defendant was to be tried. The amendment strengthened the information, but, as the amendment was conclusory, it was not strictly necessary in order to sustain a subsequent conviction.

4. At the time the alleged violation of section 2040 occurred and at the time the defendant was arraigned, a violation of that statute was classified as a misdemeanor. On June 1, 1954 and before the trial of this action, such a violation was changed from a misdemeanor to an offense. The District Court had jurisdiction to try the charge against the defendant (Nassau County District Court Act, § 230).

5. The defendant, by her attorney, entered a plea of "not guilty" and proceeded to trial with no apparent objection. In this case the failure to inform defendant of her right of removal for the purpose of having the charges against her presented to a Grand Jury (Nassau County District Court Act, § 231; Code Crim. Pro., §§ 57, 58) is [***3] not such a defect as would invalidate the subsequent proceedings.

 

2603 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Zimmerman v. Kelly


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Monroe County


9 Misc. 2d 989; 170 N.Y.S.2d 847; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3794



February 28, 1958 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner driver had his operator's license to operate a motor vehicle has been suspended by respondent commissioner, temporarily pending hearing, and sought to have the order anulled.


OVERVIEW: The driver attacked the order and sought to have it annulled on the ground that it was not authorized by the statute or alternatively that if the statute did so authorize a suspension without a hearing, it was unconstitutional as depriving the licensee of property without due process. The commissioner in his return showed that at the time he issued his order the only facts he had in his possession were that the driver had been arrested on a charge of speeding, that he was arraigned and deposited bail with the Magistrate, and that he failed to appear upon the date set for a trial and the bail was forfeited. There was no trial or plea of guilty and no hearing. The court held that upon these facts alone the order of suspension granted by the commissioner was ungrounded and should have been annulled.


OUTCOME: The court granted the driver's motion and annulled the revocation of his operator's license.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- operator's license -- petitioner, charged with speeding, did not plead guilty and has had no trial; order of State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles suspending petitioner's operator's license "temporarily pending hearing" (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 71, subd. 3) annulled.

1. Petitioner was arrested for speeding, was arraigned and deposited bail, and failed to appear for trial, whereupon the bail was forfeited. There was no trial and no plea of guilty. Thereafter respondent State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles suspended petitioner's license to operate a motor vehicle "temporarily pending hearing" pursuant to the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 71, subd. 3). Petitioner has had no hearing. The commissioner erred in making the order of suspension, and said order should be annulled.

2. Even if under certain circumstances, an operator's license may possibly be suspended or revoked without the commissioner first having had a hearing, he should have before him factual evidence of substantial character, sufficient to justify such drastic action.

 

2604 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Windsor Madison Corp. v. O'Connell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


9 Misc. 2d 1087; 172 N.Y.S.2d 198; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3915



February 6, 1958 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner business requested the court to review a determination of respondent Commissioner of Licenses of the City of New York that denied the business a license to conduct a going out of business sale.


OVERVIEW: The corporation applied to the License Commissioner for a license to advertise that the corporation was being forced to go out of business. The License Commissioner refused to issue the license under New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-28 The corporation contended that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-28 was unconstitutional because it deprived the corporation of property without due process and interfered with the corporation's right of free speech. The corporation also contended that the License Commissioner acted arbitrarily because the corporation was being evicted from its premises. The court held that the corporation's property rights were not being interfered with because the corporation was not being restricted in the sale of its goods and its prices were not being limited. The court stated that free speech was not involved. The court also held that The License Commissioner was not acting arbitrarily because the corporation previously conducted a sale improperly, and it was not certain if and when the corporation would be required to evacuate the premises.


OUTCOME: The court denied the corporation's motion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- licenses -- "going out of business" sale -- provisions of New York City Administrative Code requiring license to conduct "going out of business" sale neither deprive merchant of property without due process of law nor interfere with right of free speech; refusal to grant license not arbitrary.

1. The provisions of the New York City Administrative Code requiring a license to conduct a "going out of business" sale (ch. 32, tit. B, art. 28) neither deprive a merchant of property without due process of law nor interfere with his right of free speech, and are not, for those reasons, unconstitutional.

2. The police power extends to the regulation of advertising that may mislead the public.

3. The same formalities which surround the revocations of certain licenses are not required to be observed on an application for a license to conduct a "going out of business" sale. The applicant appears voluntarily, and if he is not represented by counsel nor informed as to what he must do to satisfy the requirements, there is no obligation to inform him.

4. The refusal of the Commissioner of Licenses to grant petitioner a "going out of business" sale [***2] license was not arbitrary, where petitioner had applied for a similar license on an earlier occasion, conducted a sale, but did not go out of business, and on the occasion in issue petitioner did not wait for the issuance of a license but displayed signs appropriate to a closing out sale.

5. While the governing statute, when read in its entirety, appeared to limit the commissioner's discretion to a finding as to whether the proposed sale was legitimate, his determination was not arbitrary. Neither the prior sale nor the violation of law in advertising without a license would necessarily be conclusive on that question, but as grounds of decision they were not so far afield as to be deemed capricious.

 

2605 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bevilacqua


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Essex County


12 Misc. 2d 558; 170 N.Y.S.2d 423; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3934



February 3, 1958 



DISPOSITION: The judgment of conviction and sentence are both affirmed.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Court of Special Sessions of the Town of Ticonderoga, Essex County (New York), which convicted defendant of public intoxication in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 1221.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested for public intoxication right after his election as mayor of the town. Defendant contended that after he was convicted he was improperly denied the right to a jury trial. However, defendant had no right to a jury trial for public intoxication under § 1221. The offense was triable summarily by the court. Defendant contended that the statement of the District Attorney did not constitute an opening sufficient to comply with N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 388. This argument was without merit where both the trier of the facts and defendant were well apprised of the nature of the accusation and the prospective proof even before the opening. The court found that the evidence was sufficient to sustain a verdict of guilty. Finally, defendant argued that § 1221 was unconstitutional because the word "intoxicated" in the statute was not defined and the term was so vague, indefinite and uncertain that the statute failed to prescribe an ascertainable standard of guilt and was a violation of due process. Defendant argued that the statute failed to make known to a person what conduct would render him liable to its penalties. The court found the statute was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of conviction and the sentence.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- public intoxication -- defendant properly convicted of public intoxication (Penal Law, § 1221) -- information sufficient -- defendant not entitled to jury trial -- statement by District Attorney constituted sufficient opening (Code Crim. Pro., § 388) -- evidence sufficient -- Justice of Peace before whom defendant was first taken properly permitted to testify on trial before different Justice of Peace -- Justice of Peace not incompetent to testify that defendant had admitted being drunk and had later denied it -- word "intoxicated" not so vague, indefinite or uncertain that it fails to prescribe ascertainable standard of guilt -- statute not unconstitutional.

1. Defendant was properly convicted of public intoxication in violation of section 1221 of the Penal Law.

2. The information was legally sufficient.

3. Defendant [***2] was not entitled to a trial by jury. Public intoxication is an offense triable summarily by the court.

4. The statement of the District Attorney constituted an opening sufficient to comply with section 388 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

5. The evidence was sufficient to sustain a verdict of guilty.

6. Defendant was first taken to the home of a Justice of the Peace, who observed defendant at the time of the laying of the information and the taking of a deposition. That Justice of the Peace was properly permitted to testify on the trial before another Justice of the Peace to whom, by appropriate order of the County Court, the case was transferred. A distinction is made between the situation where a judge or justice is allowed to testify before another judge as to matters previously had in his own court and the situation where the judge or justice would not be allowed to testify in a trial over which he is then presiding.

7. That part of the testimony of the Justice of the Peace in which he stated that defendant had later admitted being drunk the night of his arrest and, still later, denied it, did not amount to an offer to plead guilty which could not be admitted in evidence.  [***3] It either was or was not an admission. That, together with its voluntariness, was a question for the trier of the facts. Any other person could have testified on that point, and it was not incompetent for the Justice of the Peace to do so.

8. The word "intoxicated" is not so vague, indefinite and uncertain that it fails to prescribe an ascertainable standard of guilt. Under the New York law, a man is intoxicated when there is an impairment to his capacity to think and act correctly and when he has lost, even in part, the control of his physical and mental faculties. Accordingly, section 1221 of the Penal Law is not unconstitutional.

 

2606 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hayuk v. Hallock


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oneida County


11 Misc. 2d 1086; 172 N.Y.S.2d 19; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3988



January 27, 1958 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant driver, appearing specially, filed a motion for an order to vacate and to set aside the services of the summonses upon him, which were made pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 52, in plaintiff passenger's action for personal injuries.


OVERVIEW: The passengers filed personal injury actions arising out of a collision between an automobile in which they were passengers and an automobile owned and operated by the driver, a nonresident. In denying the driver's motion, the court held that the services of the summonses were in accordance with N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 52, that they were sufficient services upon the driver, that the court had acquired jurisdiction of the driver and that these actions were pending from the time of the services on the Secretary of State. The court further found that by the driver's service of the notice to examine the passengers before trial, the driver declared himself to be a party. Accordingly, the court held that the driver waived his objection to the question of the jurisdiction of the court because he served the notice to examine the passengers.


OUTCOME: The court denied the driver's motion to vacate and to set aside the services of the summonses upon the driver in the passenger's action for personal injuries.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- service of process on nonresidents and absentees -- sufficiency of incomplete service -- service of process was sufficient to give court jurisdiction over nonresident defendant where copies of summonses and complaints in actions arising from automobile accident within State were sent by registered mail pursuant to section 52 of Vehicle and Traffic Law and were actually received by Secretary of State and by defendant in New Jersey, although plaintiffs were unable to comply with statute's further requirement of filing return receipts along with other papers because of Post Office Department's failure to supply such return receipts despite request therefor; omission of such filing could not possibly prejudice defendant -- moreover, defendant, by serving notice to examine plaintiffs before trial and by actually examining one plaintiff, appeared informally and thereby waived right to object to court's jurisdiction or was estopped from asserting objection.

1. Service of summonses and complaints in three actions against defendant, a nonresident, arising out of an automobile collision in this State, was initiated pursuant to section 52 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law [***2] by plaintiffs' attorney who sent copies thereof by registered mail to the Secretary of State and to defendant at a New Jersey address with requests for return receipts. Such copies were actually received by the addressees but because the Post Office Department failed to supply the return receipt signed by defendant or his qualified agent, plaintiffs were unable to comply with the further requirement of section 52 that such return receipt, along with other documents, be filed with the clerk of the court. The summonses and complaints were served in accordance with the statute and were sufficiently served so that the court acquired jurisdiction of defendant, and the actions were pending from the time of service on the Secretary of State. Defendant was fully apprised that these actions had been commenced against him and could not possibly be prejudiced by the omission of the filing, and it would be improper for the court, which had discretion to supply an omission or defect if a substantial right of a party was not thereby prejudiced (Civ. Prac. Act, § 105), to grant defendant's motion to vacate the service because of the omission of such filing.

2. Moreover, defendant, who served [***3] a notice to examine plaintiffs before trial at his attorney's offices, thereby appeared informally in these actions although he had not generally participated in an actual trial. The statutes (Civ. Prac. Act, §§ 288, 290; Rules Civ. Prac., rule 121-a), pursuant to which defendant's notice of examination of plaintiffs before trial was served, provided for such pretrial examination by a party and, therefore, defendant, by serving such notice, declared himself to be a party and participated in the merits of the litigation, thereby giving the court personal jurisdiction.

3. The actual pretrial examination of one plaintiff by defendant pursuant to the notice served by defendant, and that plaintiff's physical examination at defendant's request constitute additional reason for holding that defendant appeared informally in these actions and thereby submitted to the jurisdiction of the court.

4. Defendant waived his objection to question the court's jurisdiction, or is estopped from asserting such objection, because of his serving the notice of pretrial examinations of plaintiffs, one of whom he did examine in response to such notice. His special appearance objecting to the court's [***4] jurisdiction is inconsistent with his service of the notice of examination before trial.

 

2607 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. White of Massapequa, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


12 Misc. 2d 254; 171 N.Y.S.2d 452; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3997



January 23, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Since the defendants concede that they sold items other than those specifically enumerated in section 2147 of the Penal Law, the convictions of the lower court are affirmed.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a corporation, its president, and its employees, challenged a decision from the First District Court of Nassau County (New York), which convicted them of violations of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 2143, 2146, and 2147, commonly referred to as the Sunday Laws.


OVERVIEW: The informations alleged that on the various Sundays therein mentioned, defendants, each aiding and abetting the others, sold the following allegedly prohibited items: three sets of men's underwear, a pair of boys' shorts, two pairs of socks and a hammer. The corporation forthrightly admitted having sold the items set forth in the informations and of displaying the myriad of other articles. It contended, however, that since fresh vegetables and other farm produce were also sold, the place of business was a "farmers' market" as defined in both N.Y. Penal Law § 2147(5) and N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 156-e(3) and thus avoids the prohibitions of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 2143 and 2146. The court found that it was immaterial whether the corporation was designated as a farmers' market because pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 2147, the most important consideration was the nature of the items being sold on the Sabbath. The specific items enumerated in § 2147 that could be sold on the Sabbath were properly classed as the necessities of everyday living. Defendants readily admitted that they sold items outside those specifically enumerated in § 2147; thus, they were properly convicted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions for violations of the Sunday Laws.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sales on Sunday -- "farmers' market" -- defendant corporation, operator of so-called "farmers' market" properly convicted of violations of Penal Law ( §§ 2143, 2146, 2147) for sale of underwear, shorts, socks and hammer on Sunday -- provision in statute (Penal Law, § 2147), permitting "farmers' market" to operate on Sunday, not intended to permit operation of defendant's two-story structure with floor area of 29,000 square feet, erected on six acres of land, having over 500 counters and between 25 and 30 employees supervising sales.

1. Defendant corporation is the owner and operator of a so-called "farmers' market". The remaining defendants are the president and employees of the corporation. The informations charged defendants with violations of sections 2143, 2146 and [***2] 2147 of the Penal Law in that they sold men's underwear, boys' shorts, socks and a hammer on Sunday. Defendant corporation has a two-story structure with a floor area of over 29,000 square feet erected on six acres of land. Within the building are over 500 counters from which 5,000 different items are displayed for sale. Between 25 and 30 employees supervise the sale of the merchandise. Ten per cent of the sales over a 12 months' period were from wearing apparel for men, women and children, 5% from furniture, toys and kindred items, and 85% from the remaining items displayed for sale. Some fruit and fresh vegetables were also sold. Section 2147 prohibits all manner of public selling or offering for sale of any property on Sunday but provides that "farmers' markets or roadside stands selling fresh vegetables and other farm produce, and fishing tackle and bait stores may sell, supply, serve and deliver merchandise usually sold by them, at any time of the day." The intent of the Legislature was to except either farmers' markets or roadside stands selling fresh vegetables and other farm produce. It intended to make available to the public only edibles and the usual necessities commensurate [***3] with everyday living. There was no intent to favor "farmers' markets" and permit them, to the exclusion of everyone else, to operate a department store on Sunday. Defendants concede that they sold items other than those specifically enumerated in section 2147 of the Penal Law and, accordingly, were properly convicted.

2. The definition of "farmers' markets" in subdivision 3 of section 156-e of the Agriculture and Markets Law did not contemplate the Sabbath Law.

 

2608 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York State Comm'n Against Discrimination v. Pelham Hall Apartments, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


10 Misc. 2d 334; 170 N.Y.S.2d 750; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4110



January 16, 1958 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner New York State Commission Against Discrimination (commission) brought an action pursuant to the authority of N.Y. Exec. Law art. 15, known as the "Law Against Discrimination," against respondents, corporation and officers acting as managing agents. The commission sought to enforce its order directed against alleged racially discriminatory practices with respect to the leasing of apartments in publicly assisted housing accommodations.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law art. 15, § 297, a Negro charged that respondents refused to lease him an apartment based on his race. The commission issued a cease and desist order against the corporation, the owner of the apartment dwelling, and the officers, who acted as its managing agents. Respondents admitted the discriminatory conduct but claimed that the building was not a "publicly-assisted housing accommodation" subject to statutes barring discrimination. They also argued that applying the statutes against them violated their constitutional rights. The commission held that the 1955 and 1956 statutory amendments prohibiting discrimination in such buildings applied to respondents' conduct. On appeal, the court affirmed. The building was a multiple dwelling financed, after July 1, 1955, in whole or in part by a federally insured loan. It thus fell within N.Y. Civil Rights Law art. 2-A and N.Y. Exec. Law art. 15. The court rejected arguments that the amendments were constitutionally invalid, as the state's police power to regulate private property by enacting such laws outweighed respondents' private property rights. The court also rejected respondents' equal protection arguments.


OUTCOME: The court granted, in all respects, the commission's petition seeking judicial enforcement of its order against respondents for engaging in discriminatory practices with respect to leasing apartments in publicly assisted housing accommodations.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Civil rights -- discrimination in publicly assisted housing accommodations-proceeding by State Commission Against Discrimination to enforce its cease and desist order directed against discriminatory practices of respondents, stock corporation and its officers, with respect to leasing of apartments in multiple dwelling financed by FHA insured mortgage; application granted (Civil Rights Law, art. 2-A; Executive Law, art. 15); constitutional rights of respondents not violated.

1. In a proceeding instituted by the State Commission Against Discrimination to enforce its cease and desist order directed against discriminatory practices of respondents, a stock corporation and its officers, with respect to leasing of apartments in publicy assisted housing accommodations, the application of the commission was granted. The proceeding was grounded upon article 2-A of the Civil Rights Law, rendering unlawful the practice of discrimination in publicy assisted housing accommodations located in a multiple dwelling, "the acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of which is, after July first, nineteen hundred fifty-five, financed in whole or in part by a loan * * * the repayment [***2] of which is guaranteed or insured by the federal government or any agency thereof * * *" and upon amendment to the Executive Law, effective July 1, 1956, bringing within the coverage and remedial procedures of article 15 of the Executive Law, known as the Law Against Discrimination, the same publicly assisted housing accommodations covered by the Civil Rights Law.

2. Respondents' building, a multiple dwelling housing project financed by means of a Federal Housing Administration insured mortgage loan, fell within the statutory definition of publicly assisted housing accommodation subject to the anti-discrimination provisions of article 2-A of the Civil Rights Law and article 15 of the Executive Law, notwithstanding that the original FHA commitment for a loan was issued on June 30, 1955, where the building project became "financed in whole or in part" following the commitment, and after July 1, 1955, upon the making and use in the project of advances on account of the insured loan, and upon the subsequent making of an additional FHA insured loan.

3. The constitutional rights of respondents were not violated by the application of the provisions of article 15 of the Executive Law and [***3] article 2-A of the Civil Rights Law as against them and their apartment building.

4. The private ownership of private property, free of unreasonable restriction upon the control thereof, is part of our way of life; but, on the oth&er hand, we as a People hold firmly to the philosophy that all men are created equal. Discrimination against any individual on account of race, color or religion is antagonistic to fundamental tenets of our form of Government and of the God in whom we place our trust.

5. The controversy in issue involved a conflict between the rights of the private property owner and the inherent power of the State to regulate the use and enjoyment of private property in the interest of public welfare. The power of the State, when reasonably exercised, is supreme.

6. Private property rights are subject to the exercise of police power legislation, and thus the matter of the rental of private real property, and the rights of the owner with respect thereto, are subject to legislative regulation enacted in the interest of public welfare.

7. The policy, wisdom and expediency of police power legislation affecting private property rights are for the Legislature and Governor.

 [***4] 8. Broad discretion resides in the Legislature to decide what is necessary in the interests of the public good.

9. Article 15 of the Executive Law and article 2-A of the Civil Rights Law, directed against the practice of racial or religious discrimination, were presumed constitutional, and could be stricken down by the courts only if it appeared that they were clearly arbitrary, discriminatory and without any reasonable basis.

10. Article 15 of the Executive Law and article 2-A of the Civil Rights Law were not to be declared unconstitutional merely because they might tend to cut down the property rights of certain private property owners and might result in some financial loss to them without provision for compensation therefor. The legislation would be sustained as against an attack by an aggrieved property owner unless it appeared that the enforcement thereof amounted to confiscation; that is, operated to preclude the use of the owner's property for any purpose to which it was reasonably adapted. Pecuniary profits of the individual are secondary to the public welfare.

11. The statutory provisions against the practice of discrimination in housing accommodations did not offend [***5] the equal protection clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions because they were made applicable solely to multiple dwellings, the financing of which was publicly assisted, rather than generally to all such dwellings whether or not so assisted, nor because they were confined to multiple dwellings so publicly assisted after July 1, 1955. The prohibition against the denial of equal protection of laws does not preclude a State from resorting to classification for purposes of legislation.

12. In passing upon the validity of legislation claimed to offend against the equal protection clauses because operating solely with respect to particular classes of persons or property, the test is whether or not the classification rests upon some reasonable basis, bearing in mind the subject matter and the object of the legislation.

13. In determining whether or not there was reasonable basis for establishing the specified classes of housing accommodations to which the provisions of the Executive Law and the Civil Rights Law were made applicable, the court could take into consideration the fact that civil rights and anti-discrimination legislation was a step by step proposition. The Legislature,  [***6] in its effort to effect a proposed reform deemed advisable from the standpoint of the public welfare, could take one step at a time, addressing itself to that phase of the problem which seemed most acute to the legislative mind.

14. A step by step proceeding by legislative bodies to eliminate the practice of racial discrimination in affairs closely connected with the lives of our citizens is not only a reasonable, but in view of changing times and circumstances, a required method of procedure in the interest of public welfare.

15. A regulation is not necessarily rendered invalid because, incidental to its prospective operation, it is written to apply only to persons or property coming within a particular category or class for the first time on or after the effective date. The constitutional provisions do not forbid statutes and statutory changes to have a beginning and thus to discriminate between the rights of an earlier and later time.

16. Respondents' contention that the 1956 amendment to article 15 of the Executive Law, effective as of July 1, 1956, was invalid because made retroactive as to housing accommodations financed by public assistance from July 1, 1955, was untenable.  [***7] The amendment to article 2-A of the Civil Rights Law, enacted in 1955, prohibited and barred as unlawful the discrimination practiced by respondents, and so far as respondents were concerned all that the 1956 amendment to the Executive Law did was to provide another remedy for an aggrieved person against the discrimination then already prohibited, namely, the remedy of proceeding by complaint to the Commission Against Discrimination and the proceeding thereon by the commission.

17. The commission had a broad discretion with respect to the rendering of an order deemed adequate and necessary to secure full compliance with the provisions of the law, including provisions for such record keeping and reports by respondents as were reasonably necessary to enable the commission to determine whether respondents were complying with the law.

 

2609 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hudson Transit Lines v. Bragalini


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


11 Misc. 2d 1094; 172 N.Y.S.2d 423; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4077



January 8, 1958 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, State Tax Commission of the State of New York (tax commission), filed a motion before answer to dismiss the complaint of plaintiff taxpayer seeking a declaratory judgment that N. Y. Tax Law §§ 183, 184, were unconstitutional as the taxpayer was engaged in interstate commerce.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer, a Delaware corporation operating omnibuses that transported passengers in interstate commerce, claimed that it was not engaged in intrastate commerce within the State of New York. It protested that the tax commission had recently demanded that taxpayer file gross earnings reports pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law §§ 183, 184, for the past 23 years, and pay a tax simultaneously with the filing of each such report. The taxpayer alleged that §§ 183, 184 were not constitutionally applicable to it and sought a declaratory judgment. The tax commission filed a motion before answer to dismiss the complaint (1) for want of jurisdiction of the subject matter, and (2) for failure to state a cause of action. The tax commission contended that State of New York was the real party in interest and that the State of New York had not consented to the lawsuit. The court denied the motion of the tax commission to dismiss the complaint. The court held that an action for a declaratory judgment could be maintained when the jurisdiction of the taxing authorities was challenged on the ground that the statute was unconstitutional or by its terms did not apply in the particular circumstance.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion of the tax commission to dismiss the taxpayer's complaint, holding that the taxpayer was seeking was a declaration of rights, lest an oppressive and an unnecessary restriction be placed on it.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory judgments -- when remedy appropriate -- action, brought by foreign corporation allegedly operating omnibuses in interstate commerce, would lie against defendants constituting State Tax Commission, for judgment declaring certain sections of Tax Law not constitutionally applicable to it: motion to dismiss complaint before answer denied.

1. An action, brought by a foreign corporation allegedly operating omnibuses in interstate commerce, would lie against defendants constituting the State Tax Commission, for a judgment declaring that sections 183 and 184 of the Tax Law were not constitutionally applicable to it, and a motion before answer to dismiss the complaint was denied. In an action for declaratory judgment the only issue, on a motion to dismiss the complaint before answer, is whether the complaint reveals a proper case for a declaratory judgment, and on such a motion the merits of the controversy are not before the court.

2. An action for declaratory judgment was maintainable, despite the provision in section 199 of the Tax Law that an article 78 proceeding to review an adverse determination was the exclusive remedy [***2] available when an adjudication of any tax liability was sought under sections 183 and 184 of the Tax Law. An action for a declaratory judgment may be maintained, despite the provisions of a taxing statute which provide that the method of judicial review prescribed therein shall be exclusive, where the jurisdiction of the taxing authorities is challenged on the ground that the statute is unconstitutional or that the statute by its own terms does not apply in a given case.

3. The ancient doctrine of sovereign immunity does not preclude an action for a declaratory judgment against officials of the State of New York in their capacity as such.

4. Section 1287 of the Civil Practice Act, which requires that article 78 proceedings against the State Tax Commission be brought in the Third Judicial District, applies only to article 78 proceedings, and is not applicable to plenary actions.

5. Where improper venue is the grievance, a motion to dismiss for want of jurisdiction is not the remedy.

 

2610 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Bunis v. Simmers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Tompkins County


13 Misc. 2d 1097; 181 N.Y.S.2d 388; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4095



January 4, 1958 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator seller was arrested and detained by respondent chief of police on a charge of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 436-d, which prohibited the sale of periodicals and books from which the covering or title pages had been removed. The seller sought his discharge in a habeas corpus proceeding on the ground that § 436-d was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The information upon which the warrant of arrest was issued alleged that the seller knowingly sold, offered, and exposed for sale periodicals and books from which the cover page had been removed. Section 436-d prohibited the same, and the question was whether or not § 436-d had any real or substantial relation to the protection of the public and constituted a proper exercise of the police powers. The court held that § 436-d was unconstitutional. The purpose of the legislation was to prevent the resale of periodicals once the publisher recalled them. It was intended to remove from circulation objectionable material. The court found that the real purpose of the legislation was to protect the trade in an economic sense from such resales rather than to protect the public from the standpoint of health, morals, safety, and welfare. Legislation, which was enacted for the special benefit or protection of a class rather than the public, was unconstitutional as an invalid exercise of the police power. Section 436-d could not be held to have any relationship to the prevention of fraud on the public, and was an invalid exercise of the police power.


OUTCOME: The writ was sustained that the seller was discharged.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- constitutional law -- section 436-d of Penal Law, prohibiting sale of periodicals from which cover has been removed, is unconstitutional and void.

Section 436-d of the Penal Law (added by L. 1956, ch. 886), providing that "Any person who knowingly sells, offers or exposes for sale, (except in bulk as waste paper) any newspaper, magazine, periodical or other publication, except a rare book, manuscript or educational text, from which the cover or title page has been removed, or from which the title, trade name, trade mark or other identification mark has been removed or obliterated, is guilty of a misdemeanor", has no relation to public welfare and is unconstitutional and void. The purpose of the section, as shown by its sponsor's statement in the Legislative Annual, is merely to assist publishers in enforcing their private economic arrangements with wholesalers whereby wholesalers tear off the cover pages of periodicals which have been returned to them unsold by retailers and return said cover page to the publishers and get credit or repayment for the unsold periodicals. This has nothing to do with preventing frauds on the public. A writ of habeas corpus is granted [***2] directing the release of a person arrested for violation of said section.

 

2611 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kantrowitz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Rockland County


10 Misc. 2d 677; 173 N.Y.S.2d 213; 1958 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4100



January 3, 1958 



DISPOSITION: The judgment of the Court of Special Sessions is affirmed. An order may be entered accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Special Sessions of the Town of Ramapo (New York) convicting him of speeding in violation of the Palisades Interstate Park Comm'n. R. & Reg. § 3, subd. j, which fixed the maximum speed limit of 40 miles per hour on any park road or parkway. Defendant claimed the regulation was an unreasonable, arbitrary, and capricious exercise of police power.


OVERVIEW: The Palisades Interstate Park Commission was authorized to make rules for the use and government of lands, parks, and parkways under its jurisdiction. Defendant claimed that the regulation he was convicted of was enacted by the Commission under an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power. The court affirmed the judgment. When an ordinance or regulation was within the power of the body, which passed it, the presumption was that it was reasonable and just. The only testimony in the record as to the physical design of the parkway was that of defendant. The court could not conclude that the Commission acted unreasonably, arbitrarily, and capriciously in adopting the speed regulation. The proof did not compel the conclusion that the regulation exceeded the limits of good judgment and discretion, which were vested in the Commission. To make the violation of an adopted rule or regulation a crime or an infraction was not a delegation of legislative power.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of special sessions was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- delegation to interstate agency to regulate speed on roads -- subdivision (j) of regulation 3 of Palisades Interstate Park Commission, interstate agency, which regulation fixes maximum speed limit of 40 miles per hour on any park road not unreasonable on face or invalid delegation of legislative power.

1. Subdivision (j) of regulation 3 of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, which was created by interstate compact between New York and New Jersey, authorized by statutes of each State and approved by joint resolution of Congress, fixes a maximum speed limit of 40 miles per hour on any park road or parkway. Said regulation is not unreasonable on its face.

2. The proof, given only by defendant himself, does not compel the conclusion that the regulation exceeded [***2] "the limits of good judgment and discretion" which are vested in the commission. The burden of showing the unreasonableness from evidence is on the person asserting it. The court does not find it necessary to substitute its judgment for that of the commission in its determination of what is reasonable.

3. The Conservation Law makes a violation of a rule of the commission a misdemeanor (§ 748) and in certain instances a traffic infraction (§ 678). The commission is authorized to make rules and regulations within the limitations prescribed. This does not constitute an invalid delegation of legislative power within the meaning of section 1 of article III of the New York State Constitution. The power to make rules for the use and government of the park and parkways was not given to individual residents or citizens as such, but to an interstate agency, as a body corporate and politic duly created by the Legislature under a compact with the State of New Jersey and with the approval of Congress with authority to the agency to act as a board. This delegation of power to an administrative body to make rules is valid.

4. The judgment of the Court of Special Sessions convicting defendant [***3] of speeding in violation of said regulation should be affirmed where it was stipulated at the trial that defendant was driving his automobile 60 miles per hour in a zone marked 40 miles per hour.

 

2612 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Harris v. Coffey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


14 Misc. 2d 916; 179 N.Y.S.2d 8; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1926



December 20, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner store owner brought a mandamus proceeding to review a decision of respondents, a building inspector and a board of trustees, and to compel the building inspector to issue a building permit to the owner.


OVERVIEW: The board adopted a resolution to repeal a provision of the zoning ordinance, which provided that no food store could occupy any area of more than 3000 square feet. After the repeal, the owner presented an application to the building inspector for a permit to build a supermarket, which would exceed 3000 square feet. Only three days after the repeal of the ordinance, the board resolved to hold a public hearing to consider reinstating the restriction it had just repealed. The building inspector, on that basis, denied the permit. The owner claimed that the restriction was arbitrary and the ordinance unconstitutional. The court ordered a full hearing before a referee on the issue of whether the owner suffered damage by the building inspector's refusal to issue the permit and whether the ordinance was unconstitutional. The court did find that the inspector's withholding of the permit was wrongful because the withholding of the approval of the permit was willfully and deliberately calculated to delay the owner until the reinstatement of the ordinance became effective. The inspector could not refuse to act on the possibility the law could be modified at some future time.


OUTCOME: The court ordered a full and complete hearing before a referee on the issues of whether the owner suffered damage by the delay in issuing the permit, and whether the ordinance was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Zoning -- building permits -- Superintendent of Building's withholding of permit because of pending legislation which would impose area restriction not complied with in application for such permit is wrongful -- applicant damaged by such wrongful withholding only if he could have commenced such operations with permit as would have created in him vested right -- whether square footage restrictions of particular type of business in district are unreasonably discriminatory depends on extent of district and its relationship to other districts in village.

1. An amendment to a village zoning ordinance, repealing a limitation on the square footage of retail food stores in a "Business AA District", became effective on November 9, 1957. On November 12, 1957, the respondent Board of Trustees resolved to hold a public hearing to consider reinstating the restriction. The hearing was held on December 2, 1957, and an amendment reinstating the restriction was adopted to become effective in accordance with the Village Law on December 22, 1957. In the meantime, on November 20, 1957, petitioner had applied to respondent Superintendent of Building for a permit to erect a supermarket of more [***2] than the limited area. After several visits to the Building Department, he was finally told on November 29, 1957 that the Board of Trustees had directed denial of his application because of the pending legislation. As it is the duty of an administrative officer to perform in accordance with the law as it presently exists, this willful withholding of the permit was wrongful. In addition, the petitioner was misled and hindered in his efforts to obtain a permit, as he was not informed of the denial until his third visit to the department.

2. Although refusal to issue the permit was wrongful, petitioner was actually damaged only if prompt action on his application would have enabled him to commence such operations under the permit as would have resulted in the creation of a vested right before the amendment became effective on December 22, 1957. Accordingly, this issue is referred to an Official Referee to hear and to report his findings and recommendations.

3. Whether the restriction is unconstitutional as being unreasonably discriminatory in that it limits the area only of food stores in a "Business AA District" can be determined only in light of the present extent of such [***3] district, and its relationship to the other districts in the village. Accordingly, this issue also is referred to an Official Referee.

 

2613 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Austin v. Board of Higher Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


9 Misc. 2d 253; 170 N.Y.S.2d 7; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1942



December 18, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the complaint for insufficiency is accordingly granted.

Order signed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former employees brought an action against defendant employer to recover their salaries from their discharge date. The employees contended that their dismissal was predicated on an unconstitutional section of the city charter and that they had been dismissed without a hearing in violation of their statutory rights attendant upon their tenure of service. The employer filed a motion to dismiss the employees' complaint for insufficiency.


OVERVIEW: The employer sought dismissal of the employees' action for recovery of lost salaries from the time of their discharge. The employer contended that the only remedy available to the employees was in the nature of mandamus under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act. art. 78, and that a proceeding by the employees under that provision was time-barred. The employer asserted that the employees had no redress for unpaid salaries in an action at law and that art. 78 was their exclusive remedy. The employees countered that their summary dismissals from their university teaching positions were predicated on an unconstitutional statute and were ordered without providing the employees with any hearing opportunities. The employees also asserted that their dismissals did not involve exercises of discretion to limit their remedy to a mandamus proceeding. The court granted the employer's motion to dismiss based on the court's determination that the employees' current action was barred until they obtained a favorable determination in an art. 78 proceeding of their right to reinstatement, as well as any rights incidental thereto including salaries from the time of their discharge.


OUTCOME: The court granted the employer's motion to dismiss the employees' action.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- teachers unconstitutionally discharged for failure to answer legislative committee's questions (U. S. Const., 5th Amdt.) can seek reinstatement and back pay by proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act only; their plenary suit for back pay dismissed.

Section 903 of the New York City Charter, terminating the employment of any city employee who, when questioned by any legislative committee as to his official conduct, refuses to answer on the ground that his answer would tend to incriminate him, is unconstitutional. (U. S. Const., 5th & 14th Amdts.) Nevertheless, such discharged employees do not have an absolute, constitutional right to reinstatement. Discretion as to their reinstatement is within the province of the city. Accordingly, the sole remedy of six such discharged employees of the Board of Higher Education of the City of New York -- assistant professors, instructors, and registrar's assistants -- is a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act. Their rights to their salaries from the time of their wrongful discharge are incidental [***2] to such a proceeding and cannot be made the subject of a plenary suit. Their plenary suit is therefore dismissed. The court does not at this time rule on the question whether the four months' Statute of Limitations (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1286) will bar such an article 78 proceeding.

 

2614 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Barnes v. Gorham


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Equity Term, Onondaga County


12 Misc. 2d 285; 175 N.Y.S.2d 376; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1949



December 17, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff trailer camp owner sued defendants, supervisor of a town and town officers, to have an ordinance imposing a monthly per trailer fee on trailer parks declared unconstitutional. The action also challenged an assessment made pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 2(6-a).


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Tax. Law § 2(6-a)(a), (b) provided for the assessment of house trailers in a trailer park for 60 days as real estate assessable to the owner of the land on which they were located. The owner claimed that the law unconstitutionally imposed double taxation. The court held that was § 2(6-a) was invalid as violative of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States. A number of situations and circumstances could have resulted in the denial of due process of the law and the equal protection of the laws. Although the purpose of the statute was to place the burden of responsibility on the owner to collect and pay additional taxes on the land used for the commercial purpose involved, a definition added by N.Y. Tax. Law § 2(6-a) made the trailers subject to assessment and sale to collect taxes, creating a different series of obligations. The obligations were made the easy subject of fraudulent and evasive tactics to avoid liability for taxation through the 60-day exception provision. The ordinance, which provided for a monthly trailer license fee, was constitutional, valid, and enforceable.


OUTCOME: The court held that the statute imposing the assessment on the house trailers was invalid, but that ordinance, which required a trailer license, was valid.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Taxation -- trailers -- constitutional law -- Tax Law ( § 2, subd. 6-a, pars. a, b), providing for assessment as real estate of house trailers situated upon premises for 60 days within boundaries of tax district and against owner of land on which they are located, is unconstitutional -- statute permits circumstances which would result in denial of due process and equal protection of laws, both as to trailer owner and to trailer park owner -- statutory provisions ambiguous and indefinite and statute incapable of being fairly administered -- Legislature has improperly declared personal property to be real property -- ordinance imposing fee of $ 3.50 per month per trailer upon house trailers in trailer park not unconstitutional.

1. A town ordinance imposing a fee of $ 3.50 per month per trailer upon house trailers in a trailer park pursuant to the Town Law ( § 130, subd. 21; § 136, subd. 11) is not unconstitutional. The evidence as to the cost incurred by the town in inspecting and regulating trailer parks in the town establishes that the fee is fair and reasonable. It is not a tax upon the real property of plaintiff, but is a regulatory and licensing provision under the Town [***2] Law and enforcible as such. A license fee sufficient to cover the cost of enforcement, inspection and licensing does not constitute the imposition of a tax on the business. The ordinance is a proper exercise of police power.

2. The town assessors assessed petitioner's premises in the sum of $ 12,500, increasing it from $ 2,000, pursuant to the provisions of subdivision 6-a (pars. a, b) of section 2 of the Tax Law, which provides for the assessment as real estate of house trailers situated upon premises for 60 days within the boundaries of a tax district, assessable to the owner of the land on which they are located. The statute is unconstitutional. Under the statutes (Tax Law, §§ 2, 8, 9), trailers are not only to be considered land, real estate and real property for the purpose of assessment, but also are assessable themselves as real estate and are subject to sale as real estate to enforce the collection of the tax. The effect thereof would be to make the series of obligations an easy subject of fraudulent and evasive tactics to avoid liability for taxation, and a variety of circumstances could be created which would result in the denial of due process and equal protection [***3] of the laws, both as to the trailer owner and to the trailer park owner. In addition, many practical problems would be presented requiring interpretation of statutory provisions which would be ambiguous, indefinite and incapable of being fairly interpreted or administered. The statute is incapable of being fairly administered and is ambiguous and indefinite and does not provide any recognized rule pertaining to the valuation of real estate.

3. There is a point beyond which the Legislature cannot go in declaring that personal property which is in no sense real estate is, nevertheless, land, real estate or real property for the purposes of the Tax Law. That point is passed in this legislation, and subdivision 6-a (pars. a, b) of section 2 of the Tax Law is invalid as in violation of section 6 of article I of the State Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

 

2615 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Zanchelli


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Columbia County


8 Misc. 2d 1069; 169 N.Y.S.2d 197; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1968



December 16, 1957 



DISPOSITION: All that the Court of Appeals said in its opinion in People v. Firth (supra) could be said of the statute here involved, and the judgment of conviction appealed from is therefore reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of a Court of Special Sessions held by a Justice of the Peace of the Town of Germantown, Columbia County (New York), which convicted defendant of violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 15(1). This section stated, in part, that every motor vehicle had to have a suitable muffler or device to prevent unnecessary noise from exhaust gases. Defendant claimed that the statute was unconstitutionally void.


OVERVIEW: The court noted that a statute which either forbade or required the performance of a certain act in language so vague that men of common experience and intellect had to guess at its meaning, and among them were able to differ as to its application, violated the first essential of due process of law. The court further noted that the physical equipment of defendant's motor vehicle was at issue, and what the statute prohibited was unnecessary noise. The court reversed defendant's conviction finding that there was nothing defective about defendant's muffler. It was a muffler in standard use that could have been purchased at any automobile accessory shop or garage. The court further noted that it was difficult on the trial for the trooper to describe the noise, but he said that trucks in operation upon the highway made more noise. The statute did not differentiate between trucks and other motor vehicles, yet the trooper testified that it was not the practice to arrest the drivers of trucks that made more noise than came from the car of defendant. The court found that the statute, as written, was susceptible to a dual interpretation, one application to trucks and one to pleasure cars.


OUTCOME: The judgment of conviction that defendant appealed from was reversed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- criminal statutes -- indefiniteness -- statute requiring that motor vehicles shall have "suitable" muffler to prevent "unnecessary noise" from exhaust gases unconstitutional for indefiniteness; statutes which create crimes must afford some comprehensible guide as to what must be done and what must be avoided, to end that ordinary member of society may know how to comply with requirements thereof.

That provision of the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 15, subd. 1) which provides that motor vehicles "shall have a suitable muffler or device to prevent unnecessary noise from exhaust gases" is unconstitutional for indefiniteness. Due process of law requires that statutes which create crimes must be definite, specifying [***2] conduct which is condemned or prohibited; they must afford some comprehensible guide, rule or information as to what must be done and what must be avoided, to the end that the ordinary member of society may know how to comply with the requirements thereof.

 

2616 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Temple Israel of Lawrence v. Plaut


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


10 Misc. 2d 1084; 170 N.Y.S.2d 393; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1969



December 16, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition is granted and the determination of the respondent board is reversed and annulled.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner synagogue filed an action pursuant to N.Y.C.P.L.R. § 78, seeking an order that reversed a determination of respondent zoning board that denied the synagogue's request for a zoning variance construct an extension to its present structure for use as classrooms and to include a gymnasium and swimming pool.


OVERVIEW: The zoning board argued that its denial of the synagogue's request for a variance was proper because the synagogue failed to show that it would have suffered unnecessary hardship by complying with the existing zoning regulations. The zoning board further argued that the synagogue had the ability to build its addition in such a fashion that it would comply with existing zoning regulations and that the synagogue had failed to establish that it suffered any injustice by being forced to comply with the existing zoning regulations. The synagogue argued that it could not be prevented form constructing an extension to its building unless there was a clear showing that such use would impair the health, safety, morals, or general welfare of the community. The court agreed with the synagogue and reversed and annulled the zoning board. The court noted that erection of synagogues and churches were not subject to exclusion under zoning ordinances absent a clear showing of impairment of public health, welfare or safety of the community and denials of applications for construction of synagogues for reasons other than the impairment of public health, welfare and safety were not permitted.


OUTCOME: The court granted the synagogue's petition and reversed and annulled the zoning board's determination to deny a construction permit to the synagogue. The court directed that a permit was to be issued upon the synagogue's presentation of a proper application.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- determination denying application for variance to permit extension of existing synagogue structure in residence district, to house classrooms for religious instruction and gymnasium and swimming pool for congregation, reversed and annulled and permit for erection of proposed structure directed to be issued.

1. A determination of a village board of zoning appeals denying the application of petitioner synagogue for a variance so as to permit the erection on property in a zone devoted to one-family dwellings of an extension to an existing synagogue structure, to be used for classrooms for religious training and instruction and to include a gymnasium and swimming pool for use by congregation members, was reversed and annulled, and a permit for erection of the proposed structure directed to be issued upon proper application therefor.

2. Objections to petitioner's application for an order reversing, annulling and setting aside the determination of the board, challenging the validity of service of the petition and raising the defense of the Statute [***2] of Limitations, were waived by respondents' contest of the application on the merits.

3. A zoning ordinance may not exclude a church or synagogue from any residential district, though appropriate restrictions may be imposed in furtherance of safety and welfare of the community and those in attendance at church and school. Where the record did not warrant a conclusion that the health, welfare or safety of the community or of the congregation would be impaired by the proposed extension, denial of the building permit sought was contrary to law.

4. Classrooms for religious instruction are an approved adjunct to houses of worship and construction thereof is for a religious purpose. Playgrounds, gymnasiums and consonant facilities are permitted as accessory uses to houses of worship.

5. Since petitioner was not subject to exclusion under the zoning ordinance, it was under no legal compulsion to seek a variance to erect the extension. Its participation in a proceeding for a variance was not an assumption of validity of the ordinance depriving petitioner of its right to issuance of the permit.

6. Diminution of the esthetic, inconvenience to neighboring property owners or traffic problems,  [***3] where such factors do not impair the welfare or safety of the community, are not to be considered in determining an application for a permit to erect a church, synagogue or its accessory uses of schools for religious training and incidental recreational facilities.

 

2617 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Price


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Police Court of New York, Village of Spring Valley


16 Misc. 2d 71; 169 N.Y.S.2d 200; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1971



December 14, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss the charge of "Dangerous Speed" is granted.

It is so ordered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the charge of "dangerous speed" on the ground that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1) was violative of due process. Defendant had also been charged with reckless driving, in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 58.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped by a patrolman, who issued two separate traffic tickets arising out of a single incident, one charging "dangerous speed," and the other charging reckless driving. Defendant moved to dismiss the "dangerous speed" charge. The court granted the motion, holding that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1) was unconstitutionally vague and that the alleged violation of its prohibitions could not constitute an offense. The court noted that § 56(1) contained no standard whereby the conduct of a driver was to be measured. No specific speed limits or prohibited actions were set forth in the traffic statute.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss the charge of "dangerous speed."


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- speed which "endangers" -- section 56 (subd. 1) of Vehicle and Traffic Law is too vague and is therefore unconstitutional.

Subdivision 1 of section 56 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, providing that no person shall drive "at such a speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person, nor at a rate of speed greater than will permit such person to bring the vehicle to a stop without injury to another or his property", is too vague to be enforcible and is therefore unconstitutional ( People v. Firth, 3 N Y 2d 472, followed).

 

2618 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rublick v. Weaver


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


9 Misc. 2d 619; 170 N.Y.S.2d 61; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2012



December 10, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Plaintiff's motions are denied and defendant's motions, other than that under rule 212 of the Rules of Civil Practice, are granted.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord brought an action for an injunction and for judgment declaring void the State Residential Rent Law, 1946 N.Y. Laws 274, to the extent that it controlled housing accommodations as they became vacant. The landlord moved for an order striking out defendant New York State Rent Administrator's affirmative defense and for summary judgment. The Administrator filed a cross motion for an order dismissing the amended complaint.


OVERVIEW: Almost all of the motions turned on the constitutionality of the New York Residential Rent Law. The question of whether the court should have exercised discretionary was disposed of first, with the court holding that the case lent itself to the remedy of declaratory judgment. There was no merit to the landlord's argument that he was denied due process, as the legislature was required to address the over-all housing picture. The argument that the statute was discriminatory in that it provided for decontrol of housing accommodations in one- and two-family houses as they become vacant, but failed to provide for decontrol in larger buildings, lacked real merit. It was within the competence of the legislature to determine that decontrol of small housings would not appreciably affect the housing shortage. The argument that the statute was discriminatory in that it provided for decontrol of housing accommodations as they become vacant in Nassau County, but failed to provide the decontrol of housing accommodations in Queens County, was also without merit. The legislature was allowed to properly distinguish between a highly concentrated population and more sparsely settled areas.


OUTCOME: After finding the New York Residential Rent Law was constitutional, the court denied the landlord's motions. The Administrator's non-procedural motions, including the motions for summary judgment and dismissal, were granted.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- State Residential Rent Law is not unconstitutional -- court, in exercise of discretion, should not dismiss complaint as insufficient where facts alleged show that plaintiff is not entitled to declaration of rights as he claims them to be; court should retain jurisdiction and declare rights of parties.

1. Defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint in an action for judgment declaring unconstitutional the State Residential Rent Law to the extent that the statute continues to control housing accommodations as they become vacant, made on the ground that an exercise of discretionary jurisdiction is not warranted, is denied. A complaint in an action for declaratory judgment should not be dismissed as insufficient merely because the facts alleged show that plaintiff is not entitled to a declaration of rights as he claims them to be. The court should retain jurisdiction to declare the rights of the parties.

2. The statute is not rendered unconstitutional by the facts that, as to the new tenant,  [***2] there is no shortage of housing accommodations since he has found adequate space; that the statute provides for decontrol of housing accommodations in one- and two-family houses as they become vacant, but fails to provide for such decontrol in buildings containing more than two housing accommodations, or that it provides for decontrol of housing accommodations as they become vacant in Nassau County, but fails to provide the decontrol of housing accommodations in Queens County.

 

2619 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pelham Jewish Center v. Board of Trustees


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


9 Misc. 2d 564; 170 N.Y.S.2d 136; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2030



December 9, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petition dismissed. No costs. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, a mayor and a board of trustees, filed a motion to dismiss the petition for insufficiency to state a case that entitled petitioner religious corporation to relief. Specifically, respondents claimed that the proceeding was not maintainable in that it appeared that the acts of respondents that the corporation wanted reviewed or actions on respondents' part that the corporation sought to compel were purely legislative in nature.


OVERVIEW: The corporation brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding against respondents because it was not allowed to use its property for a religious purpose as a result of a zoning ordinance of the village. The corporation petitioned the board of trustees to repeal the zoning ordinance and the board of trusties denied the petition. The court granted respondents' motion to dismiss the action and held that under the circumstances, the proceeding was not maintainable against respondents to test the validity of the provisions of the ordinance insofar as they affected the corporation's property. The court noted that, generally speaking, a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding was not maintainable against a legislative body to test the validity of its legislative acts. Further, such a proceeding did not lie to review action that was legislative in nature or to compel a legislative body to enact particular legislation. Therefore, the proceeding was not maintainable to review the determination of the board of trustees insofar as the determination was a denial of the corporation's petition to amend or change the provisions of the zoning ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court granted respondents' motion to dismiss the corporation's petition.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against body or officer -- village board of trustees -- legislative actions -- refusal of village board of trustees to amend zoning ordinance to permit use of petitioner's property as synagogue is legislative act and not reviewable in proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act.

1. Petitioner, a religious corporation, is the owner of real property situated in a Residence "A" District in the village of Pelham Manor. The village zoning ordinance prohibits the use of real property in such districts for church or religious purposes. The petitioner desires to use its property as a synagogue and petitioned the board of trustees to repeal the amendments to the ordinance prohibiting such use. This proceeding, brought pursuant to article 78 of the Civil Practice Act, is not maintainable to review the determination of the board of trustees in denying the petition to change the provisions of the ordinance.

2. This proceeding does not lie to compel the board of trustees to issue a building permit to petitioner since, by local ordinance, such a permit is to be obtained from the building inspector and not the [***2] board of trustees.

3. The proceeding does not lie to procure a special use permit from the board of trustees since there is no provision under the local ordinance to grant such a permit in a Residence "A" District. The board had no power to act except legislatively, by amending the ordinance, and a failure to so act is not reviewable under an article 78 proceeding. Accordingly, the petition is dismissed.

 

2620 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Whitehall Pharmacal Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


10 Misc. 2d 548; 169 N.Y.S.2d 543; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2044



December 6, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss all causes of action other than the first is accordingly granted.

Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Illinois corporation's first cause of action sought a declaratory judgment that its sales to customers in defendant city were exempt from the city's general business tax because a tax on such sales would have constituted an unconstitutional tax on interstate commerce. The city moved for summary judgment dismissing the complaint. The Illinois corporation also filed nine causes of action seeking recovery of payments of the tax.


OVERVIEW: The Illinois corporation made no sales in New York, filled no orders in New York, and did not hold itself out to receive orders in New York to be transmitted elsewhere for acceptance. On the contrary, the Illinois corporation directed that all orders go to New Jersey.
