The court was of the opinion that the cause of action for declaratory judgment in the Illinois corporation's favor should not have been dismissed, as requested by the city, and that the Illinois corporation was entitled to declaratory judgment in its favor. All but one of the remaining causes of action to recover taxes paid to the city involved taxes paid without protest. A recent decision required a holding that such payments were voluntary and unrecoverable. The claim that the payments were made under mistakes of fact was without merit, as the Illinois corporation was chargeable with knowledge of the facts relating to its method of doing business. If there was any mistake, it was one of law, and, as such, not a proper basis for recovery. The only payment made under protest was made more than six years prior to the commencement of the action, and recovery was barred by the Statute of Limitations.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the Illinois corporation was entitled to summary judgment on its motion seeking a declaratory judgment that its sales to customers in the city were exempt from the city's general business tax. The city's motion seeking to dismiss all of the Illinois corporation's causes of action seeking recovery of tax payments was granted.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City general business tax -- interstate commerce -- refunds -- sales made by foreign corporation to customers in New York City constituted transactions in interstate commerce exempt from city's general business tax, where corporation's sales business done from New Jersey warehouse, and New York office used only for corporate, financial, executive and administrative purposes of general and nationwide nature and not for establishing or holding market in this State; payments of taxes made without protest could not be recovered.

1. Sales made by an Illinois corporation to customers in New York City constituted transactions in interstate commerce, and were for that reason exempt from the city's general business tax, where the corporation had no factory or warehouses and no stocks of merchandise, customers' show rooms or sample rooms in New York, orders solicited from or sent by New York customers were accepted or rejected at the corporation's warehouse in New Jersey, and if accepted the customer was billed from New Jersey and shipment made F. O. B. the [***2] warehouse in New Jersey, with title passing at that point, and the corporation's New York office was used only for corporate, financial, executive, administrative and similar purposes of a general and nationwide nature and not for establishing or holding a market in this State.

2. Payments of taxes without protest were voluntary payments and could not be recovered on the theory that they were made under mistakes of fact. The corporation was chargeable with knowledge of the facts relating to its method of doing business, and if there was any mistake it was one of law and, as such, not a proper basis for recovery.

 

2621 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Linn v. Hempstead


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


10 Misc. 2d 774; 170 N.Y.S.2d 217; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2047



December 6, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners brought a lawsuit to declare a zoning ordinance of defendant town that rezoned a parcel of land from residential to business invalid and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The town enacted a ordinance rezoning a parcel of land from residential to business. The property owners owned one-family dwellings in a district adjacent to the rezoned parcel. The court dismissed the property owner's lawsuit seeking to have the zoning ordinance declared unconstitutional and invalid. The property owners did not demonstrate that the rezoning of the subject property was arbitrary or unreasonable or that it constituted spot zoning. Spot zoning was the process of singling out a small parcel of land for a use classification totally different from that of the surrounding area, for the benefit of the owner of such property and to the detriment of other owners. If an ordinance was enacted in accordance with a comprehensive zoning plan, it was not spot zoning, even though it singled out and affected but one small plot or created in the center of a large zone small areas or districts devoted to a different use. The zoning was not inconsistent with the comprehensive plan because the needs of the residents of the area were not properly met by other businesses in the vicinity. Any resultant traffic problems were the domain of the police, not zoning authorities.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the property owner's lawsuit to declare the town's a zoning ordinance of that rezoned a parcel of land from residential to business invalid and unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- zoning -- "spot zoning" -- rezoning of parcel 250 feet by 300 feet from "C-A Residence" to" Business", under which proposed shopping center permissible, not arbitrary or unreasonable and not "spot zoning"; in action by owners of one-family dwellings in adjacent "C-A Residence" district to declare rezoning ordinance unconstitutional, complaint dismissed.

1. A town zoning ordinance which rezoned a parcel of land approximately 250 feet by 300 feet fronting on two streets, from "C-A Residence" to "Business", under which classification a proposed shopping center would be permitted, was not arbitrary or unreasonable and not "spot zoning" accomplished for the special benefit of individuals rather than pursuant to a comprehensive plan for the general welfare of the community. In an action by owners of one-family dwellings in the adjacent "C-A Residence" district to declare such rezoning ordinance unconstitutional, the complaint was dismissed.

2. Zoning is a legislative function and the validity of a zoning or rezoning ordinance or an amendment thereto is presumed. The burden of proving the invalidity of a zoning ordinance or an amendment thereto is upon [***2] the party who assails its validity. The assailant must show by a fair preponderance of credible evidence that the zoning determination of the legislative body was arbitrary, capricious or unreasonable. If the validity of the legislative classification for zoning purposes is fairly debatable, the judgment of the legislative body is conclusive and beyond interference by the courts.

3. An ordinance enacted in accordance with a comprehensive zoning plan is not "spot zoning", even though it singles out and affects but one small plot or creates in the center of a large zone small areas or districts devoted to a different use. The relevant inquiry is not whether the particular zoning under attack consists of areas fixed within larger areas of different use, but whether it was accomplished for the benefit of individual owners rather than pursuant to a comprehensive plan for the general welfare of the community.

4. It was not material to the validity of the rezoning complained of that the construction of a large shopping center on the subject property would create a traffic hazard. Traffic problems are within the domain of the police and not the zoning authorities.

5. An amendment to [***3] a zoning ordinance is a legislative act and the courts may not inquire into the motives of the Town Board or go behind the duly enacted legislation of the board in an attempt to seek a wrongful motive. Hence, plaintiffs were not entitled to elicit from a councilman testimony with respect to the motives of the Town Board in enacting the amendment in question.

6. The amendment to the zoning ordinance in question was not a contract between the town and the owners of the subject property. An obligation assumed by the owners in a "declaration of restrictions" accepted by resolution of the Town Board, to maintain a fence along certain lines of their premises and to permit no ingress or egress to or from one of the streets on which the property fronted, was not a condition for rezoning legislation, but merely a voluntary agreement by the owners for the benefit of nearby residents and an attempt to maintain the good will of the Town Board and of the residents.

7. The circumstances that plaintiffs would suffer property detriment by reason of the rezoning, even if established, was not of great significance, where the rezoning was part of a comprehensive plan or scheme for the good of the [***4] area involved. The pecuniary profits of the individual are secondary to the public welfare.

 

2622 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Klein v. Long Island R. Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


9 Misc. 2d 486; 170 N.Y.S.2d 67; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2080



December 2, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss is accordingly granted.

Submit order.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- railroads -- article 7 of Railroad Law not unconstitutional; motion to dismiss complaint in action for judgment declaring statute unconstitutional and that defendant has forfeited its status under said statute, granted.

The complaint seeks judgment declaring that article 7 of the Railroad Law is unconstitutional and that defendant has forfeited its status under that law. Defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action and for the court's lack of jurisdiction of the subject of the action is granted. The statute is constitutional, and no facts are pleaded to show power in the court to declare a forfeiture of defendant's status acquired under said statute.

 

2623 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sohmer Factors Corp. v. 187-20 Tioga Drive Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


9 Misc. 2d 862; 169 N.Y.S.2d 557; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2123



November 25, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a mortgage assignee, filed a motion for summary judgment striking out an amended answer. The principal defendant debtors cross-filed a motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint and sought an affirmative judgment on their counterclaims in an action to foreclose a second mortgage on a one-family house.


OVERVIEW: The debtors were the owners of a one-family dwelling. In answer to an advertisement broadcast over the radio, they called the mortgage assignee, a funding corporation, and asked to borrow money. A representative of the corporation came to look at the house and told one of the debtors that he needed to incorporate. The debtors signed papers including a bond and mortgage and obtained a loan. The debtors later counterclaimed for cancellation of the bond and mortgage, and the foreclosure ensued. On cross motions for summary judgment, the court held that as to mortgages executed prior to April 6, 1956, amendments rescinding disability of certain corporations to plead usury merely permitted a defense of usury to be interposed in an action instituted for collection, enforcement, or foreclosure of a note, bond or mortgage. Such amendments would not entitle the debtors to cancellation of a "usurious" bond and mortgage. The court further held that because the mortgage assignee was on notice as to the true facts about the loan, it could not successfully claim to have relied on an estoppel certificate received from the debtor's corporation that was organized to execute the mortgage.


OUTCOME: The court denied the mortgage assignee's motion for summary judgment and granted the debtors' cross motion to the extent of dismissing the complaint.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Mortgages -- foreclosure -- defense of usury by corporation -- General Business Law ( § 374, as amd. eff. April 26, 1957), permits corporation whose principal asset is one- or two-family dwelling and which was organized within six months prior to execution of bond and mortgage covering dwelling to plead defense of usury in respect to mortgages executed prior to April 6, 1956 in any action to foreclose such mortgage -- statute is procedural and applies to pending actions -- statute constitutional.

1. This is an action to foreclose a second mortgage on a one-family house known as 187-20 Tioga Drive. The two individual defendants owned said house and one of them called a funding corporation and asked to borrow $ 2,700. Said individual defendant was told that he "would have to be incorporated", and on April 30, 1954, said individual defendants executed a bond and mortgage by "187-20 Tioga Drive Corp." for $ 4,200 with interest at 6% to said funding corporation, as mortgagee, and received checks totaling only $ 2,690 and a payment booklet for monthly payments to be made to plaintiff corporation to which corporation the mortgagee had assigned the mortgage on the same day it was [***2] executed. The loan was usurious and defendant 187-20 Tioga Drive Corporation may plead usury as a defense. Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied and defendants' cross motion is granted to the extent of dismissing the complaint.

2. Section 374 of the General Business Law (as amd. by L. 1957, ch. 968, eff. April 26, 1957) provides that no corporation shall thereafter interpose the defense of usury in any action, with the exception of a corporation, the principal asset of which shall be a one- or two-family house where the corporation was organized within a period of six months prior to the execution by the corporation of a bond or note evidencing indebtedness and a mortgage creating a lien for said indebtedness on the said one- or two-family dwelling. The statute is procedural and applies to pending actions.

3. The legislation is constitutional.

4. Plaintiff argues that since it received an estoppel certificate from the Tioga Corporation, the various defenses, even if valid, cannot be interposed in this action. But the statute itself declares void any instrument whereby the corporation would be estopped from asserting the defense of usury if such instrument was executed [***3] prior to, simultaneously with, or within 60 days after the delivery of any moneys to the borrower. Moreover plaintiff was on notice as to the true facts about the loan and cannot claim to have relied on the estoppel certificate.

5. The counterclaims whereby defendants seek cancellation of the bond and mortgage, will have to be severed and await trial since, as to mortgages executed prior to April 6, 1956, "the defense of usury may be interposed only in an action or proceeding instituted for the collection, enforcement or foreclosure of such note, bond or mortgage" (General Business Law, § 374, subd. 2).

 

2624 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rochester v. Schonleber


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester, Civil Branch


9 Misc. 2d 160; 168 N.Y.S.2d 412; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2137



November 21, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the City of Rochester, brought an action seeking to recover a statutory penalty from defendant, a bakery owner, based upon the fact that the owner allegedly operated a catering service without a proper license, pursuant to the requirements of Rochester, N.Y., Mun. Code vol. II, ch. 23.1. The owner contended that ch. 23.1was unconstitutional and invalid.


OVERVIEW: The owner operated a bakery for many years and had also sold prepared food from the premises. The owner had procured a sanitary certificate that was required pursuant to N.Y. Lab. Law § 337. The City contended that the owner failed to procure a catering license pursuant to Rochester, N.Y., Ordinance § 23.1-1. The City contended that a bakery was not exempt from the provisions of the ordinance governing catering services. The court found that the City had authority to regulate catering to protect the health of its citizens, pursuant to N.Y. Gen. City Law § 20 and other local provisions, and that there was no conflict between the ordinance and N.Y. Lab. Law art. 12 because the State did not regulate catering services. However, it was clear to the court that the ordinance excluded bakeries from the catering provisions because of prior state and federal regulations regarding the operation of bakeries. Further, the City explicitly excluded bakeries from its definition of "restaurant" under Rochester, N.Y., Ordinance § 23.1-1(2). Thus, the owner did not come within the provisions of the ordinance. Because of this determination, the court did not reach the constitutionality question.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- ordinances -- ordinance of City of Rochester, imposing sanitation requirements for eating and drinking establishments, excluded from its provisions bakery business wherein fried fish, baked beans, potato salad and macaroni salad, prepared on premises, were sold over counter for off-premises consumption; in action by city to recover statutory penalty for operating "catering service" without license, complaint dismissed (Rochester Municipal Code vol. II, ch. 23.1).

1. An ordinance of the City of Rochester, imposing sanitation requirements for eating and drinking establishments and providing for licensing and periodic inspection of such establishments, in subdivision 2 thereof expressly excluded from the definition of restaurant, "bakeries, food manufacturers, catering services and boarding houses", and in subdivision 4 defined catering service to mean "the service rendered by a person engaged in the cooking or preparation of food for sale on the premises, or elsewhere or the distribution and serving of such food so cooked or prepared." The ordinance, by its terms, excluded from its provisions a bakery business conducted by defendant, wherein fried fish,  [***2] baked beans, potato salad and marcaroni salad, prepared on the premises with the same kind of equipment used in the preparation and sale of bread and pastry products, were sold only over the counter for off-premises consumption. In an action by the City of Rochester to recover from defendant a statutory penalty, grounded on the claim that defendant operated a catering service without having procured the license required therefor, the complaint was dismissed. A construction of the ordinance excluding bakeries as such under the definition of restaurants in subdivision 2 and again in bringing them within the provisions of the ordinance in subdivision 4 defining "catering service", would be contrary to the plain meaning of the ordinance and to the specific exclusion intended therein. It was reasonable to assume that the City of Rochester specifically excepted "bakeries" from the provisions of the ordinance, recognizing that the State and Federal Governments had enacted legislation adequate for the protection of the health and safety of its citizens in the operation of bakeries, and that its own health officer was designated as the enforcement official of the State law (Rochester Municipal [***3] Code, vol. II, ch. 23.1.)

2. The City of Rochester has ample authority to adopt ordinances which afford to its inhabitants and visitors protection of health and life and impose appropriate fees for the enforcement thereof (General City Law, § 20; Rochester City Charter [L. 1907, ch. 755, § 86, as amd.]).

3. The authority of the city to legislate is subject, however, to the limitation that regulations imposed shall not be inconsistent with the laws of the State of New York. Nor may such regulations alter or supersede any act of the Legislature (City Home Rule Law, § 11, subd. 2; N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 12).

4. The City of Rochester, in regulating by the ordinance the conduct and operation of "catering service", did not intrude into a field pre-empted by the State. There was no conflict between the provisions of the ordinance and article 12 of the Labor Law, relating to bakeries.

5. Municipal ordinances which have for their purpose the protection of public health must be construed liberally.

6. The circumstance that defendant's activities in his bakery shop, in selling on-premises prepared foods over the counter for off-premises consumption, without furnishing delivery [***4] service or utensils, did not fit within a dictionary definition of the word "caterer" was not material. Where the local legislative body, in view of the cause for the passage of the ordinance, the results to be obtained by its passage and the evil to be remedied thereby, defined its own terms in the ordinance, such legislative pronouncement could not be abrogated by reference to etymological definition of a particular term.

7. Courts are not bound in the interpretation of laws containing words that are not specifically defined to follow dictionary definition.

8. The ordinance provided, as to catering services, that "Catering services shall be operated in a manner approved by, and satisfactory to the health officer and in compliance with the applicable sections of this Chapter." Quare, whether the ordinance, insofar as it purported to regulate a "catering service", was unconstitutional because no definite ascertainable standard of compliance was prescribed therein.

 

2625 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grac v. Hempstead


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


9 Misc. 2d 935; 174 N.Y.S.2d 33; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2143



November 21, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the complaint is dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner sought a judgment declaring defendant town's building zone ordinance unconstitutional and void, as it placed her property in a residence district amid a neighborhood having a commercial character, thereby making her property totally unfit for any of the uses to which it was restricted and suited only for business purposes.


OVERVIEW: The owner held an irregularly shaped parcel of land, which was near a turnpike that was heavily traveled. Over the years, the town re-zoned several individual parcels on the turnpike to "business" and those parcels were developed with stores, restaurants, gasoline stations, and places of amusement, interspersed with occasional one-family dwellings. Despite the change in the character of the neighborhood, the owner was denied two applications to have her property zoned for business. The court dismissed the complaint based on the owner's failure to exhaust her administrative remedies. The court held that the owner could apply to the Board of Zoning Appeals if she could establish that she suffered unnecessary hardship and practical difficulties, that her property burdened with its present restrictions, could not yield a reasonable return, and that her situation was unique in the neighborhood. In addition, the court noted that she could not be barred from seeking such relief despite the fact that her property was acquired by her with knowledge of the zoning restrictions.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the owner's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- action would not lie for judgment declaring zoning ordinance confiscatory, insofar as it placed plaintiff's property in residence district, until plaintiff had exhausted all available administrative remedies.

1. An action would not lie for a judgment declaring that a town zoning ordinance was confiscatory, insofar as it placed plaintiff's property in an "A" residence district, where plaintiff had not exhausted her administrative remedies. The complaint is an action seeking such relief was, accordingly, dismissed. One may not attack a zoning ordinance on the ground that it is unconstitutional and confiscatory only as to her particular property, until she has exhausted all available administrative remedies.

2. Plaintiff owned land improved with two one-family dwellings in an area developed with a great many stores, restaurants, gasoline stations and places of amusement, interspersed with occasional one-family dwellings, and in which the town board had in recent years re-zoned 45 individual parcels to "business." Proof that plaintiff's property could be more profitably used for [***2] business than for residential purposes would be insufficient to warrant a declaration that the zoning ordinance was confiscatory and unconstitutional. However, should plaintiff be able to establish that she suffered unnecessary hardship and practical difficulties, that her property burdened with existing restrictions could not yield a reasonable return, and that her situation was unique in the neighborhood, plaintiff might apply to the Board of Zoning Appeals for relief by way of a use variance.

3. Plaintiff could not be barred from seeking relief on the ground that any hardship suffered was self-imposed, in that plaintiff acquired the subject property with knowledge of the zoning restrictions, where plaintiff's present hardship, if any, was created solely by the piecemeal re-zoning of the neighborhood.

 

2626 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Burke v. Kingsley Books, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


8 Misc. 2d 306; 167 N.Y.S.2d 615; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2282



October 30, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporation counsel filed an action under N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 22-a against defendants, retail booksellers and newspaper vendors, for an injunction to enjoin the sale of "strip-tease nudes" photographs on defendants' businesses and of photographs of similar type subsequently acquired. Defendants had challenged the constitutionality of § 22-a, and disposition had been held in abeyance pending a determination of the validity of § 22-a.


OVERVIEW: Packages of individual photographs of one or more female persons in a semi-nude or a nude state were available on sale at the places of business of defendants, who were retail booksellers and newspaper vendors. The photographs were "strip-tease nudes," in that after a set of images in any one package was consecutively arranged by a viewer, he could then observe a pictured female in a progressive state of undress. The corporation counsel filed an action in equity under § 22-a against defendants, seeking an injunction to enjoin the sale of such photographs and of photographs of similar type subsequently acquired, but were not in evidence. The court held that: (1) § 22-a had been upheld by the court, by the Court of Appeals of New York, and by the Supreme Court of the United States; (2) the "strip-tease nudes" photographs were not "obscene" under § 22-a because to the average person, applying contemporary community standards, the dominant theme of the photographs did not appeal to the prurient interest; and (3) to suppress photographs that had not been exhibited for adjudication would be impermissible as a matter of law and would be inappropriate as a matter of civil liberty.


OUTCOME: The court entered a judgment in favor of the retail booksellers and of the newspaper vendors and dismissed the complaint of the city's corporation counsel.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Injunctions -- obscene photographs -- photographs of nudes arranged in progressive "strip-tease" are not obscene within meaning of section 22-a of Code of Criminal Procedure -- moreover, Corporation Counsel states that decree directing sheriff to destroy 75 strips which were exhibited in court would be fruitless unless court also enjoins defendants from distributing, and directs sheriff to seize and destroy any "similar" photographs; sheriff could not adjudge what court did not see, nor could defendants be jailed for contempt of such vague decree; complaint dismissed.

1. Packages of photographs of one or more female persons in various semi-nude or nude states except for some covering of the genitalia, the photographs being so arranged that a viewer may observe the pictured female in a progressive state of undress, are not "obscene" within the meaning of section 22-a of the Code of Criminal Prosedure and as the term "obscene" has been authoritatively defined by our appellate courts in the light of the Bill of Rights.

2. Moreover, under section 22-a of the Code of Criminal Procedure, plaintiff Corporation Counsel asks the court not only to direct the sheriff to seize and destroy [***2] the 75 packages of photographs which were taken from defendant booksellers and newspaper vendors and which were exhibited to the court in this case, and not only to seize and destroy any further prints made from the same negatives, but also to direct the sheriff to seize and destroy any "similar" photographs and to enjoin the defendants from selling or distributing any "similar" pictures. Under such a decree, it would become the sheriff's duty to determine, at peril of being charged with official misfeasance, just what is or is not "similar" to the exhibits which the court saw. The sheriff would thus become an administrative censor -- a status or responsibility not envisaged in the statute -- rather than an executive arm of the judicial process. Furthermore, under such a decree, the defendants would not be sufficiently informed in advance -- on pain of being jailed for contempt -- as to just what they are forbidden by the decree to do. Thus, to enjoin and suppress what has not been exhibited to the court for adjudication would be impermissible as a matter of law, impractical as a matter of execution, and inappropriate as a matter of civil liberty. Plaintiff frankly states that [***3] if the decree were limited to the 75 seized packages, it would be a meaningless and fruitless decree. It appears that plaintiff does not wish a decree if limited -- as it must be -- to the 75 packages. Equity will not do a useless or vain thing. The complaint will be dismissed.

 

2627 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Albrecht Realty Co. v. New Castle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


8 Misc. 2d 255; 167 N.Y.S.2d 843; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2330



October 23, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, developers of real estate, brought an action against defendant town to declare invalid and unconstitutional Town of New Castle, N.Y., Zoning Ordinance, art. VIII B (1956) and to enjoin its enforcement.


OVERVIEW: After the developers purchased land and expended money for its development, the town enacted Town of New Castle, N.Y., Zoning Ordinance, art. VIII B (1956), which limited the issuance of building permits for any land in a special residence district. The town then declared almost all residential land to be in that special residence district. The developers argued that the provisions of article VIII B were beyond the powers granted to the town board by N.Y. Town Law § 261 and violated the constitutional provisions against the taking of property without just compensation. In affirming, the court agreed with the developers' arguments. The court found that § 261 did not give the town the power to regulate its rate of growth and that the zoning article under attack was a direct regulation of the growth rate. Under N.Y. Town Law § 263, the town would have been required to make a regulation of the growth rate in accordance with a comprehensive plan to facilitate the adequate provision of schools. That was not done. Further, it was an unconstitutional deprivation to the developers of all beneficial use of their land, and it made a reasonable return on their investment an impossibility.


OUTCOME: The court declared the town's zoning ordinance invalid and void for its violation of the constitutional prohibition against taking property without just compensation and because no power to enact it was vested in the town by New York Town Law. Further, the court enjoined the town and their successors in office from enforcing or threatening the enforcement of the contested article of the zoning ordinance.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- zoning -- regulation of building permits -- town without power to amend zoning ordinance to regulate rate of growth by providing that no more than 112 residence building permits per annum would issue in special residence district, allotted 25% to quarters beginning June 1 and September 1, 15% to quarter beginning December 1, and 35% to quarter beginning March 1 of each year.

1. Defendant was without power to amend its zoning ordinance to provide that, after the date thereof, no more than 112 residential building permits per annum should be issued for any land that the Town Board should thereafter declare to be within a special residence district and that the 112 permits for each year should be allotted 25% to the quarters beginning June 1, and September 1; 15% to the quarter beginning December 1, and 35% to the quarter beginning March 1 of each year. Section 261 of the Town Law does not give the town power to regulate the rate of its growth. Even if that statute vested that power in the town, it would still be required (Town Law, § 263) to make the regulation in accord with a comprehensive plan to facilitate the adequate provision of schools, and [***2] there is no showing of any such comprehensive plan.

2. Even if the defendant town had been granted the power by the Town Law, the ordinance would be unconstitutional because it would deprive plaintiffs of all beneficial use of their land and would make it impossible for them to make any reasonable return on their investment.

 

2628 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grove Hill Realty Co. v. Ferncliff Cemetery Asso.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


9 Misc. 2d 47; 167 N.Y.S.2d 675; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2401



October 8, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state cemetery board filed a motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiff realty company on the ground of legal insufficiency pursuant to N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 106(4). The company's declaratory judgment action against the board was predicated upon a contract for the sale of land between the company and defendant cemetery association.


OVERVIEW: The company and the association entered into an agreement for the sale of real property whereby the association agreed, inter alia, to pay the company one half of the proceeds of the each sale of plots to the public. Thereafter, company challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Membership Corp. Law §§ 87, 86-a, both of which had been revised or amended after the agreement had been in effect for several years, on the ground that the deductions required of the association by §§ 87 and 86-a for the sale of each plot impaired the contract between the company and the association. The court determined that, in light of a recent ruling by another court in a similar case, the challenged statutory provisions were constitutional. The court noted that it could not dismiss the company's declaratory judgment action because such a dismissal was inconsistent with the parties' rights where there was no question of act but merely a question of law. The court concluded that the board was entitled to judgment on the merits to the extent of declaring that § 87(2) and § 86-a were valid and constitutional insofar as they affected the company's agreement with the association.


OUTCOME: The court denied the board's motion to dismiss but entered a judgment on the merits in favor of the board.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional law -- cemetery corporations -- subdivision 2 of section 87 and section 86-a of Membership Corporations Law requiring cemetery corporations to set up current and permanent maintenance funds are valid and constitutional.

1. Plaintiff sold certain land to defendant cemetery association in consideration for which said defendant agreed that upon the sale of plots to the public, it would pay to the plaintiff one half of the proceeds of each sale. Subsequently, section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law was amended and new section 86-a of such law was enacted, requiring the defendant cemetery association to maintain a permanent maintenance fund, into which must first be deposited not less than 10% of the gross proceeds of the sale of any plot, and a current maintenance fund into which must also be deposited an additional 15% of such gross proceeds. If such deductions are made, plaintiff may then only be entitled to receive one half of the net proceeds remaining after the sales price has been reduced by those deposits. Plaintiff, claiming that if these deductions are made, there will be a breach of its contract with defendant, and that the statute is unconstitutional [***2] because the provisions thereof impair said contract, sues for a declaratory judgment. Subdivision 2 of section 87 and section 86-a of the Membership Corporations Law, insofar as they affect plaintiff's agreement with defendant association, are valid.

2. Defendant cemetery board's motion to dismiss the complaint is denied. A dismissal would be inconsistent with a declaration of the rights of the parties.

 

2629 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Watkins v. Town Board of Oyster Bay


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


8 Misc. 2d 251; 169 N.Y.S.2d 753; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2472



September 24, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the application is granted.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner individual filed an application pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78 for an order compelling respondents, a town board and other parties, to execute its consent to a petition submitted to it under N.Y. Village Law § 348. The individual filed a petition for the annexation of certain territory.


OVERVIEW: The petition sought the annexation of certain territory, and the town board refused consent. The court granted the individual's application to compel consent. The court stated that the town board found that the petition for proposed annexation was in due and proper form and complied with requirements of law pertaining thereto. The court stated that it must, therefore, have been inferred the petition complied with § 348. The court ruled that the town board was not entitled to raise issues regarding the advertisement of the public hearing and ruled that other arguments did not have sufficient substance.


OUTCOME: The court granted the individual's application.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- annexation -- town board having found that petition for annexation of certain territory in town to adjoining village complied with section 348 of Village Law, its only remaining function was ministerial, to consent to annexation.

An application for an order compelling the Town Board of the Town of Oyster Bay to execute its consent to a petition submitted to it under section 348 of the Village Law for annexation of certain territory in the town to the adjoining Village of Laurel Hollow, is granted. Chapter 818 of the Laws of 1954, which purported to give to the town boards of Nassau County the power to determine whether the annexation of town territory to villages was in the public interest, has been held unconstitutional and the function of the Town Board merely to determine whether the petition complied with the statute ( Matter of Cutler v. Herman, 2 A D 2d 782, affd. 3 N Y 2d 334). The Town Board found that the petition complied with section 348 of the Village Law. Its only remaining function is a ministerial one -- to consent to the annexation.

 

2630 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


De Veau v. Braisted


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Richmond County


11 Misc. 2d 661; 166 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2550; 40 L.R.R.M. 2612; 33 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P70,945



September 5, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petitioners' application for an injunction pendente lite together with the petitioners' cross motion for judgment dismissing the complaint and for judgment on the pleadings in his favor, is granted.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a union and one of its officers, filed an application for an injunction pendente lite seeking to restrain respondent county district attorney from enforcing § 8, 1953 N.Y. Laws 882, 883, of the Waterfront Commission Act (the Act) and forcing the union to suspend the officer because he had previously been convicted of a felony. The district attorney filed a motion to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The officer pleaded guilty to a felony and received a suspended sentence. The district attorney notified the union that as long as the officer remained in its employ, the union was forbidden by § 8 of the Act to collect dues. Thus, the union suspended the officer. In denying petitioners' claim for an injunction, the court held that the provisions of § 8 of the Act were not void because they did not conflict with § 7, 29 U.S.C.S. § 157, of the National Labor Relations Act. Further, the court rejected petitioners' contention that a plea of guilty to a felony, followed by a suspended sentence, did not constitute a conviction within the meaning of § 8, 1953 N.Y. Laws 882-883, of the Act. The background of the Act revealed that it was enacted out of concern with individuals who had escaped conviction despite frequent skirmishes with the law. According to the court, that fact, coupled with the fact that a technical judgment of conviction was not necessary in order to prohibit individuals in professional fields from participating in their livelihood, mandated the conclusion that a plea of guilty followed by a suspended sentence was a conviction within the meaning of § 8 of the Act.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioners' application for the injunction and granted the district attorney's motion for judgment dismissing the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- New York Harbor Waterfront Commission Act -- section 8 of Waterfront Commission Act (L. 1953, ch. 882, part III) validly forbids any labor organization any officer of which is convicted of felony to collect dues from registered longshoremen; section applies to elected officers and appointed agents, and does not unconstitutionally conflict with right of employees under National Labor Relations Act to choose their own collective bargaining representatives -- suspended sentence is conviction, within intent of Waterfront Commission Act.

1. Section 8 of the act establishing a Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor (L. 1953, ch. 882, part III) forbids the collection of dues from registered longshoremen on behalf of a labor organization any officer or agent of which has been convicted of a felony. This provision applies to an elected officer as well as to an appointed agent and does not unconstitutionally conflict with the [***2] provision of section 7 of the National Labor Relations Act (U. S. Code, tit. 29, § 157) authorizing employees to select representatives of their own choosing for collective bargaining.

2. The union officer's conviction occurred in 1922, on his plea of guilty of attempted grand larceny, and resulted in a suspended sentence. For the purposes and intent of the Waterfront Commission Act, a suspended sentence is a conviction.

 

2631 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Murtha v. Monaghan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


7 Misc. 2d 568; 169 N.Y.S.2d 137; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2649



August 2, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] It follows that plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is granted and that defendant's cross motion to dismiss the complaint is denied.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff would-be official filed suit against defendant, Commissioner of the Harness Racing Commission of the State of New York, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law § 41 (1953). The would-be official filed a motion for summary judgment, and the Commissioner filed a cross motion to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The would-be official made application to the Commissioner for a position of race official at a pari-mutuel trotting tracks. Although concededly qualified for such position, his application was denied on the sole ground that he had not obtained a license from a particular private corporation as required by § 41. The would-be official filed suit, alleging that the statute was unconstitutional. Upon consideration, the court agreed and declared the statute unconstitutional. The delegation by the legislature of its licensing power to a private corporation was such an abdication as to be patently an unconstitutional relinquishment of legislative power in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, which provided that the legislative power of the state was vested in the senate and assembly. Even if the legislature's power to license had been delegated to a governmental agency, N.Y. Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law § 41 (1953) would still have been stricken down for lack of guides and proper standards.


OUTCOME: The would-be official's motion for summary judgment was granted, and the Commissioner's cross motion to dismiss the complaint was denied.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- horse racing -- Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law (L. 1940, ch. 254, § 41, as amd. by L. 1953, ch. 391) insofar as it provides that no person shall be designated as judge or starter unless licensed by United States Trotting Association as race meeting official, is unconstitutional.

The Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law (L. 1940, ch. 254, § 41, as amd. by L. 1953, ch. 391) insofar as it provides that: "No person shall be designated as a judge or starter unless he shall be licensed by the United States Trotting Association as a duly qualified pari-mutuel race meeting official", is unconstitutional.

 

2632 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


St. Nicholas Cathedral of Russian Orthodox Church v. Kreshik


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


9 Misc. 2d 1069; 166 N.Y.S.2d 245; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2760



July 3, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant dean filed a motion to dismiss an action for ejectment filed by plaintiff corporation, alleging that the corporation and not the dean should have use and possession of a specific cathedral.


OVERVIEW: The issue was whether the use and possession of the cathedral was is to be in the dean as appointee of the Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church in Moscow or in the corporation by its elected ecclesiastic. The court dismissed the complaint. The court found that the corporation held the legal title, but for the beneficial use of the appropriate authorities spiritual. The court also found that the corporation failed to establish adequate grounds for a finding in its favor, or for ejectment. The court determined that the evidence drawn from testimony, literature, and reasonably accurate information warranted the conclusion that the Patriarchate of Moscow was the head of a functioning religious order and that the cathedral was under his direction.


OUTCOME: Judgment was entered dismissing complaint in the action for ejectment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Religious corporations and associations -- administration of church property -- Patriarchate of Moscow found to be head of functioning religious order, capable of administering temporalities of cathedral of Russian Orthodox Church in New York City; in action in ejectment, brought to resolve right to use and possession of cathedral as between plaintiff, St. Nicholas Cathedral of Russian Orthodox Church in North America, and appointee of Patriarch of Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church in Moscow, complaint dismissed.

The Court of Appeals remitted to the Supreme Court for new trial an action in ejectment, brought to resolve the right to the use and possession of cathedral premises of the Russian Orthodox Church in New York City as between plaintiff, St. Nicholas Cathedral of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America, and the appointee of the Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church in Moscow, and ordered that the Supreme Court, at such trial, direct its inquiry to the existence and status of the central church authorities in Moscow and their ability to carry out the purposes of the religious trust involved in the possession of the cathedral premises, namely,  [***2] to administer the temporalities of the cathedral for the benefit of the faithful for whose use it was originally dedicated ( St. Nicholas Cathedral v. Kedroff, 306 N. Y. 38). The Supreme Court, having followed the injunction of the Court of Appeals "to gather all the evidence possible, to entertain the views of expert church scholars, to analyze the available documents and the canon law, to make findings of fact and to exercise sound discretion thereon, building up a record which is suitable for intelligent review and adjudication by the appellate courts", was unable to conclude, as argued by plaintiff, that the Moscow Patriarchate was "a secular arm of an atheistic government bent on destroying the United States", but found that the Patriarchate of Moscow was the head of a functioning religious order, that the St. Nicholas Cathedral of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America was under his direction, and that the central church authorities were able to carry out effectively and faithfully the purposes of the religious trust. The complaint was dismissed.

 

2633 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Grimshaw


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Jefferson County


7 Misc. 2d 218; 165 N.Y.S.2d 263; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2798



June 26, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner licensee instituted a proceeding to review an order of respondent Commissioner of Motor Vehicles of the State of New York, which temporarily suspended his license to drive an automobile, pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71-a.


OVERVIEW: The licensee's car was stopped on the highway due to a mechanical failure, and he proceeded on foot to a roadstand to call a garage. A state trooper observed the car and went to the roadstand to question the licensee. The licensee was arrested for driving while intoxicated either before or after he allegedly refused to consent to a chemical test. Subsequently, the Commissioner suspended the licensee's driver's license. The court annulled and revoked the suspension. The provisions of § 71-a, granting to the Commissioner the right to revoke the license of a person who refused to submit to the chemical test, were made contingent upon the Commissioner giving such person an opportunity to be heard. Such a hearing was required to have been scheduled before issuing a temporary suspension order. Thus, the suspension order issued by the Commissioner was unauthorized, as no hearing was scheduled prior to its issuance. The trooper's report did not contain any statement of facts constituting the grounds upon which he had reason to believe that the licensee was driving in an intoxicated condition. Thus, the report did not satisfy the requirements for the issuance of a suspension order.


OUTCOME: The court annulled and revoked the Commissioner's order.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- suspension of driver's license -- before license could be temporarily suspended for failure to submit to chemical test to determine whether licensee was intoxicated, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles was required to schedule hearing (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 71-a); moreover, report of arresting officer as to such failure to submit to chemical test was required to recite facts as to intoxication and not legal conclusion in words of statute; temporary suspension of petitioner's license effected without hearing and without proper report was annulled.

1. Before the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles could issue an order temporarily suspending petitioner's license to drive an automobile under section 71-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which granted to the commissioner the right to revoke the license of a person who refused to submit to a chemical test to determine whether he was driving while intoxicated, the commissioner was required by the statute to schedule a hearing.

2. The report of refusal to submit to a chemical test filed with the commissioner by the arresting officer which merely stated the conclusion of the officer in the words of section 71-a that he [***2] had reasonable grounds to believe petitioner was driving in an intoxicated condition, and which report contained no facts to substantiate the conclusion, was insufficient.

3. Where petitioner's license was temporarily suspended without a hearing, and based on an insufficient report, the action of the commissioner in suspending temporarily petitioner's license must be annulled.

 

2634 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ticket Clubs of New Jersey, Inc. v. O'Connell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


8 Misc. 2d 519; 166 N.Y.S.2d 294; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2821



June 24, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff ticket broker moved to enjoin the enforcement of a regulation of defendant Commissioner of Licenses of the City of New York, which prohibited New York City theatres from selling more than 10 tickets to a broker not licensed by the Commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The broker, a New Jersey corporation, engaged in the business of selling theatre tickets. The Commissioner had adopted a regulation forbidding a theatre from selling more than 10 tickets to a person who intended to resell them and whom did the Commissioner not license. The ticket broker challenged the regulation, contending that it was invalid and arbitrary and that it imposed an undue burden upon interstate commerce and violated the broker's constitutional rights. The court denied the broker's motion to enjoin the enforcement of the regulation. The court rejected the broker's claim that the ticket regulation denied it equal protection and deprived it of its property without due process of law. The court concluded that the regulation bore a real relation to the suitable protection of the people of the state, was reasonable in its requirements, and did not impose an undue burden upon interstate commerce.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- ticket brokers -- regulation of New York City department of licenses forbidding New York City theatres from selling more than 10 tickets to broker not licensed by that department, was neither arbitrary nor capricious; regulation, as applied to New Jersey ticket broker, did not impose undue burden on interstate commerce and was not otherwise unconstitutional.

1. A regulation of the New York City department of licenses forbidding New York City theatres from selling more than 10 tickets to a broker not licensed by that department was neither arbitrary nor capricious, and enforcement thereof would not be enjoined.

2. The regulation, as applied to a New Jersey corporation engaged in the business of selling theatre tickets, did not impose an undue burden on interstate commerce, nor did it deny equal protection of the laws or deprive such corporation of its property without due process of law.

 

2635 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gair v. Peck


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


6 Misc. 2d 739; 165 N.Y.S.2d 247; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2869



June 14, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion of the plaintiffs for summary judgment is granted. Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff attorneys brought this action to challenge the promulgation of a rule by defendant supreme court, appellate division, which fixed maximum legal fees and declared that any fee in excess thereof was unreasonable and unconscionable. The attorneys here sought summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The appellate division of the supreme court adopted a rule which established a scale of fees for personal injury and wrongful death cases and stated that receipt or retention of a greater fee would be considered the exaction of unreasonable and unconscionable compensation in violation of the bar association's canons of professional ethics. Several attorneys brought this action to challenge the promulgation of the rule. The attorneys sought summary judgment. The court granted summary judgment to the attorneys. The court held that the rule did in fact fix legal fees and, as such, exceeded the disciplinary power the court had over lawyers as set forth in N.Y. Judiciary Law § 90(2). N.Y. Judiciary Law § 474 allowed an attorney and client generally to reach their own agreement regarding fees.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment to the attorneys in their action against the appellate division of the supreme court arising from the appellate division's promulgation of a rule limiting legal fees and declaring that any fee in excess of such limit was unreasonable and unconscionable.


HEADNOTES

Attorneys -- regulation of contingent fees -- Appellate Division without power to promulgate special rule regulating contingent fees in claims and actions for personal injuries and wrongful death.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, was without power to promulgate a special rule regulating contingent fees in claims and actions for personal injuries and wrongful death, wherein a scale of fees was established and receipt of any sum in excess of scheduled fees, unless authorized by court order, declared to constitute the exaction of unreasonable and unconscionable compensation in violation of the Canons of Professional Ethics. The Legislature elected to say that parties might by agreement provide for the fixing of fees, and where it felt that the right to fix fees should be restricted it so stated and made provision therefor (Judiciary Law, § 474). That right was not intended to be exercised concurrently by the Appellate Division, and subdivision 2 of section 90 of the Judiciary Law, conferring upon the Appellate Division the power to admit persons to or remove them [***2] from the practice of law, did not confer that right. Nor was the special rule sanctioned by section 83 of the Judiciary Law, giving the Appellate Division power to adopt special rules "not inconsistent with any statute or rule of civil practice."

 

2636 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Mayers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of General Sessions of County of New York


9 Misc. 2d 212; 169 N.Y.S.2d 839; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2928



June 3, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the foregoing, this application is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A California superior court, under the terms of its reciprocal witness statute, granted a certificate requesting the issuance of a subpoena for the appearance and attendance of a resident of New York as a witness at a grand jury investigation in progress in California. The prospective witness strenuously objected to the application.


OVERVIEW: The prospective witness contended that California provided no immunity statute such as N.Y. Penal Law § 2447, that N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 618-a did not authorize the issuance of a subpoena duces tecum, and that § 618-a was unconstitutional. At the hearing of the motion, the assistant attorney-general representing California testified in substance that the prospective witness would become a defendant if the facts should warrant it. The court ruled in favor of the prospective witness. The court held that a serious preliminary question arose as to whether the witness was solely a witness or whether the Uniform Witness Act was in reality being used for the purpose of effectuating the return of the witness in order to make him a defendant instead. The court held that the Act seemed harsh and carried interference with personal liberty to an extreme limit. In view thereof, the court stated that the Act's terms should be strictly construed and that it ought not to be used against any person unless that person was slated strictly as a statutory witness. Here, the good faith of the moving party was in issue, and the matter was resolved in favor of the prospective witness.


OUTCOME: The court denied the application.


HEADNOTES

Witnesses -- Uniform Witness Act -- application for issuance of subpoena for appearance and attendance as witness of New York State resident at Grand Jury investigation in California, pursuant to Uniform Witness Act, denied where witness may become defendant.

A California court, under the terms of the reciprocal witness statute of California, requested the appearance and attendance of a New York State resident as a witness at a Grand Jury investigation being held in California. Under California law, the prospective witness might become a defendant if the facts should warrant it. The application for the issuance of a subpoena is denied. The Uniform Witness Act should not be used against any person unless he is intended strictly as a statutory witness and is not in jeopardy of becoming a defendant.

 

2637 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. James


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester, Criminal Branch


6 Misc. 2d 441; 162 N.Y.S.2d 927; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3017



May 15, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motions made by defendant, upon which the court reserved decision, are granted. The defendant is acquitted and the information is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the case against him for a violation of Rochester, N.Y., Ordinances § 70-61 regarding noise emitted from mufflers.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested when a police officer stopped him for operating a motor vehicle with a loud noise coming from its muffler. He filed a motion to dismiss the charges against him on the ground that § 70-61 was unconstitutional. The court held that the ordinance, in its entirety, was unconstitutional because it was so vague as to be invalid for lack of an objective standard. The court found that it purported to adopt a conclusive standard by nomenclature that did not exist, and, consequently, it did not afford a comprehensible guide to an ordinary member of society and was devoid of intelligent expression as to what had to be done and avoided. The court noted that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 15(1) required only that a motor vehicle have a suitable muffler or device to prevent unnecessary noise from exhaust gases, so the State did not indulge in prescribing what make or type of mufflers were prohibited.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion and ordered him acquitted and the information against him dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- noisy mufflers -- city ordinance prohibiting use of "so-called 'Hollywood' muffler" or any muffler noisier than "standard type muffler" is unconstitutional for vagueness.

The following ordinance of the City of Rochester: "Sec. 70-61, Mufflers. No person shall operate on any public street or park within the City of Rochester, a motor vehicle equipped with a so-called 'Hollywood' muffler or with any muffler that produces a noise louder than that of the standard type muffler used in the manufacture of the car being so operated. The use of so-called 'cut-outs' is prohibited", is unconstitutional and void. The evidence in this criminal prosecution is that the phrase "Hollywood muffler" is vague, nontechnical, uncertain and altogether useless as a statutory standard. The Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 15, subd. 1) merely requires that a motor vehicle "shall have a suitable muffler or device to prevent unnecessary noise from exhaust gases". It is also questionable whether the City of Rochester had the power to enact [***2] this ordinance (see Vehicle and Traffic Law §§ 54, 90). Defendant is acquitted and the information is dismissed.

 

2638 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Robbins v. Schechter


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


7 Misc. 2d 436; 162 N.Y.S.2d 790; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3129



April 24, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The application is accordingly denied and the stay heretofore granted to the petitioners is vacated. Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, nine candidates for police captain, applied to the court to review and annul the adoption of a mathematical formula by respondents, Chairman of the City Civil Service Commission for the City of New York and the Commission, for grading a promotion examination for captain in the police department. The formula had the effect of reducing the passing grade for the first part of a two-part written examination.


OVERVIEW: The rules of a promotion examination for captain in the police department stated that if a candidate failed to pass any part of the exam he would be deemed to have failed the entire exam and no further part of the exam would be graded. After the exam was held, the Commission determined that it was too difficult and applied a formula that had the effect of reducing the passing grade for part one of the exam. The Commission was aware that the promotion list contained 202 eligibles and that, based on an exam sampling, only 79 candidates would receive a passing grade. The nine candidates contested the Commission's use of the formula because it allowed candidates who would otherwise have been eliminated to attain a higher grade on the entire exam. The court held that: (1) there was nothing contrary to the competitive requirements of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6, in the use of a formula to adjust the grades of all of the candidates where, without the aid of the formula, there would be too few successful candidates to provide an adequate promotion list; and (2) the adoption of the formula was in accordance with the rules promulgated prior to the exam and thus was not arbitrary or capricious.


OUTCOME: The court denied the nine candidates' application and vacated a stay theretofore granted the candidates.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- examinations -- use of grading formula to increase number of successful candidates -- in multiple phase promotion examination for captain of police, city civil service commission, finding that number of passing eligibles would not be adequate, applied formula in grading to increase number of those passing; application of such formula was not unconstitutional and not arbitrary.

There was nothing unconstitutional in connection with a multiple phase promotion examination for captain in the police department of the City of New York in the use by the city civil service commission of a mathematical formula to adjust the grades of all candidates who took such multiple phase examination which required that all its parts be passed, where the examination was found to be too difficult and where, without the aid of the formula, there would have been too few successful candidates to provide an adequate promotion list, especially where a rule promulgated prior to the date the examination was held, specifically provided that the director of examinations [***2] might apply a mathematical formula of penalties for incorrect answers where there was an insufficient number of candidates to provide an adequate eligible list. Adoption of the formula by the commission in the instant proceeding was, therefore, neither unlawful, arbitrary, nor capricious.

 

2639 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Public Porters Protective & Defense Asso. v. O'Connell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special and Trial Term, New York County


6 Misc. 2d 36; 167 N.Y.S.2d 479; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3184



April 10, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Public Porters Protective and Defense Association brought an action seeking an order directing Respondent Commissioner of Licenses to annul, withdraw, and declare void a regulation restricting the activities of porters to 100 feet from piers, bus terminals, or railroad depot stations.


OVERVIEW: The City Council enacted a law giving the Commissioner authority to promulgate regulations for the conduct of public porters, New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § B32-112.0 (1939), which included the time and place where they could be permitted to solicit employment. Pursuant to this authority, the Commissioner issued a regulation prohibiting public porters from soliciting and accepting employment within 100 feet of any railroad station, pier, or bus terminal. The regulation was not enforced until 17 years later when the original number of porters had diminished greatly, and the Association filed an action seeking an order directing the Commissioner to annul, withdraw, and declare the regulation void. The court determined that the regulation should have been declared void because its enforcement would not have served to eradicate any sort of evil, instead it merely impinged upon the porters' right to obtain a license necessary for them to pursue a reasonable occupation. The test of constitutionality was whether an evil existed and whether a logical relation existed between the eradication of the evil and the promulgation of regulations intended to cure the evil.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Association's petition for an order directing the Commissioner to annul, withdraw, and declare void a certain regulation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Licenses -- public porters -- old municipal regulation forbidding licensed public porters to operate in vicinity of transportation terminals, invalidated.

In 1939 there were about 500 licensed public porters in New York City. In that year a local law was enacted discontinuing the issuance of new licenses, but providing that existing licenses could still be renewed annually, and authorizing the city's commissioner of licenses to promulgate regulations as to times and places where porters could solicit business (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B32-112.0). The commissioner issued a regulation forbidding public porters from operating within 100 feet of railroad stations, piers, or bus terminals where the management supplied a staff to serve the patrons. This regulation was not enforced for 17 years. Meanwhile the number of public porters dwindled to only 37. They now petition for an order restraining the police commissioner from enforcing the old regulation. No compelling necessity appears for the promulgation of the regulation, or any evil for which these porters might be responsible. In effect, it would deprive them of the benefit of the licenses for which [***2] they have paid a fee. Their petition is granted.

 

2640 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hugo v. Wade


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Ontario County


5 Misc. 2d 451; 160 N.Y.S.2d 534; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3272



March 25, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to strike, therefore, is also denied.

Submit order accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved for an order to dismiss the second cause of action in a wrongful death claim brought by plaintiff executor of the decedent's estate against defendants, for failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action, in that the executor failed to allege freedom from contributory negligence on the decedent's part, and to strike out allegations in the first cause of action that defendants' conduct frightened the decedent.


OVERVIEW: One or both of the drivers struck the decedent while he was crossing the street. As a result, the decedent could not move and was struck by a third car. He eventually died. The executor brought a wrongful death action against both of the drivers. A cause of action for recovery for the decedent's pain and suffering was included. The drivers moved to dismiss the action for pain and suffering, claiming that the executor failed to allege the decedent's freedom from contributory negligence. The drivers also moved to strike the executor's allegation that the driver's conduct frightened the decedent because there was no right to sue for damages resulting from fright. The court ruled that the pain and suffering claim was sufficient because under the statute, the drivers had the burden of proving contributory negligence on the decedent's part. The court concluded that the allegation that the decedent was frightened by the drivers' negligence was made to establish a causal relation between the drivers' conduct and the decedent's injury. Thus, although the allegations were not in the most artistic form, they were sufficient for the purpose and sufficient to withstand the motion to strike.


OUTCOME: The court denied the drivers' motions.


HEADNOTES

Death -- proof of contributory negligence -- in action for both pain and wrongful death, decedent's contributory negligence must be pleaded and proved by defendant (Decedent Estate Law, § 119); section constitutional -- complaint alleged that two automobiles sped toward decedent pedestrian and frightened, disoriented, and immobilized him, that one or both knocked him unconscious, so that third automobile also struck him; this is not suit for fright alone; complaint is sufficient.

1. Section 119 of the Decedent Estate Law, providing that where a cause of action for wrongful death is joined with one for decedent's pain and suffering, "the contributory negligence of the deceased person shall be a defense, to be pleaded and proven by the defendant", is a constitutional exercise of the Legislature's power to classify causes of action.

2. Where a plaintiff has not been touched at all, he has no cause of action for fright. This rule has been laid down because of practical considerations as to possible fictitious claims. This rule does not apply to the instant complaint. The complaint alleges that [***2] decedent, a pedestrian, was crossing the main street of a city when two automobiles, one owned and operated by one set of defendants and the other owned and operated by another set of defendants, drove toward him at an excessive rate of speed and in a negligent manner and caused him "to be frightened and disoriented and unable to move from a place of danger" and that decedent was struck "by either or both of the vehicles of the defendants" and knocked unconscious, so that he was later struck again by a third automobile, whose owner is not a party to this action. These allegations state a cause of action against both sets of defendants. Motion to strike such allegations is denied.

 

2641 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


United Medical Service, Inc. v. Holz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


5 Misc. 2d 999; 161 N.Y.S.2d 624; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3279



March 25, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied and the petition is dismissed. Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner insurance plan brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to review the determination of respondent, the Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York, who ruled that an amendment to N.Y. Ins. Law § 250, L. 1953, ch. 634, eff. April 13, 1953, required that the plan allow reimbursement for treatment in the field of oral surgery irrespective of whether the specific patient was attended by a physician or a dentist.


OVERVIEW: The plan contended that the Superintendent misconstrued the plain meaning of the 1953 amendment to N.Y. Ins. Law § 250 and that the statute as construed was unconstitutional. Noting that the essential dispute was whether the Superintendent's ruling was arbitrary, unreasonable, or capricious, the court held that the Superintendent's determination was in consonance with the opinion expressed by the Attorney-General and was in accord with the intent and purport of the pertinent act. The court noted that a memorandum from the Insurance Department submitted to the Governor prior to signing the bill, including the 1953 amendment, stated that by the amendment a subscriber would be entitled to reimbursement for care within the coverage of the policy whether provided by a licensed physician or a licensed dentist. The court rejected the plan's contention that the construction made by the Superintendent constituted an unconstitutional impairment of the obligation of the contracts between the plan and its subscribers, noting that the question as to the proper extent of coverage and consequent responsibility for reimbursement was clearly known to interested organizations such as the plan.


OUTCOME: The court denied the plan's motion and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- nonprofit medical expense indemnity contracts -- Superintendent of Insurance properly ruled that, if Blue Shield plan included oral surgery, it must include it regardless of whether surgery was performed by doctor or dentist (Insurance Law, § 250, as amd. by L. 1953, ch. 634) -- amendment not retroactive as to contracts made before April 13, 1953, but does govern contracts made after that.

1. The State Superintendent of Insurance properly made a regulation construing the Insurance Law (§ 250, as amd. by L. 1953, ch. 634, eff. April 13, 1953) as requiring that, if a nonprofit medical expense indemnity contract (such as a "Blue Shield" plan) made after April 13, 1953, included oral surgery, then the indemnity must be paid regardless of whether it was a physician or a dentist who treated the patient.

2. The statute and regulation do not affect contracts made before the effective date of the amendment, April 13, 1953. As to contracts made after that date, this petitioner was well aware of the issues. It cannot be said that the statute and regulation impair the obligations of contracts [***2] made after the effective date of the amendment.

 

2642 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lopez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Queens County


5 Misc. 2d 1054; 165 N.Y.S.2d 1001; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3317



March 19, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant demurred to an indictment charging defendant with the crimes of grand larceny in the second degree and the possession of a dangerous weapon in a case brought against defendant and others under N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 323. Defendant asserted that the grand jury had no legal authority to act because N.Y. Jud. Law § 609 violated the New York Constitution.


OVERVIEW: The court disallowed defendant's demurrer. It found that a demurrer served only to raise objections that appeared on the face of defendant's indictment. Thus, no substance existed to the first ground of defendant's assertions, N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 323(1), because the allegedly improper conduct did not appear on the face of defendant's indictment. Also, defendant's constitutional rights were not violated even though a grand jury was selected under an invalid statute because N.Y. Jud. Law § 609 was not unconstitutional. Upon an examination of the indictment, the court found that defendant's indictment clearly complied with N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. §§ 275, 276, that the acts alleged in the indictment constituted crimes, and that defendant's indictment contained no matter constituting a legal justification or excuse for the acts charged or other legal bar to the prosecution. Therefore, no substance existed to the other three grounds raised in defendant's demurrer. The court disallowed defendant's demurrer because no defect appeared on the face of it.


OUTCOME: The court disallowed defendant's demurrer in all respects.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Grand jury -- selection of jurors in New York City -- Judiciary Law ( § 609) is constitutional; demurrer to indictment found by grand jury in New York City overruled.

 Section 609 of the Judiciary Law, as to selection of grand juries in New York City, was enacted on the recommendation of the Judicial Council and hence is not invalid as a local bill (N. Y. Const., art III, §§ 17, 21; Judiciary Law, § 45, subd. [e]). Indictments found by such grand juries are not demurrable for lack of authority (Code Crim. Pro., § 323, subd. 1).

 

2643 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Zember v. State


Claim Nos. 33531, 33532, 33533


Court of Claims of New York
