5 Misc. 2d 216; 160 N.Y.S.2d 510; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3392



March 4, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant property owner submitted three claims involving the appropriation of land she owned by defendants, the State of New York and others. Included in the taking were four lots and substantially half of another lot in a subdivision. On July 11, 1953, a contractor working for the New York Thruway Authority came upon the owner's land, and since then she had been denied use of the property.


OVERVIEW: On the date of the taking, the property owner's land was being used by her husband for truck gardening. All the crops were destroyed and the contractor took total possession. A map of the taking was filed in the office of the county clerk in April 1954. Personal service on the property owner, however, was not made until December 23, 1955, 22 days after the owner filed her claim with the clerk of the Court of Claims. The court determined that the best available use of the land appropriated by the State was for residential or commercial building lots. The court viewed the premises and determined that the fair and reasonable market value of the owner's land prior to the appropriation was $ 4,000, and the value of the land after its appropriation was $ 250. The court held that the owner was entitled to the difference, plus interest accruing from the date of the taking. The court reasoned that if interest were not awarded under the circumstances, the property owner would be deprived of just compensation for the taking of her property.


OUTCOME: The court awarded the property owner $ 3,750, with interest to the date of the entry of judgment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Eminent domain -- interest on award -- "just compensation" (N. Y. Const., art I, § 7) requires award of value of property at time of taking, plus legal interest or rental value as damages for delay in payment -- amount of "just compensation" cannot constitutionally be fixed without notice and opportunity to be heard (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6) -- after filing of appropriation map in Secretary of State's office, contractor for Thruway Authority took possession of claimant's land (Highway Law, §§ 30, 347) in 1953, but notice of appropriation was not served on claimant until December 1955, and clamant filed her claim in December, 1955; Court of Claims Act ( § 19, subd. 1), purporting to eliminate interest for part of such period, cannot be constitutionally applied to such case; claimant is entitled to value of her property plus interest from 1953 to date.

1. The requirement of "just compensation" for appropriated property (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 7) includes (1) the value of the property at the date of the taking and (2) damages for the delay in paying said value. Ordinarily, legal interest is the measure of the latter damages, unless the owner can show that the property had [***2] a rental value greater than legal interest.

2. Property may constitutionally be appropriated by the sovereign without notice to the owner; but "just compensation" cannot constitutionally be determined without due process; that is, without notice to the owner and an opportunity to be heard (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6).

3. The Court of Claims Act ( § 19, subd. 1) provides that "If a claim which bears interest, is not filed until more than six months after the accrual of said claim, no interest shall be allowed between the expiration of six months from the time of such accrual and the time of the filing of such claim." Claimant's real property was shown on a New York State Thruway Authority appropriation map filed in the office of the Secretary of State. Upon such filing the State had the right to take possession (Highway Law, §§ 30, 347). Total possession was thus taken by a contractor for the Authority on July 11, 1953. The map was not filed in the County Clerk's office until April, 1954. Claimant filed her claim for damages on December 1, 1955, in the office of the clerk of the Court of Claims. Notice of appropriation was not personally served on claimant until December 23,  [***3] 1955. In these circumstances, section 19 (subd. 1) cannot constitutionally be construed to extinguish any part of claimant's right to legal interest from July 11, 1953. As applied to an appropriation claim, said subdivision cannot constitutionally be read as effective until six months after a property owner has been given an opportunity to be heard by a notice of appropriation as provided in the appropriation statute. Claimant is awarded $ 3,750 for the appropriation, plus interest from July 11, 1953 to the date of entry of this judgment.

 

2644 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Firth


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


5 Misc. 2d 439; 159 N.Y.S.2d 794; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3433



February 26, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Solely on this ground the judgment of conviction appealed from is reversed; the information dismissed; and the fine, if paid, remitted.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Court of Special Sessions (New York), which convicted him of violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1).


OVERVIEW: A collision occurred between an automobile operated by defendant and a bicycle, which was being ridden by a 12-year-old girl. As a result of the collision, the youngster was seriously injured and her bicycle was damaged or destroyed. Defendant was charged with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1). The trial court found defendant guilty. On appeal, the court reversed defendant's conviction and determined that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1) was unconstitutionally vague. The court found that there was ample evidence to support a finding that defendant's speed was unreasonable and imprudent under the conditions present. The court determined that the statute made it a traffic infraction to set a vehicle in motion, even at the lowest speed possible to constitute motion, if such vehicle was thereafter involved in an accident that caused injury to another or his property. Thus, the court concluded that the statute attempted to impose liability without any fault on the part of defendant.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for driving at a speed that was unreasonable and imprudent.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- crimes -- speed which endangers or is too high to permit safe stop -- subdivision 1 of section 56 of Vehicle and Traffic Law is too vague to be enforced and hence is unconstitutional.

Subdivision 1 of section 56 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides that "No person shall operate a motor vehicle or a motor cycle upon a public highway at such a speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person, nor at a rate of speed greater than will permit such person to bring the vehicle to a stop without injury to another or his property", is too vague and indefinite to be enforced and is therefore unconstitutional. The County Court reverses a judgment of conviction and dismisses the information.

 

2645 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York, Bronx County


7 Misc. 2d 597; 165 N.Y.S.2d 286; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3446



February 25, 1957 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] On Reargument, July 12, 1957.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court by a notice of motion, defendant sought an order dismissing the information against him.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with violating N.Y. Penal Law § 1141. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information. The court denied the motion and overruled the demurrer to the information. The court initially determined that defendant had used an improper procedure to challenge the sufficiency of the information. The court found that a demurrer could not be entertained so long as a not guilty plea stood. The courts overlooked the technical defects in the procedure because the notice of motion had sought such other and further relief, the court would consider the present application as one seeking relief by way of demurrer. The court determined that the information charged defendant with possessing books, etc., which were lewd, indecent, lascivious, obscene, filthy, sadistic, masochistic, and disgusting. The court found that the information was sufficient. The court rejected defendant's argument that N.Y. Penal Law § 1141 was unconstitutionally vague because persons of common intelligence could understand what a "lewd" book, or a "filthy" book or a "disgusting" book was.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion and overruled the demurrer to the information.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- obscenity -- intelligibility and constitutionality of information in words of section 1141 of Penal Law are for trial court; demurrer overruled.

An information charging, substantially in the words of section 1141 of the Penal Law, that defendant "did have in his possession with intent to sell, lend, give away, distribute and show a quantity of lewd, indecent, lascivious, obscene, filthy, sadistic, masochistic and disgusting books, magazines, pamphlets, writings and publications," and "did show and did offer to sell, lend, give away, distribute and show such books, magazines, pamphlets, writings and publications", is not so vague as to be unintelligible and demurrable. In any event, the constitutionality and intelligibility of the statute as applied to this defendant will be a question for the trial court.

 

2646 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lewis v. Allen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


5 Misc. 2d 68; 159 N.Y.S.2d 807; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3449



February 23, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petition dismissed upon the merits, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners sought to compel respondent Commissioner of Education of the State of New York to revoke and rescind a regulation enforced in the public schools requiring the use of the phrase "under God" in the pledge of allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and directing him to reestablish the use of said pledge without that phrase.


OVERVIEW: The pledge of allegiance was amended by Congress to include the words "under God." Thereafter, the Commissioner amended the regulation to reflect the amended pledge. The parents objected to the use of the phrase "under God" and sought to compel the Commissioner to rescind the regulation. The court dismissed their petition, finding that no statutory duty required the Commissioner to rescind or revoke the regulation and, to the contrary, in amending the regulation the Commissioner was performing his duties under N.Y. Educ. Law § 802.The court also rejected the contention that the Commissioner could not perform that duty because including the words "under God" contravened the First Amendment, as the determination of constitutionality was exclusively in the domain of the judiciary. In addition, no penalties were imposed for noncompliance with the regulation. Finally, although the parents' right to disbelieve was guaranteed by the First Amendment and neither they nor their children can be compelled to recite the words "under God" in the pledge of allegiance, the First Amendment afforded them no preference over those who chose to express their belief in God in the pledge.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the parents' petition to require the Commissioner to rescind a regulation including the phrase "under God" in the pledge of allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- pledge of allegiance to flag -- petition in proceeding to compel State Commissioner of Education to revoke his regulation allegedly enforced in public schools requiring use of phrase "under God" in pledge of allegiance to flag of United States and directing him to re-establish use of pledge without said phrase, dismissed.

1. The petition in this proceeding under the Civil Practice Act (art. 78, § 1296, subd. 1) to compel respondent, State Commissioner of Education, to perform his alleged duty to revoke a certain regulation allegedly enforced in the public schools of the State "requiring the use of the phrase 'under God' in the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and directing him to reestablish the use of said pledge, without that phrase", should be dismissed on the merits.

2. No statutory duty has been shown which requires the commissioner to revoke the regulation and therefore it cannot be said that he has failed to perform a duty imposed on him by statute.

3. The Education Law ( § 802, as amd. by L. 1956, ch. 177) provides that it shall be the duty of the State Commissioner [***2] of Education to prepare, for the use of the public schools of the State, a program providing for a salute to the flag "and a pledge of allegiance to the flag". In 1954, the Congress amended section 172 of title 36 of the United States Code by inserting the words "under God" in the pledge of allegiance to the flag so that the pledge now reads as follows: "I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one Nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all." Thereafter the State Commissioner of Education amended his regulation recommending a pledge of allegiance in the words enacted by the Congress. The commissioner was performing his duties in amending his regulation in accordance with the Education Law and with an act of Congress.

4. Petitioners contend that the present pledge of allegiance to the flag of the United States violates the First Amendment to the United States Constitution (which by the 14th Amendment binds this State) and also violates the State Constitution. Petitioners, therefore, urge that the commissioner cannot perform the duties which the Legislature has directed him to perform, since the [***3] amendment of the regulation to include the words "under God" contravenes the First Amendment. To sustain such contention implies that the commissioner has not only the right but the duty to determine the constitutionality of an act of the State Legislature or of the Congress and to refuse to perform, where in his judgment such act is unconstitutional. This is not a function of administrative officials, but is in the exclusive domain of the judiciary.

5. The United States Constitution (1st Amdt.) provides that Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; and the Fourteenth Amendment makes the First amendment binding on the State of New York. The New York Constitution (art. I, § 3) provides for the free exercise and enjoyment of religious profession and worship, without discrimination or preference, and section 4 of article XI provides that the State and any subdivision thereof shall not use its money, property, or credit to maintain any school, wholly or in part, under the control or direction of any religious denomination, or in which any denominational tenet or doctrine is taught. Petitioners claim that freethinkers,  [***4] nonbelievers, atheists and agnostics cannot be compelled to recite the present pledge of allegiance because it includes "under God" and such compulsion violates the constitutional provisions. But, the regulation under attack has no compulsory aspect. The pledge is made voluntarily and no penalties are attached to a failure or refusal to recite the pledge.

6. There are two general bases for attacking a statute or regulation on the grounds that it violates the above provisions of the Constitutions. One such basis is where a person is deprived of property for unconstitutional purposes, such as a direct or indirect tax to support a religious establishment. But no tax or deprivation of property is involved whether or not the words "under God" are used in the pledge. The second basis is where a person is required to submit to some religious rite or instruction or is deprived or threatened with deprivation of his freedom for resisting that unconstitutional requirement. Petitioners' right to disbelieve is guaranteed by the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution and neither petitioners nor their children can be compelled to recite the words "under God" in the pledge. But the First [***5] Amendment affords them no preference over those who do believe in God and who, in pledging their allegiance, choose to express that belief.

 

2647 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Dauphin Deposit Trust Co. v. Commer. Travelers Mut. Accident Ass'n


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Oneida County


8 Misc. 2d 210; 165 N.Y.S.2d 566; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3463



February 20, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is, therefore, denied with $ 10 costs. Order accordingly.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- service of process on unauthorized insurer -- Pennsylvania Unauthorized Insurers Process Act, effective September 1, 1949, authorizing substituted service upon foreign insurance companies, applicable to action on policy written by New York mail order insurance company, though assured died in February, 1949; service of process under act effected September 14, 1949; as long as policy remained in force so that rights of either party thereto could be enforced after effective date of act, that circumstance was sufficient to bring policy within effect of act.

The Pennsylvania Unauthorized Insurers Process Act, effective September 1, 1949, authorizing substituted service upon foreign insurance companies, was applicable to an action brought in that State upon a policy of insurance written by a New York mail order insurance company, and a judgment rendered therein was entitled to full faith and credit in New York, though the assured died in February, 1949. Proof of loss was required to be filed within 90 days, after which a cause of action on the policy accrued in 60 days, and action on the policy [***2] was required to be instituted within two years from the expiration of the 90-day period for filing the proof of loss. Service of process under the act was effected on September 14, 1949. The statute provided, among other things, that any transaction of insurance business in respect to a particular policy was equivalent to the appointment of the Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner as attorney upon whom lawful process might be served in any action arising out of the contract of insurance. Every act in relation to the conduct of the insurance business arising out of the policy, including payment or refusal of payment of the contract and, in the event of refusal of payment, the further action taken on behalf of the assured under the provisions of the contract, constituted "transactions of insurance business" within the meaning of the act. As long as a policy of insurance remained in force so that the rights of either party thereto could be enforced after the effective date of the Unauthorized Insurers Process Act, that circumstance was sufficient to bring the policy within the effect of the act.

 

2648 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cuglar v. Power Authority of State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, St. Lawrence County


4 Misc. 2d 879; 163 N.Y.S.2d 902; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3504



February 14, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court therefore concludes there are no justiciable issues raised by the complaints in these five actions, and accordingly, defendants' motion to dismiss is, in each instance, granted, without costs.

Orders may be submitted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowners filed complaints against defendant agency responsible for the management of a major river system in which they sought, in part, to permanently enjoin the agency from entering upon the parts of the appropriated lands above a planed the flood plain and to declare said appropriations unconstitutional. The court had before it the agency's motions to dismiss on the grounds that the complaint did not state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: Defendant agency under the Power Authority Act, N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1001, was authorized to manage as a public trust two important river systems. The agency sought to build dams that would flood plaintiffs landowners' property; the landowners sought to enjoin the eminent domain proceedings not only against the land that would be flooded, but against additional land that was above the flood plain yet still desired by the agency as part of its plan. The landowners said the "taking" was ultra vires, unconstitutional, and excessive. The court granted the agency's motions to dismiss, holding that first the agency had the power, as delegated to it by the legislature, to pursue eminent domain proceedings against any land needed for the public benefit. Second, this included land ancillary to the land that would actually be flooded by the development plan, if it were necessary to carry out the agency's plan. Third, the court must defer to the plan because it was not clearly arbitrary or capricious. Fourth, the only limitation upon the agency's eminent domain power was that it be used for the public good, that compensation must be made, and that due process be observed.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant agency's motions to dismiss because no justiciable issues existed. The agency's eminent domain proceedings against plaintiffs landowners were for public use, constitutional and within its authority pursuant to the Power Authority Act.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- action to restrain taking of allegedly excess property for private uses -- State Power Authority, in building dam in New York portion of St. Lawrence River which will result in flooding lands and creating waterpower pool, may at same time take additional lands above flood line, which lands it deems necessary to guard against future fluctuations of water and against future claims and to protect powerhouse (Public Authorities Law, § 1001 et seq.) -- highland in midst of such pool will become island; authority may issue 20-year leases to dispossessed home owners who wish to relocate on such island, and may construct public utilities and parks and commercial areas there and recoup such expenses with rents (State Finance Law, § 178-c; Public Authorities Law, §§ 1005, 1007) -- action by present owners of such highland, to restrain such taking as excessive and for private uses, dismissed.

1. The act creating a Power Authority of the [***2] State of New York (Public Authorities Law, § 1001 et seq.) declares that the parts of the St. Lawrence River within the State boundaries are a natural resource of the State to be used and developed for purposes of navigation, commerce, creation of hydroelectric power, and the preservation and enhancement of scenic beauty (§ 1001), and that such projects are for the health and welfare of the people of the State ( § 1012); and the act directs the Authority to improve and develop the International Rapids Section of the river accordingly, to accept licenses from the International (Canadian-American) Joint Commission and from the Federal Power Commission upon such terms and conditions as may be tendered to the Authority and as it may deem appropriate (§ 1005, subd. 3); and empowers the Authority "to exercise all the powers necessary or convenient to * * * effectuate the purposes and provisions of this title; and as incidental thereto to own, lease, build, operate, maintain and dispose of real and personal property" (Public Authorities Law, § 1005, subd. 8), and to "find and determine" that any real property which is "necessary or convenient * * * for immediate or future use * *  [***3] * is required for a public use", to acquire such property by purchase or condemnation or appropriation (§ 1007), and to sell or exchange any such appropriated lands "in whole or in part, on terms beneficial to the state and the authority", and to give the former owners the first opportunity to make such purchases (§ 1007, subd. 10). The Authority accepted a 50-year license from the Federal Power Commission to build dams and powerhouses at the International Rapids Section, upon condition that, before flooding the reservoir or power pool thus to be created, the Authority should clear all lands which were less than 249 feet above sea level. The Authority's engineers estimate that the pool will settle at about 242 feet above sea level, and they estimate that a 246-foot elevation is the minimum needed to operate the power project. The Authority has also condemned additional lands bordering on the river and on the proposed power pool and above the 246-foot elevation, for the following publicly announced reasons: (1) in accordance with criteria laid down by the International Joint Commission to protect the river banks in case of possible future fluctuations in water levels; (2) as a [***4] precaution against possible future claims and complaints based on erosion and on the rise, fall and movement of the waters; and (3) to own and control, for the protection of the power works, all of certain islands and peninsulas which will be created by the flooding. Part of plaintiffs' lands are above the 246-foot level. Their complaints, in these suits to enjoin and restrain the appropriation of their lands as contrary to the eminent domain and due process provisions of the State and Federal Constitutions, are dismissed as insufficient in law.

2. The determination of whether lands are needed for a stated public use is a legislative function, which may validly be delegated to the discretion of an Authority, as the Legislature did in this case. The Authority's notice of appropriation to plaintiffs stated that it "deems necessary" the acquisition of these lands, "for the improvement and development of the International Rapids Section of the Saint Lawrence river." The Authority's determination cannot be set aside by the courts, in the absence of a showing of bad faith or palpable unreasonableness or that excessive property is being taken from plaintiffs or that plaintiffs' property [***5] is to be sold or devoted to private uses.

3. The license from the Federal Power Commission pursuant to the Federal Power Act (U.S. Code, tit. 16, § 791a et seq.) requires the Authority to allow the public to have reasonable access to the Authority's lands and waters for recreational purposes, but requires that title should remain in the State unless and until the whole project is recaptured by the Federal Government. The Authority has announced that it will build an access road to an island which will be created by the rising waters, that the Authority will lease sites on the island on which approximately 200 former property owners may relocate their dwellings, that the Authority will move their dwellings if feasible, and deduct the cost from the awards, that the Authority will construct the necessary roads and public utilities and lay out community parks and commercial areas on the island, and that the cost of all such facilities will be amortized on a 20-year basis and returned to the Authority in the form of rent. Some of the plaintiffs allege that their lands or parts of their lands will be part of such island, and that therefore their lands are being taken for private [***6] uses. But the relocation of former residents of appropriated lands is a public purpose (State Finance Law, § 178-c), and particularly so in this case, where their homes will be flooded. Such relocation is reasonably related to the "benefit of commerce * * * in, through, along and past * * * the international rapids section" (Public Authorities Law, § 1005, subd. 5) and is "necessary", "convenient", and "incidental" to the Authority's control of the whole project (§ 1005, subd. 8). The temporary, leased use of these sites to private individuals is reasonably and supplementally related to the essential purposes of the project and is "beneficial to the state and the authority" (§ 1007, subd. 10). Moreover, the three reasons stated by the Authority and restated in headnote paragraph 1 above are sufficient reasons for the Authority's appropriation of this island which will emerge in the midst of the power pool. Plaintiffs' complaints present no justiciable issues, and they are dismissed.

 

2649 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


La Porte v. State


Claim No. 33115


Court of Claims of New York


5 Misc. 2d 419; 159 N.Y.S.2d 596; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3510



February 13, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is denied. Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State of New York filed an application to amend the trial court's decision and to reduce the amount of interest allowed upon the award for the appropriation of claimant property owners' lands by the State.


OVERVIEW: An appropriation of the property owners' land was made for the purpose of a state thruway system. The court allowed interest to the property owners from the date title vested in the State to the entry of the judgment. The State then filed an application to reduce the amount of interest allowed, and the court denied the application. The court noted that the combined map and description that were prepared following an actual survey of the appropriated property was not served on the property owners for almost two years. The court found that the property owners lost their property almost two years before they were served with the notice, map, and description. The court ascribed to the legislature the intention to conform the Court of Claims Act to the mandate of the N.Y. Constitution and of natural law that just compensation had to be made for the property taken in invitum. The court concluded that because interest was embraced with the term "just compensation," the property owners were entitled to receive interest for the delay in payment of the value of his land. The court held that N.Y. Ct. Cl. Act § 19(1) was not applicable.


OUTCOME: The court denied the State's motion.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- interest on award -- award to property owner must include interest from date of vesting of title in State to date of entry of such judgment for "just compensation" (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 7; U. S. Const., 14th Amdt.) -- Court of Claims Act ( § 19, subd. 1) cannot constitutionally be construed to deprive property owner of interest for any part of period before he was served with notice of appropriation (Highway Law, § 347, subd. 9) -- motion by State to exclude interest from date six months after vesting until date when owner filed claim (Court of Claims Act, § 19, subd. 1), denied.

1. Under the Highway Law ( § 347, subds. 5, 5-a), when the State Department of Public Works files an appropriation map in the offices of the Secretary of State and the local County Clerk, the State immediately acquires title to the property and the right to take possession -- in this case, June 1, 1953. Subsequently, under said section (subd. 8), the Department of Public Works obtains a list of the names of the owners and files the list in the County Clerk's office -- in this case, also, on June 1, 1953. Subsequently, under said section [***2] (subd. 9), the owners are personally served with a copy of the map and property descriptions and a notice of appropriation -- in this case, on April 26, 1955. Such an owner is entitled to "just compensation" (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 7; due process clause of U.S. Const., 14th Amdt.), which must include interest, as damages for the delay in paying him, from June 1, 1953 to the date of entry of the judgment in his favor for the amount of compensation awarded him.

2. The owner in this case filed his claim in the Court of Claims on April 7, 1955. The Court of Claims Act ( § 19, subd. 1), which provides that, if a claim is not filed until more than six months have elapsed since the claim accrued, no interest shall be allowed thereon for the period between the expiration of said six-month period and the date the claim was filed, cannot constitutionally be construed as applicable to a claim for just compensation for an appropriation. A judgment is directed in favor of claimant, with interest on the amount awarded from June 1, 1953, to the date of entry of such judgment.

3. This motion by the State, to disallow interest from December 1, 1953 (six months after vesting date) to April 7,  [***3] 1955 (when owner filed claim), was made within 15 days after the Court of Claims filed its decision and before judgment was entered. Such motion is considered as a motion for a new trial, so that it may be decided on the merits (Court of Claims Act, § 9, subd. 8; Civ. Prac. Act, § 549; Rules Civ. Prac., rule 60-a). The motion is denied.

 

2650 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Public Porters Protective & Defense Asso. v. O'Connell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


8 Misc. 2d 1001; 168 N.Y.S.2d 350; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3566



February 4, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, unincorporated association of licensed public porters, sought a direction to respondent license commissioner to withdraw a regulation that prevented public porters from soliciting employment within 100 feet of any railroad station or pier where the management supplied a staff to serve the patrons of location. The association sought an order prohibiting respondent police commissioner from enforcing it.


OVERVIEW: After the license commissioner passed the regulation, it was not enforced. Later, the license commissioner gave notice that unless the porters complied with the regulation, action to forfeit their licenses was to be forthcoming. Respondents claimed that the association had not chosen the right remedy, which was an application filed pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78. The court held that the petition raised a question as to its constitutionality because it deprived the porters of the benefit of their license and under the guise of regulation prevented them from earning their livelihood in a calling that was legal. The court ruled that the license commissioner could not be ordered by mandamus to annul a statute because it was unconstitutional. The court indicated that because the police commissioner was in the position of an officer about to act under an unconstitutional statute, the action could be enjoined. The court stated that the decision as to whether the statute was unconstitutional was based on whether it was grounded in a sufficient public necessity.


OUTCOME: The court remitted the matter to the trial court to determine whether the statute was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Licenses -- public porters -- whether regulation issued pursuant to statute by New York City commissioner of licenses in relation to public porters is unconstitutional rests on facts; matter remitted to Trial Term -- mandamus improper method of raising question against said commissioner -- but as against police commissioner who is about to act under statute, writ available.

1. Whether a regulation issued by the New York City commissioner of licenses pursuant to the New York City Administrative Code (§ B32-112.0) forbidding public porters from soliciting or accepting employment within 100 feet of any railroad station or pier used by ocean or coastal vessels or bus terminals, where the management supplied a staff to serve the patrons of the station, pier or terminal, is not grounded on sufficient public necessity and thus unconstitutional, rests upon the facts. The matter should be remitted to Trial Term.

2. But respondent commissioner of licenses who has been given authority to make rules cannot by mandamus be ordered to annul a statute because it is unconstitutional. The proper method of raising the question is either by way of declaratory judgment or in resistance to prosecution.

 [***2] 3. As to respondent police commissioner, he is in the position of an officer about to act under an unconstitutional statute. Such action can be enjoined and against him a writ would have been available.

 

2651 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Flatbush Real Estate Board, Inc. v. Weaver


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


5 Misc. 2d 75; 160 N.Y.S.2d 276; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3656



January 21, 1957 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, two real estate corporations, filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding against respondent state rent administrator challenging the validity of amendment no. 48 to N.Y. Rent & Evictions Regs. § 61.


OVERVIEW: Two real estate corporations challenged the validity of Amendment No. 48 that changed N.Y. Rent & Evictions Regs. § 61. The two real estate corporations contended that the amendment was an unlawful usurpation of power by the rent commission and that the amendment was unconstitutional. The court found that the rent commission had the power to promulgate rules and regulations that are necessary or proper in order to effectuate the purposes of the statute. The court found that the amendment was designed to prevent exaction by a landlord of an illegal rent by using brokers to accomplish that purpose. The court, however, held that the rule was far broader that was necessary for the accomplishment of its purpose. The court found that the question of whether a brokerage fee constituted a rent overcharge depended upon the particular facts involved but that the amendment barred inquiry into the facts in any case where the property had previously been listed with the broker. The court concluded that anticipated difficulties afforded no valid basis for the promulgation of a rule that was unreasonably restrictive of a legitimate business.


OUTCOME: The court granted judgment in favor of the two real estate corporations and held that the challenged amendment was invalid.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- residential space -- State Rent and Eviction Regulations (§ 61) makes it unlawful for any person to demand any rent for any housing accommodation in excess of maximum rent and defines "rent" as also including payment by tenant of fee or rental commission to landlord or any person or real estate broker in specified cases "or where the landlord lists the housing accommodation with such person or real estate broker for rental purposes"; quoted phrase is unreasonable and invalid where, under State Rent Commission's own interpretation of section, payment of broker's commission by tenant where property has previously been listed with broker is presumed, conclusively, to be overcharge of rent.

1. Section 61 of the State Rent and Eviction Regulations provides that it shall be unlawful for any person to demand or receive any rent for any housing accommodations in excess of the maximum rent and the section was amended by Amendment No. 48 to provide that the term "rent" shall also include the payment by a tenant of a fee or rental commission to a landlord or to any person or real estate broker where such person or real estate broker is an agent [***2] or employee of the landlord or is employed by the landlord in connection with the operation of the building, "or where the landlord lists the housing accommodation with such person or real estate broker for rental purposes," or where such person or real estate broker manages the building in which the housing accommodation is located, or where the landlord or his employee refer the tenant to such person or real estate broker for the purpose of renting the housing accommodation. Petitioners, real estate boards, challenge the validity of the above-quoted phrase in Amendment No. 48. Under the interpretation of the amendment by the State Rent Commission, the payment of a broker's commission by a tenant where the property has previously been listed by the owner with the broker is presumed, conclusively, to be an overcharge of rent and therefore in violation of the State Residential Rent Law and the regulations. Although the commission concedes, in its interpretation, that there may be situations where a broker may be entitled to a commission from a tenant even though the apartment has been listed with him and the question whether a broker's fee constitutes a rent overcharge must depend [***3] upon the particular facts involved, the regulation, as written, bars the possibility of inquiry into the facts in particular instances and precludes any proceeding or hearing adapted to the full disclosure of those facts. It necessarily follows that petitioners and others similarly situated are prospectively deprived of the right to judicial review. The challenged portion of the amendment is unreasonable, not a proper exercise of the discretion vested in the commission by the State Residential Rent Law (§ 4, subd. 5, par. [a]; § 4, subds. 6, 7), and is invalid.

2. Anticipated administrative difficulties afford no valid basis for the promulgation of a rule such as this, which is unreasonably restrictive of a legitimate business.

 

2652 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Emray Realty Corp. v. De Stefano


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


5 Misc. 2d 352; 160 N.Y.S.2d 433; 1957 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3683



January 16, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenement owner filed a motion to require respondent municipal court clerk to turn over certain moneys to the tenement owner. The moneys had been deposited with the municipal court clerk pursuant to an order under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1446-a.


OVERVIEW: After certain of the tenement owner's tenants had failed to pay their rent, a proceeding to evict them resulted in an order under § 1446-a that required the tenants to deposit the rent with the municipal court clerk. The tenement owner then filed a motion to require the municipal court clerk to turn over the rental moneys. The tenement owner contended that the building repairs were the obligation of the tenants and that § 1446-a was unconstitutional. The court denied the tenement owner's motion. The court held (1) that the tenement owner was not entitled to the moneys due to the tenants' alleged building repair obligations, as the record was insufficient to grant relief on that basis; and (2) that § 1446-a was constitutional, as the test set forth in § 1446-a was not meaningless and the placing of violations and the correction of dangerous or unsanitary conditions was a proper exercise of the state's police power.


OUTCOME: The court denied the tenement owner's motion to require the municipal court clerk to turn over rental moneys.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- action to recover deposit of rents held by court pending removal of violation against residential property -- motion by tenement owner to recover from court clerk certain rents deposited by it pursuant to Civil Practice Act ( § 1446-a) pending removal of violations against petitioner's residential property denied -- Civil Practice Act ( § 1446-a) permitting said deposit of rents not unconstitutional.

1. Petitioner, an owner of a tenement building, seeks by an order to show cause to have the clerk of the Municipal Court of the City of New York in a certain district turn over certain moneys to it. The clerk appeared specially to challenge the service. Since the clerk has been served pursuant to an agreement of the parties, the service is now complete.

2. The tenement is maintained at a large and continuing loss to petitioner, and the building has many violations and to correct these would result in an expenditure far in excess of the valuation of the building. Petitioner's request to withdraw the building from the rental market has not been permitted. Certain tenants have failed to pay their rent, and a proceeding to evict [***2] them has resulted in an order pursuant to the Civil Practice Act ( § 1446-a) which provides that where there is a violation against residential property of a certain degree the court may order that the rents be deposited with the court and may not be withdrawn until the violation is removed. Petitioner's application should be denied.

3. It would be an injustice to withhold the rents until repairs were made or violations were removed if the obligation in regard to them was not that of the landlord, but it is not clear what the nature of the violations are or whether or not they are chargeable to the tenants.

4. Section 1446-a of the Civil Practice Act is not unconstitutional as petitioner claims. The test in the statute is that when a violation refers to a condition that, in the opinion of the court, would amount to a constructive eviction from a portion of the premises, the order requiring a deposit of the rents may be made by the court. Such test does not render the statute meaningless, for there can be a constructive eviction even though the tenant is not actually forced to leave the premises. The placing of violations and the correction of dangerous or unsanitary conditions [***3] is a proper exercise of police powers, and a measure, like section 1446-a, which is not unreasonably severe to induce compliance, seems unobjectionable.

 

2653 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


St. Regis Tribe of Mohawk Indians v. State


Claim No. 32879


Court of Claims of New York


4 Misc. 2d 110; 158 N.Y.S.2d 540; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1213



December 27, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant the State of New York filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff tribe's action that sought damages for the state's permanent appropriation of certain land, riverbed, and water rights.


OVERVIEW: The tribe filed a claim for damages against the state, alleging that its original title to the property, which the state had permanently appropriated was never extinguished. The court denied the state's motion to dismiss the tribe's claim. The court held that the claim was sufficiently pled and that there was a triable issue on title or interest presented. The court also found that N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1007(7), (10), N.Y. High. Law §30(2), and N.Y. Const. art. I, §7, which authorized the exercise of the right of eminent domain also gave the tribe authority for filing its claim for compensation. The state contended that there was an incurable defect of parties because there were other tribes in Canada that may have had an interest in the action but were not joined. The court considered N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 194, which provided the rule for necessary joinder, and held that the it was not precluded from taking jurisdiction of the claim because those parties were without the state and could not have been served or brought into the action effectually. The court also found that whether the tribe had released its claim was a question of fact that was entitled to resolution at trial.


OUTCOME: The court denied in all respects the state's motion to dismiss the tribe's action seeking damages for the state's permanent appropriation of the property for which the tribe claimed its original title was never extinguished.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Indians -- eminent domain -- Court of Claims -- action by tribe for compensation for appropriation of land and water -- St. Regis Tribe of Mohawk Indians in New York State has legal capacity to sue State of New York for compensation for appropriation of island in St. Lawrence River and adjacent bed of river and water power of river, and Court of Claims has jurisdiction of such suit.

1. The St. Regis Tribe of Mohawk Indians in New York State has legal capacity to sue the State of New York for compensation for the appropriation, by the State's power of eminent domain, of the tribe's interest in (1) land known as Barnhart's Island located in St. Lawrence River, County of St. Lawrence, State of New York, (2) the bed of St. Lawrence River surrounding said island and within the respective boundaries of 1783 and 1822, and (3) water power of the St. Lawrence River; and the Court of Claims has jurisdiction of the suit (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 7; Court of Claims Act, §§ 8, 9; Highway Law, § 30, subds. 2, 14; Public Authorities Law, § 1007, subds. 7, 10; U. S. Code, tit. 25, § 177).

2. Triable issues of fact exist as to whether the treaty of cession, made in 1796 between the State [***2] of New York and the Seven Nations of Canada represented by the St. Regis Tribe and the Caughnawaga Tribe (7 U.S. Stat. 55), included Barnhart's Island and whether the St. Regis Tribe released its interest to the State of New York by said treaty.

3. The St. Regis Tribe is divided into two tribes, each with a separate governmental existence -- one in New York and one in Canada. The New York Court of Claims has no jurisdiction over the Canadian tribe. Also, the Caughnawaga Tribe may have an interest in this property. Nevertheless, the St. Regis Tribe in New York may sue in the New York Court of Claims for compensation for its undivided interest, if any. Section 194 of the Civil Practice Act provides as follows: "Necessary joinder of parties. Of the parties to the action those who are united in interest must be joined as plaintiffs or defendants except as otherwise expressly prescribed in this act. If the consent of any one who should be joined as a plaintiff cannot be obtained he may be made a defendant, the reason therefor being stated in the complaint." This section has been interpreted by the courts as not requiring the bringing in of parties who are not within the jurisdiction.

 [***3] 4. Accordingly, motion of State of New York for dismissal of claim is denied.

 

2654 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cubiotti


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


4 Misc. 2d 44; 157 N.Y.S.2d 784; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1264



December 17, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant is acquitted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14(9) in that he operated a motor vehicle upon the highway in excess of the weight limitations.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was operating a truck equipped with pneumatic tires and tandem axles as an employee of a truck owner when he was stopped for operating the truck on the highway in excess of the weight limitations provided in N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14(9). The charge was that defendant operated the vehicle with a total weight, 1,330 pounds, in excess of the statutory limitation. The court acquitted defendant concluding that to hold defendant, an operator-employee, guilty and to invoke the mandatory sentence provided, where he had no control over the loading, or scales provided or available to check weight, and had no knowledge of excess weight would have led to an unjust result. The court held that the legislature did not intend to permit the conviction of an operator-employee of an overweight truck without proper proof of knowledge of the breach on the part of such person, or a basis upon which an inference of knowledge could have properly been drawn. The court concluded that the 1,330 extra pounds fell within the 4.6 percent variance allowed when two scales were used instead of four, which the manufacturer recommended.


OUTCOME: The court acquitted defendant of operating a motor vehicle upon the highway in excess of the weight limitations therein provided.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- weights -- employee-operator may not be convicted of operating overweight vehicle (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 14, subd. 9) in absence of proof of knowledge on his part of excessive weight or basis upon which inference of knowledge may be drawn.

1. An employee-operator of a motor truck may not be convicted upon a charge of operating a vehicle while loaded in excess of the weight limitations provided by statute (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 14, subd. 9) in the absence of adequate proof of knowledge on his part of excessive weight or a basis upon which an inference of knowledge may properly be drawn. An employee-operator charged with operating an overweight truck was acquitted.

2. The police, in weighing the truck, which was equipped with tandem axles, used scales in a manner not recommended by the manufacturer and such as to cause an unpredictable plus and minus variance in the accuracy thereof. The court could not make a finding of unlawful weight beyond a reasonable doubt upon conjecture that in the case at bar the variance was minus rather than plus.

 

2655 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Horowitz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Schoharie County


4 Misc. 2d 632; 158 N.Y.S.2d 166; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1311



December 10, 1956 



DISPOSITION: For the reasons above set forth and on constitutional grounds, the conviction appealed from is reversed and the fine remitted. Order may be entered accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1) due to the fact that his vehicle collided with another vehicle. He was directed to pay a fine. Defendant appealed his conviction.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted under the portion of N.Y, Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1) which stated no person shall operate a motor vehicle or a motor cycle upon a public highway at a rate of speed greater than will permit such person to bring the vehicle to a stop without injury to another or his property. The testimony at trial led to the conclusion that defendant's car collided with another car. There was nothing in the record to indicate the conditions under which the other car was stopped, its location on the highway, the distance from defendant's car, the direction in which defendant's car was proceeding, or any other fact relating to the collision or bearing on defendant's ability or inability to stop his car. There was no proof that the collision was due to defendant's inability to stop or to any other fault or omission on the part of defendant. The mere fact of the collision was relied upon as the basis for prosecution without regard to any culpability on the part of defendant. The court held that the conviction on that basis could not stand. The court also struck down as unconstitutional § 56(1) because it did not provide due process.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the conviction and ordered that the fine be remitted.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- motor vehicles -- limitation of speed -- Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 56, subd. 1) providing that no person shall operate motor vehicle at rate of speed greater than will permit such person to bring vehicle to stop without injury to another or his property, does not present proper basis to impose criminal liability if established by competent proof, and is unconstitutional.

 [***2] 1. Defendant was convicted of a violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 56, subd. 1) on an information which stated that defendant, while driving a car, struck and damaged a vehicle owned by another, contrary to said statute. There was no allegation as to any rate of speed at which defendant was operating the motor vehicle, nor was there any testimony given as to the actual speed at which defendant's car was being operated. The mere fact of the collision was relied on as the basis for prosecution without regard to any culpability on defendant's part. There must be some evidence of fault on defendant's part to sustain a conviction.

2. The second portion of subdivision 1 of section 56 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides that no person shall operate a motor vehicle upon a public highway "at a rate of speed greater than will permit such person to bring the vehicle to a stop without injury to another or his property" does not and cannot, by its wording, present a proper basis to impose criminal liability if established by competent proof. Due process of law is not provided by such second portion of the statute, and since subdivision 1 is, in its present form, inseparable [***3] the subdivision must be held unconstitutional. Accordingly, on constitutional grounds, the conviction of defendant should be reversed and the fine remitted.

 

2656 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Frank v. State Ins. Fund


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Cattaraugus County


4 Misc. 2d 124; 157 N.Y.S.2d 858; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1348



December 3, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent State Insurance Fund claimed a lien for all payments of compensation from petitioner administrator of a decedent's estate and claimed to be entitled to reimbursement from the widow's recovery against a third party, pursuant to N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 29.


OVERVIEW: A state employee died during the course of his duties and the widow was granted his pension. The estate was also awarded damages in a death action against a third party, and the Workmen's Compensation Board found that the widow was entitled to a weekly benefit. The Fund, pursuant to § 29, claimed a lien for all payments and compensation, which had a direct effect of reducing the amount the Board awarded the widow. The court dismissed the Fund's claim. The court held that the New York Constitution forbade diminishing or impairing a pension and that it was a mere evasion of the Constitution by the state in taking money from the widow's workmen's compensation award. The court also held that the Fund was not a proper party to the proceeding because if it enforced the lien, which it claims it was entitled to, it would be for the purpose of reducing the pension by the exact amount. The court found that § 29, in the present action, was unconstitutional and, therefore, the filing by the Fund of its claim was unconstitutional and violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the Fund's lien claims.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] State -- retirement system -- benefits not to be diminished or impaired -- pension based on accidental death of State employee granted to widow; Workmen's Compensation Board allowed widow compensation benefit and pension reduced by corresponding amount; State Insurance Fund, as State's compensation carrier, had no lien for payments of compensation upon proceeds of third-party death action.

A pension based on accidental death of a State employee while in the performance of his duties was granted to the employee's widow by the New York State Retirement System. Thereafter the Workmen's Compensation Board allowed the widow a compensation benefit and the pension of the widow was reduced by an amount equal to the compensation benefit. A death action brought against a third party resulted in the recovery of a sum in the hands of the deceased employee's administrator. The State Insurance Fund, as the State's workmen's compensation carrier, had no lien for payments of compensation out of the proceeds of the third-party death action and was not a proper party to the administrator's proceeding for apportionment of the proceeds of that action (Workmen's Compensation Law, § 29). A [***2] contrary holding would result in a violation of section 7 of article V of the State Constitution, which provides that membership in any pension or retirement system of the State shall be a contractual relationship, the benefits of which shall not be diminished or impaired.

 

2657 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grundman v. Brighton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Monroe County


5 Misc. 2d 1006; 166 N.Y.S.2d 55; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1412



November 17, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motions of plaintiff and the cross motion of the Authority to strike the "First", "Second", and "Third" defenses raised by the original defendants are granted, without costs.

Let an order enter accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff licensee and defendant New York State Liquor Authority moved to strike certain defenses raised by defendant town in an action to have the town's zoning ordinance declared invalid and in conflict with the N.Y. Alcoholic Beverage Control Law.


OVERVIEW: The licensee, having been granted a state liquor license, brought an action against the town to enjoin the enforcement of a zoning ordinance. The ordinance prohibited the location of places selling alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption within one-half mile of a school and within 1,000 feet of any public playground, hospital, church, synagogue, or children's home. The licensee's business was within one-half mile of a public school. In response to the motions, the court struck the town's first three defenses, finding that (1) no grounds for review under N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 121 were presented, (2) the town's ordinance did not, through its mere existence, give the town the right to be heard before the Authority on a license application, the granting of which would conflict with the ordinance, and (3) the state had occupied the field of liquor licensing, stating in N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 2 that localities had no right to increase requirements on the locations of taverns.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to strike the first three defenses raised by the town.


HEADNOTES

Intoxicating liquors -- local laws -- town zoning ordinance more restrictive than Alcoholic Beverage Control Law concerning location of licensed premises, invalid -- action of licensing board may not be collaterally attacked (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, §§ 2, 121, 124).

1. An Alcoholic Beverage Control Board granted to plaintiff a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, although the town's zoning ordinance proscribed any place selling alcoholic beverages within a half-mile from a school. The board acted without notice to local officials or property owners and without affording them a hearing. Plaintiff sues to enjoin such officials from enforcing the local ordinance against his premises. The State Liquor Authority has been permitted to intervene (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, § 124), and supports plaintiff's position. The town contends that its ordinance is necessary for public health and safety. However,  [***2] the State has occupied this field of regulation, to the necessary exclusion of local interference in the matter (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, § 2). The town's ordinance is invalid.

2. Defendant town, by challenging the action of the local alcoholic beverage control board as arbitrary, seeks to review its determination. However, section 121 of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law enumerates the only cases in which the board's action may be reviewed by a court, and this is not one of them. The section is constitutional. Since an applicant may not ask judicial review, a third party should have no greater rights.

 

2658 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lloyd Harbor v. Huntington


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Suffolk County


3 Misc. 2d 849; 157 N.Y.S.2d 442; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1444



November 8, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, Villages of Lloyd Harbor and Huntington Bay and a private citizen, sought a judgment declaring 1955 N.Y. Laws ch. 840 invalid as violative of the U.S. Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. III, § 17, and enjoining defendant Town of Huntington from establishing, maintaining, or operating a public beach within the corporate limits of either village. The citizen sought to set aside an acquisition of land by the Town for a beach.


OVERVIEW: The Villages and a private citizen sought a declaration that 1955 N.Y. Laws ch. 840 violated the U.S. Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. III, § 17. The court found that the legislation was designed specifically to take from the villages within the town of Huntington certain powers granted them by their charters, as embodied in the Village Law, and that it singled them out from all the villages in the State of New York for that special treatment and destroyed the uniformity which the Constitution guaranteed. The court declared the statute unconstitutional. The court held that the Town Law controlled the Town's attempt to establish the bathing beaches. The court found that the private citizen did not establish that the use of the land by the Town would produce great and irreparable injury and would depreciate the market value of the citizen's home and property.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the state statute that permitted the Town to acquire property to operate a public beach within the Villages was unconstitutional and void. The court enjoined the Town from establishing, maintaining, or operating public beaches within the corporate limits of the Villages. The court denied the citizen's complaint for injunctive relief requiring the sale of property purchased by the Town.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional law -- private or local laws -- chapter 840 of Laws of 1955, purporting to authorize Town of Huntington, notwithstanding "any other general, special or local law * * *" to establish public bathing beaches at any place within territorial boundaries of town, violated provision of New York Constitution (art. III, § 17) forbidding private or local bills incorporating villages.

1. Chapter 840 of the Laws of 1955 purported to authorize the Town of Huntington, notwithstanding "any other general, special or local law * * *", to establish, maintain and operate public bathing beaches, parking fields and playgrounds, on lands owned or leased at any place within the territorial boundaries of the town. Villages within the territorial limits of the town sought a judgment declaring that statute unconstitutional and enjoining the town from establishing, maintaining or operating a public beach within the corporate limits of the villages. Individual plaintiffs, owners of private property within one such village, sought the same relief and asked, in addition, that the acquisition by defendant town of certain lands for beach purposes be declared illegal and void.

2. Only as [***2] a last resort will the courts strike down a legislative act on the ground that it conflicts with the State or Federal Constitution. Every presumption in favor of its validity must be made, but if it appears to be a clear usurpation of a prohibited power, then it may be declared unconstitutional.

3. Chapter 840 of the Laws of 1955 offends section 17 of article III of the New York Constitution, which forbids private or local bills incorporating villages. The constitutional provision was designed to provide and to maintain a uniform charter for all villages. Chapter 840 of the Laws of 1955 was intended specifically to take from the villages within the town of Huntington certain powers granted them by their charters, as embodied in the Village Law. It singled them out from all the villages in the State of New York for that special treatment and destroyed the uniformity which the Constitution guarantees.

4. Defendant town was not authorized to establish public parks or recreational areas by sections 81 and 220 of the Town Law, authorizing towns to establish public parking places, parks and playgrounds and to acquire the necessary lands therefor, apart from chapter 840 of the Laws [***3] of 1955 and against the will of an incorporated village within which such parks or areas were to be located. In seeking the legislative intent, all parts of the Town Law must be read together and, if possible, harmonized with each other as well as with the general intent of the whole enactment. Section 198 of the Town Law, which reads, in part: "4. Park districts. * * * No property situated within an incorporated village * * * shall be acquired in any manner for park purposes, unless the permission and consent of the board of trustees of such village * * * is first obtained", applies to parks, and prevents a town from imposing upon a village, against its wishes, any public park use.

5. The text of a statute must take precedence over its title. While a title or heading may help clarify or point the meaning of an imprecise or dubious provision, it may not alter or limit the effect of unambiguous language in the body of the statute itself; the character of a statute is to be determined by its provisions, and not by its title.

6. Unless defendant town requested permission of plaintiff villages to acquire properties for park purposes ( Town Law, § 198) and was refused, defendant town [***4] could not attack plaintiffs' zoning ordinances. Until that time, the court was required to assume that, in a proper case, permission would be granted.

7. Accordingly, plaintiff villages were entitled to judgment declaring chapter 840 of the Laws of 1955 to be invalid as violative of section 17 of article III of the Constitution of the State of New York, declaring that the acquisition of lands within plaintiff villages by defendant town was illegal under subdivision 4 of section 198 of the Town Law, and enjoining defendant town from establishing, maintaining or operating public beaches within the corporate limits of plaintiff villages. The same relief was granted to the individual plaintiff property owners upon their complaint, but so much thereof as sought a direction to defendant to sell the property already acquired was denied, since subdivision 4 of section 198 of the Town Law contains a further provision "that such permission and consent, if obtained subsequent to the acquisition of any such property, shall be effective for all purposes and to the same extent as though obtained prior to such acquisition." Defendant town was entitled to a reasonable opportunity to apply for such [***5] consent to acquire property within the villages for park purposes, and, if it was denied, to test the reasonableness of such refusal.

8. The court could not find, on the proof adduced, that the proposed use of land in one of plaintiff villages by defendant town should be enjoined because it would result in great and irreparable injury to individual plaintiffs and would substantially depreciate the market value of their homes and properties. The adverse effect upon property values or decreased enjoyment of neighborhood properties by reason of noise and inconvenience occasioned by the establishment, under proper conditions and safeguards, of a public park, beach or recreational area, was insufficient ground to bar such a use.

 

2659 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


P. & A. Carting Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


7 Misc. 2d 815; 158 N.Y.S.2d 296; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1453



November 2, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is accordingly granted and the complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff private cartmen filed suit against defendants, a city and its license commissioner, to declare invalid and enjoin the enforcement of implementing regulations promulgated by the commissioner relating to commercial refuse removal. They charged that the commissioner exceeded his authority in promulgating the regulation and that it was an oppressive and illegal requirement. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The cartmen were required by regulation to enter into written contracts with their refuse customers, to deliver a signed copy thereof to each customer, and to file with the department of licenses a separate memorandum containing the terms of each contract, signed by the licensee and the customer, on forms supplied by the department. The court held that the challenged regulation was a measure reasonably designed for the protection of the numerous customers and that it did not restrain freedom of contract except that it required whatever contract was agreed to by the parties be set forth in a signed writing. Judged in the light of this basic principle of "public interest" as defining the permissible limits of administrative regulatory power, the regulation neither offended due process nor violated the rule against improper assumption of legislative power. It was entirely proper for the city to provide a general guide for the control of the cartmen who were to be licensed to perform on its behalf a governmental service and to authorize the commissioner of licenses to make the detailed regulations to carry out its provisions. The regulation was neither arbitrary nor unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motion dismissed the cartmen's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- delegation of legislative power -- implementing regulation promulgated by license commissioner of City of New York pursuant to provision of local law dealing with problem of commercial refuse removal (Local Laws, 1956, No. 29) not invalid as unreasonable exercise of power delegated to commissioner; regulation did not offend due process.

1. An implementing regulation promulgated by the license commissioner of the City of New York, pursuant to the provisions of a local law dealing with the problem of commercial refuse removal (Local Laws, 1956, No. 29), which required that cartmen licensed to remove commercial refuse enter into written contracts with their customers, leave a signed copy with the customer, and file with the Department of Licenses a separate memorandum containing the terms of each contract signed by the cartman and the customer, was not invalid as an unreasonable exercise of the power delegated to the commissioner to fix and refix maximum rates, to "promulgate such rules and regulations as may be necessary to control the conduct of licensees" and to "require licensees [***2] * * * to keep such records as he may determine are necessary or useful for carrying out the purposes of this article"; nor did the implementing regulation offend due process.

2. The propriety of an enforcement measure can best be judged with relation to the nature of the evil it is intended to eliminate.

3. A municipality may perform the function of garbage and waste removal directly through its own department, or it may have that function performed under a public contract, or it may require a license to be obtained by persons or firms authorized and qualified to perform that function, but the municipality has the duty to exercise such supervision and control as will prevent danger to public health and injury to the public interest.

4. Freedom of contract is subject to regulation which is reasonable in relation to its subject and is adopted in the interests of the community, where the business concerned is affected with a public interest, and certainly where the business affected with a public interest is one in the public domain itself. The gathering of garbage is not a trade, business or occupation, but it is a public duty.

 

2660 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


International Longshoremen's Asso., Independent v. Hogan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


3 Misc. 2d 893; 156 N.Y.S.2d 512; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1501; 31 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P70,276



October 16, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the cross motion of the defendant Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor for judgment on the pleadings dismissing the complaint insofar as it seeks an injunction on the ground that it fails to state a cause of action and for a declaratory judgment in its favor is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, an international longshoremen's association, its international agent, and its president, filed an action for a declaratory judgment that § 8 of the Waterfront Commission Act (Act) was unconstitutional and sought temporary and permanent injunctions prohibiting its enforcement. Defendant, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, filed a motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim or for judgment on the pleadings.


OVERVIEW: The Commission filed a complaint with defendant, the New York County District Attorney, who notified the association that pursuant to § 8 of the Act, it could not collect dues from registered longshoremen so long as it employed the agent, who had been convicted in federal court of a felony, income tax evasion. Plaintiffs alleged that § 8 of the Act conflicted with § 7 of the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA), that the association was exempt from the Act's provisions because it was a federation or congress of labor organizations organized on a national or international basis, and that the Act's provisions did not contemplate including income tax evasion as a felony. Granting the Commission's motion, the court held that (1) § 8 of the Act did not violate the Constitution or conflict with § 7 of the NLRA, as it was a reasonable exercise of the State's police powers, intended to remedy the long history of crime on the waterfront; (2) the association was not included within the exception to § 8 of the Act for a federation or congress of labor organizations; and (3) the Act clearly intended to disqualify an agent who had been convicted of any felony by a court of the United States.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Commission's motion for judgment on the pleadings dismissing the complaint insofar as it sought an injunction on the ground that it failed to state a cause of action and granted a declaratory judgment in the Commission's favor.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- New York Harbor Waterfront Commission Act -- constitutional law -- section 8 of Waterfront Commission Act (L. 1953, ch. 882, part III) validly forbids any labor organization any officer of which is convicted of Federal or State felony to collect dues from registered longshoremen; section is within police power and does not unconstitutionally conflict with right of employees under National Labor Relations Act to choose their own collective bargaining representatives.

1. Section 8 of the act establishing a Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor (L. 1953, ch. 882, part III) forbids the collection of dues from registered longshoremen on behalf of a labor organization any officer of which "has been convicted by a court of the United States, or any state or territory thereof, of a felony". This provision is a reasonable exercise of the State's police power and does not unconstitutionally [***2] conflict with the provision of section 7 of the National Labor Relations Act (U. S. Code, tit. 29, § 157) authorizing employees to select representatives of their own choosing for collective bargaining.

2. Section 8 of said Waterfront Commission Act excepts "a federation or congress of labor organizations organized on a national or international basis". This means an organization such as the American Federation of Labor or the Congress of Industrial Organizations. It does not mean the independent International Longshoremen's Association, even though it is an international union comprised of local unions.

3. An international representative or agent of said International Longshoremen's Association was convicted by a United States court of the Federal felony of evading Federal income taxes. This is a felony under the United States Criminal Code; and, under the wording of section 8 of our Waterfront Commission Act, it is immaterial whether or not such a crime would be only a misdemeanor under our Penal Law.

4. Accordingly, defendant Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor is granted judgment on the pleadings dismissing the complaint of said International Longshoremen's Association [***3] and of said agent, insofar as said complaint seeks to restrain enforcement of section 8 of the Waterfront Commission Act; and the commission is also granted a declaratory judgment in its favor.

 

2661 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of 181 East 73rd Street Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


6 Misc. 2d 688; 157 N.Y.S.2d 67; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1527



October 4, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding pursuant to N.Y.
