C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner landlords sought to set aside the orders of respondent State Rent Administrator (New York), which denied their protests against amendments to N.Y. Rent & Eviction Regs. §§ 54(2) and 58(a). The landlords also sought to declare Amendments No. 49 and 52 to the New York Rent and Eviction Regulations unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The landlords had recently purchased apartment houses for the express purpose of demolishing them and erecting new apartment houses. The rent commission found that the increase in the demolition of old housing in order to create new housing placed substantial burdens on the evicted tenants. The Administrator concurred with the findings and the New York Rent and Eviction Regulations were amended to provide for a fixed cash stipend to help displaced tenants and to change the three-month stay to a maximum of six months. The landlords challenged the amendments. The court dismissed the petitions, holding that the rent commission had authority to amend its regulations. Moreover, a fixed stipend to help displaced tenants meet the exigencies confronting them was not unreasonable. The court concluded that the landlords failed to show a basis for declaring the rent regulations, as amended, to be outside the scope of the state's police power.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the landlords' petitions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- regulations of State Rent Commission requiring payment of fixed stipend to tenant prior to eviction to permit demolition of building and providing for six-month stay are reasonable and proper (State Rent and Eviction Regulations, § 58, as amd. by Amdt. No. 49; § 54, as amd. by Amdt. No. 52) -- commission has power to amend its regulations.

1. Petitioners are among landlords who purchase old apartment houses for the purpose of demolition in order to build larger ones. They challenge the propriety of regulations providing for payment of a fixed stipend to a tenant prior to eviction (State Rent and Eviction Regulations, § 58, as amd. by Amdt. No. 49) and granting a six-month stay (§ 54, as amd. by Amdt. No. 52). These regulations are in accord with the purpose of the Residential Rent Law and constitute a reasonable exercise of the police power. The petition is dismissed.

2. The State Rent Commission has the power to amend its regulations.

3. The contention that the amendments are invalid because designed primarily to remedy a condition peculiar to the Yorkville section is without merit.

 

2662 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of New York County Lawyers Asso.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


4 Misc. 2d 728; 156 N.Y.S.2d 651; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1542



October 1, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the New York County Lawyers Association, filed a proceeding pursuant N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 90(2), 750(B) wherein it sought to have respondent legal consultant adjudged in criminal contempt and to enjoin him from specified acts claimed to constitute the illegal practice of law.


OVERVIEW: The adviser prepared legal documents for filing in Mexico under Mexican law. The major issue was whether the practice of "law," prohibited by N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 90(2), 750(B) merely encompassed the giving of advice on matters of New York law, the appearance in New York courts, and the preparation of documents for filing in New York, or whether it also included the giving to laymen of advice on foreign law and the preparation for them of documents to be filed outside of New York. The court held the consultant in contempt and enjoined his action. Practicing "law" was reasonably interpreted to include the giving of advice as to all jural relationships and proceedings, regardless of the jurisdiction initially giving rise to such relationships and proceedings. "Practicing law" covered any legal counsel given concerning foreign law.


OUTCOME: The court adjudged the consultant to be in criminal contempt. He was permanently enjoined from committing, within the State of New York, any of the acts described in the prayer for relief in the petition. No fine was imposed.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attorney and client -- Mexican lawyer -- Mexican lawyer who is not New York lawyer and who advertises to public and has office in New York where he advises laymen on Mexican law and who institutes divorce actions in Mexico, is illegally practicing law here and is adjudged in criminal contempt and is permanently enjoined ( Penal Law, § 270; Judiciary Law, § 90, subd. 2; § 750, subd. B).

1. A Mexican lawyer, who is not a member of the New York Bar, and who maintains an office in New York where he advises New York residents on Mexican law and undertakes for a fee to institute divorce actions in Mexico, is practicing law within the prohibition of section 270 of the Penal Law. Since the facts are not disputed, this proceeding was properly instituted by a bar association to have him adjudged in criminal contempt and to enjoin him permanently from committing within New York State any of the acts described in the prayer of this petition for relief ( Judiciary Law, § 90, subd. 2; § 750, subd. B). The petition is granted. However, no fine will be imposed in this case.

2. It is not sought to enjoin respondent from giving advice to New York lawyers on Mexican law, so it is not necessary [***2] to decide whether such advice would constitute the practice of law. But, undoubtedly, such advice to laymen is practicing law. Practitioners of law in New York State must have the requisite knowledge and character and be admitted to the Bar here and must conform to our discipline, including our Canon of Ethics against advertising. Respondent is not an American citizen. He advertises to the public. Due process of law is not violated by requiring him to meet the same standards as New York lawyers.

 

2663 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Calder v. Teachers' Retirement Board


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


4 Misc. 2d 166; 156 N.Y.S.2d 494; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1557



September 25, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is accordingly denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school teacher filed a complaint against defendant teachers' retirement board, seeking a declaratory judgment that she was entitled to have a prior service certificate, certifying to 14 years, 10 months, and 21 days of prior outside teaching service. The board moved for judgment on the pleadings and admissions, pursuant to N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112 and N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 476, dismissing the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The dispute concerned the board's requirement that the teacher pay into the reserve fund a certain sum, based upon the current cost at her then salary level, that being the time of her demand for a certificate, and her contention that she needed to pay only the amount to purchase that credit under her entrance salary schedule of 1941, based on her claim that the board should have issued a correct certification when she entered city service. The board argued that the action was barred by the statute of limitations. The court held that whether the teacher's action was barred depended on whether the four month limitation of N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1286 ran from the time that the board denied the teacher's request or from the issuance of the certificate certifying to zero years, months, and days of prior service. The court held that the action was timely commenced because it was brought within four months of the board's denial and to compel the board to verify her statement. However, the court held that if at trial the board proved that there was actually some evaluation of the statement when it was issued, rather than just a perfunctory verification, the action was barred.


OUTCOME: The court denied the board's motion.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- New York City Teachers' Retirement Board -- four-month limitation on action for declaratory judgment -- New York City schoolteacher alleged that, when she was appointed in 1941 and filed statement of her prior outside teaching service, Teachers' Retirement Board failed to perform its ministerial and continuing duty of verifying her statement (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B20-4.0) and wrongly certified to her that she had no such prior service, that she asked board in 1953 to verify it and board then certified that she had 14 years of such prior service but demanded that she pay into retirement reserve, not $ 1,500 as would have been required in 1941, but $ 6,570.31 as current cost of such retirement credit; in 1955 she demanded that board perform its continuing duty of verifying her original statement as of 1941; motion on pleadings to dismiss her action for declaratory judgment as barred by four-month Statute of Limitations and by laches, denied; defenses must be tried.

1. The Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ B20-4.0) provides that each schoolteacher shall file with the Teachers' Retirement Board [***2] a detailed statement of all prior teaching service, this being done according to the rules of the board at time of entrance into city service. The statute then requires that "As soon as practicable thereafter, such board shall verify such statement as to prior-service and shall issue to each teacher a certificate certifying to the aggregate length of his prior-service". The actual determination of the length of prior-service is to be based on an evaluation of prior outside teaching experience thus verified and "shall be the amount of time determined by the actuary to be equivalent to the time which would have been rendered in city-service, had the reserves received on behalf of such new-entrant been paid into the retirement system under the salary schedule in which such new-entrant begins service". The statute does not compel an automatic grant of certificate for prior teaching experience but calls for fact-finding and the exercise of discretion in determining whether such schools and the teacher's service therein qualify and in computing the equivalency of such experience in terms of city service. Plaintiff schoolteacher alleges that she duly filed with defendant board in 1941,  [***3] at the time of her appointment as a city schoolteacher, a detailed statement of all prior service rendered by her in other schools; that the board did not verify such statement, but simply issued to her a "Work Sheet" stating "Outside service not allowable for retirement purposes" and a "Certificate" wrongly stating "That the Retirement Board has verified such statement of prior service and hereby certifies to said contributor that she is entitled to an aggregate credit of '0' years, '0' months and '0' days as a Prior Service Allowance"; that on July 24, 1953 the board did on plaintiff's application verify plaintiff's statement and issued to her a letter certifying the aggregate length of her prior service to be 14 years, 10 months and 21 days; that plaintiff offered then to pay for such credit into the reserve the amount due under the salary schedule when she began service in 1941, approximately $ 1,500, but that the board requested payment at the current cost thereof, $ 6,570.31, in accordance with a resolution adopted December 17, 1952 permitting modification of prior service certificates under certain conditions, including payment at current cost thereof. Plaintiff, by failure [***4] to deny a notice to admit, admits that in 1941 she signed forms of the board which stated that she had "carefully reviewed the verification of service claimed on my detailed statement of prior service and have also examined the work sheet showing the evaluation of all prior service claims" and "I therefore ask that a prior service certificate be issued granting 0 years 0 months and 0 days credit." In this action, plaintiff asks for a judgment declaring that the resolution of 1952 is void and inapplicable to her case and that she is entitled to a prior service certificate upon payment on the basis of her entrance salary in 1941, plus interest. On the pleadings and admissions, it must be deemed that this action seeks to compel the board to perform its ministerial and continuing duty of verifying her statement filed in 1941 and treating it for all purposes under the law as of the date when originally filed, and that she timely commenced this action in 1955 within four months after the board refused in 1955 to comply with her demand for such relief (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1286).

2. Although this action is for a declaratory judgment, its gravamen is such that it is subject to the four-month [***5] limitation in section 1286 of article 78 of the Civil Practice Act.

3. It does not appear from the pleadings and admissions that plaintiff was guilty of laches, to the disadvantage of the board's fund, so as to warrant a dismissal of her action even though commenced within the statutory period.

4. Accordingly, motion to dismiss the complaint on the pleadings and admissions is denied. At the trial, defendant may be able to prove facts which will establish its defense of laches or its defense of the four-month Statute of Limitations. If it should appear that the work sheet was the result of some evaluation of her statement, then her claim should be deemed barred by said four-month statute.

 

2664 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bianchi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Second District, Nassau County


3 Misc. 2d 696; 155 N.Y.S.2d 703; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1598



August 29, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion of the defendant to dismiss the informations is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss two informations, which charged that he violated Town of Hempstead, N.Y., Ordinances art. 1, §§ 9, 10, which prohibited a boat operator from throwing up a dangerous wake and from operating a boat at a greater speed than 12 miles per hour in channels. He argued the ordinances were unconstitutional on the grounds that a channel was a navigable waterway under the exclusive jurisdiction of the federal government.


OVERVIEW: The alleged violations occurred on a channel that was within the territorial limits of the town. The channel was also a navigable waterway such as the U.S. Government might have regulated pursuant to the Commerce Clause. Defendant argued that the act of navigation was "commerce" and that the regulation of boats on navigable waters was a field preempted by the U.S. Government. The court ruled that although the U.S. Government had jurisdiction over interstate commerce, the town, as a derivative creature of the State, was not prohibited from exercising its police power to regulate a local incident of commerce so long as the regulation was within the scope of the town's powers and did not unreasonably burden interstate commerce. The court determined that the regulation of the speed of boats was within the town's police powers. The court further ruled that although the U.S. Government had enacted laws prohibiting the reckless operation of boats in certain areas, the U.S. Congress had not intended such legislation to occupy the field relating to boat speed. The court concluded that despite the U.S. Government's interest in the field of navigation, local laws were not preempted.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the informations.


HEADNOTES

Navigable waters -- local regulation -- provisions of town ordinance regulating speed and operation of boats upon town waters, which embraced navigable tidewater, constitutional.

1. Provisions of a town ordinance regulating the speed and operation of boats upon town waters, which embraced navigable tidewater, were not unconstitutional by reason of encroachment upon the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Government, and informations charging violations of such provisions in a navigable tidewater channel within the territorial limits of the town would not be dismissed. The provisions of the ordinance were within the authority conferred by section 130 (subd. 17) of the Town Law and the State had the power to enact such legislation and could delegate that power.

2. The Federal Government does not possess exclusive dominion over those activities described as interstate commerce, and the State or its municipal derivative may regulate the local aspects of that commerce, subject only to the criteria that the local police power shall not exceed its proper limits and that commerce must not be unreasonably [***2] burdened thereby (U. S. Const., art. I, § 8, subd. 3). The police power includes the right to regulate the speed of vehicular transport, whether nautical or terrestrial in nature, it being only required that the vehicle in question be within the territorial limits of the political unit in question.

3. The town ordinance did not unreasonably impose upon navigation but, on the contrary, contributed to its more effective operation by eliminating hazardous and obstructive practices.

4. The Navigation Law of New York, in providing that the Superintendent of Public Works shall have jurisdiction over navigation on the navigable waters of the State, and defining "navigable waters of the State" as meaning all inland lakes and streams wholly included within the State and not privately owned which are navigable in fact and are not connected by navigable channels with tidewater, does not purport to limit the general sovereign power of the State but merely to define the scope of a particular law and the functional orbit of the Superintendent of Public Works (Navigation Law, § 2, subd. 4; § 30). The Navigation Law does not reflect a recognition and acquiescence by the State Legislature in [***3] the Federal Government's control over navigable channels connected with tidewater.

5. The court would take judicial notice that Reynolds Channel, Long Beach, was not a Federal mooring area.

6. The Congress of the United States, by the enactment of the Motor Boat Act of 1940 (U. S. Code, tit. 46, § 526 et seq.), prohibiting reckless or negligent operation of vessels, did not pre-empt that field, rendering the town ordinance unconstitutional.

7. Where the Congress of the United States partially regulates an area, the State may legislate on those phases neglected by the United States.

8. The United States Government and the governments of the several States may each enact laws for the protection of its citizens and State laws will be upheld unless the conflict be so clear and direct that the one is repugnant to the other. In those cases wherein it has been found that Congress had intended to pre-empt the field, Congress had enacted broad-gauged, finely-wrought, unified regulatory systems to achieve comprehensive central control, and central control would be embarrassed by State legislation to such extent that it must have been the intent of Congress to pre-empt the field. While [***4] the Federal Government has an interest in the field of navigation, that interest is not so dominant, and the problems involved are not so completely national in character, as to make any or all local regulation unthinkable where the Federal Government has acted. The Federal regulatory scheme established in the Motor Boat Act of 1940 is not so complete as to make reasonable the inference that Congress left no room for the States to supplement it.

9. A law duly enacted will be presumed to be constitutional.

 

2665 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rand v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


3 Misc. 2d 769; 155 N.Y.S.2d 753; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1622



August 16, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is granted. Defendants' cross motion is denied.

Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner filed a declaratory judgment against defendants, city and associated individuals, seeking to have N.Y. Gen. City Law § 35 declared unconstitutional in its application to her property as a taking without just compensation. The owner and defendants filed cross-motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: When the city adopted a map laying out a proposed street, more than 80 percent of the owner's vacant property lay in the bed of the proposed street. Thus, the owner was denied a building permit for the erection of a non-storage garage on the ground that was forbidden by § 35 in that it lay in the bed of a mapped street. The Board of Standards and Appeals granted a variance on condition that, in the event of condemnation, the cost was to be amortized over a term of 10 years at the rate of 10 percent per year, starting from the completion of the building. The owner filed a declaratory judgment action, alleging that § 35, as it applied to her property, was an unconstitutional taking without just compensation. The court awarded summary judgment to the owner. The property owner was to receive no compensation for the building if condemnation took place more than 10 years from the completion of the building, even though it might have had a useful life of 40 years. If the condemnation were to take place sooner, the owner's compensation was to be reduced by 10 percent for each year that elapsed, although proper depreciation would have been closer two percent.


OUTCOME: The court granted the owner's motion for summary judgment and denied defendants' motion for summary judgment in the owner's declaratory judgment action concerning the taking of her property without just compensation.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- building in mapped street -- Board of Standards and Appeals, in granting permission to person who acquired lot within officially mapped street to erect one-story garage thereon, imposed confiscatory condition that, in case of condemnation, cost of building should be amortized at 10% a year and no award at all made after 10 years, even though building would be useful for 50 years; owner not limited to certiorari but may sue for declaratory judgment; owner granted summary judgment (General City Law, § 35).

1. A person who acquired title to a lot, most of which lay within the bed of a proposed street on the official city map, was granted permission by the City's Board of Standards and Appeals to erect a building thereon, on conditions (General City Law, § 35). The proposed building was a one-story brick and steel garage which normally would have a useful life of 50 years. The board unreasonably and confiscatorily imposed a condition that, in case of condemnation, the cost of the building should be amortized over a term of 10 years at the rate [***2] of 10% a year from the completion of the building. Under this condition, plaintiff would receive no compensation for the building if condemnation took place after 10 years, though the building would be useful for 40 years more. Moreover, 2% a year depreciation during the 10 years would be the more proper rate. The condition amounts to a taking of property without just compensation.

2. Section 35 of the General City Law provides for review by certiorari; nevertheless the owner is entitled to maintain this action for a judgment declaring that the statute has been unconstitutionally applied to her property. She is granted summary judgment.

 

2666 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Syracuse v. Wright


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Onondaga County


4 Misc. 2d 714; 160 N.Y.S.2d 342; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1655



August 4, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a city, filed a motion under N.Y. City Home Rule Law § 16 for review of its objections to a referendum petition filed by defendant citizens pursuant to N.Y. City Home Rule Law § 19-a for a proposed local law to amend provisions of the city charter for the provision of minimum salary schedules for designated members of the city's police and fire departments, prohibition of any reduction of the salaries, and revision of the city budget.


OVERVIEW: The city's council authorized the city's corporation counsel to file the proceeding for the consideration of its objections to the proposed local law. The city contended that the plan that provided for moneys and revenues to meet the expenditures and increases required by the proposed law were insufficient, inadequate, invalid, and illegal. The city further contended that the proposal could not be submitted to the voters on the date designated because a referendum of a municipal question could not be submitted in an even-numbered year. The court held that: (1) there was no constitutional prohibition to the submission of the proposition to the city's voters at the next general election; (2) it appeared that the city would have had funds in the next year available for general city purposes in excess of the funds that were available in that current year; and (3) the proposed plan that provided moneys and revenues sufficient to meet proposed expenditures by an increase of the general tax levy on property was sufficient because there were sufficient revenues that were available from all sources that provided for all contemplated increases in expenditures for the next year.


OUTCOME: The court denied the city's application for an order that restrained the city clerk from transmittal of the referendum of the proposed law to a board of elections.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- local law referendum -- referendum on proposed local law of city, to provide minimum salary schedules for police and fire department employees, may be submitted to voters of city in even or odd-numbered year (City Home Rule Law, § 19-a) -- on testimony from both sides, court finds that city will have enough revenues in ensuing year, including increase in real estate taxes, to meet increased expenditures -- "plan to provide moneys" (City Home Rule Law, § 19-a) need not and should not specify tax rates; sufficient if plan states that real estate taxes should be increased -- motion by city to restrain transmission of referendum to Board of Elections (City Home Rule Law, § 16), denied.

1. Pursuant to the City Home Rule Law (§ 19-a), a number of voters of the City of Syracuse filed with the city clerk a petition for a referendum as to whether a proposed local law should be enacted amending sections 11, 71, and 92 of the Syracuse City Charter (Local Laws, 1935, No. 7 of City of Syracuse) so as to provide, among other things, minimum salary schedules for certain designated members of the police and fire departments, to prohibit the Common Council from [***2] reducing such salaries, and requiring revision of the 1957 budget and appropriation of additional funds therefor. On the city's objections to the petition (City Home Rule Law, § 16), the court rules as follows.

2. "If a referendum is required, the legislative body may submit it to the electors of the city at the next general election" (City Home Rule Law, § 19-a), which in this case is November 6, 1956. Concededly, the subject of this proposed local law is such that, under the statute, a referendum is mandatory. But this is not a proposal for "elections of city officers", which elections can be held "in an odd-numbered year" only (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 15; see, also, Second Class Cities Law, § 14). There is no prohibition in the State Constitution against submitting this referendum at a general election in an even-numbered year.

3. The City Home Rule Law (§ 19-a) provides that "No such proposed local law requiring the expenditure of money shall be accepted by the city clerk or be adopted or become effective unless there shall be submitted as a part of such proposed local law, a plan to provide moneys and revenues sufficient to meet such proposed expenditures." The proposed [***3] plan is that the general tax levy on real property in the city should be increased. After taking testimony from the proponents and opponents of the plan, the court finds that sufficient revenues are available to the city from all sources, including a general tax levy within the 2% constitutional limit on real property in the city, to provide for all contemplated increases in expenditures for the year 1957, including the contemplated salary increases in the police and fire departments if the referendum is carried. Therefore such plan is sufficient. Section 19-a does not require that the "plan" specify what taxes and what rates are to be levied. Those are matters which the State Constitution has vested in the local legislative bodies.

4. Accordingly, the application by the city to restrain the city clerk from transmitting the referendum of the proposed local law to the Board of Elections (City Home Rule Law, § 16) is denied.

 

2667 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Margot Von Opel v. Fritz Von Opel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


154 N.Y.S.2d 616; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2529



August 1, 1956, Decided

 

2668 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Birnbaum v. New York State Teachers Retirement System


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Onondaga County


4 Misc. 2d 356; 156 N.Y.S.2d 620; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1672



July 30, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, state teachers' retirement system, sought a judgment on the pleadings or, in the alternative, to dismiss a complaint in an action by plaintiffs, school teachers on behalf of themselves and others, for a declaratory judgment as to the validity of an action of the state teachers' retirement system in adopting a new actuarial table.


OVERVIEW: The court found that the teachers' declaratory judgment action had the effect of decreasing payments under the system. Also, the importance of the retirement system and presence of constitutional questions warranted a consideration of the action despite the fact that the teachers had no present interest in the subject matter as they had not resigned or applied for retirement. The court further held that revision of actuarial tables for pension payments to reflect increased longevity of members was not an invalid breach of contractual relationship as to members of the retirement system prior to an effective date of a constitutional provision declaring that membership in a retirement system was a contractual relationship, the benefits of which was not be diminished or impaired. The purpose of the constitutional amendment providing that membership in any pension or retirement system of a state was a contractual relationship where the benefits were not to be diminished or impaired was to preserve the integrity of pension systems of the state and civil divisions in which, prior thereto, the members had acquired no vested interest until retirement status was attained.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss was granted.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Civil service -- pensions -- schools -- New York State Teachers' Retirement System, because of increased life expectancy of its members, validly decreased by about 5% its tables of annuity benefits payable to members who retire thereafter (Education Law, § 508, subds. 4, 5; § 510, subd. 2, par. a) -- constitutional amendment declaring that, after July 1, 1940, membership in retirement systems of State or its civil divisions is "contractual relationship" (N. Y. Const., art. V, § 7), was not intended to fix rate of annuity benefits.

1. The New York State Teachers' Retirement System was established in 1921 (Education Law, § 502). Retirement of teachers who are members of this system was then, and is now, permissive upon completion of 25 years of service and attainment of age 60 while in service. Then, as now, the statute provided that, upon retirement, a teacher shall receive a retirement allowance and "An annuity which shall be the actuarial equivalent of his accumulated contributions at the time of his retirement" (Education Law, § 510, subd. 2, par. a). The statute did not and does not state or promise that the "actuarial equivalent" shall be fixed at the time a teacher [***2] becomes a member. On the contrary, the statute then, as now, provided that the actuarial valuation of annuity benefits, based on tables of mortality and service, shall be revised from time to time on the basis of the mortality and service experience of the members of the retirement system (Education Law, § 508, subds. 4, 5). Accordingly, the System in 1946, because of the increased life expectancy of its members, revised its tables of the actuarial equivalents of the contributions of members who would retire thereafter, and thus the System validly and legally reduced by about 5% the rates of annuity benefits payable to members who shall retire thereafter.

2. Section 7 of article V of the Constitution of the State of New York was adopted in 1938 and provides: "After July first, nineteen hundred forty, membership in any pension or retirement system of the state or of a civil division thereof shall be a contractual relationship, the benefits of which shall not be diminished or impaired." Prior to this amendment, a retirement plan could be terminated or its solvency imperiled by the neglect or failure of legislative bodies to appropriate the necessary funds to maintain the systems [***3] on a sound actuarial basis. This amendment was intended to preserve the pension systems. It was not intended to fix and vest the rates of annuity benefits at the rates payable on July 1, 1940. In this action for judgment declaring the revised table of annuity benefits unconstitutional and void as to prior members, the complaint is dismissed, and the New York State Teachers' Retirement System is granted judgment declaring that the revised table was validly and legally adopted.

3. Plaintiff teachers could properly bring this action, even though they are still employed in the public schools and have not applied for retirement.

 

2669 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Application of Paponja


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Jefferson County


2 Misc. 2d 620; 154 N.Y.S.2d 57; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1681



July 25, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the director of a mental hospital, filed an action pursuant to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 74 and N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 248 to involuntarily commit respondent patient as mentally ill. The issue before the court was whether N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 74, as amended by 1955 N.Y. Laws 794, which allowed a petition to be presented to a court of record without verification or acknowledgment or any form of oath, was valid.


OVERVIEW: A recent amendment to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 74 permitted an involuntary commitment petition to be filed without any verification, acknowledgement, or sworn statement by the petitioner or certifying physicians. The court noted that the commitment proceeding brought before it was intended to test the validity of the amended statute. The court held that a commitment proceeding for a mentally ill person under § 74 was a special proceeding and that N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 248 required all pleadings in such proceedings to be verified. Therefore, the court held that any portions of N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 74 as may hold that a verified petition was not required or that the certified examiners need not, under oath, certify to the facts presented was not only unconstitutional, but, if constitutional, then the statutes referring to verification of proceedings in a judicial proceeding were applicable.


OUTCOME: The court held that despite recent amendments to the applicable law, the involuntary commitment petition had to be verified. Accordingly, the court entered an order that directed the examining physicians to certify, under oath, their findings, and that the director as the petitioner was ordered to verify his petition before a duly constituted officer, competent to administer oaths, before proceeding any further.


HEADNOTES

Insane and other incompetent persons -- commitment -- statutory provisions that petition for commitment of allegedly mentally ill person, together with certifications of examining physicians, may be presented without verification or acknowledgment or oath, unconstitutional; even if constitutional, verification would be required by Civil Practice Act ( § 248).

Such portions of chapter 794 of the Laws of 1955 (Mental Hygiene Law, § 74) as provide that a petition for commitment of an allegedly mentally ill person, together with accompanying certifications of examining physicians, may be presented to a court of record without verification or acknowledgment or any form of oath, is unconstitutional. Even were those portions of the statute purporting to make unnecessary verification or oath constitutional, verification would still be required by section 248 of the Civil Practice Act.

 

2670 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York City Transit Authority v. Loos


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


2 Misc. 2d 733; 154 N.Y.S.2d 209; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1690; 38 L.R.R.M. 2472



July 24, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff transit authority brought suit to restrain defendant, motorman's benevolent association, from striking. The transit authority moved for an injunction pendente lite, while the association applied for an injunction pendente lite to restrain the transit authority from maintaining disciplinary proceedings against the motormen under the Condon-Wadlin Act, N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 22-a.


OVERVIEW: The transit authority alleged that the association was urging motormen to strike n violation of § 22-a for the purpose of coercing the transit authority into recognizing the association as the bargaining agent of its members. The court granted the injunction, concluding that it was bound to give effect to the legislative declaration that in the operation of its facilities, the transit authority was performing a governmental function and that the court was not entitled to restrain the transit authority from managing the transit system in accordance with the powers given to it by law. Because there was an imminent danger of a strike against the public interest, by public employees engaged in a governmental function, it was not necessary to rest the transit authority's right to an injunction solely upon the Act. Even absent the statute, the court would nevertheless have had the power and the duty to enjoin a strike which would have wrecked so essential a governmental service. The court further concluded that it was not free to legislate on behalf of the association and could not enjoin the transit authority from refusing to recognize it as the exclusive union representative.


OUTCOME: The court granted the transit authority's motion for an injunction pendente lite restraining the association from striking; The court, however, denied the association's motion for an injunction pendente lite.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- right of public employees to strike -- temporary injunction should issue in favor of New York City Transit Authority restraining defendants, motormen employed by authority, from instigating, promoting or carrying on strike -- there is immediate danger of strike by defendant motormen in operation of rapid transit facilities, governmental function (Condon- Wadlin Act [Civil Service Law, § 22-a, subd. 2]) -- Condon-Wadlin Act constitutional -- defendants' motion to dismiss complaint for insufficiency and to enjoin plaintiff authority, pendente lite, from recognizing certain union as exclusive union representative of motormen and from refusing to recognize defendant association as such exclusive union representative, denied -- plaintiff may not be enjoined from maintaining disciplinary proceedings under Condon-Wadlin Act.

1. Plaintiff, New York City Transit Authority, sues for an injunction restraining defendant association and the officers or members of the association, as well as all other persons employed by plaintiff under the title [***2] "motorman" from striking or instigating a strike or other work stoppage, and moves for a temporary injunction. From the affidavits, an injunction should issue restraining defendants pendente lite from instigating, promoting or carrying on a strike.

2. The papers establish that there is imminent danger of a strike by defendant motormen which will prevent the operation of plaintiff's rapid transit lines carrying millions of passengers each weekday. The operation of the rapid transit facilities in the city of New York is properly and necessarily a governmental function; and therefore, those employed in that vital service, like police officers and members of the fire department, may not strike (Condon-Wadlin Act [Civil Service Law, § 22-a, subd. 2]). The court must give effect to the legislative declaration that in the operation of its facilities the Transit Authority is performing a governmental function (Public Authorities Law, § 1802). In respect to defendants' contention that plaintiff is engaged in a proprietary function of government and one which is not essentially governmental in character, a distinction in the situation here between governmental and proprietary functions [***3] is wholly inapposite.

3. Even in the absence of the Condon-Wadlin Act, the court would nevertheless have the power and duty to enjoin a strike which would wreck so essential a governmental service as that represented by the rapid transit facilities of the city of New York.

4. The Condon-Wadlin Act is constitutional insofar as defendant rapid transit motormen are concerned.

5. The procedural requirements of section 876-a of the Civil Practice Act have no application to these public employees.

6. The individual defendants have no rights under the State Labor Relations Law, for section 715 of the Labor Law specifically provides that such act shall not apply to public employees generally.

7. Defendants' motion for an order dismissing the complaint for insufficiency and enjoining the plaintiff Transit Authority, pendente lite, from recognizing a certain union as the exclusive union representative of the motormen, and from refusing to recognize said defendant association as such exclusive union representative or, in the alternative, requiring an election to be held to determine which group is to be the union representative of the motormen, should be denied.

8. Plaintiff may not [***4] be enjoined from maintaining disciplinary proceedings under the Condon-Wadlin Act.

 

2671 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Bogan v. Roberts


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Utica


2 Misc. 2d 668; 154 N.Y.S.2d 201; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1694



July 21, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought a discharge and dismissal of his indictment under N.Y. Penal Law § 1141 for the crime of possession of obscene photographs with intent to sell, lend, distribute, or give away, on the basis that only one article, a photo album, was involved, the photographs were neither identical nor similar even if they were separate articles, and § 1141(3) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: When a police officer requested to search defendant's business premises, he confiscated the photo album containing 10 admittedly pornographic pictures that was in a desk drawer and defendant was charged under § 1141, which required that defendant intend to sell the pictures. However, the State presented no evidence of a sale or offer of sale in the preliminary hearing, nor did it present convincing proof of a specific intent by defendant to sell the album or offer it for sale. The lack of sales intent would have concluded the matter had not an amendment to § 1141 held that six or more identical or similar pornographic items were presumptive evidence of a violation of § 1141. Thus, defendant argued that § 1141(3) was unconstitutional as an invalid presumption because it conflicted with the presumption of innocence. Rejecting that argument, the court held that defendant should answer the charge. In so doing, the court found that the 10 photographs plainly encompassed more than a single article, that the pictures were not identical, but were clearly similar, and that the presumption was a legal presumption and thus rebuttable by defendant at the close of the State's case.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant must be held to answer the charge of possession of obscene photographs with intent to sell, lend, distribute, or give away.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- obscene photographs -- presumption from possession of intent to sell, lend, distribute or give away obscene photographs -- album containing 10 concededly obscene photographs found in defendant's possession; defendant charged under subdivision 1 of section 1141 of Penal Law with intent to sell, lend, distribute or give away such photographs; subdivision 3 of section 1141, relied on by prosecution, provided that possession of six or more "similar" or "identical" obscene articles should be "presumptive evidence of a violation of this section"; defendant held, on preliminary examination, to answer charge; album, consisting of series of photographs attached together by metal clasp and readily removable, not single article; photographs "similar" in that all were lewd and obscene; legislative intent was to create rebuttable presumption that possession was for purpose of sale, loan, distribution, etc. and defendant's presumption of innocence not destroyed; while there might be merit to contention that Legislature did not accurately draft intention in words, where legislative  [***2] intent clear no constitutional question presented.

1. Defendant, in whose possession was found an album containing 10 photographs concededly obscene within the meaning of subdivision 1 of section 1141 of the Penal Law, was charged under that subdivision with possession with "intent to sell, lend, distribute or give away, obscene * * * photographs." The prosecution was unable to present any evidence of a sale or an offer of sale by defendant, or any convincing proof of a specific intent on the part of defendant to sell or offer for sale the album of photographs, and mere possession of obscene material has not been made a criminal offense. The prosecution relied on subdivision 3 of section 1141 of the Penal Law, providing that the possession by any person of six or more similar or identical articles coming within subdivision one of said section 1141 should be "presumptive evidence of a violation of this section." Defendant moved, upon preliminary examination, for his discharge on the grounds: (a) that there was merely one article, namely, an album or book of pictures; (b) that the photographs were not identical or similar even if they should be considered as separate articles; and [***3] (c) that said subdivision 3 was unconstitutional in that it created an invalid presumption in conflict with the presumption of innocence. Defendant was held to answer the charge.

2. The album consisted of a series of photographs attached together by means of a metal clasp. By merely bending the top ends of the clasp, the photographs could be removed and reinserted in the same or different order and the clasp ends rebent. The album could not realistically be held to be a single article.

3. While the photographs were not "identical", in that they were not "exactly the same", yet they were similar within the meaning of subdivision 3, in that they were all lewd and obscene. The Legislature intended to make lewdness and obscenity the criterion of "similarity" rather than the composition of the material itself.

4. The legislative intent was to create a rebuttable presumption of law that possession of six or more "identical" or "similar" articles by a person is for the purpose of sale, loan, gift, distribution, exhibition or transmission of at least some of the articles to others. Defendant's contention that the Legislature went further than merely to create a legal presumption, that [***4] it specifically made possession "presumptive evidence of a violation" and in so doing destroyed defendant's presumption of innocence, was untenable.

5. While there might be merit to the contention that the Legislature did not accurately draft its intention in words, where the legislative intent was clear, no constitutional question was presented. The words "presumptive evidence of a violation" were intended to mean "presumptive evidence of intent."

 

2672 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Trio Distributor Corp. v. Albany


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Albany County


2 Misc. 2d 627; 156 N.Y.S.2d 906; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1726



July 7, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a corporation, an officer, and an employee, filed an action for an adjudication that an ordinance enacted by defendant city was unconstitutional and sought to permanently enjoin its enforcement.


OVERVIEW: The city enacted an ordinance that required any person who sold from a vehicle in the public street to have an attendant whose sole purpose was to protect children from injury. The officer, the employee, and another employee were arrested and charged with violating the ordinance. Plaintiffs sued for an adjudication that the ordinance was unconstitutional and sought to permanently enjoin its enforcement. The court ruled in favor of plaintiffs and held that the ordinance failed to provide with clearness and precision suitable standards delineating what must be done and what must be avoided by the accompanying attendant to elude its penal consequences in the performance of the imposed duties to protect and safeguard children from injury. The court ruled that the ordinance failed to inform the vendor, corporate employer, or co-employee clearly and precisely whether he was subject to its penalties for the attendant's failure to comply with its provisions. The court held that without such standards for the guidance of the persons whom it affected, the enactment violated due process of law and was void.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of plaintiffs for the permanent relief demanded in the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- ordinances -- ordinance which provided that any person vending from vehicle in public streets in manner which assembled children for purchase of products should be accompanied by attendant whose sole duty should be to guard children, and made violation of ordinance punishable by fine or imprisonment or both, violative of due process of law in that it failed to provide with clearness and precision suitable standards delineating what was required to be done and what avoided to elude penal consequences of ordinance.

An ordinance of the City of Albany which provides that any person vending or peddling from a vehicle in the public streets of that city in a manner which assembles children for the purpose of purchasing his products "shall be accompanied by an attendant whose sole duty and occupation shall be to protect and safeguard the children from injury and the hazards of street vehicle traffic and he shall maintain a constant look-out for approaching vehicles and shall warn the children and guard them from injury", and makes violation of the ordinance punishable [***2] by fine or imprisonment or both, is violative of due process of law in that it fails to provide with clearness and precision suitable standards delineating what must be done and what must be avoided by the accompanying attendant to elude the penal consequences of the ordinance in the performance of the imposed duties to protect and safeguard children from injury. When in the exercise of its police power a municipality undertakes to enact a regulatory ordinance in which conduct which is otherwise lawful is converted into that which is criminal, its terms must be clear, precise, definite and certain in specifying the conduct which is prohibited and in prescribing some comprehensible guide, rule or information as to what must be done and what must be avoided, to the end that the ordinary member of society may know how to comply with its requirements.

 

2673 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gaebel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


2 Misc. 2d 458; 153 N.Y.S.2d 102; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1747



June 28, 1956 



DISPOSITION: The judgment of conviction is reversed; the information dismissed; and the fine, if paid, remitted.

Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of conviction from the Court of Special Sessions, Town of Henrietta, Monroe County (New York) for committing the infraction of Dangerous Speed in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Laws § 56(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with committing the infraction of dangerous speed in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1). At his trial, a state trooper testified that he responded to a report of an accident and that defendant stated that he was unable to stop and struck the rear of the car he was travelling behind. The trooper was the only witness called by the prosecution and defendant was found guilty. He appealed and the court reversed the conviction and dismissed the information. The court held that the judgment was not supported by the evidence. There was no evidence of fault on defendant's part in causing the accident. Proof of an accident and injury was not sufficient to justify a conviction under the statute. There was no proof that defendant was driving at a speed which could have been found to be unreasonable and imprudent under the conditions present. The court found that §56(1) was too vague and indefinite to be enforced. It failed to set up a standard for the operation of motor vehicles, a deviation of which could form the basis for criminal prosecution.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment of conviction and dismissed the information.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- motor vehicles -- speed -- judgment convicting defendant of violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 56, subd. 1) in operating motor vehicle at rate of speed greater than would permit him to bring his vehicle to stop without injury to another's property not supported by evidence which did not show any fault on defendant's part in causing accident -- statute too vague to be enforced and violation of its prohibitions does not constitute traffic offense.

1. Defendant was found guilty of committing the "infraction of Dangerous Speed" in violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 56, subd. 1) in that he operated a motor vehicle upon a public highway "at a rate of speed greater than would permit him to bring his vehicle to a stop without injury to another's property." A State trooper,  [***2] the only witness for the prosecution, testified that he found two cars at the side of the highway which had apparently been involved in a collision; that he did not see the accident; that defendant stated to the trooper that he was behind a Buick automobile and the Buick was making a right hand turn into a driveway, and defendant could not stop in time to avoid striking the rear of the Buick. Defendant testified that he was traveling in a 35-mile zone at a speed of 25 to 30, or 30 to 35, miles per hour, following two cars, and suddenly the car ahead of him pulled to its left on the two-lane highway, passed the second car ahead (the Buick), at which time he saw the Buick turning into a driveway, and a car approaching from the opposite direction about 100 feet away, and that he applied his brakes and skidded into the rear of the Buick which was turning. The judgment of conviction is not supported by the evidence. No evidence was submitted of fault on defendant's part in causing the accident.

2. The Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 56, subd. 1) does not prohibit the operation of a vehicle at a speed greater than that which is "reasonable and prudent under the conditions." It does not set [***3] up a standard for the operation of a motor vehicle on a public highway, a deviation from which can properly be made the basis for a criminal prosecution, and therefore it is too vague and indefinite to be enforced; and a violation of its prohibitions does not, in fact, constitute a traffic offense or infraction.

3. The judgment of conviction should be reversed, the information dismissed, and the fine, if paid, remitted.

 

2674 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Huie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Sullivan County


28 Misc. 2d 708; 221 N.Y.S.2d 689; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1823



May 26, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The application is denied, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant property owner filed an application for an order directing petitioner, the Board of Water Supply of the City of New York, to accept his claim to recover the value of lands that had been appropriated for water use and present the same to the commissioners of appraisal in accordance with the Water Supply Act, N.Y. Admin. Code § K41.


OVERVIEW: After the Board followed the procedural requirements to appropriate a parcel of land that belonged to the property owner, notice was published as required by N.Y. Admin. Code § K41-8.0 and the commissioners of appraisal filed their oath's in office. At that point, title to the property owner's lands became vested in the city. More than three years later, the property owner filed an application to recover the value of the lands in which he contended that the statute of limitations of Admin. Code § K41-18.0(a) did not apply because his due process rights were violated. The court denied the property owner's application, holding that the notice requirements of the Water Supply Act were sufficient because they gave the property owner notice reasonably adapted to bring the pendency of the appropriation to his attention. Further, personal service was not necessary and constructive notice by publication met the test of constitutionality. The fact that actual, personal knowledge was not brought home to an individual claimant was not sufficient to brand constructive notice as unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the application.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- compensation -- Statute of Limitations is valid, without providing for service in person or by mail.

Unfiled claims against the City of New York for appropriations in Sullivan County and elsewhere for said city's water supply sources are validly and constitutionally barred when three years have elapsed since the Commissioners of Appraisal filed their oaths of office (Administrative Code of City of New York, § K41-18.0). The statute's provisions for public hearing, maps, publication, posting, filing, and judicial proceedings (§§ K41-3.0, K41-6.0, K41-7.0, K41-8.0, K41-11.0) are adequate. The State and Federal Constitutions do not require that such a statute should additionally require that the realty owners be served in person or by mail.

 

2675 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In the Matter of the Application of MOSES KOOPERSTEIN, JOSEPH P. BRENNAN, LUCIUS C. BUTTS and J. HOWARD PAYNE, JR., Petitioners, -against- JAMES M. POWER, DAVID B. COSTUMA, DENNIS J. MAHON and JOHN R. CREWS, Commissioners of Elections, constituting the Board of Elections of the City of New York, and CARMINE G. DE SAPIO, HULAN E. JACK, ROSEMARY FAY, DENNIS J. MAHON and ESTELLE M. KARPF, Members of a Committee to fill Vacancies, Respondents, for an order pursuant to the Election Law of the State of New York declaring invalid and striking out the petitions purporting to designate JOSEPH A. COX and S. SAMUEL DI FALCO for the Public Offices of Surrogates of New York County, and JAMES A. BYRNES and EMILIO NUNEZ for the Public Offices of Justices of the City Court of the City of New York, County of New York, and CHARLES MARKS, THOMAS DICKENS and IRWIN D. DAVIDSON for the Public Offices of Judges of the Court of General Sessions, County of New York, and restraining the Board of Elections from printing and placing the names of the said persons upon the ballot to be used in the forthcoming Primary Election of the Democratic Party.


6219-55


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


153 N.Y.S.2d 908; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2357



May 22, 1956, Decided 
May 22, 1956, Filed

 

2676 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Whalen v. Wagner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


2 Misc. 2d 89; 152 N.Y.S.2d 386; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1879



May 7, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Defendants' motion for the relief sought is granted (cf. German Masonic Temple Assn. v. City of New York, 279 N. Y. 452). Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, an attorney general, a board of estimate, a port authority, and other municipal authorities, filed a motion to dismiss an action by plaintiff taxpayers challenging the validity of certain statutes on the ground that there was a failure to comply with the home rule provisions of a state constitution.


OVERVIEW: The statutes in question, 1955 N.Y. Laws 806-809, pertained to the construction of bridges, tunnels, bus terminals, and a network of roads and expressways in the city of New York. The taxpayers filed an action challenging the constitutionality of the statutes, claiming that special meeting at which the city council concurred in a home rule message was invalid for failure to give due notice of the meeting as required by the city's charter. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint on the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. On review, the court held that it was only as to laws in relation to the property, affairs, or government of the city that a request had to be made by the mayor or local legislative body for the legislation in question. The court found that the statutes dealt with bridges and highways that were essential connecting links in a coordinated state highway system. The court stated that the statutes were enacted for the purpose of improving intrastate and interstate vehicular transportation. The court concluded that the statutes related to matters of state concern and were not subject to home rule requirements.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for defendants.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- home rule -- statutes representing "package legislation" wherein provision was made for construction and operation by Port of New York Authority and Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority of bridges and network of roads to provide access to bridges and connections with State arterial highway system, related to matters of State concern; Legislature free to act thereon without home rule message (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 11).

1. Chapters 806-809 of the Laws of 1955, representing "package legislation" wherein provision was made for construction and operation by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority of a bridge across the Narrows connecting Brooklyn with Staten Island, a bridge at Throgs Neck connecting the borough of Queens with The Bronx, a second deck to the George Washington Bridge, and a network of roads [***2] and expressways to provide access to the bridges and connections with the State arterial highway system, related to matters of State concern, rather than to the "property, affairs or government of any city", and the Legislature was free to act thereon without a home rule message (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 11).

2. Even if it were assumed that proceedings in the New York City Council in connection with concurrence in the request of the mayor of the city of New York that the Legislature act in relation to the subject matter of such statutes (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 11) were defective, challenge of the validity of the statutes was precluded by reason of certificates of the presiding officers of the Legislature to the effect that the statutes were properly adopted pursuant to home rule messages. Those certificates constituted "conclusive evidence", as certified therein, that all requisite steps necessary for the passage of the laws in question were properly carried out (Legislative Law, § 40).

3. Section 33 of the New York City Charter, requiring publication of notice of a meeting of the New York City Council one day in advance of the meeting date, was substantially complied with [***3] in the adoption of the home rule messages, where a meeting held on the day of publication of the notice was recessed to the following day and the action of the council concurring in the messages was taken on the latter day, when all members of the council, with the exception of one who had been excused, were present.

 

2677 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McGuire v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


3 Misc. 2d 569; 153 N.Y.S.2d 368; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1895



May 2, 1956 



DISPOSITION: The motion to strike out the defense is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff injured party filed a motion to strike out defendant city's defense that the injured party's action was barred by a one-year statute of limitations.


OVERVIEW: The injured party was a passenger on one of the city subway trains when an explosion occurred and caused him harm. The city raised the defense that the claim was barred by the one-year period of limitations provided for in either New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 394a-1.0(c); or, N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law, §§ 50-b, 50-c. The injured party alleged that management of the subway was a "propriety" function of the city and the three-year period of limitations under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act §49(6)as to negligence claims applied. The court denied the injured party's motion to strike the city's defense, and held that whether the action arose from a "proprietary" or "governmental" function in the traditional sense, the power of the legislature to lay down a reasonable, short statute of limitations as to all litigation against a municipality was beyond dispute. The one-year statute of limitations was applicable to the injured party's claim and the city's defense was proper.


OUTCOME: The court denied the injured party's action to strike out the city's defense that the action was barred by a one-year statute of limitations.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- actions against municipalities -- limitations -- action against City of New York to recover damages for personal injuries resulting from negligence, whether arising out of performance of proprietary or governmental function, controlled by one-year Statute of Limitations.

1. An action against the City of New York to recover damages for personal injuries resulting from negligence, whether arising out of the performance of a proprietary or governmental function, is controlled by the one-year Statute of Limitations (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 394a-1.0, subd. c; General Municipal Law, §§ 50-b, 50-c). Whether an action against a municipality springs from a proprietary or governmental function in the traditional sense, the power of the Legislature to lay down a reasonable, short Statute of Limitations as to all litigation against a municipality is beyond dispute.

2. Statutes of the nature of the Administrative Code and the more generic General Municipal Law setting up a one-year period of limitations in [***2] tort actions are a concomitant of the State's waiver of immunity from civil suit in tort with the sovereign's right to attach conditions thereto. Such statutes are not to be read as applying only to causes of action arising from derelictions in fields in which a municipality formerly was not answerable to civil suit, that is, in fields where the activities were governmental and not proprietary.

3. In the light of modern governmental practices, concepts and accepted responsibilities, the whole question of the artificial distinction between "governmental" and "proprietary" functions may well stand reappraisal. Many functions once deemed unconstitutional excursions into the field of private enterprise are now deemed both acceptable and desirable attributes of good government in the public interest.

 

2678 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Thompson-Starrett Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


5 Misc. 2d 576; 165 N.Y.S.2d 554; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1928



April 20, 1956 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss is granted and the motion for a temporary injunction denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, city and comptroller, sought to dismiss plaintiff contractor's complaint for a declaratory judgment and injunction to prohibit the comptroller from assessing taxes on the contractor for construction jobs that the contractor had completed within the city, because the comptroller had used a formula to arrive at the assessed taxes rather than a complete audit of each job that the contractor completed.


OVERVIEW: The contractor claimed that it was entitled to a declaratory judgment and injunction to prohibit the city from enforcing the determination by the comptroller that it owed taxes prior to a decision by the comptroller. The court dismissed the contractor's complaint for a declaratory judgment and temporary injunction against the city and the comptroller and held that the remedy that was available to the contractor was an appeal after the administrative process of appealing the comptroller's decision was completed pursuant to N.Y. Civil Practices Act § 78 and that the contractor was required to exhaust the administrative remedies prior to seeking relief from the court. The court further held that the contractor had failed to provide the documentation with which the comptroller could determine the taxes owed for the other projects in which the contractor had been involved and in the absence of not being able to review those documents it was appropriate for the comptroller to use the formula.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion of the city and comptroller to dismiss the complaint of the contractor for a declaratory judgment and denied the contractor's motion for a temporary injunction against the city from conducting hearings with the comptroller to assess the amount of taxes claimed by the city to be owed by the contractor for construction jobs completed in the city.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City sales tax -- sales tax deficiency determination is reviewable by article 78 proceeding; action for declaratory judgment dismissed and plaintiff's motion for temporary injunction denied -- city's formula, based on partial audit, that 6.026% of construction contractor's gross billings were taxable sales of personalty, is not necessarily erroneous; such determination properly reviewable in article 78 proceeding, even though it may put taxpayer to expense of proving sales tax status of every subcontract.

1. A sales tax deficiency determination by the New York City Comptroller should ordinarily be reviewed by a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act "for error, illegality * * * or any reason whatsoever" (Administrative Code of City of New York, § N41-7.0). This action for a declaratory judgment, wherein plaintiff also seeks an injunction pendente lite, is dismissed on defendants' motion prior to answer (Rules Civ. Prac., rule 106, subd. 4; rule 212).

2. Plaintiff is a corporation specializing in large construction projects. The defendants are the [***2] city and the city comptroller. The complaint alleges that defendants audited plaintiff's records to determine whether a deficiency in city sales tax was owed as the result of purchase of personal property by plaintiff in connection with its construction projects; that the only records examined by defendants pertained to the construction of two buildings for a hospital; that defendants determined that taxable sales represented 6.026% of the gross amount of the hospital contract; that this percentage was applied to gross billings on nonhospital work done by plaintiff for a three-year period; that the city's formula failed to credit plaintiff with sales tax payments made by it to its subcontractors, who, in turn, had paid the taxes to the city; that plaintiff's rights, under its contracts with its subcontractors, to be reimbursed for sales taxes which plaintiff is required to pay to the city, would be impaired or defeated if such taxes were assessed and paid under a blanket formula without any specification of the transactions which were taxable; that the city's formula places on plaintiff the expensive burden of proving, either before the comptroller or in an article 78 proceeding,  [***3] what sales taxes, if any, were involved in each subcontract; but that nevertheless, on said audit and after informal hearings, defendants determined that plaintiff owed a deficiency in sales tax payments. It appears that the two hospital projects may have accounted for 70% of plaintiff's gross business in the city in the three-year period, and that plaintiff claimed that additional records were unavailable. The city's formula is not necessarily illegal or erroneous. Plaintiff does not claim to be entirely exempt from city sales taxes. Defendants are acting entirely within their jurisdiction. To permit actions for declaratory judgments as to the correctness and legality of methods employed in computing tax liability or as to the propriety of evidence adduced before a commission or comptroller or other body or official, would disrupt orderly procedure, and unnecessarily increase litigation by having the same question affecting a plaintiff's liability determined in a declaratory judgment action and the remaining questions decided in an article 78 proceeding. Plaintiff's motion for a temporary injunction is denied and the action is dismissed.

 

2679 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


London Sporting Club, Inc. v. Helfand


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


3 Misc. 2d 431; 152 N.Y.S.2d 819; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2002



March 27, 1956 



DISPOSITION: The petition is accordingly dismissed and stay vacated.

Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, an athletic club and boxing entrepreneur, initiated a N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding to review a determination of the New York State Athletic Commission, which revoked the license of the club as boxing promoter and of the entrepreneur as matchmaker and imposed a $ 5,000 fine against the club.


OVERVIEW: The club was a boxing promoter and the entrepreneur was a boxing matchmaker. Although not required by 1920 N.Y. Laws 912, which established the Commission with authority and jurisdiction over the sport of boxing, a hearing at which evidence was taken was granted to the club and the entrepreneur to determine if they were guilty of acts detrimental to the interests of boxing. The Commission revoked their licenses and fined the club $ 5000. On petition for judicial review, they complained of the insufficiency of the evidence under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1296(6), (7) and requested a transfer to the appellate court. The court denied the request because the right to assert questions under § 1296(6), (7) was limited to determinations where evidence was taken pursuant to statutory direction, which was not the case. The court then dismissed the petition and vacated a stay because the Commission's decision, based on the recited evidence of malfeasance, was not arbitrary, capricious, or an abuse of discretion. Furthermore, the fine was not disproportionate to the offense or the club's financial ability.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition and vacated a previously imposed stay.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against body or officer -- hearing granted by commission as favor -- State Athletic Commission -- prize fighting is illegal in New York except to extent licensed by State Athletic Commission; licensees have no statutory or constitutional right to hearing; commission gave them hearing merely as favor; hence they are not entitled to review of competency and sufficiency of evidence and to transfer of this review proceeding to Appellate Division (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1296, subds. 6, 7) -- revocation of promoter's and matchmaker's licenses was not arbitrary -- fine of $ 5,000, maximum under State Athletic Commission Act, was not abuse of discretion (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1296, subd. 5-a) and was not deprivation of property without due process.

1. Review by the courts of determinations of administrative bodies is ordinarily limited to questions of the statutory jurisdiction of the administrative body and whether the determination was arbitrary (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1296, subds. 1 to 5-a). If evidence was taken by the administrator, judicial [***2] review thereof is ordinarily limited to ascertaining whether there was any evidence at all to support the determination.

2. Prize fighting and boxing matches are illegal occupations in this State, except to the extent of licenses issued by the State Athletic Commission (L. 1920, ch. 912, as amd.). Such licenses, in an otherwise illegal occupation, are not vested or property rights. The licensees have no statutory or constitutional right to a hearing before the commission before it may revoke their licenses and fine them under the statute.

3. The State Athletic Commission did grant a full hearing, but the hearing was a favor and not a statutory or constitutional right. Hence, the licensees are not entitled to a judicial review of the sufficiency and competency of the evidence and to a transfer of this review proceeding to the Appellate Division (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1296, subds. 6, 7).

4. The commission revoked the promoter's license of an incorporated boxing club and the matchmaker's license of an individual, and fined the club $ 5,000, which is the maximum fine under the statute (§ 16; L. 1952, ch. 666). The fine was an authorized disciplinary measure arising out of the license.  [***3] It did not constitute a deprivation of property without due process of law, and hence the licensee was not entitled to a hearing as a matter of right.

5. The measure of punishment was not an abuse of discretion (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1296, subd. 5-a). The commission was not arbitrary or capricious when it found that the matchmaker and the promoting corporation were each "guilty of an act detrimental to the interests of boxing * * * generally or to the public interest, convenience or necessity." (L. 1920, ch. 912, § 17, as amd. by L. 1952, ch. 666). The matchmaker had previously been suspended and the corporation fined a substantial sum, for violating rules of the commission. The commission could properly consider that such former suspension and fine had produced no effect on these licensees. The commission found that they thereafter attempted to circumvent a rule of the commission against payments out of purses to a so-called boxing managers' guild, that they negotiated with unlicensed boxing managers and with a revoked licensee, that they paid cash to an unlicensed manager and not to his boxer, and that they had no explanation for the deposit of $ 66,000 of the corporation's funds [***4] to the credit of a newly organized corporation in New Jersey, apparently for payments to unlicensed persons. The commission has a responsibility for the maintenance of fair dealing, honesty, and clean sport in a field which has in the past been infested with undesirable elements, and its rules are not arbitrary.

 

2680 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rothrock Syosset, Inc. v. Kreutzer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


3 Misc. 2d 64; 150 N.Y.S.2d 689; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2095



March 1, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:
