PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff developer sued defendants, the commissioners of a water district in Nassau County, New York, seeking (1) the return of the cost of the installation of water mains on its property, paid under its contract with the commissioners, and (2) the return of a loan made to the commissioners for the cost of implementing the district well supply and storage. The developer moved for judgment on the pleadings as to the first cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The developer's contract with the commissioners authorized them to advertise for bids to install and lay water pipes and mains on its property and to contract with the low bidder for this work. Pursuant to the terms of the contract, the developer deposited with the commissioners a certain sum to cover the cost of installation and an additional amount in the nature of a loan toward the cost of implementing the district well supply and storage. After construction was completed, the developer repudiated the contract and brought this suit, alleging the commissioners were without authority to enter the contract. The court disagreed. Nassau County Civil Divisions Act § 255.4(c) provided that the board of commissioners of every water district in the county of Nassau had the power to make any and all contracts for district purposes, including contracts with developers of subdivisions for the installation of a system of water mains and hydrants in such subdivisions. However, the court held the commissioners were without authority to secure the loan from the developer. Such improvements as were contemplated were required to be financed by an ad valorem tax upon the entire district.


OUTCOME: The court granted judgment to the commissioners, dismissing that part of the developer's action, which sought the return of the actual cost of the installation of the water mains, paid under its contract. It granted judgment to the developer as to that part, which sought the return of the loan.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- water district -- contracts -- money had and received -- in action by land development corporation to recover, as moneys had and received, $ 6,921 paid to commissioners of water district to have water mains installed (Nassau County Civil Divisions Act, § 255.4, subd. [c]), board entitled to judgment of dismissal on pleadings -- corporation entitled to judgment on pleadings for $ 2,000 loaned to board without interest in order to implement district well supply.

1. The Nassau County Civil Divisions Act (§ 255.4; L. 1939, ch. 273, as amd. by L. 1949, ch. 270) provides, in part, that "The board of commissioners of every water district in the county of Nassau shall have the following powers in addition to all other powers now or hereafter conferred on such board * * * (c) * * * the power to make any and all contracts for district purposes, including contracts with developers of subdivisions for the installation of a system of water mains and hydrants in such subdivisions and for the purchase of water supply pipe lines, materials and appurtenances". Pursuant to this statute, such a board validly [***2] entered into a contract with a corporate developer of a subdivision, whereby the developer authorized the board to advertise for bids to install and lay water pipes and mains in the subdivision and to contract with the low bidder for this work, all on the developer's behalf, and whereby the developer deposited $ 6,921 with the board to cover the cost of installation, engineering and legal fees, and whereby the developer gave title to such pipes and mains to the board and created a permanent easement for them over its lands. This board was not restricted, as in the Town Law ( § 199, subd. 1, par. [a]; § 199, subd. 2; § 202), to levying ad valorem local assessments throughout the water district, in order to pay for the expense of constructing water mains. In this action by the developer for the return of moneys had and received, the board is entitled to summary judgment dismissing the cause of action for $ 6,921.

2. Under the contract, the developer also loaned $ 2,000 to the board, without interest, to be used by the board toward the cost of implementing the district well supply and storage facilities; and the board, after completing such installation, returned what was left,  [***3] $ 279.22, to the developer. The developer is entitled to summary judgment for the return of the $ 2,000 less $ 279.22. Borrowing money in this manner is not included in the statutory powers of the board. The $ 2,000 constituted an illegal assessment against a particular property for the benefit of the entire water district. Such improvements must be financed by an ad valorem tax on the entire district.

3. This action against the board is not barred by a one-year limitation, or by an eighteen-month limitation, on certain types of actions against towns (Town Law, §§ 65, 67). The Nassau County Civil Divisions Act ( § 255.4) states that actions may be maintained against a board of commissioners of a water district, and it does not state any such limitations of time.

 

2681 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Peoples Dairy v. Lackawanna


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Erie County


1 Misc. 2d 700; 149 N.Y.S.2d 392; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2098



March 1, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a licensed milk dealer, filed suit against defendant city, seeking a declaration that a city ordinance was unconstitutional and an injunction restraining its enforcement. The ordinance prohibited coin-operated milk-dispensing machines unless such machines were located within a regular place of business. A violation of the ordinance was punishable by fine or, if the fine was not paid, by imprisonment until the fine was paid.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance stated that its purpose was to remedy a condition that made it impossible to properly inspect the quality and weight of such milk. The court declared the ordinance unconstitutional. Under the mere guise of police regulations, personal rights and private property could not be arbitrarily invaded. If an ordinance was passed ostensibly for the public health, and thereby destroyed or took away the property of a citizen, or interfered with his personal liberty, then it was for the courts to scrutinize the ordinance and see whether it really related to and was convenient and appropriate to promote the public health. Here, there was no proof that the health of the community was or would be jeopardized by the sale of milk through milk-vending machines. There was also no evidence that the location of these coin-vending machines created traffic hazards and congestion. Even if this were true, a traffic ordinance would be the remedy. The ordinance was not a regulatory or licensing ordinance, but a prohibitory ordinance. If the city was sincere in its desire to protect the public by inspection, it could easily be accomplished by a regulatory or licensing ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court declared the ordinance at issue to be unconstitutional and issued an injunction permanently enjoining and restraining the city from attempting to enforce the ordinance.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- police power -- city ordinance prohibiting coin-operated, refrigerated milk-vending machines from being located out-of-doors, unconstitutional and void.

1. A licensed milk dealer, which installed a coin-operated, refrigerated, insulated, vending machine containing milk in bottles or sealed containers, on private property but out-of-doors and not within a regular place of business, was granted a judgment declaring the unconstitutionality of a city ordinance prohibiting such machines from being located outside of any building, and an injunction against enforcement of such ordinance.

2. The ordinance recited, by way of preamble, that no operator or attendant was present at such coin machines to unlock them for inspection by the city's and State's inspectors, and further that the location of the machines created traffic hazards and congestion. Both of these purposes can readily be accomplished by a regulatory or licensing ordinance. The purpose of this prohibitory ordinance is to protect retail storekeepers from competition. Such ordinance is not a proper exercise of the police power and is void.

 

2682 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lincoln Bldg. Associates v. Barr


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Municipal Court of the City of New York, Borough of Manhattan


1 Misc. 2d 560; 149 N.Y.S.2d 460; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2113



February 24, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Final order is awarded in favor of each of the tenants dismissing the petition on the merits.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord filed summary proceedings against respondent tenants to recover possession of real property.


OVERVIEW: The landlord brought summary proceedings to recover possession of office premises from the tenants, claiming that they held over after the expiration of their terms. Justification for their continued possession lay in the Business Rent Law, 1945 N.Y. Laws ch. 314, as amd., as re-enacted and extended by 1955 N.Y. Laws ch. 701. The enactment precluded dispossession of a tenant from office premises after the expiration of his lease so long as he continued to pay rent and otherwise complied with his statutory obligations as a tenant. The landlord undertook to prove the absence of an emergency, despite the finding in the statute to the contrary. The determination of the existence of an emergency was lodged in the legislature. The court's review was limited to a finding that there was no reasonable basis for the legislature's determination. The court could not accept the landlord's claim that there was a failure to show an emergency. The question the court had to decide was whether the controls statute lacked any basis in fact. The evidence was not so clear or convincing as to sway the court's determination to a factual finding that no emergency existed. The petition was dismissed.


OUTCOME: In the landlord's action to recover possession of real property, the court awarded a final order in favor of each of the tenants, dismissing the petition on the merits.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- constitutionality of Business Rent Law, as re-enacted and extended in 1955 (L. 1955, ch. 701), attacked, in summary proceedings, on ground that legislative finding of emergency was without foundation in fact; legislative finding not overcome by proof adduced; constitutionality of statute sustained; final order awarded in favor of tenants.

In summary proceedings to recover possession of office space, wherein the constitutionality of the Business Rent Law as re-enacted and extended in 1955 (L. 1955, ch. 701) was attacked on the ground that the legislative finding of emergency, upon the basis of which the statute was re-enacted, was without foundation in fact, the legislative finding was not overcome by proof adduced, the constitutionality of the statute was sustained and a final order awarded in favor of each of several tenants dismissing the petition on the merits.

 

2683 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Eastman Kodak Co. v. Siegel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


2 Misc. 2d 966; 150 N.Y.S.2d 99; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2127



February 23, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff manufacturer sought a permanent injunction pursuant to the New York Fair Trade Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§369-a through 369-e, against defendant retailer to prohibit the retailer from selling photographic equipment and supplied in a packaged unit, which contained separate products with different trademarks from the manufacturer's trademark.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer claimed that it had a fair-trade agreement with respect to the minimum retail resale prices of certain of the its products and the retailer was selling the manufacturer's product below such prices. The retailer, a nonsigner of the agreement, claimed that the commodities did not bear the manufacturer's trade-marks, brands, and names, and were in fair and open competition in the state with commodities of the same general class produced by others manufacturers. The court ordered that the manufacturer was entitled to a permanent injunction against the retailer from selling the manufacturer's products in the package with other items as a unit and held that the retailer was violating the New York Fair Trade Law by selling the products, which had different trademarks from different manufacturers, in the same packaged unit for a price below that which the manufacturer had agreed in its fair-trade agreement that could be charged for the product.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the manufacturer was entitled to judgment for a permanent injunction that prohibited the retailer from selling the manufacturer's product in a package with other items from different manufacturers with different trademarks.


HEADNOTES

Trade-marks, trade names and unfair competition -- price fixing of trade-marked commodities -- manufacturer of photographic equipment and supplies was not entitled, under provisions of Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, §§ 369-a-369-e), to establish fair-trade resale price for flash camera outfit containing at least one item, trade-marked but not fair-traded by it, along with its trade-marked and individually fair-traded items and other components of different manufacture -- in its action to restrain retailer from selling its products at less than established fair-trade minimum resale price, manufacturer was entitled to judgment, but, as regards such outfit, it did not have protection afforded by Fair Trade Law.

1. The Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, §§ 369-a-369-e) did not protect a manufacturer of photographic equipment and supplies as to a flash camera outfit consisting in part of different trade-marked products of the manufacturer where no fair-trade minimum resale price had been fixed for at least one such component when sold independently and separately.  [***2] The manufacturer was not entitled to establish a fair-trade minimum resale price for the outfit, although in its action for an injunction against sales of certain of its products by a retailer at less than their established fair-trade resale prices the manufacturer was entitled to judgment under the Fair Trade Law.

2. The language of the statute (General Business Law, § 369-a, subd. 1) limiting its applicability to a commodity "in fair and open competition with commodities of the same general class produced by others" was not vague and indefinite and therefore a denial of due process of law in violation of the Constitution (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6).

3. The manufacturer satisfied the statutory requirement that its products were in free and open competition with commodities of the same general class produced by others, within the meaning of the Fair Trade Law. The phrase "free and open competition" has received a liberal interpretation in this State and the fact that a commodity has been copyrighted or patented did not preclude the establishment of a fair-trade price.

4. The manufacturer's activities and program of enforcing its fair-trade agreement were adequate, diligent,  [***3] consistent and nondiscriminatory. There was no requirement that it establish and maintain a separate espionage section in charge of a full-time official, and its practice of allowing three successive violations before undertaking court action was not unrealistic, unfair or discriminatory.

5. The manufacturer did not abandon its entire fair-trade enforcement system by its dealings with a concern maintaining stores in New York City and Washington, D. C., both of which were franchised by the manufacturer as authorized retail dealers. Although the store in Washington, D. C. -- a noncontrolled trade jurisdiction -- advertised nationally, accepted mail orders and shipped the manufacturer's products to fair-trade localities at prices below established local fair-trade prices, such mail-order business done in New York by the Washington store -- amounting only to $ 260 in New York City and $ 1,000 elsewhere in the State -- had no appreciable effect upon the manufacturer's enforcement policy in New York, and the principle of de minimis non curat lex would be applicable. Moreover, the questions of whether the McGuire Act (U. S. Code, tit. 15, § 45) prevented sales from uncontrolled trade [***4] areas to fair-trade States, and whether a manufacturer's enforcement of fair-trade agreements was constitutionally limited to actions against violators located in fair-trade States, remained unsettled, and the manufacturer should not be required to assume the risk of violating antitrust laws by refusing to sell to the Washington, D. C., store because of its mail-order activities.

6. The question of whether an outfit or any combination of separate items sold as a unit is a "commodity" within the meaning and protection of the Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, § 369-a, subd. 1) should be primarily determined, among other things, by the nature of the package and of its components rather than by the fact that more than one separate item is involved. Although the statute used the word "commodity" in the singular it would seem immaterial that a group of separate items was the subject of sale, provided they were sold as a unit in an outfit and were in free and open competition, as such unit, with similar outfits.

7. Combination sales of identical or different fair-traded products of the same manufacturer at less than the sum of the fair-trade prices for the individual itmes would appear [***5] to be protected under the Fair Trade Law.

8. Where a package consisted of two or more different trade-marked and individually fair-traded articles, produced by different manufacturers, none of such manufacturers should be allowed to fair trade the combination and thus make possible a horizontal price maintenance structure by inter-manufacturer agreement which would be illegal and outside the coverage of fair trade laws.

9. The manufacturer did not violate section 2354 of the Penal Law, relating to offenses against trade-marks, by packaging an outfit, containing trade-marked products of other manufacturers in addition to its own products, in a box and cover bearing words indicating that the outfit was made and trade-marked by the manufacturer. However, under some circumstances, the Fair Trade Law should encompass an outfit containing items of different manufacture, although some were not individually fair-traded.

 

2684 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Main v. Klufus


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court of New York, Borough of Manhattan, Felony Court


1 Misc. 2d 828; 149 N.Y.S.2d 821; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2180



February 3, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, all motions on behalf of defendant are denied and defendant is found guilty as charged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss a complaint against him on the ground that New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 436-5.0(g), upon which the prosecution was based, was unconstitutional and void because it violated the constitutional guarantees protecting personal liberty and private property. Defendant also contended that § 436-5.0(g) was vague and indefinite in that it failed to provide comprehensive guides for its enforcement.


OVERVIEW: The complainant, a police officer, arrested defendant, along with three others, all seated in an automobile stolen in the State of New Jersey. A search of the car disclosed hidden under the front seat, an object substantially the same size and dimensions as a .45 calibre automatic. It was constructed of wood, painted black, containing plastic hand guards and a barrel, wholly opened, and fitted with a metal rim extending into the barrel about one inch. Defendant, a New Jersey resident, admitted he owned the pistol, which he had constructed while in service on active duty in Korea. Defendant was charged with the violation of New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 436-5.0(g). Defendant moved to dismiss the complaint and the court held that § 436-5.0(g) was constitutional. The court stated that legislation which had for its object the promotion of the public welfare and safety, fell within the scope of the police power and was required to be submitted to even though it imposed restraints and burdens on the individual. The court held that the provisions of § 436-5.0(g) were clear and readily understandable by anyone purchasing an imitation pistol.


OUTCOME: The court denied all motions on behalf of defendant and found him guilty as charged.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- possession of imitation weapon -- Administrative Code of City of New York (§ 436-5.0, subd. g) which prohibits possession of imitation weapon appearing substantially like actual weapon unless imitation be colored other than black, blue, silver or aluminum and provides barrel be closed, is enactment in furtherance of police power, constitutional, and not so vague as to be unenforcible; defendant, found in stolen car, who admitted ownership of prohibited imitation weapon, guilty of violating that provision.

1. Defendant was found in a stolen automobile and admitted ownership of an object found therein substantially of the same size and dimensions as a .45 calibre automatic, constructed of wood, painted black, containing plastic hand guards and a barrel, wholly opened, fitted with a metal rim extending into the barrel about one inch. Subdivision g of section 436-5.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York renders it unlawful for any [***2] person to sell, possess or use any imitation pistol which substantially duplicates an actual pistol unless the imitation be colored in colors other than black, blue, silver or aluminum, and further provides that the barrel be closed with the same material of which the imitation is made for a distance of not less than one-half inch from the front end of the barrel. Defendant was found guilty of violating that section.

2. The provision of the Administrative Code (§ 436-5.0, subd. g) is a constitutional exercise of the police power. It is a regulatory act which prohibits the sale, possession and use of imitation pistols, surrounding them with stringent tests as to size, color and barrel. The legislation has for its object the promotion of the public welfare and safety and must be submitted to even though imposing restraints and burdens on the individual.

3. The provision prohibits imitation pistols colored black, blue, silver or aluminum, those being the common colors of actual weapons. It does not prohibit any other color. The statute likewise provides that the barrel must be closed and plugged with over one-half inch of material. Such provisions are clear and readily understandable [***3] by anyone purchasing an imitation pistol. These limitations make the statute clear and definite and capable of being understood and enforced.

4. The State has not pre-empted the entire field by the passage of such laws as section 1894-a of the Penal Law, section 1896 of the Penal Law and section 1897 of the Penal Law, which deal with weapons in which powder in some form is used. The State has made no enactments in the field of imitation pistols which substantially duplicate actual pistols.

 

2685 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Levitt v. Sands Point


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


3 Misc. 2d 92; 148 N.Y.S.2d 798; 1956 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2224



January 18, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, an incorporated village and associated others, moved pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 106 to dismiss plaintiff property owners' amended complaint upon the ground that each of the four causes of action were insufficient in that they failed to set forth facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action in a declaratory judgment action that sought to invalidate certain amendments to the village's building zone ordinance.


OVERVIEW: The property owners owned a tract of land comprising approximately 127 acres and located in the village. The property was purchased for purposes of subdivision into one-acre residential building plots, as permitted by the zoning regulations in force at the time of the property owners acquisition and resale of the property. By a resolution adopted by the village board of trustees the zoning ordinance was amended so as to divide the village into two classes of residential districts. As a result of the amendment, the land of the property owners was placed in a district where the erection of a single family residence on a plot of ground having less than two acres was prohibited. The property owners sought a judgment declaring the ordinance, as amended, to be ineffective, unreasonable, unconstitutional, and void. The court held that the property owners stated a cause of action. The court also found the property owners' cause of action alleging that the attempted delegation of power to the appeals board was beyond the power of the village and not a valid exercise of the police powers vested in them was sufficient.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion to dismiss the property owners' amended complaint.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- action for declaratory judgment invalidating amendments to village Building Zone Ordinance; ordinance amended in 1954 so as to prohibit erection of single-family residence on plot of ground having less than two acres; cause of action seeking judgment declaring ordinance insofar as it restricts minimum plot area on plaintiffs' land to two acres to be void is sufficient where plaintiffs allege facts showing that their property is adjacent to single-family residences on plots having area of 7,500 square feet and also adjacent to multiple low-cost housing project.

1. Plaintiffs seek a declaratory judgment invalidating certain amendments to the Building Zone Ordinance of a village. Since 1951, plaintiffs owned a tract of land of 127 acres in the village. The tract was situated in a residence district, and the ordinance permitted single-family detached dwellings with the minimum lot area of one acre in such district. On April 27, 1954, the Building Zone Ordinance was amended (effective in May, 1954) so as to prohibit the erection of a single-family residence on a plot of ground having less than two acres [***2] in the district in which plaintiffs' tract was located. In January and February, 1954, plaintiffs had engaged in negotiations with a corporation for the sale to it of the tract, and buyer and seller incurred expenses in the preparation of tentative plans for subdividing the land into one-acre plots for appraisals, etc. On March 8, 1954, the property was sold to the buyer who paid a deposit. Three days before the making of this contract, newspaper notice was given of a special meeting of the village Board of Trustees to be held on March 22, 1954 to consider the amendment of the Building Zone Ordinance which would require a minimum area of two acres per plot for residential purposes. The published notice did not come to the attention of plaintiffs or of the buyer until after the date on which the contract of sale was signed. Thereafter, the board adopted the amendment and the buyer disaffirmed the contract of sale. Plaintiffs, in their first cause of action, seek a judgment declaring the Building Zone Ordinance, insofar as it restricts the minimum plot area on plaintiffs' land to two acres, to be void on the ground that opposite their property land is developed with small single-family [***3] residences on plots having a maximum area of 7,500 square feet and that further south, on the opposite side of the highway abutting plaintiffs' property, the land is improved with a multiple low-cost housing project. The first cause of action alleges sufficient facts to question the validity of the ordinance inasmuch as such question turns on whether plaintiffs' property is so situated, in the light of the character of the surrounding neighborhood, that up-zoning is confiscatory and operates to deprive plaintiffs of their property without due process of law.

2. The second cause of action alleges that the adoption of the amendment with knowledge of the contract of sale and of the expenses incurred by both parties to the contract deprives plaintiffs of their property and contract rights without due process of law. That, by reason of the adoption of the amendment, plaintiffs may have suffered a depreciation in value of their property because of the restrictions placed on its use does not render the ordinance void. Accordingly, the second cause of action should be dismissed.

3. In the third cause of action plaintiffs seek a judgment declaring that other amendments which conferred [***4] on the Board of Appeals power to grant permits to engage in the business of building houses for resale are void. Section 175 of the Village Law, which gives a board of trustees of a village power to legislate on matters of zoning, does not authorize it to license persons for the purpose of engaging in the building business or to delegate such a power to the board of appeals. The motion to dismiss the third cause of action is denied.

4. Plaintiffs, in their fourth cause of action, allege that the amendment to the zoning ordinance adopted in April, 1954 is without force because of the failure of the village to comply with certain procedural requirements in its enactment. Chapter 556 of the Laws of 1955 validates zoning ordinances adopted pursuant to the Village Law (art. 6-a) even though there has been a failure to post the ordinance or to publish it or the map adopted in connection therewith. The allegations of the complaint, however, go beyond the question of posting and publication, for the complaint also alleges that the Board of Trustees failed to prepare an amended map and this is not covered by the curative statute. The motion to dismiss said cause of action is denied.

 

2686 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Greenbaum v. New York City Housing Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


4 Misc. 2d 781; 147 N.Y.S.2d 315; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2140



December 16, 1955 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion for a temporary injunction is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In their action for a declaratory judgment, plaintiff tenants filed a motion for a temporary injunction and defendant landlord filed a cross-motion to dismiss the complaint for insufficiency. Previously, a final order was issued in the Municipal Court, Borough of Manhattan, Second District (New York) against the tenants and in favor of the landlord in a holdover proceeding.


OVERVIEW: The landlord discovered that the tenant made more money than he had declared, and had been living in a federally-funded, low income housing project. The landlord began termination proceedings. The municipal court issued a final order in favor of the landlord in a holdover proceeding. A stay of the execution warrant was ordered. The tenants sought a declaratory judgment, and the landlord filed a cross-motion to dismiss. The court granted the landlord's cross-motion. The court found that the landlord was permitted to terminate the tenants' lease for misrepresentations under New York City Housing Authority Resolution No. 53-3-185, § 2.01c. The court found that the jural relationship between the parties had already been decided by the municipal court, and denied the tenants' motion for a temporary injunction.


OUTCOME: The court granted the landlord's cross-motion to dismiss and denied the tenants' motion for a temporary injunction in the tenants' action for a declaratory judgment.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- public housing -- summary proceeding by municipal housing authority -- municipal housing authority may dispossess tenant on any ground authorized by its governing statute or regulations (State Residential Rent Law, § 5, subd. 4) -- New York City Housing Authority adopted resolution (Public Housing Law, § 37, subd. 1, par. [w]; § 54) specifying grounds for eviction, including tenant's misrepresentation; authority found that tenant had misrepresented income; he did not seek review (under Civ. Prac. Act, art. 78); in Municipal Court summary proceeding he contended that he could not be evicted, because his income was within limit allowed by Public Housing Law ( § 156, subds. 3, 4); final order against tenant was not appealed; issues were thus adjudicated, and tenant's present action for judgment declaring resolution invalid is dismissed.

1. A municipal housing authority may maintain summary dispossess proceedings against a tenant upon any ground authorized by its governing statute or regulations (State Residential Rent Law, § 5, subd. 4; L. 1946, ch. 274, as amd.).

2. Pursuant to the authority [***2] of the Public Housing Law ( § 37, subd. 1, par. [w]; §§ 54, 220) the New York City Housing Authority adopted a resolution No. 53-3-185, specifying grounds for eviction. One of the grounds is misrepresentation by the tenant. The tenants in the development in this case were given written one-month leases, renewable from month to month and terminable on one month's notice. The rent was determined by the number of rooms, the income of the family, and the size of the family. A tenant misrepresented his income, and thus was given a lease of an apartment at a much lower rental than he should have paid, although his true income was within the permissible limits for that size of apartment and family (Public Housing Law, § 156). The housing authority investigated, made a finding of tenant's misrepresentation, served an appropriate notice on the tenant of termination of his monthly tenancy, and then instituted a holdover summary dispossess proceeding in Municipal Court. The tenant contested the legal sufficiency of the petition and then the proceeding itself, contending that the authority must establish that it had complied with the Public Housing Law ( § 156, subds. 3, 4) relating to [***3] excess-income tenants. Tenant's contentions were overruled, and a final order of dispossess was issued, but stayed. Tenant then instituted this action in the New York Supreme Court for a judgment declaring that, under the Public Housing Law ( §§ 2, 37, 156), the authority's resolution authorizing eviction for misrepresentation is unconstitutional and void, and that the monthly lease is invalid, and that the sole possible ground for eviction in this case is excess income. The authority's motion to dismiss the complaint is granted.

3. The jural relations of plaintiff and defendant have been adjudicated. No proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act was instituted to review the authority's finding and determination. No further appeals were taken from the court orders. Implicit in the order upholding the sufficiency of the petition and in the final order of dispossess were adjudications that the monthly lease was valid and that the Municipal Court had jurisdiction. The present action is therefore dismissed.

 

2687 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Del Gardo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court of New York, Borough of Manhattan, Upper Manhattan Court


1 Misc. 2d 821; 146 N.Y.S.2d 350; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2200



December 1, 1955 



DISPOSITION: The complaint is dismissed and the defendant is discharged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State charged defendant with violating New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 436-5. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that § 436-5 was unconstitutional and conflicted with N.Y. Penal Law § 1894-a because the state pre-empted the entire field with respect to the sale, use, and possession of toy cap and imitation pistols, and the ordinance did not set up standards that adequately defined the crime. The court determined that the ordinance interdicted without exception that which was permitted by state law, and was thus inconsistent with the state law. An ordinance that conflicted with a state law of general character and statewide application was invalid. The court further determined that the state had preempted the entire field relating to toy guns. Therefore, the ordinance was invalid. The court dismissed the indictment and discharged defendant.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss, dismissed the complaint, and discharged defendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sale or possession of imitation weapon -- toy pistols -- ordinances -- constitutional law -- ordinance prohibiting sale or possession of toy or imitation pistol unless barrel closed and distinctively colored (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 436-5.0, subd. g) unconstitutional and void, since it conflicted with field pre-empted by State laws ( Penal Law, §§ 1894-a, 1897, 1898).

1. A city ordinance which provides that "It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, possess or use or attempt to use or give away, any toy or imitation pistol or revolver which substantially duplicates an actual pistol or revolver, unless said imitation or toy pistol or revolver shall be colored in colors other than black, blue, silver or aluminum, and further provided that the barrel of said toy or imitation pistol or revolver shall be closed with the same material of which the toy or imitation pistol or revolver is made for a distance of not less than one-half inch from the front end of said barrel" (Administrative Code of City of New [***2] York, § 436-5.0, subd. g) is unconstitutional and void.

2. The ordinance conflicts with a State-wide law which defines and regulates "fireworks" but which excludes therefrom "toy pistols * * * or other devices in which paper caps" containing a stipulated amount of explosive compound "are used, * * * the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times" ( Penal Law, § 1894-a, subd. 1, par. [a]).

3. The ordinance purports to enter a field already pre-empted by State-wide legislation. In addition to section 1894-a, above quoted, the Penal Law provides that a person who attempts "to use against another an imitation pistol * * * or who, with intent to use the same unlawfully against another, carries or possesses a * * * imitation pistol" is guilty of a crime (§ 1897) and that "The possession, by any person other than a public officer, of any of the weapons, instruments or appliances specified in sections eighteen hundred and ninety-seven * * * except as permitted therein, is presumptive evidence of carrying, concealing or possessing with intent to use the same in violation of this article" (§ 1898). It has been held that this statutory presumption is rebuttable. The ordinance [***3] as promulgated by the city makes lawful the possession of any imitation or toy pistol or revolver if the same meets the requirements of the ordinance. Under this ordinance a potential robber and mugger may without fear of arrest carry a toy or imitation pistol or revolver until he has the time or opportunity to carry out his nefarious act. The ordinance, furthermore, may conceivably deprive children of playthings. Thus there is a direct conflict with State law and policy under sections 1894-a, 1897 and 1898 of the Penal Law. The State law, of course, must prevail.

4. The home rule provisions (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 12; City Home Rule Law, § 11, subd. 2) do not empower cities to supersede the general criminal law of the State.

 

2688 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Greene v. Holz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part III


148 N.Y.S.2d 291; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3908



December 1, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant superintendent of insurance (superintendent) moved to dismiss plaintiff trustees' complaint on the grounds that no justiciable controversy existed, that the trustees were seeking an advisory opinion, and that the court should decline jurisdiction in its discretion. The trustees brought suit for a declaration that federal labor law preempted welfare benefit provisions in collective bargaining agreements in interstate industries.


OVERVIEW: The trustees were ultimately seeking a declaration that the state insurance law did not apply to them and that the trustees could establish and operate a non-insured welfare program in compliance with the Labor Management Relations Act, Taft-Hartley Law, 28 U.S.C.S. § 141 et seq., without being subject to the superintendent's jurisdiction. The court agreed with the superintendent and granted the superintendent's motion to dismiss the trustees' complaint. The court held that what was being requested by the trustees was an advisory opinion and that the declaratory remedy could not be invoked for such a purpose.


OUTCOME: The superintendent's motion for dismissal of the trustees' complaint was granted.

 

2689 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pomeranz v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


1 Misc. 2d 486; 151 N.Y.S.2d 789; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2238



November 15, 1955 



DISPOSITION: The complaint is, accordingly, dismissed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, owner of a garage, filed an action for declaratory judgment against defendant city and challenged the constitutionality of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-250.0 et seq. and the rules promulgated thereunder for the licensing and regulation of garages and parking lots within the city.


OVERVIEW: New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B32-250.0 et seq. required the owner of a garage to obtain a license, to file with the commission of licenses a schedule of rates showing the prices charged, and to post at the public entrance a sign setting forth the schedule of rates charged. The local law prohibited the licensee from making any charges in excess of the rates set forth in the schedule, except upon filing and posting of an amended schedule of rates that would be effective 60 days from the filing. The court found that the regulation of garages was properly within the sphere of legislative power of the city as defined by the state constitution, the City Home Rule Law and the New York City Charter. The court held that the findings of the city council's committee on general welfare as to the abuses that were prevalent prior to the enactment of the § B32-250.0 et seq. made it abundantly clear that the regulation of garages had a substantial relation to the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. The court concluded that the specific provisions under attack did not offend either the federal or the state constitutions and constituted a valid exercise of the police power.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the garage owner's complaint and held that the local law and the rules and regulations challenged were constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- police power -- New York City -- licensing and regulation of garages and parking lots -- declaratory judgment -- (1) local law of City of New York providing for licensing and regulating garages and parking lots (1947, No. 61; Administrative Code, § B32-250.0 et seq.) within legislative power of city and offended neither State nor Federal Constitution -- (2) action by owner of garage and parking lot for declaratory judgment, wherein constitutionality of local law and rules promulgated thereunder were challenged; declaratory judgment would not be withheld on ground that issues could have been and were raised in criminal prosecution against plaintiff for failure conspicuously to display price sign as required by local law; broad question presented in action for declaratory judgment with regard to constitutionality of entire statute not before City Magistrate in criminal proceeding; declaratory judgment would be inappropriate only if all issues could be determined in already pending action; moreover, possible existence of other methods to test validity of local  [***2] law did not per se preclude plaintiff from resorting to action for declaratory judgment.

1. A local law of the City of New York providing for licensing and regulating garages and parking lots (1947, No. 61; Administrative Code, § B32-250.0 et seq.), enacted after a public hearing revealing a shortage of garage and parking space of emergency proportions and widespread rate-gouging and other abuses, had a substantial relation to the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. The local law was within the legislative power of the city as defined by the State Constitution (art. IX, § 12), the City Home Rule Law (§ 11, subd. 2) and the New York City Charter (§ 27), which conferred upon the City Council broad legislative power to provide by local law for the preservation and promotion of the health, safety and general welfare of the city's inhabitants, and offended neither the State nor the Federal Constitution.

2. In an action by an owner of a garage and parking lot for a declaratory judgment, wherein the constitutionality of the local law and rules promulgated thereunder were challenged, declaratory judgment would not be withheld on the ground that the issues could have [***3] been and were raised in a criminal prosecution against plaintiff for failure conspicuously to display a price sign as required by the local law (Administrative Code, § B32-254.0), and that plaintiff's remedy was by appeal from the judgment of conviction rendered therein. The City Magistrate before whom plaintiff was tried declined to pass upon the constitutionality of the statute for the reason that the violation with which plaintiff was charged was too narrow and limited in scope to warrant such consideration. The broad question presented in the action for a declaratory judgment with regard to the constitutionality of the entire statute was not before the City Magistrate. Declaratory judgment would be inappropriate only if all the issues could be determined in an already pending action. Moreover, the possible existence of other methods to test the validity of the local law involved did not per se preclude plaintiff from resorting to an action for a declaratory judgment.

 

2690 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Nehrbas v. Lloyd Harbor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


147 N.Y.S.2d 738; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3210



November 7, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowners filed an action against defendants, a village, its mayor, and members of the board of trustees (village), to permanently enjoin the village from using its property for municipal purposes and to declare a zoning ordinance void and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The village enacted the ordinance that placed the entire village in a single residence district and eliminated the business section. The village purchased property across from the landowners and proposed to build a meeting place, courtroom, and quarters for its highway employees and highway equipment. The landowners claimed that the ordinance was unconstitutional and that the village's use of the property was offensive and a nuisance. The court granted in part the landowners' request for an injunction. The court held that the village had a right to determine its zoning, that the village exercised its legislative power, that the ordinance was not unconstitutional, and that the village did not violate any restrictive covenants in the deed by which the village acquired its property. The court held, however, that although the village's use of the property for a meeting place and a courtroom were governmental in character and could not be enjoined, the use of the property for the storage and maintenance of garbage trucks, highway equipment, and quarters for highway employees constituted a proprietary function, which use was subject to an injunction because it constituted a nuisance.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landowners' request for an injunction as to the constitutionality of the ordinance, as to the village's violation of the restrictive covenants, and as to the village's use of the property for the meeting place and the courtroom. The court permanently enjoined the village from using the property for the maintenance of highway equipment and quarters for highway employees.

 

2691 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Iasilli v. Nadler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court of New York, Borough of Manhattan, Municipal Term


1 Misc. 2d 31; 146 N.Y.S.2d 35; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2282



October 21, 1955 



DISPOSITION: On all the foregoing, the court finds that the statute is based upon real and substantial distinction, bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect to which such classification is imposed, that the statute is a valid exercise of the police power of the municipality, and that its enforcement is proper, and accordingly finds the defendant guilty as charged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff fire department, an agency of the City, charged defendant attorney with maintaining a refrigerating system in his office without a permit from the fire department, in violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § C19-96.0(c).


OVERVIEW: The fire department, in its capacity of an enforcement agency, contended that it had the right to require a permit for a water cooler in the attorney's office pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § C19-97.0. The court found that the fire department had a right to pass laws for the well being, protection, and the advancement of the City's inhabitants, and prescribe for the enforcement requirements of a proper license or permit. The attorney asserted that he was discriminated against in that while the code made unlawful the maintenance or operation of any refrigerating system in an office without a permit, it did not require a permit for it when maintained or operated in the residence portion of a dwelling. The court found that the attorney was not under different restrictions as those in his own class, for the exemptions from a permit herein were not to other lawyers or businesses but to a residence. The court concluded that the statute was based upon a real and substantial distinction in classification, that the statute was a valid exercise of the police power of the fire department, and that its enforcement was proper, and accordingly found the attorney guilty as charged.


OUTCOME: The court found that the attorney was guilty of maintaining a refrigerating system in his office without a permit from the fire department as required.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- equal protection of laws -- (1) provision of New York City Administrative Code (§ C19-96.0) requiring permit for refrigerating system of class embracing water coolers, except when maintained in dwelling containing not more than two families or in residence portion of tenement house or business building, not invalid as class legislation -- (2) that municipal department charged with administration of code provision made no periodic or regular inspection did not render provision invalid -- (3) City Magistrate's Court empowered to determine constitutionality of provision.

1. A provision of the Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ C19-96.0) requiring a permit for the maintenance or operation of a refrigerating [***2] system of a certain class embracing water coolers, except when maintained or operated in the residence portion of a dwelling containing not more than two families, or in the residence portion of either a tenement house or a business building, was not class legislation and for that reason invalid as to an attorney who maintained a water cooler in his office. The provision required a permit for the maintenance of a water cooler in all places where business was conducted and was based upon a real and substantial distinction, bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect to which classification was imposed and was a valid exercise of the police power of the municipality.

2. That the municipal department charged with administration of the code provision made no periodic or regular inspection did not render the provision invalid.

3. The City Magistrate's Court of New York was empowered to determine the issue of the constitutionality of the provision.

 

2692 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Peka v. Kaye


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Bronx County


208 Misc. 1003; 145 N.Y.S.2d 156; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3299



October 14, 1955 



DISPOSITION: The motion is accordingly granted and the third-party complaint dismissed. Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A jury awarded damages to third party pilot's wife for injuries she sustained in a plane crash. Third-party defendant insurer, in the name of a corporation, filed an action against the pilot to recover the money paid to the wife in satisfaction of the jury verdict. The pilot filed a third-party action against the insurer alleging that the insurer was required to indemnify him if the corporation recovered a judgment against him.


OVERVIEW: The wife was injured in a plane, which was piloted by her husband and owned by a corporation. The insurer's motion to dismiss the pilot's third-party action was based upon N.Y. Ins. Law § 167(3), which excluded from insurance coverage any liability of an assured because of death or injuries to his spouse. On appeal, the court granted the insurer's motion to dismiss. The court reasoned that there wold be no point in the insurer continuing its action if the pilot's complaint was sustained because the insurer would be required to indemnify him for the very liability it sought to assert against him in the action against the corporation. The court also found that to permit the pilot to claim over against the insurer because it was the corporation rather that his wife who happened to be the plaintiff in an action against him for negligent causation of her injuries would be to honor form over substance.


OUTCOME: The court granted the insurer's motion to dismiss the pilot's third-party indemnity action.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- aircraft liability insurance -- exclusion of coverage for injuries to spouse -- injuries to spouse -- (1) Insurance Law ( § 167, subd. 3), excluding from coverage any liability of assured for death or injuries to "his or her spouse * * * unless express provision relating specifically thereto is included in the policy", applicable to policy issued by foreign insurer, not licensed in New York, providing for indemnification of individual and corporate assured for sums which they should become liable to pay for injuries to passengers in airplane owned by corporate assured; wife of individual assured was paid sum of money by insurer in satisfaction of judgment obtained by her against corporate assured for personal injuries suffered by her when plane, piloted by husband, crashed; no obligation imposed upon insurer to defend, on behalf of individual assured, later action brought in name of corporate assured to recover sums paid in wife's action -- (2) statute (Insurance Law, § 167, subd. 3) excludes policy coverage whenever indemnification  [***2] is asked by husband because of injuries to wife as result of his negligence -- (3) policy not removed from operation of Insurance Law ( § 167, subd. 3) because foreign insurer issued policy through Montreal office and delivered it in this State -- (4) provision in policy whereby insurer agreed, at assured's request, to submit to jurisdiction of any court within United States, constituted voluntary submission of insurer and negatived any contention of nonapplicability of statute.

1. Subdivision 3 of section 167 of the Insurance Law, which excludes from insurance coverage "any liability of an assured because of the death or injuries to his or her spouse * * * unless express provision relating specifically thereto is included in the policy", was applicable to an aircraft and aviation insurance policy issued by a foreign insurer, not licensed in New York, providing for indemnification of an individual and a corporation, of which the individual was an officer, against all sums which they should become legally liable to pay as compensation for injuries to passengers while being carried in an airplane owned by the corporation. Where the wife of the individual assured was paid a sum of [***3] money by the insurer in satisfaction of a judgment obtained by her against the corporate assured for personal injuries suffered by her when the plane piloted by her husband crashed, there was no obligation on the insurer to defend, on behalf of the individual assured, a later action brought in the name of the corporate assured to recover from the individual assured the sum paid to his wife in satisfaction of the judgment, plus fees and expenses incurred in the defense of her action.

2. Exclusion from policy coverage results, under the language of the statute, whenever indemnification is asked by a husband whose liability, regardless of the form in which or person by whom asserted, is basically and unquestionably, because of injuries sustained by his wife as a result of his negligence. Courts may not lend themselves to an indirect avoidance of, or a flank attack upon, a law whose purpose is to protect against collusive actions between husbands and wives.

3. The policy was not removed from the operation of subdivision 3 of section 167 of the Insurance Law because the foreign insurer issued the policy through its Montreal office and delivered it in this State. The expression, "issued [***4] or delivered in this State", in the opening paragraph of section 167 of the Insurance Law carries out the legislative intent to hold policies delivered by foreign insurers to New York residents to be subject to our laws in the same manner and to the same degree as those issued here by domestic insurers. To compel submission of unlicensed foreign insurers to our courts under section 59-a of the Insurance Law, but to deny the protection of subdivision 3 of section 167 to such insurers delivering policies in this State, would be unconstitutional.

4. A provision in the policy to the effect that, the insurer would at the assured's request, submit to the jurisdiction of any court within the United States, constituted a voluntary submission on the part of the insurer and negatived any possible contention of nonapplicability of the statute.

 

2693 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Wilson v. Denno


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


145 N.Y.S.2d 175; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3302



September 16, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner in a habeas corpus proceeding contended that he was illegally detained after his conviction for rape in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 2010(3) and his sentence of an indeterminate term, the minimum of which was to be one day and the maximum was to be for the duration of his natural life.


OVERVIEW: After petitioner's conviction for rape in the first degree, he was sentenced to an indeterminate term ranging from one day to life in prison. Petitioner, in a habeas corpus proceeding, contended that he was illegally detained. The court disagreed and remanded petitioner. The court found that an indeterminate sentence was in effect a sentence for the maximum term. Because parole was not a right but an act of grace, the sentencing court, in imposing an indeterminate sentence, had to be deemed to have sentenced the prisoner to his maximum term, subject to the discretionary power of the board of parole to grant him parole. Therefore, petitioner was lawfully detained in prison rather than jail. The court concluded that it was within the power of the legislature to require that a report as to petitioner's condition be furnished only to the sentencing judge, and not to petitioner, in order that the judge could determine which of the two forms of sentence should be imposed. In a habeas corpus proceeding, petitioner could not argue that the evidence against him was insufficient.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the writ and remanded petitioner.

 

2694 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York State Trailer Coach Asso. v. Steckel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Equity Term, Monroe County


208 Misc. 308; 144 N.Y.S.2d 82; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2955



September 2, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a trailer association and persons similarly situated, brought an action for a declaratory judgment against defendants, a town, a county and a state, in a real property tax dispute.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs sought a declaration that N.Y. Tax Law § 2(6-a) was unconstitutional. Plaintiffs argued that the law should be declared invalid because it was it violated N.Y. Const. art. 1, § 6, was in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, was indefinite and ambiguous, and was incapable of fair administration. The court concluded that (1) calling real estate such mobile property as a 60-day trailer compelled action on the part of the taxing district which in one way or another was a denial of due process and the equal protection of the laws; (2) the tax laws on real property were designed to apply to property which had some measure of permanent location in the tax district; and (3) to try to bring within the definition of real property a 60-day trailer, as provided in the Tax Law amendment under attack, was to lead inevitably to situations denying to citizens due process of law and equal protection of the laws as guaranteed in both Federal and State Constitutions.


OUTCOME: The court declared the New York tax law invalid.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- house trailers as real property -- (1) occupied trailers defined by Tax Law ( § 2, subd. 6-a) as real property for tax purposes if located within tax district 60 days or more; statute invalid as leading inevitably to situations denying due process of law and equal protection of laws in violation of Federal and State Constitutions (U.S. Const., 14th Amendt.; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6) -- (2) "60-day trailers" lack permanency, inherent in realty, characteristic of other property defined as real estate -- (3) State may tax trailers but may not, by calling them something they are not, impose taxes on those who do not own them; statutory definition and provisions (Tax Law, § 9) that property be assessed according to ownership in tax district where located and be liable for any tax levied against it will compel tax district action which will be denial of due process and equal protection of laws.

1. Subdivision 6-a of section 2 of the Tax Law (added by L. 1954, ch. 726), which declares occupied trailers to be real property for tax purposes if such trailers have been located within the boundaries of a tax district for 60 days [***2] or more, is invalid as in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions (U.S. Const., 14th Amendt.; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6). This attempt to bring a "60-day trailer" within the definition of real property will lead inevitably to situations denying to citizens due process of law and the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by both Federal and State Constitutions.

2. Wharves, piers, railroads and other similar items of property which have been legislatively declared to be real property for tax purposes have the characteristic of permanency inherent in real property which a "60-day trailer", within the statutory definition, lacks.

3. Section 9 of the Tax Law provides that real property shall be assessed according to its condition and ownership in the tax district in which the property is situated and that the property itself shall be liable for any tax levied upon it. The State may not, by calling trailers something which they are not, impose taxes upon people who do not own them. Although trailers are like automobiles and other property subject to State taxation, defining as real estate such mobile property as a "60-day trailer" will compel action by the taxing district [***3] which, in one way or another, will be a denial of due process and the equal protection of the laws.

 

2695 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Consolidated Edison Co. v. Briarcliff Manor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


208 Misc. 295; 144 N.Y.S.2d 379; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3752; 11 P.U.R.3d 46



August 2, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner electric public utility corporation sought to review, reverse, and annul a decision by respondents, village zoning board of appeals and building inspector, that denied the corporation a variance to erect and maintain a high-tension electric transmission line through a residential district in the village. In the alternative, the utility corporation sought an order of mandamus directing the village to issue the necessary permit.


OVERVIEW: The utility corporation had earlier acquired a continuous strip of land for its proposed line running through the village. Subsequently, the village adopted a zoning ordinance that made the strip lie within a zoned residential area. The village board of appeals then denied the public utility the right to erect a transmission line through the strip. On appeal, the court ruled that when the only bar to a building permit was a certain ordinance provision prohibiting the proposed use of the particular premises, and the owner would be entitled to permit as a matter of right except for such provision, the validity of the provision could be challenged and issue determined in an N.Y. art. 78 proceeding to obtain an order directing the issuance of the permit. The court ruled the provisions of the village's zoning ordinance were invalid insofar as they absolutely prohibited the utility corporation from constructing and maintaining through the village a publicly needed high-tension electric line. The court held the ordinance provisions offended the due process and equal protection clause of the U.S. and state constitutions and could not stand as authorized by police power.


OUTCOME: The court found there was no issue of fact requiring a trial and ordered the issuance of the building permit sought by the utility corporation.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- variance for erection of electric transmission line -- (1) village zoning ordinance pertaining to residence district forbade erection of electric transmission lines; village board of appeals correctly denied variance to electric corporation for purpose of erecting line where situation was not one of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship justifying variance -- (2) in proceeding to review determination of board of zoning appeals denying variance, or in alternative to direct issuance of permit for erection of transmission lines, question of validity of zoning ordinance properly came before court -- (3) where electric corporation had duty to provide service under State law and there was necessity for public utility improvement proposed, village could not interfere, in absence of express grant of authority, with State law and policy by adoption of zoning ordinance; zoning ordinance invalid to extent that construction and maintenance of hightension electric line through village was prohibited; respondents directed to issue construction permit -- (4) zoning ordinance violated electric  [***2] corporation's constitutional right to equal protection of laws and due process of law -- (5) village could not exclude line from village; location of line not subject to dictate of village; local regulation of corporation to alleviate private damage caused by utility installation permissible.

1. An "electric corporation" (Public Service Law, § 2) and "gas and electric corporation" (Transportation Corporations Law, § 10) furnishing electric power generally throughout a county sought from a village therein whose zoning ordinance prohibited the erection of high-tension electric lines in a residence district, a variance permitting it to erect a portion of such a line through the village so that it might complete the line. All other municipalities affected had granted permission for the erection of such line. Such corporation was the owner of, or had easements over, a continuous strip of land not less than 200 feet in width for the 4,000-foot segment of its proposed line running through the village. The lands so acquired lay wholly within a residence district. A determination of the village zoning board of appeals denying the variance was correct. There was nothing in the record [***3] tending to establish that its determination was arbitrary or unreasonable. The board correctly held that the situation was not one of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship justifying a variance.

2. In an article 78 proceeding to annul the determination of the village board of appeals denying a variance, or in the alternative, to secure an order directing respondents to issue the necessary permit, the question of whether the ordinance was valid properly came before the court. The board was not a court and could not pass on the constitutionality or legality of the zoning ordinance under which it was authorized to act. Where the only bar to the permit was the ordinance provision, that provision was properly reviewable in the article 78 proceeding.

3. The undisputed facts showed the necessity for the public utility improvement proposed by the corporation. Subdivision 1 of section 65 of the Public Service Law mandated that petitioner should "furnish and provide such service, instrumentalities and facilities". Since petitioner had the franchise and also a duty, subject to reasonable regulation, to erect and maintain the proposed transmission line, no local government might,  [***4] without unequivocal and express statutory authority, enact a local ordinance tending to contravene State law and policy with respect to such utility. The general grant of power to a municipality to adopt zoning laws in the interest of the public welfare did not permit the local legislative body to override such State law and policy. Accordingly, the village zoning ordinance was invalid to the extent that it absolutely forbade petitioner from constructing and maintaining through the village a publicly needed high-tension electric line. Respondents were directed to issue the permit subject to the imposition by the proper authorities of proper regulations.

4. Moreover, the ordinance was invalid as in derogation of the electric corporation's constitutional rights. Provisions of a zoning ordinance restricting the use of lands by a landowner and not tending to promote the public interest and general welfare may not be justified as a proper exercise of the police power. The village ordinance, standing in the way of the erection of a necessary public utility development, was contrary to the general welfare. Such zoning ordinance, as to petitioner corporation, was unconstitutional as [***5] violating the due process and equal protection clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions and could not stand as authorized by the police power.

5. The village did not have the right to exclude the proposed electric transmission line from the village. It was not the prerogative of the village to dictate where the line should be located and the discretionary powers of the electric utility in that respect could not be questioned by local authorities and were not subject to court supervision, provided it acted in good faith and in accordance with valid regulations. Reasonable local regulation of public utilities was permissible to alleviate as much as possible private damage and annoyance caused by utility installations.

 

2696 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Weixel v. New York City Housing Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


208 Misc. 246; 143 N.Y.S.2d 589; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2877



July 28, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tenants filed a motion for a temporary injunction restraining defendant city housing authority from evicting them from a federally aided housing project, pending the final determination of their action against the authority. The tenants sought a judgment declaring that the authority could not terminate their lease and an injunction restraining the authority from taking steps toward termination. The authority requested a dismissal.


OVERVIEW: The tenants alleged that the housing authority requested them to sign a certain certificate pursuant to a rider to an appropriation bill, known as the Gwinn Amendment, 42 U.S.C.S. § 1411c, passed by the Congress of the United States. The amendment required, as a condition of occupancy in federally aided housing projects, that tenants sign a certificate of non-membership in organizations designated as subversive by the Attorney General of the United States. Upon the tenants' refusal to sign the certificate, the authority advised the tenants that because of such refusal it elected to terminate their occupancy. The court found that the authority was authorized to terminate the tenants' occupancy. The court granted the authority's motion to dismiss the complaint and denied the tenants' motion for a temporary injunction restraining the authority from evicting the tenants. A previous decision was binding on the court through the doctrine of stare decisis. The danger that the Congress sought to avoid justified the requirement that tenants choose between government housing and membership in an organization that they knew to have been found subversive by the attorney general.


OUTCOME: The court found that the housing authority was authorized to terminate the tenants' occupancy in the federally aided housing project in which they resided. The court granted the authority's motion to dismiss the complaint. The court denied the tenants' motion for a temporary injunction restraining the authority from evicting the tenants from the federally aided housing project.


HEADNOTES

Public housing -- Gwinn Amendment -- eviction from federally-aided housing project for failure to sign certificate of nonmembership in subversive group -- (1) plaintiffs are tenants in low-rent housing project constructed in part with Federal funds; Gwinn Amendment (U. S. Code, tit. 42, § 1411c) requires as condition of occupancy in Federally-aided housing project that tenant sign certificate of nonmembership in organizations designated as subversive by Attorney General; plaintiffs refused to sign such certificate and defendant housing authority elected to terminate plaintiffs' tenancy; in action to restrain defendant from effectuating termination of tenancy, defendant entitled to judgment dismissing complaint -- (2) court takes jurisdiction of plaintiffs' action since declaratory judgment is appropriate remedy where constitutional questions are involved and no question of fact present -- (3) determinations in another proceeding that Gwinn Amendment applicable to low-rent Federal housing projects administered  [***2] by Public Housing Administration and that defendant has power to evict tenants for failure to sign certificate do not bar plaintiffs from maintaining present action; plaintiffs not bound by prior proceeding, which as to them, did not constitute another action pending between same parties for same cause justifying dismissal under Rules of Civil Practice (rule 107) -- (4) defendant's resolution requiring tenants in such low-rent, federally-aided housing project to sign certificate of nonmembership was within authority of defendant.

1. Plaintiffs, husband and wife, are tenants in a low-rent housing project constructed in part with Federal funds. Under the Gwinn Amendment (U. S. Code, tit. 42, § 1411c) it is a condition of occupancy in Federally-aided housing projects that the tenant sign a certificate of nonmembership in organizations designated as subversive by the Attorney General of the United States. Plaintiffs have refused to sign such certificate of nonmembership and defendant housing authority has advised plaintiffs that because of such refusal it elected to terminate their occupancy as of July 31, 1955. In this action for judgment declaring that defendant has no authority [***3] to terminate their lease, defendant is entitled to judgment dismissing the complaint and plaintiffs' motion for a temporary injunction restraining defendant from taking steps to evict them from the apartment is denied.

2. In a case such as this where constitutional questions are involved and there is totally lacking any question of fact, the court, in the exercise of discretion, should take jurisdiction of the subject matter of the action, for the remedy of declaratory judgment is peculiarly appropriate.

3. In another proceeding entitled Matter of Peters v. New York City Housing Auth. it was ruled that the Gwinn Amendment was applicable to all "low-rent" Federal housing projects administered by the Public Housing Administration, that the list of organizations furnished by the Attorney General was in accordance with the Gwinn Amendment, and that defendant authority was authorized as a condition of occupancy in federally-aided projects to require tenants to sign certificates of nonmembership in organizations designated by the Attorney General pursuant to Executive Order No. 10450. The determination in that case and the pendency of an appeal therein do not bar plaintiffs from [***4] maintaining this action. They were not and are not parties to those proceedings and such proceedings do not constitute as to plaintiffs "another action pending between the same parties for the same cause" (Rules Civ. Prac., rule 107), nor are such prior adjudications binding upon plaintiffs as res judicata.

4. The determinations in such prior proceeding do constitute stare decisis and are binding on this court. Since plaintiffs in their complaint have alleged that the premises in which they have an apartment constitute part of a low-rent housing project constructed in part with Federal funds, there is no question that such project is a low-rent Federal housing project administered by the Public Housing Administration to which the Gwinn Amendment applies. Defendant's resolution requiring tenants in such housing project to sign certificates of nonmembership in such designated organizations was within its authority.

 

2697 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Nickas v. Long Beach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County, Part I


144 N.Y.S.2d 60; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2946



July 15, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff lessee filed a motion to enjoin defendants, a city and various county officials, from prosecuting or threatening to prosecute him for violations of a county health ordinance during the pendency of his action for a permanent injunction restraining enforcement of the ordinance.


OVERVIEW: The lessee operated a small refreshment stand by virtue of a lease from the city. After defendants sought to enforce a county health ordinance requiring that the lessee's stand be equipped with washing facilities and separate toilets for the sexes employed therein, the lessee filed suit to restrain enforcement of the ordinance, alleging that it was arbitrary and unreasonable as applied to him and unconstitutional. The lessee also sought a temporary injunction. While his application was pending, the lessee was served with a summons for his violation of the ordinance, returnable in the district court.
