The court held that the lessee was not entitled to a temporary injunction during the pendency of his action because: (1) there was no justification for the lessee's continued violation of the ordinance; (2) there was a public health ordinance involved, and, thus, all the problems in the action demanded a speedy resolution; and (3) every allegation of the lessee's complaint as to the unconstitutionality of the ordinance could be advanced as a defense to the proceeding pending in the district court, which had the power to consider them as fully as had the court.


OUTCOME: The court denied the lessee's motion for a temporary injunction.

 

2698 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


North Hempstead v. White


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


1 Misc. 2d 228; 144 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2340



July 13, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a town and a neighboring landowner, filed an action against defendant dentist to enjoin the dentist from leasing medical offices in a medical center attached to his residence. The dentist filed counterclaims to restrain plaintiffs from interfering with his use of the medical center and filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The dentist engaged in the practice of dentistry in one portion of his residence in plaintiff town. The dentist erected an extension to the residence for the medical center for other doctors and dentists. Plaintiff town amended its zoning ordinances in order to limit the dentist's use of his residence to one profession. Plaintiffs claimed that the dentist's medical center violated the ordinance. The dentist claimed that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The court denied the dentist's motion for summary judgment and dismissed in part the dentist's counterclaims. The court held that plaintiff town amended the ordinances after the dentist's medical center was completed, that the dentist had a vested right in a permitted use, and that the amended ordinances were ineffective. The court held, however, that the medical center altered the essential character and nature of the community, that plaintiffs' complaint stated a cause of action, that the dentist's first counterclaim was required to be dismissed, but that the dentist's second counterclaim that the ordinance was confiscatory and unconstitutional presented an issue for trial.


OUTCOME: The court denied the dentist's motion for summary judgment. The court dismissed the dentist's first counterclaim regarding the interference with his use of the medical center, but refused to dismiss the dentist's second counterclaim as to the unconstitutionality of the amended ordinances.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- town zoning ordinance authorized professional office of a doctor or dentist in dwelling; ordinance further provided that in construction thereof "the singular number includes the plural"; latter provision not to be literally construed and applied indiscriminately throughout entire ordinance, where result would be absurd and chaotic; ordinance required to be construed as authorizing professional office of one doctor or one dentist in one-family residence in use district.

A town zoning ordinance authorized the professional office of a doctor or dentist in a dwelling. The ordinance provided further that in the construction thereof "the singular number includes the plural." The latter provision was not to be literally construed and applied indiscriminately throughout the entire ordinance, where the result would be absurd and chaotic. Upon application of logic and common sense to the zoning ordinance, and a consideration of the purposes for which it was enacted, the ordinance was required to be [***2] construed as authorizing the professional office of a doctor or a dentist, and to permit but one doctor or dentist to practice his profession in a one-family residence in the use district.

 

2699 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lloyd Harbor v. Huntington


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


143 N.Y.S.2d 797; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2905



June 27, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff villages filed a motion, seeking a temporary injunction against defendant town to prohibit the town from constructing a public beach.


OVERVIEW: The villages existed within the town's limits. The town sought to construct a public beach within the village limits. The villages, however, sought a temporary injunction prior to a trial on the merits regarding the constitutionality of 1955 N.Y. Laws ch. 840, that allowed the town to establish, maintain, and operate public beaches. The villages contended that the statute violated N.Y. Const. Art. III § 17, which prohibited the use of village land for use other than residential. The court found that the villages had not presented enough factual evidence to convince the court that the beaches would be destructive of the villages' rights or cause actual material and irreparable injury as distinguished from theoretical or possible injury. Further, the court was concerned that a town could not be prevented from establishing, at its own expense and on its own lands, a public health facility such as public beaches.


OUTCOME: The court denied the villages' motion.

 

2700 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Allen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Schenectady County


207 Misc. 1036; 142 N.Y.S.2d 547; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2827



June 22, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner husband signed and filed an unverified "alleged petition" in which he sought the commitment of his allegedly mentally ill wife. Medical examiners certified that the patient was mentally ill and was in need of care and treatment in an institution for the mentally ill; however, that alleged certification was also filed with the court unverified, as was purportedly allowed by 1955 N.Y. Laws 794, § 74.


OVERVIEW: Section 74 attempted to amend the law so as to eliminate the requirement that the signature of a petitioner and of examining physicians in an involuntary commitment proceeding be notarized. The husband's petition was filed in accordance with the new law. The court ruled that the law was unconstitutional in that the proceeding was one affecting the rights and liberties of an individual. Furthermore, the court ruled that pleadings were required to be verified under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 248 and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 99, 100. Although being allegedly insane or mentally ill at the time of the making of such an application, an allegedly incompetent person was entitled to every substantial right and privilege that statutes and the Constitution required.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the husband verify his petition and that the examining physicians certify their findings under oath.


HEADNOTES

Insane and other incompetent persons -- admission to institution -- those portions of chapter 794 of Laws of 1955, pertaining to admission of persons alleged to be mentally ill to institutions upon order made by judge, which delete former requirement for "verified petition" and certification "under oath" by examining physicians, unconstitutional; even if constitutional, section 248 of Civil Practice Act and rules 99 and 100 of Rules of Civil Practice, relating to verification of pleadings, applicable.

Those portions of chapter 794 of the Laws of 1955, pertaining to admission of persons alleged to be mentally ill to institutions upon an order made by a judge, which delete the former requirement for a "verified petition" and certification "under oath" by examining physicians are unconstitutional. Even were such legislation constitutional, section 248 of the Civil Practice Act and rules 99 and 100 of the Rules of Civil Practice, relating to verification of pleadings, are applicable. The court directs, upon a petition for admission of a person alleged to be mentally ill to an institution, that [***2] the petitioner verify the petition and that the examining physicians certify under oath their findings.

 

2701 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Burke v. Kingsley Books, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


208 Misc. 150; 142 N.Y.S.2d 735; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3535



June 13, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporation counsel brought an action against defendants, persons, firms, and corporations, for an injunction under N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 22-a to permanently enjoin defendants from acquiring, selling, or distributing issues of a series of booklets; to direct defendants to surrender to the sheriff all issues of the publication within their possession and control; and to direct the sheriff to seize and destroy them.


OVERVIEW: Defendants argued that the corporate counsel lacked the required legal authority to maintain the action, that § 22-a was an unconstitutional restraint on freedom of the press, and that it violated the constitutional protection against unreasonable seizures. The court issued an injunction that permanently enjoined defendants from distributing, selling, or acquiring possession of any of the volumes of the publication that were received in evidence, directed defendants to surrender all copies in their possession to the sheriff, and directed the sheriff to seize and destroy the copies because they were obscene. The court found that the booklets were pornography, unadulterated by plot, moral, or writing style, that presented a "clear and present danger" of the substantive evils that the legislature had a right to prevent. The court concluded that § 22-a did not constitute a "previous restraint" upon the dissemination of ideas, as it did not suppress in advance what was to be published. However, the court would not enjoin the publication of future volumes because that would constitute prior restraint. The court found that the corporation counsel had the capacity to sue.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for the corporation counsel. The court permanently enjoined defendants from distributing, selling, or acquiring possession of any of the volumes of the publication received in evidence and directed them to surrender all copies of the volumes in their possession to the sheriff who was directed to seize and destroy the copies.


HEADNOTES

Injunctions -- obscene book -- (1) plaintiff New York City Corporation Counsel entitled under Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 22-a) to judgment permanently enjoining defendants from distributing, selling or acquiring possession of books entitled "Nights of Horror" received in evidence; defendants directed to surrender to Sheriff such books in their possession and Sheriff directed to destroy them -- (2) words "obscene", "lewd", "lascivious", "filthy", "indecent" and "disgusting" in section 22-a sufficiently definite to make statute constitutionally valid -- (3) standards of certainty in criminal statutes higher than in statute like Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 22-a) which depends on civil sanctions -- (4) legal test for obscenity is whether tendency of matter charged would deprave those whose minds are open to such immoral influences and into whose hands publication may fall; but law will not hold crowd to morality of saints or honor views of debased persons -- (5) books in evidence not sex literature but pornography without plot, moral or writing style -- (6) on reading of each volume, no single  [***2] story found not obscene -- (7) section 22-a does not violate Federal and State constitutional guarantees against interference with free press -- (8) evidence shows such "clear and present danger" of substantive evils that suppression thereof is constitutionally valid; right of free speech not absolute and prevention and punishment of obscene utterances raise no constitutional problem -- (9) statute does not enforce "previous restraint" upon dissemination of ideas in violation of right of free speech -- (10) but court may not prohibit sale and distribution of later issues -- (11) judgment here does not constitute unconstitutional seizure -- (12) plaintiff as New York City Corporation Counsel has legal capacity to sue here.

1. The Penal Law (§ 1141, subd. 1) makes it a misdemeanor to sell or distribute any obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, indecent or disgusting book. The Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 22-a, as amd. by L. 1954, ch. 702) provides that the Supreme Court has jurisdiction to enjoin the sale or distribution of obscene prints and articles as defined in section 22-a and in section 1141 of the Penal Law and that, in the event that a final judgment of injunction be issued,  [***3] the judgment shall contain a provision directing the party against whom the injunction is granted to surrender to the Sheriff such obscene prints and articles and the Sheriff shall be directed to seize and destroy the same. Pursuant to section 22-a, plaintiff, as Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, is entitled to judgment permanently enjoining defendants from distributing, selling or acquiring possession of any of the volumes of the publication entitled "Nights of Horror" received in evidence on the trial and defendants will be directed to surrender to the Sheriff all copies of such volumes now in their possession and the Sheriff will be directed to seize and destroy them.

2. To be constitutionally valid what is statutorily interdicted must be defined with appropriate definiteness. While section 22-a has not defined the words "obscene", "lewd", "lascivious", "filthy", "indecent" and "disgusting", such words are sufficiently definite. They are themselves descriptive, are in common use and every person of ordinary intelligence understands their meaning.

3. The standards of certainty in criminal statutes are higher than in those statutes like section 22-a of the Code of [***4] Criminal Procedure which depend primarily on civil sanctions for enforcement.

4. The legal test sustained by the Court of Appeals for obscenity is whether the tendency of the matter charged as obscene is to deprave and corrupt those whose minds are open to such immoral influences and into whose hands a publication of this sort may fall. In determining what is obscene in any particular case, the law will not hold the crowd to the morality of saints and seers nor will the law honor the views of the bestial and the debased.

5. The booklets "Nights of Horror" offer only glorified concepts of lustful concupiscence, and by their tenor deride love and virtue, invite crime and voluptuousness, and excite lecherous desires. They are not sex literature as such but pornography without plot, moral or writing style. There is no attempt to achieve any literary standard. Each issue is a paper-covered booklet of from seventy to ninety-six pages, with a suggestive sex drawing on the front cover. The price varies from $ 1.98 to $ 3.00 per issue and the volumes are replete with misspelled words, typographical errors, faulty grammar, misplaced pages and poor workmanship.

6. A reading of each volume [***5] indicates that there is not a single "story" which is not "obscene", "lewd", "lascivious", "indecent" or "disgusting".

7. Section 22-a does not violate the constitutional guarantee against interference with a free press (U. S. Const., 1st Amendt.; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 8). The volumes are so totally lacking in merit and so obviously pornographic in intent that their banning poses no threat to freedom of expression in literature or otherwise.

8. In cases involving fundamental human liberties such as freedom of the press, there must be shown before there may be suppression, a "clear and present danger" of the substantive evils which the Legislature has a right to prevent. The proof submitted on behalf of plaintiff, a reading of the issues of the "Nights of Horror", the studies and Reports of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee to study the publication of comics, of the United States Senate Special Judiciary Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency, and of the Select Committee of the United States House of Representatives on Current Pornographic Materials, and our everyday observations of the shocking rise of juvenile delinquency and sex crimes indicate a clear and present [***6] danger of substantive evils. The right of free speech is not absolute at all times and under all circumstances, and the prevention and punishment of lewd and obscene utterances do not raise any constitutional problem.

9. Section 22-a does not enforce a "previous restraint" upon the dissemination of ideas in violation of the constitutional right of free speech. When the court after a hearing of the parties is able to read and examine the publications objected to, and acts judicially to enjoin their distribution, there is no "previous restraint" in the genuine historical and constitutional sense of that term. Moreover the statute does not provide for a permit or a license, it does not require any application or fee, and it does not suppress in advance what is to be published. The Legislature has simply determined that what has long been recognized as criminal by the Penal Law (§ 1141), the Supreme Court may enjoin and abate in a civil suit under section 22-a.

10. But the statute does not in express terms compel a determination that the sale and distribution of later issues be enjoined. Such a determination would impose an unreasonable prior restraint on freedom of the press.  [***7] There can be no injunction regarding an unpublished book.

11. The judgment rendered here does not amount to an unconstitutional seizure (U. S. Const., 4th Amendt.; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 12). The prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures does not forbid judicially declared action based upon constitutionally authorized jurisdiction -- and duly taken thereunder -- but rather forbids certain action taken without due judicial sanction. Since a court of equity may constitutionally be given power to enjoin the sale and distribution of existing obscene publications, it may also voluntarily be given jurisdiction concomitant therewith to compel the surrender and sale of such publications.

12. Section 22-a provides that the corporation counsel of any city in which a person, firm or corporation sells or distributes the proscribed printed matter may maintain an action for injunction. The New York City Charter (§ 394, subd. [a]) provides that "Except as otherwise provided by law," the corporation counsel shall be the attorney for the city and shall have charge of all the law business of the city and "in which the city is interested". The City Home Rule Law (§ 30) specifically [***8] reserves to the State Legislature the power to pass laws regulating "mattersof state concern". Plaintiff has legal capacity to sue here and section 22-a is an instance in which "otherwise" was "provided by law". Moreover, what may be matters of State concern may also be something "in which the city is interested"; and the publication and distribution of obscene matter is also the concern of the city.

 

2702 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bergerman v. Gerosa


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


208 Misc. 477; 144 N.Y.S.2d 95; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3674



June 13, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a chairman of a citizens committee, for himself individually and as chairman, sought an order restraining respondents, Comptroller of the City of New York, New York and other interested parties, from paying claims that were presented to the Comptroller pursuant to 1955 N.Y. Laws 842.


OVERVIEW: About 23 years prior to the passage of chapter 842, the salaries of city employees were reduced when the salary provisions of the city's charter were suspended by valid emergency legislation. Chapter 842 was designed to pay the city employees the money that they would have received if the salaries provided by the charter were paid. The chairman claimed that the payments were unconstitutional, and the court so held. The court ruled that the previous reduction in salaries set the compensation level of the city's employees and that, pursuant to N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 10, the payment of the difference between the charter level salaries and the emergency level salaries was extra compensation to the city employees. Thus, N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 10 forbade the payments. The court further ruled that it was beyond its authority to consider the morality of 1955 N.Y. Laws 842, and it refused to do so.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the Comptroller not to pay city employees the difference between what they would have earned under the city charter and the amount they were paid under the emergency legislation.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- municipal corporations -- New York City salaries -- retroactive extra compensation prohibited -- (1) statute providing that any city has moral obligation to pay, and shall pay to any present elected incumbent of office, difference between his salary as fixed by charter and amount actually paid to him at any past time (L. 1955, ch. 842), is valid insofar as it provides for payment of salaries fixed by Constitution, but unconstitutional and void as to other reduced salaries validly fixed in budgets of City of New York between 1933 and 1937 pursuant to emergency authorization by Legislature (L. 1932, ch. 637) -- (2) Legislature cannot make it moral obligation to pay compensation above that legally fixed when services were rendered (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 10).

1. A statute providing that any city or county contained in a city has a moral obligation to pay, and shall pay to any present elected incumbent of public office, the difference between the amount of his salary as fixed by the Constitution or any general or special or local law or charter andthe amount of salary actually paid to him at [***2] any past time (L. 1955, ch. 842), is valid insofar as it provides for the payment of salaries fixed by the Constitution but is unconstitutional and void as to other reduced salaries which were validly fixed by the budgets of the City of New York from 1933 to 1937, pursuant to emergency authorization of the Legislature suspending the operation of the city charter as to salaries (L. 1932, ch. 637; Matter of Moran v. La Guardia. 270 N.Y. 450).

2. The State Constitution (art. IX, § 10) prohibits payment of extra compensation to city officers. This has been construed to prohibit the Legislature from making it a moral obligation to pay compensation over and above that fixed pursuant to law when the services were rendered ( Matter of Mahon v. Board of Educ. of City of N. Y., 171 N.Y. 263).

 

2703 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Keith v. Maple Grove Cemetery Asso.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


208 Misc. 217; 145 N.Y.S.2d 198; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3304



June 9, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff holder sought a declaratory judgment determining that defendant association was required to distribute to its land-certificate holders the proceeds of a condemnation award and 50 percent of the proceeds from sales of lots for burial purposes, without the deduction of maintenance funds. In the alternative, the holder sought a judgment declaring N.Y. Membership Corp. Law § 87 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The association was a membership corporation and acquired 75 acres of land from a grantor for the operation of a cemetery. By the terms of the contract between the grantor and the association, it was provided that the latter pay to the grantor or her assigns one-half of the proceeds of all sales of lots. Pursuant to such contract, the proceeds of sales of land were divided into 1500 equal parts, evidenced by certificates issued by the association. The holder was an assignee of the grantor and owned of 65 of the land certificates. The association, by virtue of an amendment of § 87, deducted from the proceeds of the sales of the land 10 percent for a permanent maintenance fund and 15 percent for a current maintenance fund. The holder asserted that if such deductions were made, the amendment to § 87 was unconstitutional. The court dismissed the holder's complaint and held that the even if was assumed that § 87 impaired the association's contract rights and deprived her of property, long-standing constitutional principles of law relating to the exercise of police power removed all merit from an argument that the requirement of deducting maintenance fees was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the holder's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Cemeteries -- maintenance funds -- (1) defendant cemetery association in 1875 acquired land for cemetery, agreement requiring defendant association to pay one half of proceeds of sales of lots to grantor or assigns; plaintiff assignee of grantor, owner of 65/1500 of land certificates; land of cemetery condemned by City of New York for expressway and defendant association received condemnation award; Membership Corporations Law (§ 87, as amd. in 1949) required defendant association to deduct from proceeds of sale of land 10% for permanent maintenance fund and 15% for current maintenance fund; stated purpose of 1949 amendment was to promote public welfare in exercise of police power; in action for determination that entire proceeds of condemnation award should be distributed to land-certificate holders and 50% of proceeds of sales of lots for burial purposes should be paid to certificate holders without deduction for maintenance funds, complaint dismissed -- (2) funds for maintenance required to be deducted first before payment of 50% to land-certificate holders such as plaintiff under Membership Corporations Law (§ 87, subd. 2) as amended  [***2] -- (3) enactment not unconstitutional as impairing obligation of contract and as depriving plaintiff of property without due process of law; plaintiff's contract rights subject to exercise of police power -- (4) condemnation award deemed substituted for proceeds of sales of land covered by contract of plaintiff's assignor with defendant association; land acquired in condemnation could no longer be sold for cemetery purposes but award took place of land; rights as existing with respect to proceeds of sale of cemetery lots continued in award; plaintiff entitled to 50% of gross condemnation award up to amendment of Membership Corporations Law in 1949, and thereafter subject to deduction for maintenance funds before distribution of 50% to holders of land certificates.

1. Defendant cemetery association, organized as a membership corporation under the Rural Cemetery Act of the State of New York, in 1875 acquired land in Kew Gardens, Queens County, for the operation of a cemetery. The agreement between the grantor and defendant association required defendant association to pay to the grantor or her assigns "one-half of the proceeds of all sales of lots and plots made from said lands."  [***3] Pursuant to the contract the proceeds of sales of land were divided into 1,500 equal parts, evidenced by land certificates of which plaintiff, assignee of the grantor, held 65. Subdivision 2 of section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law was amended (L. 1949, ch. 533) to require that a cemetery corporation should, as agreed with the person from whom the lands were purchased, pay therefor a share not exceeding one half of the proceeds of the sale of lots therein, provided "that there be first deducted from said proceeds of sales the amount required [by section 86-a] to be deposited in the permanent maintenance fund [10%] and current maintenance fund [15%] as aforesaid together with the expenses of sale". In December, 1951, defendant association received a condemnation award from the City of New York for land taken in connection with an expressway. Section 1 of chapter 533 of the Laws of 1949, amending section 87, stated that its purpose was to promote the public welfare and to prevent cemeteries from falling into disrepair and that the enactment was "in the exercise of the police power of the state". In an action for judgment determining that defendant association was required [***4] to distribute to its land-certificate holders the entire proceeds of the condemnation award and 50% of the proceeds from sales of lots for burial purposes, without deduction of maintenance funds, or, in the alternative, for judgment declaring section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law to be unconstitutional, judgment was rendered in favor of defendants declaring section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law to be constitutional, and the complaint was, in all other respects, dismissed upon the merits.

2. The language of subdivision 2 of section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law that "there be first deducted from the said proceeds of sales" the sums to be paid into the maintenance funds, negatived plaintiff's contention that the payments to the maintenance funds were to be made by cemetery corporations out of the balance remaining after paying the full 50% of the proceeds of sales to certificate holders. Under the law prior to the 1949 amendment, plaintiff was entitled only to share in the net proceeds rather than in the gross proceeds of sales of the cemetery lands.

3. Section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law would not be held unconstitutional as impairing the obligation [***5] of plaintiff's contract with defendant association and as depriving her of property without due process of law. Plaintiff's property rights and contract rights were required to give way to a proper exercise of the police power. In the absence of proof that the amendment of section 87 was not a proper exercise of the police power of the State, the court could not interfere with the legislative promulgation. Moreover, the enactment was a wholly proper exercise of police power.

4. Equitable principles required that the condemnation award be deemed substituted for the proceeds of the sale of lands covered by the contract with plaintiff's assignor. Grants of land are held subject to the exercise of the sovereign power of the State and the right of the State to authorize condemnation must be deemed an inherent condition of every land contract. As a result of the condemnation proceedings, the land could no longer be devoted to cemetery purposes, notwithstanding the contract between defendant association and plaintiff's grantor. A court of equity will grant relief where there is a breach of a condition arising out of the exercise of sovereign power. The fund received as an award therefore [***6] took the place of the land and such rights as existed with respect to the proceeds of the sale of cemetery lots included in such land continued in the substituted fund. Accordingly, land-certificate holders were entitled to 50% of the gross condemnation award up to the date of the amendment of section 87 of the Membership Corporations Law by chapter 533 of the Laws of 1949, and thereafter subject to deductions of 10% and 15% for maintenance funds before computing the 50% payable to certificate holders.

 

2704 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re City of New York ex rel. New York City Hous. Auth.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


208 Misc. 757; 143 N.Y.S.2d 346; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3671



June 7, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mortgagee moved for payment to him of the award made in a final decree authorizing the taking of a parcel of land. Respondent city cross-moved for payment of its judgment for demolition costs.


OVERVIEW: The mortgagee contended that the city's lien should not be deemed superior to his lien because the only notice given in the "unsafe building" proceeding was to the then owner, thus affording the mortgagee no opportunity to repair the building and thereby save his mortgage. The court held that the cost to the city in demolishing the dangerous structure required to be done in the public interest could be granted priority over earlier mortgages by legislative enactment because mortgagees as well as owners hold their interest in property subject to the proper exercise of the police power. Accordingly, the court granted the city's cross-motion for payment of its judgment for demolition costs.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's cross-motion for payment of its judgment for demolition costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- police power -- municipal corporations -- priority of judgment for demolition costs rendered in unsafe building proceeding -- (1) provisions of Administrative Code of City of New York (§ C26-204.0, subd. f) that judgment for demolition costs rendered in unsafe building proceeding should become lien against premises from time of filing of notice of lis pendens and "shall have priority before any mortgage or other lien", not unconstitutional -- (2) cost to city in demolishing dangerous structure in public interest may properly be granted priority over earlier mortgages -- (3) mortgagees hold interest in property subject to proper exercise of police power; if, through owner's and mortgagee's neglect, it becomes necessary to demolish building, mortgagee may not complain that had personal notice been given to him he might have been able to repair, or that priority accorded demolition cost advanced by city -- (4) moreover, mortgagee would not be heard to complain of impact of priority provision of Administrative  [***2] Code, where he acquired mortgage long after lis pendens filed and after entry of judgment for demolition costs -- (5) upon mortgagee's motion for payment of award made on condemnation of premises, city's cross motion for payment of its judgment for demolition costs granted.

1. The provisions of the Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ C26-204.0, subd. f) that judgment for demolition costs rendered in a proceeding to demolish a building as unsafe should become a lien against the premises from the time of filing of notice of lis pendens and "shall have priority before any mortgage or other lien as may exist prior to such filing" were not unconstitutional as to a mortgagee on the ground that the only notice given in the unsafe building proceeding was to the then owner, and the mortgagee was hence afforded no opportunity to repair the building and thereby save his mortgage.

2. The cost to the city in demolishing a dangerous structure in the public interest may properly be granted priority over earlier mortgages by legislative enactment.

3. Mortgagees as well as owners hold their interest in property subject to the proper exercise of the police power. If, through the [***3] owner's and the mortgagee's neglect, it becomes necessary to demolish a building, the mortgagee may not complain that he might have been able, had personal notice been given to him, to so repair as to make the building safe, nor complain that priority is accorded the actual demolition cost advanced by the city, in view of the failure of anyone interested in the property to undertake such demolition.

4. Moreover, the mortgagee would not be heard to complain of the impact of the priority provision of the Administrative Code upon his mortgage, where he acquired the mortgage long after the filing of the lis pendens in the unsafe building proceeding and after the entry of the judgment for demolition costs.

5. Upon the mortgagee's motion for payment to him of an award made on condemnation of the premises, and the city's cross motion for payment of its judgment for demolition costs, the city's cross motion was granted.

 

2705 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Diocese of Rochester v. Planning Board of Brighton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Monroe County


207 Misc. 1021; 141 N.Y.S.2d 487; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2544



June 3, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a diocese and the executor of a decedent landowner's will, applied under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 and N.Y. Town Law § 267 for judicial review of the denial by respondents, a town planning board, the town zoning board of appeals, and the town board, of their request for a permit to build a church. Respondents moved to strike portions of the complaint and for dismissal of the petition in toto.


OVERVIEW: The executor sold the decedent's land to the diocese, but the sale was contingent upon the obtainment of permission to build a church on the land. The diocese and executor applied to respondents for a permit. Respondents denied the application and refused to grant a variance. The diocese and executor appealed. Respondents moved to strike. The court held that respondents were not prejudiced by the allegations they sought to strike. The court stated that the diocese and the executor could not both assail the constitutionality of the town ordinance and rely upon the ordinance for a variance. The court held that the ordinance was valid on its face. The court reviewed the transcripts and found that there was no evidence that respondents had applied the ordinance in a discriminatory manner. Respondents' decision to reject the application for a permit to erect a church, a school, several playgrounds, and a large parking area in a Class A residential district was a proper and legal exercise of discretionary powers, neither arbitrary, capricious, nor contrary to law. As the record of proceedings before respondents was voluminous and complete, no trial of the alleged issues was required.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition and affirmed respondents' determination.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- churches and private schools -- (1) under town zoning ordinances, churches and schools could be erected, but not in "A" residential zone except by special permit; town boards were not arbitrary in denying such special permit to diocese to erect, on property in "A" zone, church and school and playgrounds and parking area; no triable issues; review petition dismissed -- (2) application addressed to boards' discretion; constitutionality of zoning ordinances cannot be attacked in this proceeding -- (3) nor does petition allege such intentional discrimination by boards as to result in unconstitutional administration of ordinances -- (4) residential zoning need not be subordinated to church and private school requirements -- (5) no proper analogy between unrestricted right of public authorities to establish public school and obligation of zoning authorities to permit erection of private school.

1. Under a town's zoning ordinances, churches [***2] and schools could be established throughout the township as a matter of right, except in a "Class A" residential zone, and even in such a zone if an application therefor were approved by the town planning board. The town board, the town planning board, and the zoning board of appeals did not act arbitrarily in denying, after full hearings and on a voluminous record, the application of a diocese, which urged that the only church and school of its denomination in the township were inconveniently located and inadequate, and which had contingently purchased property in a "Class A" zone, for a permit to erect on such property a church, a parochial school, several playgrounds, and a large parking area. The court will not substitute its judgment for that of the town boards. This review proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act and section 267 of the Town Law is dismissed, since there are no triable issues.

2. The application was primarily addressed to the discretion of the town boards. For that purpose, the validity of the ordinances must be assumed, and their constitutionality cannot be attacked in this proceeding.

3. Nor does the petition allege that there was such intentional [***3] discrimination by the boards as to result in an unconstitutional manner of administration of otherwise constitutional ordinances.

4. The rights of citizens who, on the faith of zoning ordinances, have made substantial investments in homes in residential zones need not necessarily be subordinated to the requirements of churches whose denominational population has increased. The boards did not deny the diocese the right to erect a church and school and playground and parking area, but only at this precise location.

5. No proper analogy may be drawn between the right of public authorities to establish a public school unrestricted by local zoning ordinances and an obligation of zoning authorities to permit the erection of a private school.

 

2706 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Frazzita


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Jefferson County


147 N.Y.S.2d 11; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2984



June 3, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding, petitioner licensee sought to set aside an order of respondent, the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles of the State of New York, which revoked his chauffeur's license pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71 and suspended his certificate of registration. The licensee had pleaded guilty to violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 58 for reckless driving.


OVERVIEW: The licensee was arrested and charged with operating an automobile while intoxicated. The licensee pleaded guilty to the reduced charge of reckless driving in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 58. Based on the fixed policy of automatic revocation where a guilty plea to a charge of reckless driving was accepted after the charge was reduced from driving while intoxicated, the Commissioner revoked the licensee's chauffeur's license pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71 and suspended his certificate of registration. The licensee sought to set aside the Commissioner's revocation order. The court found that no discretionary administrative action had been taken; therefore, the revocation order was arbitrary and should be set aside. The language of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71(3)(a) required the Commissioner to exercise his discretion when proceeding under § 71(3)(a). To do so, some investigation was necessary even though a hearing was not required. While the Commissioner could accept a certificate of conviction as proof of violation without giving the licensee a hearing, he could not automatically issue a permissive revocation without consideration of the merits.


OUTCOME: The court set aside the Commissioner's order.

 

2707 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


De Matteis v. Hempstead


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


207 Misc. 1026; 142 N.Y.S.2d 754; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3536



May 18, 1955 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Order Affirmed October 17, 1955. See 145 N.Y.S.2d 256 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff adjacent property owner filed an action against defendant town seeking a declaration that all proceedings thus far taken by the town, pursuant to Nassau County, N.Y., Admin. Law § 272 (1939), in attempting to acquire the owner's land by condemnation was null and void and seeking injunctive relief against any future steps toward acquisition. The town had filed a motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: A town acquired a parcel of land that consisted of a sandpit, and it then filed an action under ch. 272 to condemn the owner's property to provide access to the land. The map filed by the town engineer declared that the purchase was for park purposes, and the resolution authorizing the acquisition of the owner's land recited that the land was acquired to fill in the pit. The owner sought a dismissal and a stay. Then, he filed an action to declare null and void all actions thus far taken in attempting to acquire his land and to enjoin further action, alleging that ch. 272 was unconstitutional and that, as such, N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51 was also unconstitutional. The town sought a dismissal for failure to state a cause of action. The court held that: (1) in purchasing the sand pit, the map prepared by the town engineer possessed no critical significance because it was not an essential element in the exercise of the town board's power to acquire the land by purchase; and (2) if a variance existed with the terms of the resolution and with the legend inscribed on the map as to the purpose for which the sand pit was being acquired, the language of the resolution prevailed.


OUTCOME: The court granted the town's motion to dismiss the adjacent property owner's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- towns -- constitutional law -- personal service -- public purpose -- (1) Nassau County Administrative Code's provisions for condemnation not unconstitutional for failure to provide for personal service of notice to condemn -- (2) town resolved to buy land for purpose of ending threat to public safety by filling in abandoned, water-filled sand pit thereon; town engineer prepared map, which erroneously labeled property as for park purposes, but which had no procedural significance; after buying land, town passed resolution to condemn plaintiff's adjacent land in order to get access to sand pit and fill it in; such purpose was public and town board's determination was legislative; action to restrain condemnation proceeding dismissed.

1. The condemnation provisions of the Nassau County Administrative Code (L. 1939, ch. 272, as amd.) are not unconstitutional by reason of failure to provide for personal service upon the property owner of the notice to condemn or of the condemnation petition.

2. A town within Nassau County passed a resolution to purchase a parcel [***2] of land, for the expressed purpose of ending a threat to public safety by filling in an abandoned, water-filled sand pit thereon. The town engineer prepared a map of the proposed purchase, which he erroneously labeled as intended for park purposes. The resolution did not mention any map, and no map is required by law for a purchase, and the map had no procedural importance such as a condemnation map would have. After purchasing the parcel, the town passed a resolution to condemn plaintiff's adjacent property for the expressed purpose of providing access to the purchased parcel in order to fill in the sand pit "and for any future uses". It cannot be said that the town board deceived the community as to its real purpose, or that the proposed condemnation was not necessary or was not for a public purpose. The town had power to acquire property by condemnation for such purpose (Town Law, § 64, subd. 2) and the determination of the town board as embodied in the condemnation resolution was legislative in character. In this action to restrain further steps in the condemnation proceeding, as tainted with illegality (General Municipal Law, § 51), motion for dismissal of the complaint [***3] for insufficiency is granted.

 

2708 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Town of Hempstead


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SPECIAL TERM, NASSAU COUNTY


142 N.Y.S.2d 758; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3537



May 18, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner town filed a motion in a condemnation procedure for real property that sought an order providing that the real property be condemned, that the compensation to be made to respondent property owner be determined by the court without a jury, and that title in fee vest in the town. By cross-motion the owner sought to dismiss the proceeding, denial of the application, and a stay of proceedings until the determination of another action.


OVERVIEW: The property owner's cross-motion to dismiss the proceeding was based upon the alleged unconstitutionality of pertinent provisions of the Nassau County Administrative Code by reason of their failure to afford the property owner an opportunity to have a judicial determination as to the necessity for the taking and the public purpose for which the property was to be taken. He also sought denial of the application for failure to serve notice of the condemnation with sufficient time for him to act thereon and for failure to serve a copy of the petition upon him. The latter failures were claimed to constitute a denial of due process of law and equal protection of the laws under both state and federal constitutions. The court granted the town's motion and denied the cross-motion, as no violation of the property owner's constitutional rights arose from the condemnation statute's failure to require that he be given notice of the proceedings in which it was determined that his land was to be acquired for a public purpose. Nor were his constitutional rights violated by denying him an opportunity for judicial review on the matters of necessity and public purpose of the taking.


OUTCOME: The court granted the town's petition for condemnation proceeding of the property, without a jury, and denied property owner's cross-motion to dismiss the proceeding, denial of the application, and a stay of proceedings until the determination of another action.

 

2709 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Angert v. Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


141 N.Y.S.2d 603; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2700; 36 L.R.R.M. 2216; 28 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P69,190



April 29, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff store owner filed a motion for a temporary injunction to restrain defendants, a labor union and its president, from picketing the store owner's place of business. The union president filed a motion to dismiss the store owner's complaint.


OVERVIEW: The store owner sought a temporary injunction to restrain a labor union and its president from picketing the store owner's place of business. The union president sought dismissal of the store owner's complaint on the ground that the store owner had not pleaded compliance with N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 876-a. The union contended that issues presented in the instant case involved a labor dispute within the purview of N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 876-a, that in consequence an injunction could not be granted, and that the union had the right to picket peacefully in an effort to persuade the store owner's employees to join the union. The court held that: (1) the complaint stated a good cause of action and under the store owner's version of the matter, the picketing was unlawful and could be enjoined; (2) if the statements of the union and its president were true and the picketing had been peaceful and orderly and merely for organizational purposes, the picketing could not be enjoined; and (3) the foregoing factual issues could not be determined upon the affidavits submitted, and the matter had to go to trial.


OUTCOME: The court denied the store owner's motion for a temporary injunction on the condition that the union and its president accept a note of issue for trial of the action.

 

2710 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People's Dairy v. Lackawanna


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


140 N.Y.S.2d 455; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3155



April 29, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff licensed milk distributor sought a judgment declaring an ordinance enacted by defendant city to be void and restraining the city from enforcing it. The parties were before the court on the city's motion to dismiss the distributor's complaint on the ground that it failed to allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance in question prohibited coin operated milk vending machines unless such machines were located in a regular place of business. The distributor installed, on private property, a coin operated refrigerated, insulated, automatic milk vending machine. Various government inspectors approved the machine. The court held that courts should not ordinarily pass on the constitutionality of municipal ordinances without considering evidence bearing on the reasonableness or unreasonableness thereof. The ordinance in question was enacted under a general rather than a specific grant of authority by the legislature to the city. In the complaint, the distributor made allegations to the effect that the city's ordinance was unreasonable, which allegation was a statement of ultimate fact rather than a statement of law. The court held that the complaint was sufficient where the distributor had alleged facts to show that a controversy existed between it and the city as to the constitutionality of the ordinance so as to entitle the distributor to a determination by the court as to whether the ordinance was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the city's motion to dismiss the complaint. The court held the city could serve an answer within 20 days after the service of a copy of the order of the court.

 

2711 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Beagell v. Douglas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Broome County


2 Misc. 2d 361; 157 N.Y.S.2d 461; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2381



April 29, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action against respondent assessors, petitioner taxpayers challenged the constitutionality of a state revenue law obliging landowners to pay the tax for all residential trailers found on their property even if the landowners did not own all of those trailers.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers challenged the constitutionality of a tax law that obliged them to pay property taxes on two residential trailers that sat on their property--even though they only owned one of the trailers. The taxpayers claimed that the tax law was unconstitutional because it required the landowner on whose property a residential trailer sat to pay the taxes for that trailer, notwithstanding the landowner's lack of ownership or benefit from the trailer. The court rejected the taxpayers' challenge and upheld the validity of the statute. The legislature had a rational basis for enacting the law, given the prevalence of transitory people using residential trailers to move into an area without the obligation of paying taxes to support educational and public safety services. Because the statute was rationally related to a legitimate governmental interest, it was a valid law.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the tax assessment because the tax statute in question was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- house trailers as real property -- Legislature empowered to provide that house trailers should be taxed as part of real property and assessed to owner of land.

1. That portion of the Tax Law ( § 2, subd. 6-a) which subjects house trailers to taxation as real property, except transient trailers which have been located within the boundaries of a tax district for less than 60 days, and trailers which are for sale and which are not occupied, and further provides that the trailers shall be assessed to the owners of the real property on which they are located, is constitutional. Accordingly, an assessment of real property taxes against petitioner landowners for two house trailers standing upon their real estate, one of which was owned by petitioners and one of which was owned by third persons who had no interest in the land, would be sustained.

2. The Legislature has the power to classify and define what property is taxable as real property.

 

2712 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kurtz v. Adams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


141 N.Y.S.2d 77; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2471



March 21, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78, petitioner licensed "runner" employed by intervenor ship company sued to set aside an order of respondent Commissioner of the Police Department of the City of New York convicting him of a violation of New York, N.Y., Licensed Runners R. & Regs. 12. The sentence was suspended and the runner's license was renewed shortly thereafter at the usual annual renewal time. The runner wanted to clear his record.


OVERVIEW: The complaint gave a time and place for a hearing and charged the runner with giving false information. The court rejected the runner's arguments that the regulation and the notice were both vague. The court held that the notice was sufficient to inform the runner of the accusation. The court noted that the runner was represented by counsel at the hearing, raised no question as to lack of preparation, and defended vigorously on the merits. The court added that in the absence of a statutory direction for a hearing, it had the duty to decide the sufficiency of the evidence rather than transfer the proceeding to the appellate division. The only evidence against the runner came from the president of a rival company and one of its employees. The court said a vice-president of the runner's employer, another licensee, and the runner testified in his support. The court concluded that the accusations and counter-accusations of the two companies were not the basis for the guilty finding; rather, excessive shouting was ordered stopped. Because that misconduct was different from false information the court found no reasonable showing for finding him guilty and damaging his record.


OUTCOME: The court deemed the Commissioner's determination arbitrary and vacated it.

 

2713 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Powers v. Taylor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


207 Misc. 465; 139 N.Y.S.2d 166; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3433



March 9, 1955 



DISPOSITION: Motion to dismiss petition is granted. All papers to Attorney-General, except petitioner's brief and reply brief, which are herewith transmitted to his attorneys.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner, a referee under the Workmen's Compensation Law, sought to compel respondent Civil Service Commission to classify the referee position in the competitive civil service of the state of New York. Petitioner claimed that N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 150, which provided that such referees were in the exempt class of the classified civil service, was unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner, a referee under the Workmen's Compensation Law, brought a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to direct the Commission to classify the referee position in the competitive civil service of the state of New York. N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 150 provided that such referees were in the exempt class of the classified civil service, and it was petitioner's contention that § 150 violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6, which required appointments in the civil service of the state to be made according to merit and fitness to be ascertained, as far as practicable, by examination which, as far as practicable, was to be competitive. In dismissing the action, the court held that in light of the history of the position and its classification as exempt from competitive or noncompetitive examination, one could hardly say that N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 150 was an arbitrary declaration by the legislature.In so holding, the court presumed that the legislature had been well acquainted with the origin and subsequent history of the position and of the Commission's determinations that it was impracticable to fill the position by competitive or noncompetitive examinations.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the action.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- exempt class -- workmen's compensation referees -- (1) Workmen's Compensation Law ( § 150, as amd. by L. 1950, ch. 526), providing that position of referee established under Workmen's Compensation Law shall be in exempt class of classified civil service, does not violate direction of State Constitution (art. V, § 6) that appointments in civil service shall be made as far as practicable upon competitive examination; petition in proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act in nature of mandamus to direct Civil Service Commission to classify such position in competitive civil service, dismissed -- (2) Legislature has power to classify civil service employees and need not delegate that power; power must be exercised reasonably -- (3) petitioner, citizen who held office in Civil Service Employees' Association, was entitled to maintain proceeding; description of petitioner as officer of that association was mere surplusage -- (4) petitioner  [***2] not relegated to taxpayer's action provided for in section 28 of Civil Service Law -- (5) allegation in petition that it was practicable to test merits of workmen's compensation referees by competitive examination was not admitted upon motion to dismiss petition for insufficiency in law.

1. Section 150 of the Workmen's Compensation Law (as amd. by L. 1950, ch. 526), which provides that the position of referee established under the Workmen's Compensation Law shall be in the exempt class of the classified civil service, does not violate the direction of the State Constitution (art. V, § 6) that "Appointments * * * in the civil service of the state * * * shall be made according to merit and fitness to be ascertained, as far as practicable, by examination which, as far as practicable, shall be competitive". A petition in a proceedingunder article 78 of the Civil Practice Act in the nature of mandamus to direct the State Civil Service Commission to classify such position in the competitive civil service was, accordingly, dismissed. It was required to be presumed that the Legislature was well acquainted with the origin and subsequent history of the position of workmen's compensation [***3] referee and of earlier determinations of the Civil Service Commission that it was impracticable to fill the position by competitive or noncompetitive examinations, and in the light of the history of the position and its classification as exempt, it could not be said that the enactment constituted an arbitrary declaration by the Legislature.

2. The Legislature has the power to classify civil service employees. It need not delegate such power to another agency, such as the Civil Service Commission. It retains the power, within constitutional limitations as to practicability, to classify certain positions as exempt from competitive examinations. Such power cannot be exercised arbitrarily but must be exercised reasonably.

3. Petitioner's proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act in the nature of mandamus was not an action for a declaratory judgment, even though, to grant petitioner's prayer for relief, necessarily, there would have to be a declaration of the unconstitutionality of the law under attack. Petitioner, a citizen who held office in the Civil Service Employees' Association, was entitled to maintain the proceeding. Description of petitioner as an officer of [***4] that association was mere surplusage and neither added to nor detracted from the efficacy of the petition.

4. Petitioner was not relegated to the taxpayer's action provided for in section 28 of the Civil Service Law. The action therein provided for is one for a violation of the Civil Service Law itself, while the proceeding at bar was one to compel public officers to perform a duty allegedly required by constitutional mandate.

5. An allegation in the petition that it was practicable to test the merits of workmen's compensation referees by competitive examination was not admitted upon motion to dismiss the petition for insufficiency in law. Factual allegations of the petition were admitted by the motion to dismiss, but not conclusory allegations.

 

2714 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dawson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Buffalo


207 Misc. 994; 139 N.Y.S.2d 496; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3457; 28 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P69,271



March 3, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant truck drivers, who were charged with a violation of N.Y. Labor Law § 167, challenged the constitutionality of the statute on the ground that it was beyond the power of the legislature to enact legislation regulating commerce between states, the jurisdiction of the Congress of the United States with respect thereto being exclusive, and that § 167 had been superseded by the Federal Motor Carriers Act, 49 U.S.C.S. § 301 et seq.


OVERVIEW: The truck drivers were charged with a violation of N.Y. Labor Law § 167. The truck drivers contended that § 167 was unconstitutional on the ground that it was beyond the power of the legislature to enact legislation regulating commerce between states and that § 167 had been superseded by the Federal Motor Carriers Act, 49 U.S.C.S. § 301 et seq. The court held that so far as the trucking industry was concerned, when it was engaged directly in interstate commerce, N.Y. Labor Law § 167 had no application to said trucking industry, but the rules and regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission governed and controlled. It was reasoned that Congress was empowered to regulate and to provide the law for the government of interstate commerce. Further, the court held that Congress had the power to enact all appropriate regulation for its protection and advancement, to adopt measures to promote its growth and insure its safety, and to foster, protect, control and restrain. Thus, the court found that the State's contention that the federal regulations did not supersede the State law was untenable. Therefore, the court discharged the truck drivers.


OUTCOME: The court discharged the truck drivers who were charged with violating the law as it related to driving a truck or bus continuously for more hours than allowed by law without taking a break for a certain amount of hours.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- carriers -- commerce -- motor vehicles -- hours of labor of operators of motor trucks and buses -- Labor Law ( § 167) directs rest period for drivers off bus or truck after ten hours on duty; statute has no application to drivers engaged directly in interstate commerce, but in such case rules and regulations of Interstate Commerce Commission govern.

 Section 167 of the Labor Law, which provides that when any driver of a motor truck or motor bus shall have been on duty continuously for ten hours, even though part of such time shall have been outside the State of New York, he shall not continue or again go on duty without having had at least eight consecutive hours off duty off the truck or bus, has no application to drivers engaged directly in interstate commerce, but in such case the rules and regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission govern and control. Accordingly, in a prosecution under section 167 of the Labor Law of drivers of a motor truck who drove from North Carolina to New York, with a cargo of merchandise to be delivered in New York,  [***2] in one continuous journey of thirty-two consecutive hours, the defendants were required to be discharged.

 

2715 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gerosa v. Long Island R. Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


207 Misc. 360; 138 N.Y.S.2d 535; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2639



February 21, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city brought an action against defendant railroad, challenging the constitutionality of the Railroad Redevelopment Corporations Act, 1954 N.Y. Laws ch. 824. The railroad filed a motion to dismiss, for judgment on the pleadings, and for declaration of constitutionality of the Act.


OVERVIEW: The city contended that the Act was unconstitutional because it violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 17, and art. XVI, § 1. The railroad argued that the city lacked power or authority to challenge the constitutionality of the Act. The court granted the motion. The articles and sections cited by the city prohibited passing a private or local bill granting exclusive privilege, immunity, or franchise or exemption from taxation on real or personal property. The issue was whether the Act was constitutional or whether the legislation special as distinguished from general. The court held that the Act was valid and regular upon its face and that it was not limited to any one or number of railroads or to any particular geographical location but applied equally to railroads in the class specified which may presently or later qualify. As such, it was general and did not violate the constitution.


OUTCOME: The court granted the railroad's motion to dismiss, for judgment on the pleadings, and for declaration of constitutionality of the Railroad Redevelopment Corporations Act.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- private or local bills -- (1) Railroad Redevelopment Corporations Act (L. 1954, ch. 824) does not violate prohibitions of State Constitution against passage of private or local bills granting exclusive privilege, immunity or franchise or exemption from taxation (art. III, § 17; art. XVI, § 1) -- (2) general, and special or private bills, distinguished.

1. The Railroad Redevelopment Corporations Act (L. 1954, ch. 824) does not offend provisions of the State Constitution prohibiting the passage of private or local bills granting exclusive privilege, immunity or franchise (art. III, § 17), or exemption from taxation on real or personal property (art. XVI, § 1).

2. A law which relates to persons or things as a class is general, but one which relates to particular persons or things of a class is special and private. The Railroad Redevelopment Corporations Act does not specify any particular railroad or grant exclusive franchise or privilege to defendant railroad but applies equally to all which come within the class in general.

 

2716 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Vanderbilt v. Vanderbilt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


207 Misc. 294; 138 N.Y.S.2d 222; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2605



February 18, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wife instituted an action against defendant husband for a separation on the grounds of cruelty, abandonment, and nonsupport. The husband interposed, as an affirmative defense constituting a bar to the action, a final decree of absolute divorce which he obtained from the wife in Nevada. Following the dismissal of the action, the wife made a claim for maintenance pursuant to N.Y. Civil Practice Act § 1170-b.


OVERVIEW: The husband contended that § 1170-b could not lawfully be applied to the facts as presented and, in any event, contended that the statute was unconstitutional. The court held that the wife came within the purview and protection of the statute because she had been a domiciliary and resident of the state for more than a year prior to the commencement of her suit, and she was, therefore, a resident at the time of the effective date of § 1170-b. The court concluded that the wife was entitled to maintenance, pursuant to the provisions of § 1170-b, because the wife's right to maintenance was not been affected by the Nevada decree and was fully protected by § 1170-b. Finally, the court held that the denial of the separation did not terminate the action, for it continued in respect of the wife's application for maintenance and the determination of her right to maintenance. Accordingly, the court awarded the wife maintenance of a weekly sum and additional counsel fees.


OUTCOME: The court awarded the wife maintenance of a weekly sum and additional counsel fees.


HEADNOTES

Husband and wife -- maintenance of wife where divorce or annulment previously granted on nonpersonal jurisdiction -- (1) section 1170-b of Civil Practice Act provides that in action for divorce, separation or annulment, or for declaration of nullity of void marriage, where relief denied by reason of finding that divorce, annulment or judgment declaring marriage nullity had previously been granted to husband in action in which jurisdiction over person of wife had not been obtained, court may, nevertheless, render in same action such judgment as justice may require for maintenance of wife; statute constitutional -- (2) legislative intent in enactment of section 1170-b, and history and background of enactment, set forth -- (3) wife whose residence and domicile in New York was of sufficient duration to enable her to maintain action for separation, and who was resident on effective date of section 1170-b, whose action for separation has been dismissed solely by reason of bar of defendant's prior divorce in sister State granted on nonpersonal jurisdiction, comes within protection  [***2] of section 1170-b -- (4) defendant's contention that statute applies only to New York domiciliaries where marital domicile is in New York and husband has departed therefrom, untenable -- (5) section 1170-b does not present any new or different standard for making award to wife for her maintenance -- (6) wife who comes within purview of section 1170-b not in same category as wife whose marriage has been annulled; her rights are same as they were before defendant procured divorce in sister State -- (7) denial of separation did not terminate action, which continued in respect of plaintiff's application for maintenance; wife entitled to allowance for maintenance and also to counsel fee.

1. Section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act (enacted by L. 1953, ch. 663) which provides, that "in an action for divorce, separation or annulment, or for a declaration of nullity of a void marriage, where the court refuses to grant such relief by reason of a finding by the court that a divorce, annulment or judgment declaring the marriage a nullity had previously been granted to the husband in an action in which jurisdiction over the person of the wife was not obtained, the court may, nevertheless,  [***3] render in the same action such judgment as justice may require for the maintenance of the wife", is constitutional.

2. The legislative intent in the enactment of section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act, and the history and background of that enactment, set forth.

3. A wife whose residence and domicile in New York was of sufficient duration to enable her to maintain an action for separation (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1165-a, subd. 3), and who was a resident on the effective date of section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act, whose action for separation has been dismissed solely by reason of the bar of defendant's prior divorce in a sister State granted on nonpersonal jurisdiction, comes within the purview and protection of section 1170-b.

4. Defendant's contention that the statute applies only to New York domiciliaries where the marital domicile is in New York and the husband has departed therefrom, is untenable. Where the parties' mode of life was constant luxurious travel, with periodic places of residence or domicile, and defendant failed and refused to support plaintiff and returned to a sister State for the purpose of re-establishing his domicile and there instituted his action for [***4] divorce, plaintiff was not obligated to pursue defendant, and plaintiff could achieve a domicile or residence of her own choice.

5. Section 1170-b does not present any new or different standard for making an award to a wife for her maintenance. The standard of maintenance is such an amount "as justice may require."

6. A wife who comes within the purview of section 1170-b is not in the same category as a wife whose marriage has been annulled; her rights are the same as they were before defendant procured his divorce in the sister State.

7. The denial of the separation did not terminate the action, which continued in respect of plaintiff's application for maintenance and the determination of her right to maintenance under section 1170-b,both in law and in fact. Plaintiff wife is entitled to an allowance for maintenance and also to a counsel fee, notwithstanding the dismissal of her complaint for separation.

 

2717 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Foreclosure of Tax Liens


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


138 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2646



February 17, 1955 

 

2718 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Parker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court of New York, Borough of Manhattan, Youth Term Court


208 Misc. 978; 138 N.Y.S.2d 2; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2588



February 16, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with disorderly conduct by loitering in a school building in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 722-b (1954). Defendant filed motions to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: In his motion to dismiss the criminal complaint, defendant attacked § 722-b on the ground that it was too vague, indefinite, and uncertain to be enforceable as a penal statute. Alternatively, defendant argued that if the statute was deemed to be constitutional, then he should be acquitted because there was nothing in his actions or intent to provoke a breach of the peace. The court denied defendant's motions to dismiss the complaint. The court held that the statute was enforceable because its words and phrases did not appear so vague and indefinite that the penalty prescribed for its violation constituted a violation of due process of law. The court held that it was clear that the meaning of the word "loiter" as employed in § 722-b was sufficiently definite and certain to advise the public generally what acts and conduct were prohibited. The court held that based upon the evidence that defendant was on the premises for an unauthorized reason, and that he was there to linger only for personal reasons, it was satisfied that defendant had committed such an act as to constitute disorderly conduct.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions to dismiss the complaint which charged him with disorderly conduct by loitering in a school building.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- disorderly conduct -- loitering in school building -- (1) that section of Penal Law ( § 722-b) which provides that one who loiters in or about public school building or grounds shall be guilty of disorderly conduct, not too vague or indefinite to be enforced as penal statute; statute constitutional; defendant, who entered school building for purpose of meeting certain pupil in lavatory, "loitered" in building and was guilty of disorderly conduct, though he was in building only few minutes and there was no molestation or disturbance -- (2) courts should indulge every presumption in favor of validity of statute -- (3) elements to be considered in determining intent with which statutes enacted, stated -- (4) legislative intent to be sought from language in statute -- (5) statute (Penal Law, § 722-b) enacted to remedy abuses resulting from presence of intruders and loiterers in and about school premises -- (6) statute cannot be held void for uncertainty if any reasonable and practical construction can be given to its language -- (7) statute not to be determined ambiguous through  [***2] strained construction -- (8) meaning of word "loiter" sufficiently definite to advise public what conduct prohibited -- (9) word "loiter" defined -- (10) argument that statute would arbitrarily subject innocuous and legitimate acts to penal sanctions, untenable; constitutional questions not to be decided hypothetically -- (11) right to use public property subject to reasonable regulation -- (12) right of Legislature to enact law forbidding loitering on school premises beyond question -- (13) where evil sought to be prevented by statute apparent, reasonable construction of statutory language justified -- (14) "disorderly conduct" defined -- (15) term "breach of peace" includes not only violations of public peace and order, but acts which tend toward disturbance thereof; criminal law seeks to prevent as well as to vindicate -- (16) words "to loiter" used in reference to public building carry connotation of unlawful presence on part of offender; act forbidden by statute (Penal Law, § 722-b) is one motivated by reasons unconnected with purposes for which school buildings or environs used -- (17) not necessary to constitute disorderly conduct that person specifically intend to provoke  [***3] breach of peace;
