offense can be committed by doing act whereby breach of peace may be occasioned -- (18) conduct which tends to breach of peace within certain limitations is matter of discretion on part of magistrate.

1. Section 722-b of the Penal Law, which provides that any person not the parent or legal guardian of a pupil who loiters in or about any public school building or grounds shall be guilty of disorderly conduct, is not too vague, indefinite and uncertain to be enforcible as a penal statute, and is not unconstitutional. Defendant, who entered a public school building for the claimed purpose of collecting a debt from a pupil he had arranged to meet in a school lavatory, "loitered" in the building and was guilty of disorderly conduct within the statute, though he was in the building only two or three minutes and there was no evidence of molestation, annoyance, disturbance or destruction of property.

2. Courts should indulge every presumption in favor of validity and declare no act of the Legislature void unless invalidity be shown beyond a reasonable doubt.

3. The intent with which statutes have been enacted is to be determined from the content, the occasion and necessity [***4] of the law, from the evils to be corrected, and the objects and remedy in view.

4. The legislative intent is to be sought and ascertained from the words and language used in the statute.

5. Section 722-b of the Penal Law was enacted to remedy abuses resulting from the presence of intruders and loiterers in and about school premises and was designed to protect children, school personnel and school property.

6. A statute cannot be held void for uncertainty if any reasonable and practical construction can be given to its language. Mere difficulty in ascertaining its meaning, or the fact that it is susceptible of different interpretations, will not render it nugatory. In determining whether a penal statute is sufficiently explicit to inform those who are subject to it what is required by them, the courts should view the statute from the standpoint of the reasonable man who might be subject to its terms.

7. When a statute employs words or phrases that have a well-settled meaning of which a reasonable man in the ordinary conduct of his affairs is fully aware, it is not for the court to determine that the statute is ambiguous or indefinite because through a strained construction of those [***5] words and phrases some ambiguity might arise.

8. The meaning of the word "loiter" as employed in section 722-b of the Penal Law is sufficiently definite and certain to advise the public generally what acts and conduct are prohibited.

9. The term "loitering" has by long statutory usage taken on a reasonably definite meaning. The word means to be slow in moving; to delay; to hinder; to be dilatory; to spend time idly; to saunter; to lag behind.

10. Argument that the statute would arbitrarily and unreasonably subject innocuous and legitimate acts to penal sanctions is untenable. Constitutional questions are not to be decided hypothetically, and when particular facts control the decision they must be shown.

11. The rights of the individual are subservient to the welfare of the general public. The right to use public property is subject to such reasonable regulations as the governing body may make for the general good.

12. The right of the Legislature to enact a law forbidding persons from loitering on school premises, especially when students are in attendance, is beyond question.

13. Where the evil sought to be prevented by a statute is apparent, a reasonable construction of the [***6] language employed in the statute is justified.

14. Disorderly conduct embraces certain minor offenses, usually defined by statute, consisting of disturbance of the peace and quiet of the public or communities, families or a class of persons, or of conduct which tends to cause or provoke a breach of the peace or corrupt public morals, and a willful or unlawful purpose is not an element of the offense unless made so by statute.

15. The term "breach of the peace" includes not only all violations of the public peace and order, but acts which tend toward the disturbance thereof. The criminal law seeks to prevent as well as to vindicate, and a threatened danger demands correction the same as an actual one. The community is disturbed when it is alarmed. The unauthorized presence of defendant in the school came within the definition of disorderly conduct, constituting conduct which tended toward a breach of the peace.

16. When the words "to loiter" are used in reference to a public building, there is a connotation of unlawful presence on the part of the offender. While no specific intent is prescribed as an element of the offense, the act forbidden by the statute (Penal Law, § 722-b) is [***7] motivated by reasons unconnected with the purposes for which school buildings or their environs are used.

17. It is not necessary to constitute the offense of disorderly conduct that a person specifically intend to provoke a breach of the peace. The offense can be committed by the doing of any act "whereby a breach of the peace may be occasioned." That teachers and pupils were not actually annoyed is not material. The unauthorized presence could have been resented either forcibly or by loud or boisterous action.

18. Conduct which tends to a breach of the peace within certain limitations is a matter of discretion on the part of the magistrate.

 

2719 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Karom v. Altarac


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, LONG BEACH, NASSAU COUNTY


137 N.Y.S.2d 655; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2558



February 9, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tort victim commenced an action against defendant property owner to recover for personal injuries sustained by the tort victim by reason of the failure of the property owner to repair the curbstone of the sidewalk in front of his property as required by the Charter of the City of Long Beach § 256. The matter came before the court for decision.


OVERVIEW: The tort victim was performing his duties as a special police officer when he had occasion to step off the sidewalk in front of the property owner's premises. The curbstone of the sidewalk was broken, and the tort victim fell and injured himself. In the instant action, the property owner sought to dismiss the tort victim's complaint on the ground that the City Charter of the City of Long Beach § 256 (§ 256) was unconstitutional, null, and void because the city by local law was powerless to create a remedy for damages in favor of the tort victim against the property owner or to impose a liability for damages on the property owner. The property owner claimed that only the state legislature could create such a remedy in favor of the tort victim. The court rejected the property owner's contention, holding that § 256 was not subversive of the fundamental law of the state, did not supersede a state law, and met the test of constitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court granted judgment in favor of the tort victim and against the property owner.

 

2720 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gaydos v. Edwards


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


139 N.Y.S.2d 154; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3432



January 26, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff claimant asserted ownership of certain land, while defendant claimant asserted ownership of land that covered a part of the same area claimed by plaintiff. Plaintiff brought the instant action, pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Law art 15, to have the rights and interests of the parties in and to the land adjudicated and determined.


OVERVIEW: The land at issue was the subject of two separate subdivision maps that were filed in the office of the clerk of the county in which the land was located. The land underlying the two maps was doubly assessed for taxes by reference to each of the maps. At a tax sale, lots on each of the maps were sold to the county. At a subsequent tax sale, another portion of the land on one of the maps was sold to the county. The county sold certain lots to plaintiff by reference to one of the maps. The county subsequently conveyed certain lots to defendant's predecessor-in-interest by reference to the other map. All of the land conveyed by the county to defendant's predecessor-in-interest and a portion of the land conveyed by the county to plaintiff was at issue. The court held that plaintiff owned all of the land at issue that was conveyed to him by the county, except for one lot that was not acquired by the county until the second tax sale. Defendant was held to be the owner of that remaining lot.


OUTCOME: The court held that plaintiff owned the bulk of the land, while defendant owned a certain portion of the land and so much of the unopened road that was situated in front of defendant's land to the center line thereof.

 

2721 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lerner v. Casey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


138 N.Y.S.2d 777; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2681



January 25, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner subway conductor filed a petition under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 for an order directing respondent New York City Transit Authority to reinstate the conductor to his position as a conductor. The Authority filed a motion to dismiss the petition.


OVERVIEW: The conductor was terminated from his position as a conductor by the Authority on the belief he was a security risk for being a member of the communist party pursuant to N.Y. Security Risk Law § 1105. The conductor filed a petition under the N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 for an order directing the Authority to reinstate the conductor to his position. The Authority filed a motion to dismiss the petition. The court granted the Authority's motion to dismiss the petition and held that the conductor, as a civil servant, had no vested right in his position and the legislature therefore could say at any time upon what terms and conditions his employment may be continued or discontinued. The court ruled that it did not seem unreasonable for the legislature to adopt a procedure by which persons holding positions in security agencies could be dismissed where there was reason to believe that they might be members of subversive organizations. The court held that the N.Y. Security Risk Law was valid and constitutional because it was definite and clear and under its provisions the conductor was afforded all the safeguards of due process.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Authority's motion to dismiss the conductor's petition for an order that would direct the Authority to reinstate the conductor to his position as a conductor.

 

2722 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gerosa v. Long Island R. Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


138 N.Y.S.2d 533; 1955 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2638



January 13, 1955 

 

2723 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Roer Constr. Corp. v. New Rochelle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


207 Misc. 46; 136 N.Y.S.2d 414; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3137



December 23, 1954 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the motion is granted. Settle order and judgment on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowner brought an action for a declaratory judgment against defendant city seeking a declaration that the official map of the city and a resolution of the common council amending the map were unconstitutional and void as they related to the landowner's property. The landowner filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The landowner bought a 3.74-acre tract of land with the intention of building an apartment building on it. The landowner took steps to remove the temporary structures on the land and applied to the city for approval of its site plan. The city then amended its official map to show that the entire property of the landowner would be taken for the construction of a highway. The city took no further action toward construction of the highway, but under N.Y. Gen. City Law § 35 no part of the landowner's property could be developed unless the zoning board of appeals granted a permit. The board denied the landowner a permit. The court held that the city's regulation of the landowner's property went beyond the bounds of permissive regulation and became a taking of the property. The landowner could not use it for any purpose, yet the construction of the highway was indefinitely delayed. The court held that the resolution and the official map were an unconstitutional interference with the owner's property rights. It did not matter if the owner knew of the city's intention to someday construct a highway there before it bought the property.


OUTCOME: The court granted the landowner's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- official maps and planning boards -- (1) plaintiff entered into agreement to purchase parcel of land in New Rochelle consisting of approximately three and three-fourths acres in February of 1953; closing of title was set ahead to permit removal of temporary housing structures and tenants occupying them and clearing of ground for construction of apartment building; in February of 1954, plaintiff filed with municipal planning board, site plan for its apartment building and had architect prepare plans therefor; various summary proceedings, in which city participated as party, were instituted to remove tenants occupying structures and in March of 1954, plaintiff acquired title; plaintiff's site plan was approved by planning board on May 13, 1954, and four days later common council adopted resolution amending official city map so as to include plaintiff's entire premises within confines of proposed "Memorial Highway"; zoning board thereafter denied plaintiff's application under General City Law (§  [***2] 35) for building permit; property has remained unimproved and plaintiff receives no income therefrom; concededly, no date has been set for further progress in connection with acquisition of plaintiff's lands for proposed highway; plaintiff seeks declaratory judgment that amended official map and resolution adopted pursuant to General City Law (art. 3) whereby map was amended are unconstitutional and void; on plaintiff's motion for summary judgment (Rules Civ. Prac., rule 113) no material and triable issue of fact, and only issue of law, was presented; motion granted -- (2) where no material and triable issue of fact presented, but only question of law involved, motion for summary judgment may be considered and determined -- (3) provisions of General City Law relating to official maps and planning boards (art. 3) and particularly section 35 of that law intended for public purpose and to advance general welfare; where municipality so restricts use of property that it cannot be used for any reasonable purpose, act of city must be recognized as taking of such property -- (4) plaintiff established its entire property had been included in official map, as amended, that it purchased premises  [***3] with expressed desire of erecting thereon its apartment building and zoning board has denied application for building permit; city, without payment of compensation, deprived plaintiff of use and enjoyment of all its lands for period of indefinite duration; resolution and official map constitute unconstitutional interference with vested rights and are void -- (5) city contends resolution and official map were adopted for purpose of solving city's traffic problem and that plaintiff's grievance is self-created because it had notice of city's intention to include plaintiff's lands in amended map; plaintiff's property may not be taken without compensation in order to solve city's traffic problems; fact that plaintiff knew of contemplated change in official map would not bar it from relief sought; such knowledge of owner cannot validate otherwise invalid ordinance or resolution.

1. Plaintiff in February of 1953, entered into an agreement to purchase a parcel of land in the city of New Rochelle consisting of approximately three and three-fourths acres. The closing of title was set ahead about ten months and was thereafter adjourned to permit the removal of temporary housing structures [***4] on the premises and the tenants occupying them and the clearing of the property for the construction of an apartment building. In February of 1954, in compliance with pertinent ordinances of the city, plaintiff filed with the municipal planning board a site plan in connection with the construction of the apartment building, had an architect prepare plans for the proposed building and took steps necessary in connection with a mortgage in order to finance construction. In January of 1954, various summary proceedings, in which the city was a party and a participant, were instituted and completed in the City Court of New Rochelle for the purpose of dispossessing the tenants in the temporary structures and in March of 1954, plaintiff acquired title to the premises. In May of 1954, plaintiff obtained an order in the Supreme Court requiring the planning board to act on the application for approval of plaintiff's site plan and on May 13, 1954, the board approved the plan. On May 17, 1954, the common council of the city adopted a resolution amending the official map of the city so as to include plaintiff's entire premises within the confines of a proposed "Memorial Highway" in New Rochelle.  [***5] Plaintiff then applied to the zoning board of appeals for a building permit in accordance with section 35 of the General City Law, and on July 21, 1954, its application was denied. Plaintiff's property has, therefore, remained unimproved and it receives no income therefrom. It was conceded by the city that no date had been set for further progress in connection with the acquisition of plaintiff's lands for, or the construction thereon of, the proposed highway. Plaintiff seeks a declaratory judgment that the official map of the city, as amended on May 17, 1954, and the resolution adopted by the common council pursuant to article 3 of the General City Law whereby the map was amended, are unconstitutional and void, insofar as plaintiff's property is affected. The city's answer denies (1) knowledge or information that plaintiff purchased the premises for the sole purpose of erecting an apartment building in conformity with the city's zoning ordinance and (2) that the resolution of the common council and the resultant amendment of the city's official map are unconstitutional and void with respect of plaintiff's premises. However, on plaintiff's motion for summary judgment (Rules Civ.  [***6] Prac., rule 113), while no facts are contained in the city's affidavit in support of its denial in item (1), plaintiff's affidavits and exhibits establish that it purchased the property for the specific purpose and with the intention of erecting an apartment building in accordance with the zoning regulations. The city's denial as to the second item constitutes an issue of law. Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is granted.

2. Where no material and triable issue of fact is presented, but there is only involved a question of law, a motion for summary judgment may properly be considered and determined.

3. The provisions of article 3 of the General City Law [relating to official maps and planning boards] and particularly section 35 of that law, are regulatory in character and were intended for a public purpose and to advance the general welfare. However, where pursuant to authority granted by the Legislature, a municipality so restricts the use of property that it cannot be used for any reasonable purpose, then the act of the municipality goes beyond the bounds of permissive regulation and must be recognized as a taking of the property.

4. Plaintiff established: (1) that its [***7] entire property has been included in the city's official map, as amended, and has thereby been subjected to the provisions of section 35 of the General City Law; (2) that it purchased the property with the expressed desire and for the distinct purpose of erecting thereon an apartment building, which it still plans to build; and (3) that it has applied to the zoning board of appeals for a building permit so as to proceed with the erection of the structure, but that such application has been denied. Accordingly, where the city has, without the payment of any compensation therefor, deprived plaintiff of the use and enjoyment of all of its lands for a period of indefinite duration, the resolution and official map affecting such deprivation constitute an unconstitutional interference with vested rights of property and are, therefore void.

5. The city contends that the resolution and the amended official map were adopted in good faith and for the public purpose of solving the existing and future traffic problems of the city and also that when plaintiff purchased the premises it had actual or constructive notice of proposed plans in the office of the city planning board indicating the city's [***8] intention to include all of plaintiff's premises in an amended official map and hence plaintiff's grievance is a self-created hardship for which there is no basis for relief. The need for additional highways in solving the city's traffic problem may be acute, but plaintiff's property may not be taken without compensation. Nor may plaintiff similarly be deprived of the use and enjoyment thereof for an indefinite period in the guise of regulation, even for a public purpose. The fact that plaintiff knew of the contemplated change in the official map would not bar it from the relief sought. Such knowledge of an owner cannot validate an otherwise invalid ordinance or resolution and the owner is not, by such knowledge, precluded from challenging said ordinance or resolution on the ground that it is unconstitutional.

 

2724 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Parsons


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Steuben County


207 Misc. 107; 135 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3046



December 7, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers filed an action against defendant board of education to challenge the creation of a school district. The board filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: A commissioner of education entered an order consolidating school districts into one school district. The taxpayers claimed that the consolidated school district established by the commissioner was illegally created and that no district existed at law. Therefore, the taxpayers asserted that the board could not assess or tax the taxpayers' property. The board filed motions to dismiss the taxpayers' complaints, asserting that the court lacked jurisdiction, the taxpayers lacked capacity to sue, and the taxpayers' complaints failed to state a cause of action. Pursuant to State education law, the court found that the commissioner could, in his discretion, order a meeting or an election. However, the commissioner was not made a party to the taxpayers' actions. The court determined that the taxpayers were not denied their right to equal protection under the law and could not stand in for the district's taxpayers, who were also not a part of the action. As the commissioner, under powers delegated by the legislature, acted properly, the court concluded that the board was entitled to their motions to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court granted the board's motions to dismiss the taxpayers' actions.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- consolidated school districts -- (1) complaints in companion actions seek declaratory judgment determining that consolidated school district ordered established by Commissioner of Education in and about city of Corning was illegally created and enjoining defendants from acting in behalf of district and from taxing plaintiffs' properties; complaints set forth claims that consolidation not made in accordance with Education Law (§ 1526) and that in any event statute unconstitutional; complaints alleged that election on proposition was illegally conducted and that statute constitutes unlawful delegation of powers and duties of Legislature; complaints dismissed -- (2) section 2037 of Education Law vests in Commissioner of Education for determination precise question which plaintiffs seek to have Supreme Court determine, namely, validity of school election; Supreme Court does not have jurisdiction to review determination -- (3) plaintiffs do not complain that they were denied right to vote, but claim that voters in city school district were denied that right; plaintiffs do not have status to raise  [***2] that objection on behalf of such voters; no constitutional right to vote in school district -- (4) complaints defective in charging provisions of Education Law are unconstitutional as constituting delegation of legislative power without establishing suitable standards -- (5) Legislature did legislate (Education Law, § 1526) with respect to subject in controversy so far as reasonably practicable, and from necessities of case left to commissioner duty of bringing about result pointed out by statute; statute constitutional -- (6) complaints dismissed, despite absence of answers, where complaints insufficient in law.

1. The complaints in these companion actions seek a declaratory judgment determining that a consolidated school district ordered established by the State Commissioner of Education on July 1, 1954, in and about the city of Corning was illegally created, that the order was void, that no such district exists in law, and enjoining defendants from acting in behalf of the district and assessing and taxing the property of either plaintiff in the district. The pleadings allege that by the order the commissioner consolidated sixty-one school districts with school district No.  [***3] 9 of the City of Corning and set forth two basic claims that the consolidation was not made in accordance with section 1526 of the Education Law and that in any event the statute is unconstitutional. Plaintiffs contend that the election upon which the commissioner based his order was illegal because former school district No. 13 of the City of Corning was a city school district as defined by subdivision 16 of section 2 of the Education Law, and hence that the law (Education Law, §§ 2603-2606) required that it be divided into school districts, that the elections be conducted in schoolhouses and that all voters therein be duly registered before the day of an election, and it is alleged that the election on the proposition of consolidation was held in the State armory, that the voters of school district No. 13 had not been registered as required by law and by inference it is stated that some of them voted, thereby illegally affecting the result of the election. The complaints further allege that the statute does not authorize the voters of school district No. 9, with which the surrounding area is consolidated, to vote, that they were not permitted to vote and were thus denied equal [***4] protection under the law to their detriment and the detriment of plaintiffs, and that the statute (Education Law, § 1526) does not establish suitable standards as guides to the Commissioner of Education and constitutes an unlawful delegation of the powers and duties of the Legislature. Motions to dismiss the complaints are granted.

2. Section 2037 of the Education Law provides: "All disputes concerning the validity of any district meeting or election or of any of the acts of the officers of such meeting or election shall be referred to the commissioner of education for determination and his decisions in the matter shall be final and not subject to review. The commissioner may in his discretion order a new meeting or election". That section is unequivocal and mandatory and vests in the Commissioner of Education for determination the very question which plaintiffs are asking the Supreme Court to determine, namely, the validity of the school election. The court is asked to make such determination in an action to which the commissioner has not been made a party. The Supreme Court does not have jurisdiction, in these actions, to review the determination, formal or implied, of the [***5] commissioner that the election, of which plaintiffs complain, was valid. Moreover, the complaints contain no allegation that any of the voters of school district No. 13 of the City of Corning did in fact vote in this election.

3. Plaintiffs do not claim that plaintiffs were denied the right to vote, but claim merely that the voters in city school district No. 9 were denied that right. For aught that appears, the voters in the city district are satisfied with the provisions of the law which authorize their board of education to vote for them, and none has indicated to the court that he feels aggrieved. The law deals in realities in these matters and plaintiffs may not raise philosophical objections when the persons for whom they purport to speak do not object. The State Constitution has vested in the Legislature power to "provide for the maintenance and support of a system of free common schools, wherein all the children of this state may be educated" (N. Y. Const., art. XI, § 1). There is no constitutional right to vote in a school district.

4. The complaints also are defective in respect of allegations which charge that the applicable provisions of the Education Law are unconstitutional [***6] as constituting a delegation of legislative power to the Commissioner of Education without establishing suitable standards as guides for his actions in behalf of the Legislature. The office of Commissioner of Education of the State of New York is provided for by the State Constitution (art. V, §§ 2, 4). In conformity with the State Constitution (art. XI, § 1), the Legislature enacted section 301 of the Education Law which authorizes the Commissioner of Education, subject to the general direction and control of The Regents of the University of the State of New York, to exercise and perform the powers, duties and judicial functions conferred by law upon him and to make, execute and issue such determinations, orders and notices as may be required for the performance of the functions, powers and duties imposed upon the Department of Education. While the Legislature cannot broadly delegate its legislative functions to an officer, it obviously cannot, itself, administer the State free school system.

5. Where a Legislature has legislated on a subject as far as was reasonably practicable and from the necessities of the case was compelled to leave to an executive official the duty of bringing [***7] about the result pointed out by the statute, the functions of such official will be held to be administrative and lawful. The Legislature did legislate (Education Law, § 1526) so far as was reasonably practicable with relation to the subject in controversy. In connection with enlarging city school districts, it set up certain limitations and standards within which the Commissioner of Education should act, to wit: in areas contiguous to a city of less than 125,000 inhabitants, the commissioner is required, within ten daysof entering an order laying out an enlarged district, to certify his proposal to the school districts involved and no areas laid out by the commissioner may be consolidated until a majority of the qualified voters thereof adopt a proposition to consolidate, and the board of education of the city school district consent. Hence, the statute complained of is constitutional.

6. While these actions are for declaratory judgments and answers have not been interposed, the complaints must nevertheless be dismissed where they are insufficient in law.

 

2725 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Snyder v. Delmin Realty Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


207 Misc. 218; 137 N.Y.S.2d 137; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3595



November 12, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant village filed a motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiffs, a pedestrian and others, in an action to recover damages for injuries suffered by the pedestrian when she stepped into a hole in a sidewalk within the village.


OVERVIEW: The pedestrian was injured when she stepped into a hole in a village sidewalk. She sued for her injuries, and the village moved to dismiss the complaint on the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. The village argued that plaintiffs failed to comply with the notice requirements of Hempstead, N.Y., Local Laws No. 1 (1953), which amended N.Y. Village Law § 341(a). Plaintiffs contended that the local law was invalid because villages were restricted to local legislation that related only to their property, affairs, or government. The court found that plaintiffs' conclusion was unwarranted in view of the two concluding sentences of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 16. The court also found it clear that, while the power to enact local laws on matters other than those relating to the property, affairs, or government of a city flowed from a direct constitutional grant of such power, the same power was lodged in a village by virtue of an enabling statute adopted by the legislature. The court held that the local law was validly enacted and that, the complaint having failed to allege compliance with the provisions of the local law, it was fatally defective.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss without prejudice, but provided for the service of an amended complaint within 20 days.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- sidewalks -- villages -- (1) Local Law No. 1 of 1953 of Village of Hempstead, amending Village Law (§ 341-a) constitutional; local law removed from Village Law (§ 341-a) provision with respect to constructive notice of defective sidewalk conditions and made it condition precedent to maintenance of action against village that written notice of existence of defective condition shall have been given trustees and that there shall have been failure or neglect on part of village to correct condition; complaint in action to recover damages for injuries sustained when plaintiff stepped into hole in sidewalk and fell, did not contain allegation that written notice was given or that village did not correct condition after notice; complaint dismissed as to defendant Village of Hempstead, with leave to serve amended complaint -- (2) contention, that unlike cities, villages are restricted to local legislation relating to their property, affairs or government, unwarranted; Legislature, pursuant to authority of State Constitution (art. IX, § 16), enacted Village Home Rule Law so as to enable  [***2] villages to enact, amend or repeal local laws for purpose of exercising powers granted to villages by Constitution -- (3) villages may enact local laws on matters other than those relating to property, affairs or government (Village Home Rule Law, § 11, subd. 1, par. [b]) -- (4) determination of State Comptroller, rendered in 1952, to effect that village having home rule powers may not enact local law to remove constructive notice provision in Village Law (§ 341-a) not appropriate; provision of Village Home Rule Law (§ 11, subd. 4) upon which State Comptroller relied, since amended (L. 1953, ch. 744) so as to permit local legislation pertaining to matters other than property, affairs or government of villages; local law in question was enacted subsequent to effective date of amendment.

1. Local Law No. 1 of 1953 of the Village of Hempstead, effective September 1, 1953, amending section 341-a of the Village Law, was validly enacted and is constitutional. The local law, in substance, removed from section 341-a of the Village Law the provisions with respect to constructive notice of defective sidewalk conditions and made it a condition precedent to the maintenance of an action [***3] against the village that a written notice of the existence of the defective condition shall actually have been given to the board of trustees and that there shall have been a failure or neglect on the part of the village to cause such condition to be corrected or the place made reasonably safe within a reasonable time after the receipt of such notice. Accordingly, the complaint is dismissed as to defendant Village of Hempstead in this action to recover damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained when one of the plaintiffs stepped into a hole in a sidewalk within the village and fell, where the complaint fails to contain an allegation that any written notice was given or that there was a failure or neglect on the part of the village to correct the defective condition after receipt of the notice. However, leave is granted to serve an amended complaint.

2. Plaintiffs' contention that unlike cities, villages are restricted to local legislation which relates only to their property, affairs or government, is unwarranted. The two concluding sentences of section 16 of article IX of the State Constitution give authority to the Legislature to enact laws relating to matters other than [***4] the propery, affairs or government of villages having a population of five thousand or more as determined by the Federal census. This the Legislature has done through the enactment of the Village Home Rule Law with the intention of enabling villages "to enact, amend and repeal local laws for the purpose of fully and completely exercising the powers granted to villages by the terms and spirit" of section 16 of article IX of the Constitution (Village Home Rule Law, § 30).

3. The power of villages in respect of local laws is set forth in section 11 of the Village Home Rule Law. Paragraph (b) of subdivision 1 of that section confers power to enact "local laws in relation to * * * the presentation, ascertainment and discharge of claims against it * * * whether such local laws relate to the property, affairs or government of such village or not". It is further provided that such local laws "may change or supersede any provisions of an act of the legislature theretofore enacted which provision does not in terms and in effect apply alike to all villages having a population of five thousand or more as determined by the federal census". While the power to enact local laws on matters other [***5] than those relating to the property, affairs or government of a city flows from a direct constitutional grant of such power, the same power is lodged in a village by virtue of an enabling statute adopted by the Legislature in pursuance of a power expressly granted in the Constitution to do so.

4. A determination of the State Comptroller, rendered on July 7, 1952, to the effect that a village, having home rule powers, may not enact a local law which would remove the constructive notice provision contained in section 341-a of the Village Law, is not appropriate. Since the rendition of the determination, subdivision 4 of section 11 of the Village Home Rule Law, upon which the State Comptroller relied, has been amended (L. 1953, ch. 744, effective April 15, 1953), so as to remove any question of lack of power to enact local legislation when it pertains to matters other than the property, affairs or government of villages. The local law in question was enacted subsequent to the effective date of the amendment.

 

2726 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fink v. Cole


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


136 N.Y.S.2d 810; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3524



November 10, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner applicant initiated a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review the determination of respondents, the Racing Commission of the State of New York, which refused the applicant's request for an owner's racing license.


OVERVIEW: The Commission allegedly denied the applicant's request for an owner's racing license upon its prior refusal of such an application, which was judicially annulled. No formal hearing was conducted in relation to the application for a license and no new evidence of the applicant's alleged disqualification was produced. The court found that the Commission's own investigations of the applicant that followed the prior refusal disclosed nothing detrimental to the applicant's character that would have disqualified him from holding an owner's racing license. The court held that the Commission's refusal to issue a license was based solely upon the proceedings that occurred five years earlier. The court held that the application did not receive the consideration required in the full discharge of the Commission's duty. The court held that it did not appear that the element of time was considered or that any evidence was taken on the new application. The court ruled that, although no formal hearings were required, the Commission was not entitled to refuse the license on the ground of the applicant's good moral character without given the applicant a fair opportunity to meet the challenge.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the matter to the Commission for further consideration of whether the applicant was entitled to an owner's racing license.

 

2727 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Chisena v. Cent. High Sch. Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


136 N.Y.S.2d 598; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3477



October 21, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers brought an action to enjoin defendant central school district from issuing bonds, and the central school district brought a motion to dismiss the complaint upon the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The board of education of the central school district adopted a bond resolution to issue serial bonds to pay for additional school facilities. The taxpayers sought a judgment to enjoin the sale of the bonds because the indebtedness of the central school district combined with the indebtedness of its component districts exceeded 10 percent of the full value of real property subject to taxation pursuant to N.Y. Local Fin. Law § 104(d). The central school district filed a motion to dismiss the complaint upon the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. The court granted the school district's motion and held that the purposes and functions of the component districts and the central school district were mutually exclusive and distinct and that the indebtedness incurred by each separate entity was distinct from each other. The court ruled that § 104(d) was presumed to be constitutional and that this presumption had not been overcome by the taxpayers.


OUTCOME: The court granted the central school district's motion to dismiss the taxpayers' complaint upon the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.

 

2728 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mancuso v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


207 Misc. 703; 142 N.Y.S.2d 428; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3145



October 16, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant board of education sought judgment on the pleadings or summary judgment in a declaratory judgment action by plaintiff, citizen of Schenectady (New York), alleging that the tax on real property in the Schenectady city school district was illegal and that N.Y. Educ. Law § 2701(1) was, in part, unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The citizen claimed that school district tax in excess of 1 1/4 percent of the average equalized valuation was illegal. He also challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Educ. Law § 2701, which added a proviso to the N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 10 tax formula to accommodate school district boundary changes. In 1948, the school district's boundaries changed because of a land annexation. In 1949, the tax rate was more than 1 1/4 percent. The court dismissed the citizen's petition because both the tax and statute were lawful implementations of the constitution. Both N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 10(e) and N.Y. Educ. Law § 2701 were submitted to the legislature as part of a single scheme of regulation. Section 2701 was designed to take care of a situation where school district changes occurred between July 1, 1947 and January 1, 1950. The legislature intended that the geographical entity existing as of January 1, 1950, the effective date of N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 10(e), controlled the tax rate. Because the language of the statute was consistent with and could readily be reconciled with the purpose of the constitution, it was presumed constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the board's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- constitutional tax limitations affecting school districts -- subdivision 1 of section 2701 of Education Law, providing that tax limit of school district whose boundaries were altered during period between July 1, 1947, and January 1, 1950, shall be based upon first fiscal year of school district as so altered, lawful implementation of constitutional provision (N. Y. Const., art. VIII, § 10, subd. [e]) governing tax limitations affecting school districts.

The Legislature, in 1948 and 1949, approved changes in that provision of the State Constitution (art. VIII, § 10, subd. [e]) governing constitutional tax limitations affecting school districts, as part of a program for changes in city-school fiscal relations, and such changes having been approved by the People in a constitutional referendum in 1949, became effective January 1, 1950. It was provided, so far as pertinent, to limit taxes on real estate for:"any school district which is coterminous with or partly within or wholly within, a city having less than one hundred twenty-five thousand inhabitants according to the latest federal census, for school district purposes,  [***2] one and one-quarter per centum; provided, however, that if the taxes subject to this limitation levied for any such school district for its first fiscal year beginning on or after July first, nineteen hundred forty-seven, were in excess of one and one-quarter per centum but not greater than one and one-half per centum, then for such school district the limitation shall be one and one-half per centum." In 1949 the Legislature added section 2701 to the Education Law (L. 1949, ch. 847), following the formula of section 10 of article VIII of the Constitution, but adding, in subdivision 1 of section 2701, the proviso that: "Where, after July first, nineteen hundred forty-seven, and before January first, nineteen hundred fifty, a consolidated school district shall have been created, or the boundaries of any school district shall have been altered so that real estate subject to taxation for school purposes shall have been added to or subtracted from the area of such district, the term 'first fiscal year beginning on or after July first, nineteen hundred forty-seven' shall refer to the first fiscal year for which taxes were levied for the school district as so created or altered." Schenectady [***3] is a city of less than 125,000 population. In 1948 the tax rate of the City of Schenectady school district was less than 1 1/4% of the average equalized valuation of real property in that district. In that year the boundaries of that district were altered by the annexation of certain additional land, and in 1949 the tax rate was more than 1 1/4% and less than 1 1/2%. In an action for a judgment declaring that a tax in excess of 1 1/4% of the average equalized valuation of real property in the Schenectady city school district is illegal and declaring that subdivision 1 of section 2701 of the Education Law is in part unconstitutional, motion of the defendant for judgment dismissing the complaint is granted. Section 2701 of the Education law is a lawful implementation of the Constitution and is not unconstitutional insofar as it provides that the tax limit of a school district whose boundaries were altered during the period between July 1, 1947, and January 1, 1950, shall be based upon the first fiscal year of the school district as so altered. The Legislature intended that the geographical entity existing as of January 1, 1950, the effective date of the constitutional amendment,  [***4] was the one which controlled the tax rate and not that of some previously existing entity.

 

2729 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Special Sessions held by a City Magistrate of the City of New York, Borough of Queens


206 Misc. 585; 134 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2797



October 8, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, an owner of a commercial car wash, was prosecuted by the People of the State of New York pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 2143 for permitting his employees to commercially wash cars under his supervision on a Sunday. claimed that keeping cars clean was a necessary public service and that § 2143 did not specifically ban car-washing.


OVERVIEW: The People alleged that the chore of keeping cars clean on a Sunday was not a work of charity or necessity, the only exceptions to the rule found in N.Y. Penal Law § 2143, and that the necessity exception applied only to the person actually doing the labor and not a business owner whose employees performed the labor. Defendant claimed that he was aiding safety, that the Sunday laws were inconsistent, and that prior decisions that car-washing was a violation of the Sunday laws were erroneous. The court found that § 2143 was intended to give the public a day of rest; that an amendment to the law eliminated the word "servile" and thus prohibited all labor not specifically exempted; that while exceptions to the law had to be specific, the courts bore the duty of determining what was prohibited labor; and that the courts would not hesitate to declare a law valid where it was clear and commonly understood.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty as charged.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sabbath laws -- car washing on Sunday -- car washing not labor of necessity within section 2143 of Penal Law, prohibiting all labor on Sunday excepting works of necessity and charity.

Car washing is not a labor of necessity within section 2143 of the Penal Law, prohibiting all labor on Sunday "excepting the works of necessity and charity" and defining works of necessity and charity as including "whatever is needful during the day for the good order, health or comfort of the community." An officer of a corporation operating a commercial automobile laundry, who permitted employees to wash automobiles on a Sunday, was found guilty of a violation of the statute.

 

2730 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Langford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Schenectady County


206 Misc. 628; 134 N.Y.S.2d 712; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2816



October 7, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought a writ of error coram nobis to correct his judgment of conviction of robbery in the first degree and his sentence.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was 18 years old when he committed. He was 19 when he pleaded guilty to robbery in the second degree and was sentenced. The inmate admitted that the judgment was devoid of fraud or misrepresentation but alleged that the judgment and sentence were void because the Youthful Offender Law, N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 913-g(1), was unconstitutional. The inmate argued that § 913-g(1) deprived a defendant between the ages of 16 and 19 of the right to move for an investigation to determine eligibility to be adjudged a youthful offender and because § 913-p applied to crimes committed before its enactment. The court rejected the inmate's arguments and denied the writ. The court, on its own motion, or the grand jury or the district attorney could have recommended investigating a defendant ages 16 to 19 for eligibility to be adjudged a youthful offender. The defendant and his attorney did not have that privilege. The court strictly construed § 913-p and determined that the legislature did not predate or postdate the law's effective date, which was after the inmate was sentenced.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ of error coram nobis.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- coram nobis -- youthful offenders -- (1) Youthful Offender Law (Code Crim. Pro., § 913-g, subd. 1) not unconstitutional for reason that defendant not afforded thereunder right to move personally or by counsel that he be investigated for purpose of determining whether he is eligible to be adjudged youthful offender -- (2) Youthful Offender Law not applicable to defendant convicted and sentenced prior to effective date thereof, at time when he was over age of nineteen years (Code Crim. Pro., § 913-p) -- (3) defendant, petitioning for writ of error coram nobis, conceded sentence and judgment devoid of fraud, misrepresentation or deceit; defendant not entitled to writ -- (4) defendant guilty of laches in waiting ten years before making application for writ.

1. The Youthful Offender Law (Code Crim. Pro., § 913-g, subd. 1) is not unconstitutional for the reason that a defendant is not afforded thereunder the right to move personally or by counsel that he be investigated for the purpose of determining whether he is eligible to be adjudged a youthful offender.

2. The Youthful Offender Law was not applicable to a [***2] defendant convicted and sentenced prior to the effective date of its enactment, at a time when defendant was over the age of nineteen years, notwithstanding that the law (Code Crim. Pro., § 913-p) provides that it shall apply to crimes committed prior, as well as subsequent, to such effective date.

3. Where the defendant, petitioning for a writ of error coram nobis, conceded that the sentence and judgment of the court was devoid of fraud, misrepresentation or deceit, he was not entitled to such writ and to a hearing before the court.

4. Moreover, the defendant was grossly guilty of laches in waiting ten years before making application for a writ of error coram nobis.

 

2731 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


De Nicola v. Adams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


138 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2986



September 22, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner applicant brought an action against respondent police commissioner for an order compelling the commissioner to appoint the applicant to a position from a certified list.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner rejected the applicant for appointment from a certified list. The applicant then brought an action to determine if the commissioner's discretion was constitutionally exercised. The commissioner brought an action after his answer to dismiss the petition for insufficiency. Upon review, the court denied the motion to dismiss the petition. The court stated that the commissioner's power should have been be considered within the framework of constitutional safeguards, regard for community welfare and legal and natural justice in the protection of civil rights and the aspiration of each individual unthwarted to rise above and to escape unfortunate and unfavorable backgrounds.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion.

 

2732 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Stoffel Seals Corp. v. Tuckahoe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


206 Misc. 597; 134 N.Y.S.2d 114; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2487



August 25, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, an operator of punch presses, brought an action to declare Tuckahoe, N.Y., Ordinance No. 34 § 2(f) unconstitutional, invalid, illegal, and void. The village ordinance was enacted to prohibit unreasonably loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noise. The complained of portion of the ordinance was challenged as being discriminatory.


OVERVIEW: The village was empowered to regulate and prohibit noises under N.Y. Village Law § 89(48-a). The presumption of validity afforded to the village regarding the ordinance was overcome by a showing that it was a discriminatory ordinance, and even a proper exercise of the village's police power could not have saved that type of legislation. The court found that in enacting the ordinance, the village board intended to prohibit unreasonably loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noise, not every sound or noise regardless of intensity. In the portion of the ordinance under attack, any noise audible outside a building was prohibited and subjected the operator of a machine to a penalty. The noise from certain types of machines was prohibited per se, but a noise of possibly greater intensity made by another type of machine was not prohibited unless it annoyed, injured, or endangered the comfort, repose, health, or safety of others. The ordinance, by its terms, discriminated against the operation of the types of machines enumerated in Tuckahoe, N.Y., Ordinance No. 34 § 2(f) and did not afford the operator the equal protection of the law.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the operator and struck down the portion of the ordinance complained of.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- equal protection of laws -- village anti-noise ordinance -- portion of village ordinance which expressly declares to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary, operation during certain hours on weekdays and on Sundays of certain enumerated machines, is discriminatory and denies to operator thereof equal protection of laws.

That portion of a village ordinance enacted to prohibit unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise, which expressly declares to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary the operation during certain hours on weekdays and on Sundays, of "any noise creating steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, air compressor, punch press, press brake or pneumatic hammer * * * except where the operations are conducted wholly indoors and the noise created by such operations is inaudible outside the premises containing the same", discriminates against the operation of the types of machines enumerated and denies to the operator thereof the equal protection of the laws.

 

2733 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Noonan v. O'Leary


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Monroe County


206 Misc. 175; 132 N.Y.S.2d 726; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2677



August 12, 1954 



DISPOSITION: Application is denied and proceeding dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner commended the proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to compel the city clerk to accept a petition under N.Y. City Home Rule Law § 19-a. The petitioner proposed a new local law which, among other things, would have amended the city charter to abolish the city-manager form of government. The city clerk refused to accept the petition for filing.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner claimed that the proposed law provided a plan for meeting the increased expenditures with regard to the new form of government proposed and that the increased salaries of the mayor and vice-mayor were payable out of what was to have been saved by not having a city manager and his deputy. The court found that even if the petition was construed as a plan for providing money, the proposed local law contained no such plan and made no provision for providing money for the new expenditures.


OUTCOME: The court denied the application and dismissed the proceeding.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- local laws -- petition for local law requiring expenditure of moneys -- (1) city clerk properly rejected petition containing proposed local law for submission to electors which sought to amend city charter by providing mayoralty instead of city-manager form of government and to amend other local laws, ordinances and resolutions of city by substituting word "mayor" for words "city manager" -- (2) Legislature delegated to People power to initiate amendments to charters only and not to ordinances and local laws; since second portion of petition proposing local law invalid and not separable from remainder, entire proposal unconstitutional -- (3) reasons for refusal to accept petition asserted by city clerk immaterial; every question is before court in present proceeding -- (4) since proposed local law contains no enacting clause and no title, it is invalid -- (5) proposed local law also invalid since it provides for  [***2] expenditure of money but does not provide plan for raising such money (City Home Rule Law, § 19-a).

1. The city clerk of the City of Rochester properly refused to accept a petition, presented pursuant to section 19-a of the City Home Rule Law, which contained a proposed local law for submission to the electors which would amend the city charter by abolishing the city-manager form of government and which would also amend "all other local laws, ordinances and resolutions of the City of Rochester" by substituting the word "mayor" for the words "city manager" wherever the words "city manager" might be found in such local laws, ordinances and resolutions.

2. Section 19-a of the City Home Rule Law provides for the method of adopting a local law amending a city charter by a petition of the electors. The City Home Rule Law, however, did not delegate to the People power to initiate or adopt by popular vote amendments to city ordinances, resolutions or local laws other than those amending a city charter. Section 2 of the City Home Rule Law excludes ordinances and resolutions from the definition of the term "local law". Since the portion of the petition proposing the local law to amend [***3] other local laws, ordinances and resolutions is therefore unauthorized and since the invalid portion cannot be separated from the valid portion, the entire proposal is unconstitutional, for section 19-a requires that the proposed local law "as set forth in full" in the petition be submitted to the electors or adopted "without change".

3. It is immaterial what reasons were given by the city clerk for refusing to accept the petition for filing. Every question affecting the validity of the proposed local law is before the court in this proceeding and the court cannot compel the city clerk to accept for filing a petition calling for the adoption of an invalid law.

4. The State Constitution (art. III) requires that all bills enacted by the Legislature shall contain an enacting clause (§ 13) and shall contain but one subject expressed in the title (§ 15). The City Home Rule Law contains similar provisions with respect to local laws (City Home Rule Law, § 13, subds. 2, 3), and such provisions apply to a local law amending a city charter initiated under section 19-a. Moreover, the Legislature was empowered prior to the enactment of the City Home Rule Law to enact local laws subject [***4] to the requirements that there be an enacting clause and a title. When the City Home Rule Law delegated its power with respect to such legislation to the cities and, in the case of charter amendments, to the electors thereof, the Legislature could not delegate greater power than it possessed and the power delegated to the electors under section 19-a passed to them subject to the same constitutional limitations applying to the Legislature as the delegating body. The proposed local law thus is also invalid since it lacks an enacting clause and a proper title.

5. Section 19-a of the City Home Rule Law provides that a proposed local law requiring the expenditure of money shall not be accepted by the city clerk unless there shall be submitted as part of such proposed local law a plan to provide moneys and revenues sufficient to meet the proposed expenditures. The proposed local law provides for an annual salary for the Mayor of $ 15,000 and for the vice-mayor of $ 2,500. The proposed local law by its wording contains no such plan and makes no provision for providing moneys and revenues sufficient to meet the proposed expenditures. Whether sufficient moneys to pay the Mayor and vice-mayor [***5] will be realized from the abolition of the offices of city manager and deputy city manager, who have salaries totaling $ 26,750 annually, is a matter which can be determined only after the plan is put in operation. Accordingly, the proposed local law on this additional ground violates section 19-a of the City Home Rule Law. That the local law provides that the Mayor shall prepare and submit an annual budget to the council does not meet the requirements of section 19-a.

 

2734 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Peekskill Parking Authority v. L. B. Oil Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


133 N.Y.S.2d 538; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2250



August 6, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered plaintiff city's motion to strike an affirmative defense from defendant corporation's answer to the city's condemnation proceeding.


OVERVIEW: The city commenced a condemnation proceeding against the corporation that sought to acquire land to use for public parking. The corporation filed an answer to the proceeding that challenged the constitutionality of a condemnation proceeding based on such a purpose. The city filed the a motion that sought to strike the corporation's affirmative defense that challenged the validity of the proceeding. Upon consideration, the court granted the city's motion. The court held that the taking of private property for use as public parking was a valid purpose. The court explained that such a taking benefited the public by relieving traffic congestion.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion to strike an affirmative defense from the corporation's answer.

 

2735 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


RKO-Keith-Orpheum Theatres, Inc. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


206 Misc. 531; 133 N.Y.S.2d 321; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2184



July 22, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary injunction to restrain defendant New York City from enforcing New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 37 (1954), which was an amusement tax, on the grounds that it was invalid, illegal, and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The City enacted New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 37 (1954), which was an amusement tax. Plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary injunction to restrain the City from enforcing the tax. They argued that the tax was invalid, illegal, and unconstitutional. The court granted the motion to the extent of issuing a temporary injunction that restrained the City from collecting a tax in excess of five percent. It determined that the tax exceeded the authority granted to the City under 1947 N.Y. Laws ch. 278.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to the extent of issuing a temporary injunction that restrained the City from collecting an amusement tax in excess of five percent.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- amusement tax -- Administrative Code of City of New York (§ G46-2.0, subd. d) provides where tax imposed on admission charges to places of amusement includes fraction of one cent "full cent shall be paid" if fraction is one-half cent or more; but levy limited to no more than 5% on admissions (L. 1947, ch. 278); tax on eleven-cent admission, computed at 5%, is more than one-half cent, and city requires tax of one cent on such charge; one-cent tax on eleven-cent admission is in excess of 5% and is illegal; temporary injunction granted restraining collection of fractional parts of cent to extent collection imposes tax in excess of 5%.

Subdivision d of section G46-2.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York provides that where the tax imposed upon admission charges to places of amusement "includes a fraction of one cent, the fraction shall not be paid where it is less than one-half cent and a full cent shall be paid when the fraction is one-half cent or more". The imposition of the tax was authorized by chapter 278 of the Laws of 1947, which limited any levy "in excess of five per cent on admissions". Since the [***2] tax on an eleven-cent admission charge, computed at 5%, is slightly more than one-half cent, the city requires a tax of one cent on such an admission charge. A one-cent tax on an eleven-cent admission charge is slightly more than 9% and, being in excess of the 5% tax authorized by the enabling act, it is illegal. Under the circumstances, a temporary injunction will be granted restraining defendant City of New York and others from collecting fractional parts of a cent to the extent that such collection imposes a tax in excess of 5%.

 

2736 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hewlett v. Hempstead


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


3 Misc. 2d 945; 133 N.Y.S.2d 690; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1895



July 2, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff resident sued defendant town to free his property from restrictions placed upon it as a residential district under the town zoning laws, for nuisance based upon the town's erection and operation of an incinerator on adjoining property, and for a declaration that the maintenance and operation of the incinerator was illegal in the residential district.


OVERVIEW: The town and the resident owned adjoining parcels of land in a residential district. The town passed an ordinance that excepted the construction and operation of an incinerator from the residential district restrictions. An incinerator was erected on the adjoining property. The resident sued to obtain a change in zoning or removal of the incinerator. The court awarded judgment to the town. The evidence failed to establish that the incinerator was a nuisance. Although the resident's property was less desirable it was not so affected as to make it unusable for residential purposes. The zoning ordinance had not unconstitutionally impacted the resident's land and the town properly had considered the impact upon the entire area. The zoning exception for the incinerator was not improper and under the circumstances the town's disposal of garbage was a governmental and not a proprietary function. Although the zoning as applied the resident's land was proper the court noted that there was some basis for the town to grant some corrective measures. The court also noted that the resident had waited over three years while the bonds were sold and incinerator was constructed.


OUTCOME: The court awarded judgment to the town.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- zoning -- action brought to free plaintiff's property from restraints of residence district zoning, following erection by town of incinerator on adjoining property in same residence district, and to enjoin operation of incinerator; amendment of zoning ordinance to permit public and municipal uses in any district; judgment for defendants.

1. Defendant town established an incinerator district and thereafter acquired land, adjacent to a tract of land owned by plaintiff, and caused to be erected thereon a modern incinerator with a capacity in excess of 600 tons per day. Both plaintiff's parcel and the town parcel were zoned as a B residence district, except for certain frontage in a business district. No change in the zoning of the town's parcel was made prior to the erection of the incinerator so as to remove the land from a B residence district, in which the erection of an incinerator was prohibited. However, prior to the acquisition of the land and the erection of the incinerator, the town caused its zoning ordinance to be amended by adding a new section permitting uses for public and municipal purposes in any use district. In plaintiff's action,  [***2] brought primarily for the purpose of freeing plaintiff's property from the restraints and restrictions imposed by virtue of its being in a B residence district under the provisions of the zoning ordinance, and to enjoin the operation of the incinerator on the ground that it constituted a nuisance to plaintiff's property and that its erection, maintenance and operation in a B residence district were illegal and the exception created by the amendment to the zoning ordinance for public and municipal purposes a nullity, judgment was rendered for defendants.

2. One attacking the validity of a zoning ordinance must overcome the presumption of validity which attaches to the ordinance. It is not enough to show that the property could be more profitably or more beneficially used in a less restricted zoning district; it must be shown that the restrictions imposed upon the property prevent its use for any purpose to which it is reasonably adapted. The evidence adduced showed that the property of plaintiff, although it might have been made less desirable by the advent of the incinerator on the neighboring property, was not so affected as to make it unusable for residential purposes.

3. A town [***3] zoning board, in exercising its legislative power, must consider the over-all effect on the area zoned, since zoning finds its justification in what is good for the community as a whole. Adjacent areas to the subject property must also be considered in assessing the zoning program. A residential area immediately adjacent to plaintiff's property would be in some measure affected if plaintiff's property were to be rezoned. Plaintiff's proof fell short of the standard required to invalidate the zoning ordinance, and the ordinance as it affected plaintiff's property was not unconstitutional.

4. Although the statute under which the incinerator district was formed (L. 1949, ch. 171) was permissive in its terms, yet the conditions existing in the closely-knit, fast-growing defendant town made it imperative that defendant town provide for the disposal of garbage and refuse, and under those circumstances the incineration of garbage was not a proprietary but rather a governmental function.

5. On the proof, the erection of the incinerator by the town in a B residence district was permissible as being within the purview of the zoning ordinance as amended. To the extent that the zoning ordinance [***4] restricted the major portion of plaintiff's property to such uses as were permitted in a B residence district, the ordinance was not confiscatory but constitutional and valid.

6. The court was required to be mindful of the respective equities involved. The municipality proceeded step by step in procuring an amendment to the law, creating a new district, acquiring land as a site for the erection of an incinerator and thereafter proceeding with the sale of bonds and the erection of an incinerator at a cost of $ 2,500,000, all of which was well publicized within the geographical area interested in and to be served by such project. When the whole project had been consummated over a period of three years and was followed by operation of the project for a substantial period of time, it might well be questioned whether an effort to enjoin such operation did not come too late.

 

2737 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Richter


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York, County of New York


206 Misc. 304; 133 N.Y.S.2d 685; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2413



June 30, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: At the request of the child's mother, petitioner State brought a proceeding under New York City, N.Y., Crim. Cts. Act § 69(2) against respondent father for continued child support. The father contended that § 69(2) violated his equal protection rights because it applied only in New York City. Nowhere else in the state could he be held liable for support of the child beyond the age of 16.


OVERVIEW: An order of affiliation had previously been entered against the father establishing paternity and ordering him to pay child support until the child reached the age of 16 years. When the child reached 16, the mother petitioned for further support. Section 69(2) provided that support could be ordered to age 21 or longer in the discretion of the court. The statute was applicable exclusively to proceedings instituted in New York City. In the rest of the state a putative father's obligation of support terminated when the child reached 16 years of age. The court held that there was no violation of either the Fourteenth Amendment's equal protection clause or of the due process clause of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. The Legislature was free to enact special local laws for different municipal subdivisions or other geographical areas. So long as all persons subjected to such local laws were treated alike there was no constitutional violation. Differences in the laws applicable in the different states were permitted. There was no reason different laws should not be permitted in different areas of the same state.


OUTCOME: The court determined that the statute was constitutional and ordered the continuation of the proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Parent and child -- support of child over sixteen years of age -- (1) New York City Criminal Courts Act (§ 69, subd. 2) authorizing New York City Court of Special Sessions to order support for natural child over sixteen years of age is constitutional -- (2) court has jurisdiction to entertain proceeding to determine whether order should be made continuing support of child who has become sixteen years old -- (3) statute does not violate United States Constitution (14th Amendt.) or State Constitution (art. I, § 6); New York City Court of Special Sessions validly possesses jurisdiction not given to courts elsewhere in State in same type of proceeding -- (4) constitutional safeguard of equal protection of laws does not require uniformity between geographical areas -- (5) differences between New York City and other sections of State in respect to living conditions and other conditions do not warrant assumption that Legislature, in enacting statute, did not weigh such differences.

1. Subdivision 2 of section 69 of the New York City Criminal Courts [***2] Act, which empowers the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York to order support for a natural child over the age of sixteen years, is constitutional.

2. Accordingly, the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York has jurisdiction to entertain a proceeding against respondent father to determine whether an order should be made continuing the support of a child who has become sixteen years of age where, in a prior proceeding, an order of filiation was entered against respondent declaring paternity and ordering support of the child until he reached the age of sixteen years.

3. The statute does not violate either the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution (14th Amendt.) or the Due Process Clause of the State Constitution (art. I, § 6). The constitutional safeguard of equal protection of the laws does not prohibit giving to the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York additional power to order support which is not given to courts elsewhere in the State in the same type of proceeding (Domestic Relations Law, § 127).

4. Such constitutional safeguard of equal protection of the laws does not require uniformity of law between geographical areas.  [***3] When the Legislature deems that the public welfare is served by a different requirement of support in the city of New York than obtains in other portions of the State no constitutional question is involved.

5. There are differences between New York City and other sections of the State in respect of living conditions, cost of living, local community burdens of financing necessary welfare activities, recreational facilities, suitable employment and occupational opportunities for teen-age children, and a host of other relevant factors.
