In the absence of proof to the contrary, it cannot be assumed that the Legislature, in enacting subdivision 2 of section 69 of the New York City Criminal Courts Act, did not consider and appropriately weigh such differences.

 

2738 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Radinsky v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


133 N.Y.S.2d 540; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2251



June 22, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff claimant moved for an order directing an entry of judgment in his favor and against defendant city on the basis of a stipulation of settlement entered between the parties at a pretrial conference. The city cross-moved to vacate and set aside the settlement on the grounds that the claimant's original service of his notice of claim and intention to sue for personal injuries was not served in compliance with N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e(1).


OVERVIEW: The claimant sued the city for unspecified personal injuries. Though the city claimed that his notice of claim, required under § 50-e(1), was served too late, the claimant argued the disability he suffered as a result of the accident on which the claim was based prevented him from serving the notice sooner. After the parties settled the claim at a pretrial conference, the city reneged, claiming that it was beyond the city's corporate powers to consent to the settlement because it would constitute a waiver of the claimant's failure to timely serve his notice on the city. The court ruled in favor of the claimant. Noting a city's general power to compromise claims against it, the court held that such power necessarily included the power to waive rights under laws such as § 50-e(1). It also stated that where, as here, the parties in good faith advanced opposing contentions, although one argued that the other's claim lacked legal validity and was incapable of enforcement, there was sufficient consideration to support enforcement of a settlement. Finally, it observed that the city's counsel had general authority to enter into such a settlement on the city's behalf.


OUTCOME: The court granted the claimant's motion to direct an entry of judgment in his favor and denied the city's cross-motion to vacate and set aside the judgment.

 

2739 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Marcus v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


132 N.Y.S.2d 902; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2720



June 17, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner property owner sought review of a determination by respondents, the City of New York (New York) and a department of housing and buildings, that a premises violated N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law art. 6, § 187 for lack of a dual means of egress. The property owner's petition sought an order for respondents to cancel a violation notation. At issue was whether an amendment to § 187 could be applied retroactively.


OVERVIEW: The subject building was converted from a two-family dwelling to a three family-dwelling. Accordingly, respondents reclassified it as a converted multiple dwelling. At the time of the classification, § 187 only required one means of egress. Section 187 was later amended to require dual egress. Respondents then filed two criminal cases against the property owner in other courts. They argued in those cases that dual egress was required. The courts dismissed the informations. Respondents did not appeal the appealable dismissals. The property owner asked the department to cancel the violation notation in the department's records. The department refused to do so. The property owner filed the instant case. The court granted the property owner's petition. The adjudication of an action in a court that was not reversed, vacated, set aside, or modified bound the parties in later actions in other courts concerning the same controversy. Section 187 could not be applied retroactively because such an intent was not evident in § 187 or the amendment. In N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law art. 6, § 170, the legislature had set a date for compliance with the amendment that fell after the reclassification.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition.

 

2740 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Twitty v. Donlon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


133 N.Y.S.2d 381; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2208



June 11, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner uninsured employer brought an action against respondent workmen's compensation board seeking an order under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to annul the board's demand for the present value of a worker's injuries.


OVERVIEW: The board awarded insurance compensation to the employee against the uninsured employer. The award was executed in court, but remained unsatisfied by the employer. The board then fixed a present value for the employee's injuries and demanded that the employer deposit a security for payment of the compensation to the employee. The uninsured employer brought an action against the board to have the demand annulled. The court held that the board's fixing of the present value without giving notice of the hearing or presenting the employer with the opportunity to be heard deprived the employer of his due process rights. The court found that the determination for fixing compensation was quasi-judicial and required notice and a hearing. Also, the fixing of the present value of compensation was a separate inquiry from earlier proceedings, which set a periodic rate. The court also held, however, that the demand to deposit the present value was authorized by statute and was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to vacate the board's demand without prejudice.

 

2741 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Foreclosure of Tax Liens


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


132 N.Y.S.2d 867; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2708



June 3, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city filed a motion for judgment in an in rem proceeding brought pursuant to the provisions of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code tit. D, ch. 17, asking for a striking out of the answer interposed by defendant, an owner of the affected property, pursuant to N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 113, on the ground that no triable issues were presented, and for judgment on the pleadings pursuant to N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112.


OVERVIEW: The attacked answer did not deny the allegations of the complaint as to the non-payment of the taxes, the property owner's default, or the City's compliance with the provisions of the statute, confining itself to a presentation of certain affirmative defenses which challenged the constitutionality of the proceeding. The first of such defenses the property owner alleged was that the public notice of foreclosure, which the City was required to make pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § D17-6.0, was defective in that a copy thereof was required to be posted in the county court house of the county in which the property subject to such tax lien was situated and that such was not done in the instant case. The court rejected the defense, finding that a notice of foreclosure was duly posted on the bulletin board in the lobby of the county court house. As a second defense, it was urged that the Administrative Code provisions involved were unconstitutional in that there was no reasonable time for the property owner to redeem such property. The court was of the opinion that no ground for attack on the constitutionality of the proceeding had been raised by the second defense.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion as prayed for.

 

2742 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Eastman Kodak Co. v. Schwartz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part IX


133 N.Y.S.2d 908; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2468



June 2, 1954 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [**1] As Modified on Motion to Reopen the Record November 9, 1954


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, manufacturer of cameras and commodities (manufacturer), filed an action against defendant retailers, alleging that the retailers knowingly sold the manufacturer's fair-traded commodities at prices lower than the minimum retail prices established by fair-trade agreements. The manufacturer filed a motion to reopen the record to make the withdrawal of certain products from its fair-trade schedules a matter of record.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer entered into fair-trade agreements with its retailers, setting the minimum retail, resale prices of the manufacturer's trademark commodities. Certain retailers knowingly and willfully sold those commodities at prices lower than the minimum prices stipulated by the manufacturer, so the manufacturer filed an action against those retailers. The court entered judgment in favor of the manufacturer, finding that the majority of the fair-traded commodities were in fair and open competition with commodities of the same general class produced by others. The fair-trade agreements that were sought to be enforced were vertical agreements between the manufacturer and seller on the one hand and the retailer buyer and reseller of the commodities on the other hand. The fact that a subsidiary of the manufacturer sold those commodities at retail did not transform those vertical agreements into horizontal agreements. The manufacturer's agreements were proper under the McGuire Act. The defense of "clean hands" was not sustained. The court granted the manufacturer's motion to reopen its case to make the withdrawal of certain products from its fair-trade schedules a matter of record.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of the manufacturer in its action against retailers who were knowingly selling fair-traded commodities at prices lower than the minimum retail prices established by fair-trade agreements. The court granted the manufacturer's motion to reopen the record to make the withdrawal of certain products from its fair-trade schedules a matter of record.

 

2743 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Coppock


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York, New York County


206 Misc. 89; 133 N.Y.S.2d 174; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2143



June 1, 1954 



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motions are accordingly in all respects denied, and he is found guilty as charged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with driving an automobile while in an intoxicated condition in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 70(5).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was given a Drunkometer test. The alcohol present in defendant's blood was calculated at 0.25 percent. Defendant urged that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71-a was unconstitutional and both the test and the evidence exhibited were inadmissible. Defendant also argued that he was not advised he could have a physician of his own choice administer a chemical test; that he was not warned by the officer administering the test that if he failed to submit to the test his license would be revoked, and that the Harger Drunkometer was an inaccurate and unreliable test. The court held that the record was completely barren of any claim of compulsion or coercion. The statute merely added to the present law an additional safeguard that protected both the People and the accused, and in no manner curtailed police practices. The court held that the Harger Drunkometer, from the expert testimony and cross-examinations by counsel, was an accurate and reliable device to be used and recognized under the statute. The proof clearly showed that both on the sobriety test imposed by general police practices and under the Drunkometer defendant's guilt was established beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions and found him guilty as charged.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- operating motor vehicle while intoxicated -- chemical test for intoxication -- (1) defendant, charged with operating motor vehicle while intoxicated, found guilty upon proof of observations of arresting officer and results of sobriety and Harger Drunkometer tests (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 70, subd. 5; § 71-a) -- (2) "under the influence of liquor" defined -- (3) result of Harger Drunkometer test, freely submitted to by defendant, admissible -- (4) no merit to defendant's contentions that testimony with respect to result of Harger Drunkometer test inadmissible because defendant was not advised that he could have physician of own choice administer chemical test and defendant was not warned that if he failed to submit to test his license would be revoked -- (5) Harger Drunkometer accurate and reliable device.

1. Defendant, charged with operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated, upon proof of observations of the arresting officer and the results of a sobriety test and a Harger [***2] Drunkometer test, was found guilty (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 70, subd. 5; § 71-a).

2. A person is "under the influence of liquor" when he has lost to any extent that clearness of intellect and self-control that he would otherwise possess.

3. The result of the Harger Drunkometer test, freely submitted to by the defendant without compulsion or coercion, was admissible in evidence.

4. There was no merit to defendant's contentions that the testimony with respect to the result of the Harger Drunkometer test was inadmissible because defendant was not advised that he could have a physician of his own choice administer a chemical test and because defendant was not warned by the officer administering the test that if he failed to submit to the test his license would be revoked. Defendant was presumed to have known the law. In the absence of any proof of compulsion or coercion defendant was bound by the test.

5. The Harger Drunkometer is an accurate and reliable device for use in making chemical tests for intoxication.

 

2744 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Edward A. Lashins v. Griffin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


132 N.Y.S.2d 896; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2718



May 18, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, a zoning board of appeals and a building inspector, filed motions to dismiss proceedings brought by petitioner property owner under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to review the determination by the board that revoked a permit issued by the inspector to the owner to erect a building.


OVERVIEW: The inspector issued a permit to the owner for a building to be used for a dry-cleaning and shirt laundering business within a class C-business district. An adjoining landowner appealed such action to the board, which reversed the inspector's decision and revoked the permit. The owner brought two proceedings to appeal the board's decision and to compel the inspector to re-issue the permit. The court dismissed the proceedings. The court rejected the owner's contention that the board's action was invalid where the appeal was taken by a person who was not aggrieved, as required by N.Y. Village Law § 179-b. The court held that the adjoining landowner had a sufficient interest to enable him to appeal the determination permitting an unauthorized zoning use of adjoining premises. On the merits, the determination of the board had to stand because a zoning ordinance, before amendment, expressly prohibited cleaning and dyeing establishments in a class C-business district. In addition, the proposed building was prohibited by a superseding ordinance. The superseding ordinance was not unconstitutional where it did not pass the bounds of reason or assume the character of a merely arbitrary fiat.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the proceedings.

 

2745 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Application of Silver Lining Laundry, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


133 N.Y.S.2d 275; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2171



May 12, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord instituted a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to review and set aside an order of respondent, the New York State Rent Administrator of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission, which affirmed a denial by a local administrator of the landlord's applications for certificates of eviction to be effective against tenants in an apartment building of the landlord.


OVERVIEW: The landlord filed applications for certificates of eviction to be effective against tenants in its apartment building. The landlord conducted a laundry and dry cleaning business on the adjoining premises and alleged that it was necessary to use the apartment building premises to expand its business. The local administrator denied the applications without a hearing upon the ground that they were not within the purview of N.Y. Rent & Eviction Regs. § 59. The State Administrator denied the landlord's protests against such denials, stating that the landlord failed to establish compliance with § 59. The landlord appealed, and the court remitted the applications to the Commission for a hearing. Although N.Y. Unconsol. Laws § 8590(4) (McKinney) provided that housing accommodations already on the rental market could be withdrawn only with prior written approval of the Commission, N.Y. Rent & Eviction Regs. § 59 provided that a landlord could obtain an eviction certificate upon proof of an immediate and compelling necessity. The court found that the State Administrator failed to give the landlord an opportunity to establish his good faith, hardship, and compelling necessity.


OUTCOME: The court remitted the landlord's applications to the Commission for the purpose of holding a hearing and passing upon all relevant issues.

 

2746 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


King v. Ocean Beach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


132 N.Y.S.2d 879; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2711



May 11, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners moved for judgment on the pleadings under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112 in their action, which sought a judgment declaring unconstitutional an ordinance adopted by defendant village.


OVERVIEW: The village passed an ordinance prohibiting the erection of any new structure on a large tract of beach and sand dunes within the village, as well as the enlargement of existing structures or the replacing of any structures that may be totally destroyed by storm. The owners brought an action to declare the ordinance unconstitutional. They filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings. The court held that the village's justification for the legislation was declared by the terms of the ordinance itself. The owners argued this ordinance converted their property to public use without compensation to a degree far exceeding the village's police power. The court reviewed the ordinance and agreed that, on its face, the legislation was extreme but, unwilling to limit the village's police power by deciding the case on the pleadings, the court denied the motion, concluding that the constitutionality of the ordinance needed to be determined at trial.


OUTCOME: The court denied the owner's motion for judgment on the pleadings.

 

2747 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nye


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Essex County


205 Misc. 605; 131 N.Y.S.2d 688; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3354



April 13, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of the decision of the Court of Special Sessions held by a Justice of the Peace of the Town of Wilmington, Essex County (New York), which convicted them of violating N.Y. Conserv. Law § 185(2)(i) by using an artificial light upon land inhabited by deer. Defendants argued that the prohibition of the use of an artificial light for any legal purpose was clearly unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Conserv. Law § 185(2)(i) provided that wild deer and bear could only be taken on land. The statute also provided that no artificial light could be used upon land inhabited by deer. There was no proof that defendants attempted or intended to kill or take deer or that either of them had or possessed a gun or other device capable of taking a deer. The only charge against them was that they used an artificial light upon land inhabited by deer. The court determined that the judgment of conviction should have been reversed, the information dismissed, and the fines imposed remitted because the statute was unconstitutional. The statute prohibited both legal and illegal uses of artificial light on land inhabited by deer. The court concluded that the restriction was in effect a taking of property prohibited by the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and by N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the reversal of the judgment of conviction and the dismissal of the information. The court also ordered that the fines imposed be remitted.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- using artificial light on lands inhabited by deer -- (1) Conservation Law (§ 185, subd. 2, par. [i]) provides that "No jacklight * * * or other type of artificial light * * * shall be * * * used upon land inhabited by deer"; statute unconstitutional as applied to use of artificial light for legal purpose on lands inhabited by deer -- (2) conviction of defendants on charge of using artificial light on lands inhabited by deer, there being no proof that defendants intended to kill or take deer, or that defendants were armed, reversed.

1. Paragraph (i) of subdivision 2 of section 185 of the Conservation Law, which provides that "No jacklight * * * or other type of artificial light * * * shall be * * * used upon land inhabited by deer", is unconstitutional as applied to the use of an artificial light for any legal purpose on lands inhabited by deer. The statute is not [***2] a reasonable exercise of the police power and deprives many persons of property rights without due process of law or just compensation.

2. The conviction of defendants upon the sole charge of using an artificial light upon land inhabited by deer, there being no proof that the defendants intended to kill or take deer, or that the defendants had in their possession a gun or other device capable of taking deer, should be reversed, the information dismissed and fines imposed remitted.

 

2748 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Teschner v. Pittsford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


129 N.Y.S.2d 803; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3234



April 2, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, the Town of Pittsford, New York, its Board of Appeals, and the Board's members, filed a motion to dismiss petitioner landowners' application to review the Board's denial of a variance permitting the owners to use their premises in a residential district for commercial purposes.


OVERVIEW: The owners purchased a lot, which was in a residential use district. They filed an application to change the zoning from residential to commercial, which was denied. They then filed an application for a variance. After a hearing the Board denied the application. The owners appealed. Respondents filed a motion to dismiss, which the court granted. The court held that under N.Y. Town Law § 267, the court was called upon to review only the Board's decision, so the Town was not a proper party to the action. The court held that no attempt was ever made by the owners to establish that the land could not yield a reasonable return if used for residential purposes, that the owners' plight was due to unique circumstances, and that the use authorized by the variance would not alter the essential character of the locality. The failure of the owners to present such facts suggested their absence. The court held that the owners' allegation that the premises could not be profitably used as zoned failed because they did not allege that any attempt had been made to use or sell the land for the purposes permitted in the residential use district and that it was found to be impossible or impracticable.


OUTCOME: The court granted respondents' motion to dismiss.

 

2749 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


David-Zieseniss v. Zieseniss


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


205 Misc. 836; 129 N.Y.S.2d 649; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3205



March 17, 1954 



DISPOSITION: The motion is therefore in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant husband filed a motion to vacate the orders of the trial court (New York), which sequestered his property and appointed a receiver thereof. The husband sought to dismiss plaintiff wife's complaint for divorce due to lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The wife alleged the parties were married in the State of New York, lived there for several years, and that the husband no longer lived in the state.


OVERVIEW: The court denied the husband's motion to vacate the property orders and to dismiss the complaint for divorce. The court held that jurisdiction rested solely upon the fact that the parties were married in the state and lived there together. The husband argued that, under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1147, if divorce jurisdiction was based on the fact that the parties were married in the state when both parties resided or were domiciled elsewhere at the time of the action, § 1147 was unconstitutional. The court held that marriage within the state enabled the state to confer upon its courts jurisdiction over a divorce action and that § 1147 was constitutional. The court held that process in the action may have been served by publication or outside the state. The court held that by marrying in a state a person made his or her marital status a res of which enabled the state to authorize publication of process in an action by the other spouse to dissolve the marriage. The court held that by acquiring a marital status in a state a man subjected the marital status to the right of that state to dissolve it for reasons which that state established.


OUTCOME: The court denied the husband's motion to vacate the trial court's order regarding the property and to dismiss the wife's complaint for divorce.


HEADNOTES

Husband and wife -- divorce -- jurisdiction based on marriage within State (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1147, subd. 2) -- service of process in such case by publication or outside State -- (1) spouse may maintain action for divorce grounded on adultery where parties married in New York, though at time offense committed and at commencement of action both parties domiciled elsewhere; process in such action may be served by publication or outside State; sequestration allowed -- (2) great length of time statute has stood upon books without challenge to constitutionality of itself strong argument against challenge -- (3) whole subject of domestic relations left by Federal Constitution entirely to States; no State statute regulating jurisdiction of State courts over domestic relations can be violative of Federal Constitution -- (4) when judicial decision can promote socially desirable end without sacrifice of legal principle, proper to mould decision so as to promote that end -- (5) marriage within State sufficient of itself to enable State to confer upon its courts jurisdiction of action to dissolve that marriage  [***2] -- (6) broad assertion that jurisdiction of divorce depends upon domicile, in such way as to imply that jurisdiction cannot be founded upon any other fact, contrary to New York statute and case law -- (7) statute conferring jurisdiction to grant divorce solely on basis of marriage within State (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1147, subd. 2), constitutional -- (8) State constitutionally may provide for service by publication or outside State in actions which involve or are designed to affect res within jurisdiction of court; marriage within State makes marital status of parties to marriage res within meaning of such rule, even though neither spouse domiciled in State.

1. A spouse may maintain an action for divorce grounded upon adultery "when the parties were married within this state", though at the time the offense was committed and at the commencement of the action both parties were domiciled elsewhere (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1147, subd. 2). In such an action process may be served by publication or outside the State. Sequestration of the defendant's property is allowed (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1171-a).

2. The great length of time a statute has stood upon the books without challenge to its constitutionality [***3] is of itself a strong argument against challenge of the statute.

3. The whole subject of domestic relations is left by the Federal Constitution entirely to the States; hence, no State statute regulating the jurisdiction of State courts over domestic relations can be violative of the Federal Constitution.

4. When judicial decision can promote a socially desirable end without any sacrifice of legal principle, it is proper to mould decision so as to promote that end.

5. Marriage within the State is a fact sufficient of itself to enable a State to confer upon its courts jurisdiction of an action to dissolve that marriage.

6. To assert generally and broadly that jurisdiction of divorce depends or is founded upon domicile, in such a way as to imply that jurisdiction cannot be founded upon any other fact, is to say something which is palpably contrary to the statutory law of New York as it has existed for over ninety years, and contrary, also, to Gould v. Gould (235 N. Y. 14, 16).

7. Subdivision 2 of section 1147 of the Civil Practice Act, conferring jurisdiction to grant divorce solely on the basis of marriage within the State of New York, is constitutional.

8. A State constitutionally [***4] may provide for service by publication or outside the State in actions which involve or are designed to affect a res which is within the jurisdiction of the court, and also where a nonresident consents to the exercise of jurisdiction over him or does an act which the State reasonably can and does treat as a consent to the exercise of jurisdiction over him. Marriage within the State makes the marital status of the parties to the marriage something so analogous to a res as to be treated as constituing a res within the meaning of such rule, even though neither spouse is domiciled in the State.

 

2750 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Griest v. Hooey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Steuben County


205 Misc. 396; 128 N.Y.S.2d 341; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2001



March 5, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner residents brought a petition pursuant to N.Y. Gen. City Law § 82(1) seeking to annul and set aside the action of respondent, Zoning Board of Appeals of the City of Corning, in granting the application of respondent business owners for a variance and authorizing the issuance to the business owners of a permit to construct a retail tire store.


OVERVIEW: The residents contended that the action of the Board was contrary to law and was a nullity because no notice of the meeting was given to them nor to others similarly situated. The Board argued that neither the statute, N.Y. Gen. City Law § 81(4), nor the ordinance, Corning, N.Y. Zoning Ordinance, art. XVI, C(2), nor any rule or regulation of the Board, required notice to residents other than the actual parties to the petition before the Board. The court dismissed the petition, explaining that because it was not instituted within 30 days of the filing of the decision of the Board as required by N.Y. Gen. City Law, § 82(1) and N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1286 it was untimely and had to have been dismissed. The court further reasoned that the Board had no obligation to provide notice to residents who were not parties to the action pending before it. The court opined that adjoining property owners had no property interest in the property to which the variance was granted.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition seeking to annul and set aside a variance granted by the board permitting the business owners to construct a retail tire store.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- notice of hearing before city zoning board of appeals -- (1) action of city zoning board of appeals in granting application for variance and authorizing permit for construction of store building on premises largely in residential district, not annulled on petition of neighboring property owners on ground that no notice of meeting at which such action was had was given to petitioners nor to others similarly situated (General City Law, § 82, subd. 1) -- (2) proceeding for review not timely, where not instituted within thirty days of filing of decision of board in its office (General City Law, § 82, subd. 1; Civ. Prac. Act, § 1286) -- (3) petition presented to board, objecting to erection of proposed building, and meetings of board held thereafter, did not serve to extend time for bringing proceeding to review, where no new facts presented or considered by board -- (4) board would have had no right to reopen decision in absence of new facts; whether there is such change of facts as to justify rehearing primarily for board to determine on application for rehearing -- (5) neither city  [***2] ordinances nor rule or regulation of board made any provision for notice to affected neighboring owners; General City Law ( § 81, subd. 4) provides that board shall give notice of hearing "to the parties"; neighboring owners not "parties" -- (6) General City Law ( § 81, subd. 4), governing hearing of zoning appeals, not unconstitutional for failure to require publication of notice of hearing -- (7) remedy of petitioners lay in such political action as necessary to cause zoning ordinance to be amended or board of appeals to adopt rules calculated to give practical notice of hearing to affected owners.

1. The action of a city zoning board of appeals in granting an application for a variance and authorizing the issuance of a permit for the construction of a retail store building upon premises largely in a residential district, would not be annulled upon the petition of neighboring property owners, upon the ground that no notice of the meeting at which such action was had was given to petitioners nor to others similarly situated (General City Law, § 82, subd. 1).

2. The proceeding for review was not timely, where it was not instituted within thirty days of the filing of the decision [***3] of the zoning board of appeals in its office. Hence, the petition was required to be dismissed unless the action of the board of appeals was illegal for want of notice to the petitioners of the meeting of the board (General City Law, § 82, subd. 1; Civ. Prac. Act, § 1286).

3. A petition presented to the zoning board of appeals by petitioners and others, objecting to erection of the proposed building, and meetings of the zoning board of appeals thereafter, did not serve to extend the time for bringing a proceeding to review the action of the board, where no new facts were presented to nor considered by the board.

4. In the absence of new facts, the board of appeals would have had no right to reopen its decision and render a new decision even had it wished to do so. Whether there is such a change of facts or circumstances as to justify a rehearing is primarily for the board of appeals to determine on the application for rehearing.

5. Neither the city ordinances nor any rule or regulation of the zoning board of appeals made any provision for notice to affected neighboring owners. Subdivision 4 of section 81 of the General City Law provides that a zoning board of appeals shall give [***4] due notice of a hearing before it "to the parties." Neighboring owners were not "parties" to the application to the board. As citizens and members of the public they were presumed to have had notice of decisions of the zoning board of appeals filed in the clerk's office.

6. Subdivision 4 of section 81 of the General City Law, governing the hearing of zoning appeals, is not unconstitutional for failure to require publication of notice of hearing before the zoning board of appeals.

7. The remedy of the petitioners and other citizens lay in such political action as necessary to cause the city zoning ordinance to be amended or the board of appeals to adopt rules calculated to give practical notice to owners who might be affected by action of the board upon a hearing.

 

2751 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kovacik


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Special Sessions held by a City Magistrate of the City of New York, Borough of Manhattan


205 Misc. 275; 128 N.Y.S.2d 492; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2305



March 4, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 70-5, in that he operated a motor vehicle while he was in an intoxicated condition.


OVERVIEW: At the close of the entire case and upon motion of defendant's counsel for an acquittal. The court found in favor of the People on the facts, and reserved decision solely on the questions of law involved. The court convicted defendant as charged. The court held that the Harger drunkometer was a scientifically reliable and accurate device for determining the alcoholic content of a defendant's blood for compliance with N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71-a. The court further held that defendant's submission to a chemical test and waiver of his constitutional privilege against self incrimination was not obtained under duress. Finally, the court held that because it was not shown upon the trial that any demand was made by defendant or his attorney of for the results of his test, this point was untimely.


OUTCOME: Defendant was found guilty as charged.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- operating motor vehicle while in intoxicated condition -- chemical test for intoxication -- (1) defendant, charged with operating motor vehicle while in intoxicated condition, found guilty on testimony of arresting officer and further testimony of experts in operation of Harger drunkometer -- (2) theory of chemical testing for intoxication and operation of Harger drunkometer explained -- (3) Harger drunkometer scientifically reliable and accurate device for use in making chemical tests of blood, pursuant to section 71-a of Vehicle and Traffic Law -- (4) explanation made by police officer to defendant, that if defendant did not submit to chemical test his operator's license would be revoked, could not be construed as duress; moreover, constitutional privilege against self incrimination would not bar use in prosecution of results of chemical test even though defendant had not voluntarily consented thereto -- (5) section 71-a not unconstitutional because statute fails to provide that full and complete readings, figures and computations must be preserved and made available; contention  [***2] untenable as applied to defendant, who had not made demand for such information -- (6) section 71-a not unconstitutional by reason of failure to provide therein that defendant shall be given notice of his right to have physician of own choosing administer chemical test in addition to one administered by police.

1. The defendant, charged with operating a motor vehicle while in an intoxicated condition (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 70, subd. 5), was found guilty, upon the testimony of the arresting officer, who conducted a sobriety test, and the further testimony of experts in the operation of the Harger drunkometer.

2. The theory of chemical testing for intoxication and the operation of the Harger drunkometer explained.

3. The court found that the Harger drunkometer was a scientifically reliable and accurate device for use in making chemical tests of the alcoholic content of the blood, pursuant to section 71-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, of one accused of driving a motor vehicle while in an intoxicated condition.

4. The explanation made by a police officer to the defendant, after arrest, that if the defendant did not submit to the chemical test provided for by section 71-a [***3] his operator's license would be revoked, could not be construed as duress. There was no obligation on the part of the police officer to warn the defendant; the police officer made a gratuitous offer of information as to the provisions of the statute and the defendant was not bound to accept the information. Moreover, the constitutional privilege against self incrimination would not bar the use in the prosecution of the defendant of the results of a chemical test even though taken while the defendant was so drunk as to be confused or unconscious or otherwise in such a condition that it could not be said that he voluntarily consented thereto.

5. The statute (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 71-a) is not unconstitutional because, while it provides that upon request of the person tested the results of the test shall be made available to him, the statute fails to provide further that full and complete readings, figures and computations must be preserved and made available. Moreover, the contention was untenable as applied to the defendant, who had not made demand for such information.

6. Section 71-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law is not unconstitutional by reason of failure to provide therein [***4] that the defendant shall be given notice of his right to have a physician of his own choosing administer a chemical test in addition to the one administered by the police.

 

2752 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Defiance Milk Products Co. v. Du Mond


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


205 Misc. 813; 133 N.Y.S.2d 216; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2153



March 1, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff milk producer filed an action against defendant agricultural commissioner to have declared unconstitutional N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 64(2), which prohibited the sale of evaporated skim milk in less than 10-pound containers.


OVERVIEW: The milk producer sold milk products in interstate commerce. After it began selling its products in New York, the agriculture commissioner informed the milk producer that its sales were unlawful because N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 64(2) prohibited the sale of evaporated skim milk in less than 10-pound containers. The milk producer filed a declaratory judgment action to have the law declared unconstitutional. The court agreed that the law violated the due process provisions of both the state and federal constitutions and held that part of the statute void. The court recognized that the milk producer's business was a property right and thus was entitled to protection against legislation in contravention of the constitutions. On the other hand, the court said, the state was authorized by its police powers to promulgate laws for the protection and safety of its citizens. However, the court wrote, such laws were valid only if they were not arbitrary, discriminatory, capricious, or unreasonable and had a real and substantial relation to the object sought to be obtained. The court found that the provision regarding the size of the evaporated skim milk containers did not meet this standard.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for the milk producer and against the agricultural commissioner, declaring unconstitutional a statute that established a minimum size for a container of evaporated skim milk.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- police power -- regulation prohibiting sale of evaporated skimmed milk in less than ten-pound containers -- (1) that part of statute (Agriculture and Markets Law, § 64, subd. 2) which prohibits sale of evaporated skimmed milk in less than ten-pound containers, void; prohibition arbitrary exercise of police power -- (2) statute required to be declared unconstitutional in manufacturer's action for declaratory judgment; continued enforcement of statute would deprive manufacturer of property without due process of law -- (3) constitutional question can be determined in action for declaratory judgment -- (4) what must appear in order to sustain legislation under police power stated -- (5) mere enactment of statute does not raise irrebutable presumption that police power properly exercised -- (6) Legislature has no power under guise of police regulations to impose unusual and unnecessary restrictions upon lawful occupations -- (7) courts not barred from inquiring into validity of statute because statute long in existence and not previously attacked.

1. That part of subdivision 2 of section 64 of the Agriculture and [***2] Markets Law which prohibits the sale of evaporated skimmed milk in less than ten-pound containers is unconstitutional and void. The prohibition is an arbitrary exercise of the police power in that it does not tend to prevent fraud or to preserve the public health.

2. The offending portion of the statute is required to be declared unconstitutional and void in an action for a declaratory judgment brought by a manufacturer and seller of evaporated skimmed milk in less than ten-pound containers. Continued enforcement of the statute would deprive the plaintiff of its property without due process of law.

3. A constitutional question can be determined in an action for a declaratory judgment.

4. In order to sustain legislation under the police power the courts must be able to see that its operation tends in some degree to prevent some offense or evil or to preserve public health, morals, safety and welfare. If a statute discloses no such purpose, has no real or substantial relation to these objects, or is a palpable invasion of rights secured by the fundamental law, it is the duty of the courts to so hold and strike down the statute.

5. The mere enactment of a statute does not raise an [***3] irrebutable presumption that the State has properly exercised its police powers.

6. The Legislature has no power under the guise of police regulations, arbitrarily to invade the personal rights and liberty of the individual citizen, to interfere with private business or impose unusual and unnecessary restrictions upon lawful occupations or to invade property rights.

7. The courts are not barred from inquiring into the validity of a statute by the circumstance that the statute has long been in existence and has not previously been attacked.

 

2753 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schutt v. MacDuff


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Orange County


205 Misc. 43; 127 N.Y.S.2d 116; 1954 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1936



January 2, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Commissioner of Motor Vehicles sought a ruling on his motion to dismiss petitioner driver's action to annul the revocation of his motor vehicle driver's license under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71-a (1953).


OVERVIEW: The driver was arrested for suspected driving while intoxicated and he refused to submit to a blood test. The commissioner, pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71-a (1953), revoke the driver's motor vehicle driver's license. The driver brought an action to annul the revocation of his license, and the commissioner filed a motion to dismiss. The court denied the motion to dismiss, holding that § 71-a was unconstitutional. The court held that under the law, the commissioner could have revoked the license without a hearing upon mere hearsay, in violation of due process. The court held that § 71-a did not contain a provision limiting its application to a case where there had been a lawful arrest and there was no provision entitling the driver to an ultimate hearing upon an adequate record before the final taking away of his license. The court held that because the driver was entitled to a hearing, the commissioner's motion was denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied the commissioner's motion to dismiss the driver's action to annul the revocation of his motor vehicle driver's license.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- revocation or suspension of license -- chemical test for intoxication -- (1) section 71-a of Vehicle and Traffic Law provides that Commissioner of Motor Vehicles shall revoke license of driver of motor vehicle who refuses to submit, on direction of police officer having reasonable grounds to suspect him of driving in intoxicated condition, to chemical test of breath, blood, urine or saliva -- (2) statute does not infringe upon constitutional guarantees against self incrimination and unreasonable searches and seizures nor constitutional right to equal protection of laws; statute does, however, violate due process clauses of State and Federal Constitutions in that under its terms officer may, without process or arrest, demand that motorist accompany officer and submit to intoxication test, and that it confers on Commissioner of Motor Vehicles power to revoke driver's license upon hearsay and without hearing -- (3) circumstance that commissioner's action in revoking driver's license was based upon hearsay and not upon any hearing, record or adequate findings indicates arbitrary and unreasonable action;  [***2] maintenance of article 78 proceeding warranted -- (4) decision has to do with due protection against arbitrary or unlawful revocation of driver's license; practice of requesting driver to submit to chemical test after he has been duly arrested not intended to be affected.

1. Section 71-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law provides that "Any person who operates a motor vehicle or motor cycle in this state shall be deemed to have given his consent to a chemical test of his breath, blood, urine, or saliva for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content of his blood provided that such test is administered at the direction of a police officer having reasonable grounds to suspect such person of driving in an intoxicated condition. If such person refuses to submit to such chemical test the test shall not be given but the commissioner [of motor vehicles] shall revoke his license or permit to drive and any nonresident operating privilege." In a proceeding brought against the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to annul a determination of the commissioner revoking the motor vehicle driver's license of the petitioner (Civ. Prac. Act, art. 78), it appeared from the petition that petitioner was [***3] arrested on a public street by a police officer without a warrant for the crime of operating a motor vehicle while in an intoxicated condition; that petitioner was forcibly taken by the officer to police headquarters, where, after being booked, petitioner was requested by the police officer to go to a hospital and submit to a "blood test" for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content of his blood; that petitioner refused; that prior to the trial of petitioner, petitioner received a written order from the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles revoking his driver's license for refusal "to submit to a chemical test for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content of his blood"; that petitioner complied with the commissioner's direction to surrender his driver's license, though under written protest that neither the validity of section 71-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law nor the power of the commissioner to revoke the license was conceded, and that petitioner was subsequently acquitted after a trial by jury of the charge of operating a motor vehicle while in an intoxicated condition.

2. Section 71-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law does not infringe upon the petitioner's constitutional [***4] guarantees against self incrimination and against unreasonable searches and seizures, nor the petitioner's constitutional right to the equal protection of the laws. The statute does, however, violate the due process clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions in that under its terms an officer may, without specific process and without lawful arrest, demand that a motorist accompany the officer and submit to an intoxication test, and that it confers on the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles the power to revoke a driver's license upon mere hearsay and without a hearing. The constitutional validity of a law is to be tested, not by what has been done under it, but what may, by its authority, be done.

3. The circumstance that the commissioner's action in revoking the driver's license was based upon hearsay and not upon any hearing, record or adequate findings, indicates arbitrary and unreasonable action on the part of the commissioner, and warrants the maintenance of an article 78 proceeding.

4. The decision herein has to do with due protection of one against arbitrary or unlawful revocation of his driver's license and is not intended to affect the practice of requesting one to submit [***5] to a chemical test where he has been duly arrested for driving while intoxicated, nor should it limit the lawful use of the results of such a test when voluntarily submitted to.

 

2754 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Novobelske


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Broome County


208 Misc. 733; 126 N.Y.S.2d 395; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2442



December 11, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant city was before the court in an attempt to recover nearly $ 12,900 in reimbursement from a decedent's estate. The city sought the reimbursement for public assistance that had been paid by the city welfare department during decedent's lifetime to her daughter, son, and their families. The city's claim for repayment was made under an amendment to N.Y. Soc. Welf. Law § 104(1), which had been made effective after decedent's death.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Soc. Welf. Law §§ 101, 104, gave the city a cause of action for reimbursement against the husband, wife, father, mother, grandparent, or child of a public assistance recipient if such a relative had "sufficient ability" to assume the support of the recipient and failed to do so. Under the amendment to N.Y. Soc. Welf. Law § 104(1), the estate of such a relative, who failed to assume support of a welfare recipient, could be sued for reimbursement regardless of whether the relative had "sufficient ability" to support the recipient during the relative's life. The executor of the decedent's estate argued that the amendment could not be applied retroactively to allow such a suit against the decedent's estate and respondent legatees. The court held that the amendment was applicable because it became effective during the pendency of the estate's administration. However, the court also held that the legatees became equitably vested with the right to receive their legacies immediately upon the decedent's death, subject only to payment of estate's obligations and funeral and administration expenses. Therefore, the court held that the city could not pursue its claim against the legatees.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the city's claim as to all of decedent's legatees under her will, except for two legatees who had made assignments of their interests to the city's department of public welfare.


HEADNOTES

Statutes -- prospective or retrospective operation -- paupers -- recovery of relief moneys from estate of deceased person -- (1) amendment of Social Welfare Law (§ 104, subd. 1) to provide that claim of public welfare official against estate of deceased person otherwise responsible for support of recipient of public assistance should not be defeated by lack of sufficiency of ability on part of deceased person during period when assistance was received, prospective in operation; claim of municipality against estate of deceased person dismissed -- (2) in absence of clear indicia to contrary, presumed that legislative intent was to limit statute to prospective applications -- (3) Legislature without power to enact law which destroys or impairs pre-existing vested rights, titles and interests -- (4) decedent's legatees, immediately upon death of decedent, became equitably vested with right to receive legacies, subject only to reduction for debts existing on date of decedent's death and funeral and administration expenses.

1. The Social Welfare Law (§ 101, subd. 1), on the date of death, in 1952, of a mother and [***2] grandparent of recipients of public assistance, provided that a mother and grandparent of a recipient of public assistance should, "if of sufficient ability", be responsible for the support of such persons. Concededly, deceased was not "of sufficient ability" throughout the periods of time during which public assistance was extended to her children and grandchildren. However, during the course of administration of decedent's estate, the Social Welfare Law (§ 104, subd. 1) was amended (L. 1953, ch. 838, effective April 19, 1953) to provide that no claim of a public welfare official against the estate or the executors, administrators and successors in interest of a person who died leaving real or personal property should be barred or defeated by any lack of sufficiency of ability on the part of such person during the period when assistance was received. A municipality thereupon filed a claim against decedent's estate for reimbursement for assistance furnished by its welfare department to decedent's children and grandchildren. The 1953 amendment of subdivision 1 of section 104 of the Social Welfare Law was prospective, and not retrospective, in operation, and therefore the claim of the [***3] municipality was dismissed, except, however, as to legatees under decedent's will who had made assignments of their interests to the municipal department of public welfare.

2. In the absence of clear indicia to the contrary, it would be presumed that the legislative intent was to limit the statute (Social Welfare Law, § 104, subd. 1) to prospective applications only, particularly since the statute created a liability not existing at common law.

3. The Legislature is without power to enact a law which destroys or impairs pre-existing vested rights, titles and interests.

4. Decedent's legatees, immediately upon the death of decedent, became equitably vested with the right to receive their respective legacies, subject only to whatever reduction therein might be required in order to pay off all the obligations of the estate as such obligations existed at the date of decedent's death, together with nothing more than the funeral and administration expenses incurred thereafter.

 

2755 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kansas Packing Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


204 Misc. 1077; 127 N.Y.S.2d 107; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2533



December 4, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wholesaler brought a declaratory judgment action against defendants, city and related parties, to have New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 140a declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The wholesaler distributed meats, including corned beef briskets, that were processed by others. Most of the wholesaler's briskets were purchased from producers outside of the State of New York, and most of the wholesaler's sales of the product were to buyers outside of New York. The wholesaler argued that § 140a, which prohibited the sale of beef containing more than 10 percent water, was unconstitutional because it contravened an amendment to the Meat Inspection Regulations of the Department of Agriculture, 9 C.F.R. § 17.8(c)(52) (Cum. Supp.). Section 17.8(c)(52) provided for the sale of beef with 20 percent water. The court ruled that the city ordinance was unconstitutional. The court found that the products covered by the ordinance were the subject of interstate commerce and that the wholesaler was clearly engaged in interstate commerce. In so ruling, the court rejected the city's argument that the ordinance was a proper exercise of police power because the ordinance conflicted with federal law and infringed upon federal policy. It prohibited the importation of beef permitted by federal law, and it rendered negatory the inspections conducted by the federal government.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of the wholesale, rendering the city ordinance at issue unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Commerce -- local regulation of meat inspection -- (1) Federal meat inspection regulations fixed permissible maximum added weight of 20% curing solution in preparation of corned beef briskets; provision of New York City Sanitary Code (§ 140a) limited such added weight to 10%; on action of New York City wholesale dealer in meats engaged in interstate commerce, section 140a declared unconstitutional -- (2) State or municipal statute must fall if in terms or practical administration it either conflicts with Federallaw or infringes on its policy.

1. Where the Federal meat inspection regulations fixed a permissible maximum added weight of 20% curing solution in the preparation of corned beef briskets, a provision of the New York City Sanitary Code (§ 140a) limiting such added weight to 10% was declared unconstitutional on the action of a New York City wholesale dealer in such meats engaged in interstate commerce.

2. A State or municipal statute must fall if in terms or practical administration it either conflicts with the Federal law or infringes on its policy.

 

2756 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Port of New York Authority v. J. E. Linde Paper Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Municipal Court of the City of New York, Borough of Manhattan


205 Misc. 110; 127 N.Y.S.2d 155; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2539



November 30, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord instituted a holdover proceeding in the court to recover possession of certain space occupied by a tenant on the premises designated as the landlord's building.


OVERVIEW: The landlord was an agency of the state. The landlord brought a holdover proceeding against the tenant predicated on the fact that the landlord was not subject to the restrictive provisions of the Commercial Rent Law (Emergency Rent Law) because the landlord fell within the exemptive provisions. The court entered a final order for the landlord and stayed the issuance of a warrant in conformance with the parties' stipulation. Because the enactment, by its terms, did not expressly include the state or its agencies, it was evident that it as not applicable to the landlord. Because the State of New Jersey did not concur in the Emergency Rent Laws passed by the State of New York nor in their application to the landlord, the landlord could not be subject to the New York law. By virtue of the compact and the subsequent pertinent legislation, together with the judicial interpretations thereof, the court held that the landlord was endowed with all of the attributes and immunities afforded to the sovereign state, and that it thereby fell squarely within the exemptive provisions of the Emergency Rent Law. The landlord was not required to establish a statutory ground for dispossession.


OUTCOME: The court entered a final order for the landlord in its holdover proceeding against the tenant and stayed conformance with a stipulation agreed upon between the parties and incorporated in the record.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- Port of New York Authority -- holdover proceeding by Port of New York Authority to recover possession of leased space in Port of New York Authority building in city of New York; final order for Authority -- (2) Authority exempt from restrictive provisions of Commercial Rent Law -- (3) Authority created by interstate compact, uniformly held to be in position of "the State" whenever issue has arisen -- (4) tenant's contention that leasing nongovernmental function, untenable -- (5) Authority immune from unilateral regulation of one of States -- (6) exemption of Authority from Commercial Rent Law not deprivation of equal protection of laws nor violative of due process clause of Fourteenth Amendment.

1. In this holdover proceeding by the Port of New York Authority to recover possession of certain space occupied by the tenant in a Port of New York Authority building, in the city of New York the Authority is entitled to a final order.

2. The Authority is not subject to the restrictive provisions of the Commercial Rent Law since it falls within the exemptive provisions [***2] of subdivision (d) of section 13 thereof which provides: "The provisions of this act, likewise, shall be inapplicable to * * * (d) any commercial space with respect to which the state or any city or the New York City Housing Authority has heretofore acquired or shall hereafter acquire the status of landlord". Even in the absence of this provision, the Authority would be exempt from the restrictions of the Commercial Rent Law under the rule that general legislation is inapplicable to the State or its agencies unless there is express language subjecting the sovereign to the terms thereof.

3. The Port of New York Authority is a bi-State governmental agency created by an interstate compact between the States of New York and New Jersey. The Authority has uniformly been held to be in the position of "the State" whenever the issue has arisen.

4. The Authority's building, in which the tenant's premises are located, was constructed and is operated and maintained by the Authority as a self-sustaining governmental unit in the exercise of the power of both States for a public purpose. Hence, the tenant's contention that the leasing was in the exercise of a nongovernmental function cannot be [***3] sustained.

5. The Port of New York Authority, being an instrumentality of the State of New Jersey as well as the State of New York, and engaged in the effectuation of a compact between them, is immune from the unilateral imposition of a burden or restriction in its powers by taxation or regulation of one of the States. The State of New Jersey has not concurred in the Emergency Rent Laws passed by the State of New York nor in their application to the Port of New York Authority.

6. The exemption of the Port of New York Authority from the Commercial Rent Law does not deprive the tenant of the equal protection of the laws nor violate the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

 

2757 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rodenbach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


204 Misc. 905; 126 N.Y.S.2d 295; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2434



November 24, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review after a Court of Special Sessions held by a Justice of the Peace of the Town of Lancaster, Erie County (New York), convicted them of violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14(8).


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of operating trucks that were overloaded on the rear axles. Defendants contended that § 14 was unconstitutional; that the scales used were not properly established as proper or accurate scales; that the distribution of the load on the truck might have shifted, thereby changing the weight at the time of weighing; and that defendants did not have knowledge of their violation of the law. The court held that the so-called "bridge formula" had been in the statute books of New York for about 22 years. The original "weight law" had been enacted about 35 earlier. The appellate courts, including the highest court in the State, had all passed upon the statutes and none had held them unconstitutional. The question of constitutionality was best left to the higher, appellate courts; the court encouraged defendants to seek further review. The distribution of a load on a vehicle, or the knowledge or lack of knowledge of the accuracy of scales on the part of the operator of a vehicle, were questions of fact and not of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- weight of vehicles -- (1) defendants convicted of operating motor trucks on public highway while overloaded on rear axle (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 14, subd. 8); judgments of conviction affirmed -- (2) statute not unconstitutional.

1. The defendants were convicted by a Justice of the Peace of operating motor trucks which were overloaded on the rear axle, in violation of subdivision 8 of section 14 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. The defendants contended, upon appeal to the County Court, that said subdivision 8 of section 14 was unconstitutional; that the scales used were not properly established as proper or accurate scales; that the distribution of a load on the truck may shift, thereby changing the weight at the time of weighing; and that the defendants did not have knowledge of their violation of the statute. Judgments of conviction affirmed.

2. Subdivision 8 of section 14 of the [***2] Vehicle and Traffic Law is not unconstitutional.

 

2758 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Vadakin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Columbia County


204 Misc. 904; 125 N.Y.S.2d 25; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2268



October 28, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Court of Special Sessions held by a justice of the peace of the Town of Kinderhook, Columbia County (New York), which convicted defendant of violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14(8).


OVERVIEW: The proof as to the weight of the vehicle was introduced over the objection of defendant that the proper foundation for its proof had not been laid. He argued that there was no proof that the scales upon which the vehicle was weighed were accurate. In setting aside the conviction, the court found that there was no presumption that the scales of the State were accurate. Where an objection was made that the proper foundation had not been laid, the State had to first establish the accuracy of its scales. Moreover, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14(8) was unconstitutional because it violated N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. It deprived a man of his livelihood without due process of law. A defendant charged with the violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 14 could be convicted of a crime that he did not know that he committed and that it was impossible for him to ascertain whether or not he was committing. Defendant, the driver of the vehicle, did not load the truck. It would be impossible for him to check the weight of the truck.


OUTCOME: The court set aside the conviction.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- weight of vehicles -- (1) conviction for violation of subdivision 8 of section 14 of Vehicle and Traffic Law [overloading truck on one axle] set aside, where proof of weight of vehicle introduced over objection of defendant that People had offered no proof that scales were accurate -- (2) driver had received from employer bill of lading showing load within permissible limits for type of vehicle; driver had no way of checking weight of truck and weight on each of wheels thereof; statute violative of due process clause of State Constitution since possible thereunder that driver may be convicted though he had no way of knowing whether he was committing crime.

1. A conviction for violation of subdivision 8 of section 14 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law [overloading truck on one axle] should be set aside, where proof as to the weight of the vehicle was introduced over objection of the defendant [***2] that the People had offered no proof that the scales upon which the vehicle was weighed were accurate. There is no presumption that the scales of the State of New York are accurate.

2. The defendant driver of the truck had received from his employer a bill of lading showing a load within permissible limits for the type of vehicle he was driving. The driver did not weigh the truck and it would be impossible for him to check the weight of the truck and especially the weight on each of the wheels thereof. It is possible that under the statute (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 14, subd. 8) a truck driver may be convicted for a violation of the terms thereof though he had no way of determining that he was committing a crime, and, as a consequence, he might be deprived of his operator's license and opportunity to earn a living. The statute, insofar as it applies to persons who unknowingly violate its provisions, offends the due process clause of the State Constitution.

 

2759 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cushman v. McGoldrick


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


126 N.Y.S.2d 841; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2504



October 28, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, petitioner landlords filed a motion against respondent, the state rent administrator, for vacation of a determination of the New York State Rent Commission. The Commission denied a certificate of eviction of tenants. The application for the certificate was made pursuant to N.Y. Rent Regs. 59, codified at N.Y. Unconsol. Law, App.


OVERVIEW: The landlords argued that they permanently desired to withdraw an apartment from the rental market because of an immediate and compelling necessity. The landlords further argued that § 10(4) of the Emergency Housing Rent Control Law, N.Y. Unconsol. Law § 8590(4), and N.Y. Rent Regs. 59, codified at N.Y. Unconsol. Law, App., were unconstitutional in depriving the landlords of their property without due process of law. The court denied the motion and dismissed the petition. The validity of N.Y. Unconsol. Law § 8590(4) was clear. Moreover, the landlords lacked standing to challenge a law under which they participated in a proceeding. The constitutionality of N.Y. Rent Regs. 59, codified at N.Y. Unconsol. Law, App., had to be gauged in each case. In this case, the landlords failed to comply with N.Y. Unconsol. Law §§ 8590 and 8589, which required a filing of a protest to a regulation in order for later objections to be heard. The record warranted the decision by the administrator, including a failure to show that the landlords were not earning a standard return, that they could not obtain a rent increase to cover repairs, or any violations filed against the building.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion and dismissed the petition.

 

2760 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Coffrin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court, City of New York, Municipal Term Court, Borough of Queens


126 N.Y.S.2d 329; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2439



October 27, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with flying, or causing to be flown, a plane over a portion of Queens County, New York, while towing a banner for advertising purposes, in violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 435-16.0(d)(2). Defendant entered a plea of not guilty to the charges against him and sought a dismissal of the People's complaint.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that he was not guilty because the towing of the banner was not done "over the limits" of New York City, N.Y. , as charged in the complaint, but rather one-half mile off shore over the Atlantic Ocean. The court held that the prosecution was abortive for failing to show that the alleged violation was committed within the limits of New York City. In so holding, the court found that: (1) § 435-16.0(d)(2) applied only to aircraft towing banners from or upon an aircraft over the limits of New York City; (2) it was undisputed that defendant's airplane took off from the State of New Jersey and proceeded over the Atlantic Ocean to a point approximately one-half mile off shore; (3) the reference to the boundary of the New York State line limited the territory of the City of New York to that portion of the Atlantic Ocean which was at the low-water mark at the points where the respective offenses were alleged to have occurred; (4) the boundary of New York City was the shoreline of the Atlantic Ocean; and (5) § 435-16.0(d)(2) was unconstitutional in that it entirely proscribed and prohibited an activity that was permitted by federal law.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the People's complaint.

 

2761 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kaye v. Doe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Bronx County


204 Misc. 719; 125 N.Y.S.2d 135; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2292



October 20, 1953 



DISPOSITION: Both motions are accordingly denied. The defendants may appear generally within ten days after service of order with notice of entry. Orders signed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, an insurer and its attorneys, filed motions to vacate the service of process upon them in an action brought by plaintiff judgment creditors to recover on an insurance policy issued by the insurer to the judgment debtor as the insured.


OVERVIEW: The judgment creditors recovered against the insured for injuries arising out of an airplane accident. The insured became insolvent, and the judgment creditors brought suit against the insurer, a foreign corporation, with service of process upon the Superintendent of Insurance, pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law § 59-a, and the insurer's attorneys. In their motion to vacate the service of process, the insurer and the attorneys recognized the operation of § 59-a but argued that it was available only to the insured and could not be used by the judgment creditors. The court reviewed the common law concept that proceeds of liability policies could not be reached by injured third parties and the statutory enactments that allowed injured third parties to seek recovery directly from insurers. The court concluded that, given the insured's insolvency, the judgment creditors could make use of §59-a and that such use of the statute did not breach any protective constitutional provisions. Additionally, the court determined that an adequate basis existed, under language of the policy itself, to sustain service upon the attorneys. Accordingly, the court found that it properly had jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The motions of the insurer and the attorneys to vacate service of process were both denied, and they were given 10 days to appear generally.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- service of process on unauthorized foreign or alien insurers -- jurisdiction of actions -- (1) Insurance Law (§ 59-a) provides that if unauthorized foreign or alien insurer issues contract of insurance to resident of New York, such unauthorized insurer thereby designates Superintendent of Insurance as person to receive service of process in actions on behalf of "insured or beneficiary"; plaintiffs sustained injuries in airplane accident and recovered judgment in action against tort-feasor insured by liability policy issued by defendant unauthorized alien insurer; tort-feasor insolvent and action on policy then brought against such insurer; plaintiffs are "beneficiaries" within Insurance Law entitling them to bring action against insurer on policy -- (2) Insurance Law (§ 59-a) constitutional; section 167 not ineffective as against unauthorized insurers -- (3) service of process upon Superintendent of Insurance gave court jurisdiction  [***2] over person of defendant -- (4) policy provided that if defendant failed to pay amount claimed under policy, defendant would at request of insured submit to jurisdiction of any court in United States; persons named in policy to accept service of process in behalf of defendant in any suit instituted against it upon contract; service on designated persons sufficient to give court jurisdiction.

1. Section 59-a of the Insurance Law provides for the service of process on the Superintendent of Insurance as attorney for unauthorized foreign or alien insurers who do designated acts, by mail or otherwise, in this State, including among them the issuance or delivery of contracts of insurance to residents of the State, the solicitation of applications for such contracts, the collection of premiums for such contracts or any other transaction of business. That section provides that the doing of such acts shall constitute an appointment by such an insurer of the Superintendent to be its lawful attorney, upon whom may be served all lawful process in actions or proceedings instituted by or on behalf of an insured or beneficiary.
