Plaintiffs sustained personal injuries in an airplane accident [***3] and obtained a judgment against the tort-feasor, which was insured by a liability policy issued by the defendant unauthorized alien insurer. The insured tort-feasor is insolvent and the judgment remaining unpaid, this action was brought against such insurer to recover the amount of the judgment. The summons was served on the Superintendent of Insurance. An examination of section 59-a of the Insurance Law shows that jurisdiction is conferred if there is an unauthorized insurer, a contract, and any suit arising out of such contract in favor of a resident -- whether plaintiff in such suit be the insured or the benficiary. Plaintiffs, having obtained a judgment against the insolvent tort-feasor, fall within the terms of section 167 of the Insurance Law and section 59-a as "beneficiaries".

2. Section 59-a of the Insurance Law is not unconstitutional as to the defendant insurer. Nor is section 167 of the Insurance Law ineffective as against unauthorized insurers.

3. Service of process upon the Superintendent of Insurance was valid and effective under section 59-a to give the court jurisdiction over the person of defendant.

4. The insurance policy provided that if defendant did not [***4] pay the amount claimed under the policy, defendant would submit "at the request of Insured" to the jurisdiction of any court within the United States and that all matters arising under the policy should be determined in accordance with the "law and practice of such Court". It was provided further that certain named persons were designated to accept service of process in any suit. No specific reference was made in the contract as to the identity of the suitor. The language of the policy provision in itself was sufficient to give the court jurisdiction of any action brought by whatever suitor entitled to come within sections 59-a, 143 and 167 of the Insurance Law. Adequate basis exists to sustain the service upon the persons designated in the policy. If it were deemed otherwise, a hearing could be directed on the issue as to whether there was -- in the language of the policy -- "request of the insured" that defendant submit to the jurisdiction of the court.

 

2762 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Brinkman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Queens County


205 Misc. 337; 126 N.Y.S.2d 495; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2454



October 16, 1953 



DISPOSITION: As already indicated, the motion is denied but without prejudice to the defendant's right to apply for such alternative and further relief as may be deemed appropriate in the premises.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following his indictment for conspiracy, violations of N.Y. Penal Law art. 170, and violations of New York City Charter §§ 886 and 901, defendant, joined by others indicted by the same grand jury for related offenses, filed a motion for an order permitting him to examine the grand jury minutes. Defendant argued that the minutes would reveal that the indictment should be set aside.


OVERVIEW: A grand jury was engaged in a continuing investigation of the criminal aspects of the construction of a sewer and other public improvements. The grand jury conducted 33 sessions where evidence was presented, and defendant was indicted for crimes. Defendant was granted an inspection of the records of attendance of the grand jury, and he filed a motion for an order permitting him to examine the grand jury minutes. Others joined in the motion. The motion was denied without prejudice consistent with the prevailing policy of the court, but the indictment was set aside. An examination of the attendance records showed that on a vote of 17 members of the panel, by reason of the absences of several grand jurors at many of the sessions, 12 of the number who presumably concurred to indict could not possibly have honored their statutory obligation to hear substantially all of the evidence bearing on the accusations. What the absentees missed was of substantial importance, and their inattention violated the safeguards against unfounded accusation and unjust convictions. The People could appeal or could resubmit the matter to a grand jury with precautions against any recurrence of absences.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's application for an inspection of the minutes, without prejudice to defendant's right to apply for alternative and further relief as was appropriate, and it set aside the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Grand jury -- indictment where majority of grand jurors had not heard all evidence -- (1) grand jury attendance record and minutes showed that of grand jurors who concurred in finding indictment there were twelve who had not heard all evidence; indictment should be set aside for that reason -- (2) grand jury may act only upon legal evidence; individual grand juror's knowledge may only be acted upon by body when offered to it through his sworn testimony; no lawful substitute for actual hearing by each and every grand juror of evidence adduced under sanction of oath.

1. Where grand jury attendance record and minutes showed that of the grand jurors who concurred in finding an indictment there were twelve who had not heard all of the evidence adduced in connection with the crimes charged, the indictment should be set aside for that reason.

2. A grand jury may act only upon legal evidence. An individual grand juror's knowledge may only be acted [***2] upon by the body when offered to it through his sworn testimony. Hence, there can be no lawful substitute for the actual hearing by each and every grand juror of the evidence adduced under the sanction of an oath or its equivalent.

 

2763 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Humbeutel v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part IX


125 N.Y.S.2d 198; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2299



September 21, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former members of the police department sought a judgment declaring Local Law No. 71 of 1951, New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 434a-21.0, to be unconstitutional and void.


OVERVIEW: The former police officers attacked the local law on the ground that it was in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions and the City Home Rule Law and was indefinite, vague, discriminatory, arbitrary, unreasonable, a waste of public funds, and contrary to public policy. The court held that the local law fixing age 63 as the age of retirement was not so unreasonable and so arbitrary that the court could not interfere. The evidence adduced by the former officers at trial was insufficient to establish the contravention of public policy by the local law. The court could not declare the law invalid, as it was the people's representatives in the city government, and not the court, who had the responsibility of enacting legislation for the government of the city. The court held that the former officers failed to sustain the burden cast upon them to establish the local law to be indefinite, arbitrary, unreasonable, discriminatory, and contrary to public policy, and failed to effectuate public policy or promote efficiency. Judgment in favor of the city was rendered declaring local law No. 71 to be a valid enactment.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment in favor of the city and held that the local law that required the former members of the police department to retire at age 63 was valid.

 

2764 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Somers v. Camarco


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County, Part II


126 N.Y.S.2d 154; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2415



September 2, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff town sought a declaratory judgment that defendant property owners were subject to the town's zoning ordinances; the town also sought to enjoin the owners from excavating and selling sand and gravel, except under a permit provided for by the ordinances. The owners counterclaimed that the ordinances were unconstitutional and sought an injunction against their enforcement.


OVERVIEW: One of the owners purchased 27 acres on the west side of a highway and 28 acres on the east side of the road. The western parcel was mined for sand and gravel. The court found that east parcel was also used as part of that operation. The town adopted a zoning ordinance that placed the property in restricted residential zones. The ordinance provided for the continuance of bona fide prior non-conforming uses. The ordinance was amended to deal with the sand and gravel pits. The court held that the ordinance, as amended, overstepped the town's regulatory authority because it required the removal of structures and improvements at the termination of a regulatory approval period. While the town could regulate the sand and gravel business in the public interest, the destruction of a substantial business that was developed before the adoption of the zoning regulations was not justified by the public advantage the town sought. A strong public desire to improve the public condition was insufficient to abrogate the constitutional requirement that a taking had to be paid for.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the town's complaint and granted judgment on the owner's counterclaim.

 

2765 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Klein


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


124 N.Y.S.2d 460; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2188



August 26, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner owners sought a review under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 of the denial by respondent rent administrator of the owners' application for certificates of eviction for the tenants in the owners' premises.


OVERVIEW: The owners claimed in their application that it was not economical to continue maintaining their building as rental property and they desired to demolish the building. The owners also claimed that the denial of the requested certificate by the rent administrator deprived them of their property without due process and N.Y. Rent and Eviction Regs. § 59 was unconstitutional. The court determined that the evidence supported the owners' contention that it was not economical for them to continue renting the building and that the past operation of the building for the tenants was at a loss. The court held that N.Y. Emer. Hous. Rent Control Law § 10(4) gave the rent administrator the authority to deny a certificate of eviction to an owner that was intending to continue renting his premises at a later date, but the owners were entitled to a certificate when the owners showed that the continued maintenance of their premises as rental property was a hardship. The court held that the application to the owners of § 10(4) and the last sentence of N.Y. Rent and Eviction Regs. § 59 violated N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 and U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the orders of the rent administrator were set aside and declared null and void and the rent administrator was directed to issue the owners the certificates of eviction requested.

 

2766 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Leroy Franz, Inc. v. New Rochelle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


124 N.Y.S.2d 525; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2202



August 24, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff building owner instituted an action against defendant city to have a city ordinance on the collection of garbage declared invalid and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The city enacted General Ordinances of the City of New Rochelle, N.Y., § 170(1)(c) to reduce the amount and number of garbage collections in commercial and industrial areas of the city. The commercial building owner instituted an action that challenged the ordinance because it asserted that the ordinance unfairly classified the commercial and industrial areas and separately classified them from the residential areas and failed to provide an adequate definition of the collection sites. The city asserted that it had the right to enact ordinances for the public health and welfare, and could classify the collections differently to accommodate different interests in safety and health. The court determined that the city had the right to classify the commercial and industrial districts differently from the residential areas for the purpose of collections. The court declared the ordinance void and enjoined its use because it determined that the ordinance that failed to define the word "premise" as either the land and appurtenances or each separate store and office in a large building failed to provide sufficient information for the users and the city to properly enforce the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the refuse collection ordinance was invalid and restrained the city from enforcing it.

 

2767 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bohling v. Corsi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Oneida County


204 Misc. 778; 127 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2580



August 12, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Both parties filed motions for judgment on the pleadings in plaintiff employer's action against defendant state industrial commissioner (commissioner), for a declaratory judgment that the state payroll tax was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The employer had employed more than four people, but reduced his staff to less than four. Pursuant to the N.Y. Labor Law, the employer was liable for payroll tax when he had four or more employees. Under N.Y. Labor Law § 562, the employer remained liable for the tax even after he had reduced his staff for e period of time determined by the commissioner. The employer filed an action seeking a declaratory judgment that the provision which required him to continue to pay tax after he had reduced his staff below four employees was unconstitutional. Both the employer and the commissioner filed motions for judgment on the pleadings. The court granted the commissioner's motion for judgment on the pleadings and denied the employer's motion. The court held that provisions which based liability on the number of employees were valid. The court held that there was nothing discriminatory on the face of the statute because it applied to all employers equally. The court held that the statute was reasonable and based on administrative convenience and protection of workers.


OUTCOME: The court granted the commissioner's motion for judgment on the pleadings in the employer's action for a declaratory judgment that the state payroll tax was unconstitutional. The court denied the employer's motion for judgment on the pleadings.


HEADNOTES

Unemployment insurance -- contributions -- termination of coverage -- (1) Labor Law ( § 562) requires covered employer to make contributions for year after employer has less than four employees in his employ; in action to declare such section unconstitutional, Industrial Commissioner entitled to judgment declaring section constitutional -- (2) classification imposing liability upon employer of persons in excess of designated number valid and not discriminatory; continuance of tax for calendar year following that in which number of persons employed is reduced to less than four valid; statute constitutional on ground of administrative convenience.

1. Section 560 of the Labor Law renders an employer liable for unemployment insurance contributions if he employs four or more persons on fifteen or more days in any calendar year. Section 562 provides that an employer who has once become liable for contributions shall cease to be liable if he files a written application with the Industrial Commissioner during the fourth calendar quarter, in which case he may be released from coverage as of the first [***2] day of the next calendar quarter, provided the commissioner finds that the employer has not employed four or more persons in employment within each of fifteen or more days in the completed calendar year in which the application is filed. Coverage may also be terminated if the employer files a written application with the commissioner in any other calendar quarter of the year, in which case he may be released from coverage as of the first day of the calendar quarter following the filing of the application, provided the commissioner finds the employer has, before such day, in neither the calendar year in which the application is filed nor in the preceding calendar year, employed four or more persons in employment within each of fifteen or more days. In an action by a building contractor who prior to January, 1951, employed four persons and thereafter less than four, to declare unconstitutional section 562 of the Labor Law on the ground that the statute discriminates against plaintiff because it renders him liable for the tax for at least one year after he ceased to employ four persons, defendant Industrial Commissioner is entitled to judgment on the pleadings declaring such statute [***3] constitutional.

2. A classification which imposes liability upon an employer of persons in excess of a designated number for a specified period is valid. The section is not discriminatory on its face as it applies to all employers in the designated class, and the classification has a reasonable basis. Moreover, constitutionality of the statute may be sustained on the ground of administrative convenience and necessity alone. The requirement that a written application must be made before an employer is released from liability, and a finding that he had not employed four or more persons during the calendar year preceding the application are reasonable requirements and conducive to the efficient administration of the law. The law does not impose an onerous burden on the privilege of employment.

 

2768 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Karnow


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Suffolk County


204 Misc. 632; 123 N.Y.S.2d 537; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1992



August 11, 1953 



DISPOSITION: The judgment herein is accordingly reversed on the law and this proceeding is remitted to the Justice's Court, Town of Huntington.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of a Court of Special Sessions held by the Justice of the Peace of the Town of Huntington, Suffolk County (New York), which convicted defendant of violating a parking meter ordinance of the Town of Huntington.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty to violating a town parking meter ordinance. On appeal, defendant contended that the ordinance under which he was convicted was unconstitutional. The court held that: (1) there was no merit to defendant's contention that the ordinance was unconstitutional; but (2) defendant correctly contended that the justice of the peace lacked jurisdiction to try defendant because no complaint or information had been filed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the conviction and remanded the case.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- parking meter ordinance -- (1) parking meter ordinance of Town of Huntington is constitutional -- (2) ordinance provided that owner's disregard of summons left with his automobile was disorderly conduct; Penal Law (§ 722) does not define violation of parking ordinance as disorderly conduct; attempt of ordinance to make disregard of summons disorderly conduct ineffective, but punitive provisions of ordinance still enforcible -- (3) since violation of ordinance was traffic infraction, Justice of Peace had jurisdiction -- (4) procedure applicable to trial of misdemeanor applicable to traffic infraction; since no information filed against defendant, court lacked jurisdiction; judgment of conviction reversed.

1. A parking meter ordinance of the Town of Huntington [***2] was constitutional.

2. The ordinance provided, among other things, that if the owner of an automobile disregarded a summons left with his automobile, such conduct constituted disorderly conduct. Section 722 of the Penal Law describes the acts constituting disorderly conduct and violation of a parking ordinance is not among them. That part of the ordinance was ineffective, but the fact that violation of the ordinance was improperly labeled, did not render ineffective the punitive provisions of the ordinance.

3. The violation of the ordinance here, since one regulating traffic, was a traffic infraction. Subdivision 29 of section 2 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law provides that a violation of a local ordinance regulating traffic which provides a penalty is a traffic infraction. This provision gave jurisdiction of the subject matter to a Justice of the Peace sitting as a court of special sessions.

4. For the purpose of prosecuting traffic infractions, the procedural rules for the trial of misdemeanors are applicable. Since no complaint or information had been filed against defendant herein, defendant having merely appeared in response to a letter, the Justice lacked jurisdiction [***3] to try defendant. Defendant had signed no statement or admission of guilt. Where a motorist appears in court in compliance with a ticket, an information must be sworn out and defendant arraigned, unless a traffic violations bureau has been established by the municipality. The court took judicial notice that at the time defendant herein was sentenced, no such traffic violations bureau had been set up by the Town of Huntington. The judgment of conviction was, accordingly, reversed on the law and the proceeding remitted to the Justice's Court.

 

2769 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Arlington Village Development Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


204 Misc. 395; 124 N.Y.S.2d 172; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2121



July 31, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner development corporation sought certiorari under New York City, N.Y., Charter § 668 and New York City, N.Y., City Admin. Code § 668e-1.0 to review a determination of respondent board of standards and appeals granting a variance to respondent property owners for a term of 20 years to permit the erection of an automobile showroom and service station on certain premises.


OVERVIEW: The premises of the property owners, a couple, were located in a Residence Use, C Area and Class 1 Height District. The property owners applied to the department of housing and buildings for permission to erect an automobile showroom, service station, and related facilities on the premises. The application was denied by a borough superintendent, an official without power to grant a variance, because the contemplated uses were violative of New York City, N.Y., Zoning Res. § 3, and the area of the proposed structure was in excess of that permitted by New York City, N.Y., Zoning Res. § 13. The property owners then applied to the board of standards and appeals for a variance under New York City, N.Y. Zoning Res. §§ 21(7)(e), 21, and it was granted. On review, the court confirmed that determination and dismissed the petition because the variance, which was limited by numerous conditions on the construction and operation of the proposed structure, was reasonably imposed with a view to protecting and safeguarding the surrounding area and its inhabitants. With those safeguards, the court concluded, the spirit and purposes of the zoning resolutions were maintained.


OUTCOME: The court vacated an order of certiorari, it confirmed the determination of the board, and it dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- variance -- (1) respondent board of standards and appeals granted variance, under New York City Zoning Resolution (§§ 7, 21), permitting erection of automobile showroom and service station in residence district; since ample evidence supports board's finding that variance complies with Zoning Resolution and provides for public health, safety, and general welfare, board acted within its jurisdiction and its determination not set aside -- (2) section 7 of Zoning Resolution does not unlawfully delegate legislative power and is constitutional.

1. This is a certiorari proceeding, instituted under the Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ 668e-1.0) and the New York City Charter (§ 668, subd. e), to review a determination granting a variance to premises located in a Residence Use, C Area and Class 1 Height Districts, for a stated term of twenty years, permitting the erection of an automobile showroom and service station. Section 7 of the [***2] New York City Zoning Resolution provides that the board of standards and appeals may in appropriate cases and subject to appropriate conditions vary the application of the use district regulations so as to permit, for a stated term of years, uses not in conformity with the requirements of the article. Section 21 of the Zoning Resolution authorizes the board of standards and appeals to adopt rules and, in the case of practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships, to vary any provision in harmony with its general purposes and intent so that the public health, safety, and general welfare may be secured and substantial justice done. The board found that the granting of the variance was "in harmony with the spirit and purpose of the Zoning Resolution, does secure the public health, safety and general welfare and does do substantial justice". Since there is ample evidence to support such finding, the grant of a variance was justifiable under the provisions of subdivision e of section 7 or section 21 of the resolution. Since the board acted within its jurisdiction, its determination may not be set aside.

2. Section 7 of the Zoning Resolution does not unlawfully delegate legislative [***3] power to a subordinate body and is constitutional. Standards are provided which, though stated in general terms, are capable of a reasonable application and are sufficient to limit the board's discretionary powers. Accordingly the board's determination should be confirmed.

 

2770 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Carpenter v. Justices of Court


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part I


124 N.Y.S.2d 538; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2205



July 17, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner putative father moved for an order pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 seeking to prohibit the hearing of a filiation proceeding brought against him by respondent mother, who claimed that the putative father was the father of her unborn child. He argued that there was no jurisdiction to proceed in the action.


OVERVIEW: The mother was a resident of the State of Connecticut, while the putative father was a resident of the State of New Jersey. The putative father was, however, served with a summons while in the City of New York, where he was employed. The putative father argued that the provisions of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 135 controlled and provided that there was no jurisdiction where neither parent was a resident of the State of New York. The mother argued that under New York City, N.Y., Crim. Cts. Act § 64, jurisdiction existed where the putative father had been found in the City of New York. The court found that: (1) where the putative father had been found in the city, the court appeared to have jurisdiction; (2) there was no inconsistency between the statutes at issue where N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 122(1) enlarged the jurisdictional limits of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 135 and permitted jurisdiction; and (3) it was improper to prohibit the hearing in question.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion.

 

2771 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Stewart


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Broome County


204 Misc. 490; 122 N.Y.S.2d 843; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1892



July 10, 1953 



DISPOSITION: By reason of the fact, that the information is defective, on the grounds hereinbefore stated, the judgment of conviction should be reversed and the information dismissed. An order may be submitted accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed their convictions by a jury in a Court of Special Sessions held by a Justice of the Peace of the Town of Vestal, Broome County (New York) for jointly operating a trailer park without first securing an annual permit or license and without paying the necessary fee for each unit and trailer plot in violation of Vestal, Broome County, N.Y., Trailer Park Ordinance (Nov. 2, 1949).


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with operating a trailer park without securing a permit and without paying the fees for each unit and trailer plot. The information on which the warrant was issued relied on a deed of conveyance from one person to defendants, doing business as "Stewart's Four Cities Trailer Park." A certificate of an assumed name filed by defendants stated they were doing business under that name. Defendants were convicted. On appeal, the court reversed and dismissed the information. The court held that the presumption under N.Y. Penal Law § 440, that the facts stated in the certificate of assumed name were true, merely established that defendants were operating the trailer park on the day it was filed. The statute did not provide for a presumption that the persons named in the certificate continued in the actual operation of the business until the certificate was cancelled or revoked. It did not seem that such presumption of continuity in the operation of the business should have been implied in defendants' criminal proceeding, especially in light of the fact that no other facts were stated in the information as a basis for the information and belief of the informant.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendants' convictions and dismissed the information.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- trailer parks -- licenses -- (1) information charged defendants jointly with operating trailer park in violation of ordinance; sources of information and grounds of belief of informant stated in information to be certificate of doing business as trailer park filed by defendants on September 1, 1950, and deed to defendants, doing business as certain trailer park, also recorded on September 1, 1950; information charging continuing violation "from on or about September 1, 1950", inadequate, in absence of sufficient statement of source of information, to give court jurisdiction; conviction reversed and information dismissed -- (2) ordinance not unconstitutional on ground that license fee exceeds  [***2] costs of issuance and inspection; no evidence offered to show actual cost; license fee of $ 5 for each unit and trailer plot not excessive per se -- (3) Justice of Peace not disqualified because town board, of which he was member, delegated to him task of preparing ordinance; Justice received no extra compensation; Justice did not have interest in case within intent of Judiciary Law (§ 14).

1. An information charging defendants, on information and belief, with jointly operating a trailer park "since on or about the first of September, 1950" in violation of a town ordinance requiring annual permit therefor and the payment of certain license fees, was insufficient, where the information set forth the sources of informant's knowledge and the grounds for his belief as a deed of conveyance to the defendants "doing business as" a certain named trailer park, recorded on or about September 1, 1950, and a certificate of assumed name filed by defendants on September 1, 1950. The information charged a continuing crime, presumably from September 1, 1950, to the date of the verification of the information. The presumption that the facts stated in the certificate of assumed name were true [***3] merely established that defendants were operating the trailer park on September 1, 1950. The statute does not provide for a presumption that the persons named in such a certificate continue in actual operation of the business until the certificate is cancelled or revoked, and such a presumption of continuity in the operation of the business will not be implied, particularly in a criminal proceeding. An information cannot be based upon hearsay or suspicion. Timely objection to the sufficiency of the information having been made, conviction of defendants was required to be reversed and the information dismissed.

2. The ordinance would not be held unconstitutional on the ground that the license fee was excessive and more than sufficient to compensate the town for the expense of issuing and recording the license and the cost of inspection, where no evidence was offered to show the actual cost of issuing and recording the license and the cost of inspection. It could not be held as a matter of law that a license fee of $ 5 for each unit and trailer plot was per se unreasonable and excessive.

3. The Justice of the Peace issuing the warrant was not disqualified because he was delegated [***4] by the town board, of which he was a member by virtue of his office, to prepare and advise regarding the ordinance and in effect acted as attorney and counsel for the town board. In preparing the ordinance the Justice was merely acting within the scope of his duties as a member of the town board, and presumably he was not receiving any extra compensation. The Justice did not have any interest in the case within the intent of section 14 of the Judiciary Law.

 

2772 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Peters v. New York City Housing Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


9 Misc. 2d 942; 128 N.Y.S.2d 224; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1413



July 7, 1953 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The application for a stay is dismissed.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner and intervenor tenants sought an order to invalidate respondent municipal housing authority's (authority) regulation that required tenants as a condition of occupancy of federally funded housing to sign a certificate of nonmembership in organizations designated subversive by the U.S. Attorney General under the United States Housing Act of 1937 (Act), as amended, 42 U.S.C.S. § 1411c.


OVERVIEW: The Act, also known as the Gwinn Amendment, prohibited occupancy of public housing by anyone who was a member of subversive organizations as designated by the U.S. Attorney General. The authority promulgated regulations to enforce this statute that required the tenants to sign a certificate of nonmembership as a condition of occupancy. The court annulled the regulation because due process requirements under the Fifth Amendment and Fourteenth Amendment applied to administrative proceedings, and the discretion vested in the Attorney General to determine what organizations were subversive violated due process rights because it was vague and permitted arbitrary and discriminatory application and enforcement.


OUTCOME: The court declared annulled the authority's regulation, and dismissed the application for a stay as moot.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- United States Attorney General's list of subversive organizations -- public housing -- tenants in Federally aided low-rent housing projects cannot be required, by Congress or by New York City Housing Authority, to sign statements that they are not members of organizations listed by United States Attorney General, since such "subversive" listings were made without giving such organizations opportunity to be heard (U. S. Const., 5th & 14th Amdts.) -- order annulling such requirement by New York City Housing Authority.

1. The United States Attorney General's list of organizations which he, ex parte, deems to be subversive, fascist, totalitarian, communist, etc. (pursuant to Executive Order No. 9835; U. S. Code, tit. 5, § 631, note) was promulgated without giving the organizations notice and opportunity to be heard, and hence was promulgated in violation of due process of law (U. S. Const., 5th Amdt.), and hence does not establish the subversiveness or other guilty character of the organizations or of their members.

2. Therefore, the so-called Gwinn Amendment to the Independent Offices [***2] Appropriations Act of 1953, which stated that "no housing unit constructed under the United States Housing Act of 1937, as amended, shall be occupied by a person who is a member of an organization designated as subversive by the Attorney General" and that "the foregoing prohibition shall be enforced by the local housing authority" (66 U.S. Stat. 403; U. S. Code, tit. 42, § 1411c) violated due process of law (U. S. Const., 5th Amdt.).

3. Therefore, it was illegal and arbitrary for the New York City Housing Authority to implement said Gwinn Amendment by a resolution requiring all persons then or thereafter in occupancy in any Federally-aided low-rent projects to sign, under penalty of dispossess, a statement that they were not members of any organization designated as subversive by the United States Attorney General, and to require petitioners and others, tenants in Federally-aided New York City Housing Authority projects to sign a statement that they were not members of any of 194 organizations designated up to that time by said Attorney General as subversive, fascist, communist, etc., and listed in alphabetical order. (U. S. Const., 14th Amdt.)

4. Persons cannot be required, by [***3] Congress or by the New York City Housing Authority, to surrender any of the rights guaranteed to them by the United States Constitution (5th & 14th Amdts.) in order to enjoy the privileges afforded by low-rent housing laws.

5. Accordingly, petitioners are granted an order under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act annulling the resolution of the New York City Housing Authority and restraining the Authority from taking any steps to evict them.

6. Petitioner may maintain this proceeding even if she is not a member of any of the listed organizations, and even if she refuses to say whether she is or is not a member. In any event, the intervening petitioners do allege that they are members of a listed organization.

7. Even without pendency of any dispossess proceedings, the eviction of tenants who refuse to sign is sufficiently imminent to give them standing as aggrieved persons who may maintain this proceeding.

8. Moreover, since this case presents issues of vital concern to the community, the court should disregard these technical objections and should adjudicate the basic questions.

9. This proceeding (under Civ. Prac. Act, art. 78) is maintainable even though a Federal statute's [***4] unconstitutionality is involved.

10. No cogent reason appears why any Federal officer or body need be made a party to this proceeding, even though a Federal statute is involved.

 

2773 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Dog Owners Ass'n v. Hilleboe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


206 Misc. 119; 124 N.Y.S.2d 835; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2255



June 8, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, corporations and an individual, sought a declaratory judgment that the Metcalf-Hatch Act (Act), N.Y. Pub. Health Law ch. 96, § 5-a (1952), was unconstitutional. Defendants, the Commissioner of Health of the State of New York and the New York Society for Medical Research, sought a declaratory judgment that the Act was constitutional. Defendants also filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed an action against defendants, challenging the constitutionality of the Metcalf-Hatch Act (Act), N.Y. Pub. Health Law ch. 96, § 5-a (1952). Plaintiffs filed a motion for a declaratory judgment on the pleadings. Defendants filed a motion for a judgment declaring the Act constitutional. Defendants also moved for summary judgment. In granting defendants' motions, the court found no merit to plaintiffs' argument that they were deprived of property without due process of law. The court further found that it was purely within the discretion of the legislature to say how far dogs should be recognized as property. Accordingly, the court held that there could be no serious question as to the validity of the Act.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motion for a declaratory judgment that the Metcalf-Hatch Act was constitutional. The court also granted defendants' motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- statute requisitioning unclaimed dogs for scientific tests -- (1) Public Health Law (former § 5-a, added by L. 1952, ch. 96) constitutional; it empowered State Commissioner of Health to requisition, under adequate safeguards and regulations, unclaimed dogs which would otherwise be destroyed and to approve institutions which might conduct scientific tests with such dogs -- (2) Legislature may determine to what extent dogs are property; under State's police power, various municipalities made contracts with plaintiffs to impound and destroy or otherwise dispose of unclaimed dogs (Agriculture and Markets Law, §§ 120, 120-a); such custodian had no property in dogs which State could not take for public purposes -- (3) such custodian was not deprived of property, nor was its contract impaired, nor was power of condemnation illegally delegated, nor was servitude imposed (U. S. Const,. art. I, § 10; 13th Amendt.; 14th Amendt.; N. Y. Const., art I, § 6; § 7, subds. [a], [b]; § 15) -- (4) provision that institution receiving dogs should not be required to license them did not deny equal protection of laws (U. S. Const.,  [***2] 14th Amendt., § 1) -- (5) contract of one plaintiff had expired and it could not be legally holding any dogs seized by it after new act became effective; hence it was not proper party plaintiff and complaint by it was dismissed.

1. Plaintiffs in this action for a declaratory judgment were private corporations which had contracts with municipalities pursuant to the Agriculture and Markets Law ( §§ 120, 120-a) to impound unlicensed and stray dogs and to destroy or otherwise dispose according to law of such seized dogs not redeemed. The Legislature (by L. 1952, ch. 96) added section 5-a to the then existing Public Health Law. That section empowered the State Commissioner of Health to approve laboratories or institutions for scientific tests, including the use of living animals, directed him to prescribe rules to provide for the proper care and treatment of animals so used, and then provided that in lieu of their destruction, he could requisition dogs otherwise to be destroyed from public pounds, or pounds of private organizations to which public authority had been delegated by contract or statute. That section further provided safeguards to insure that only those dogs which would [***3] be otherwise destroyed should be so requisitioned. Such legislation was constitutional.

2. It is purely within the discretion of the Legislature to say how far dogs shall be recognized as property. The various laws of this State relating to licensing and harboring of dogs and the disposition of same (Penal Law, § 185; Agriculture and Markets Law, §§ 114, 119, 120, 120-a, 127; Code Crim. Pro., § 117-c) are all parts of an exercise of the police power to protect the health of the general public. The contract of one plaintiff provided that it should seize animals "for the destruction or other disposition of seized dogs, not redeemed, as provided by Law." Such contracts were a part of the general system of public handling of the dog problem, and such custody as was gained by contractors thereunder was in furtherance only of that general system. The contractors acted only as agents for the municipalities involved. It is well within the legislative power to take for public purposes dogs which no one owns or which the owners do not claim or redeem. When the State does so. the custodian who has the animal is not aggrieved. The custodian, who had no property in the dogs, is deprived [***4] of none.

3. Such a custodian was not deprived of property without due process of law, nor was private property taken for public use without compensation, nor was involuntary servitude imposed, nor was the power of condemnation unconstitutionally delegated, nor was the obligation of its contract unconstitutionally impaired, nor was it caused to violate its charter (U. S. Const., art. I, § 10; 13th Amendt.; 14th Amendt., § 1; N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6; § 7, subds. [a], [b]; § 15).

4. The act (L. 1952, ch. 96) stated that the institution receiving the dogs thereunder should not be required to license them. This was merely a re-enactment of Agriculture and Markets Law ( § 127), which allowed contracting societies to hold dogs without licensing them. It could not be said that the act denied the equal protection of the laws in that licensing was required for some dogs and not for others (U. S. Const., 14th Amendt, § 1).

5. The contract of one of the plaintiffs had expired, and it could not be holding legally any dogs seized by it after the new act became effective. Hence, it was not a qualified plaintiff in this action for a declaratory judgment, and the complaint by this [***5] party was, accordingly, dismissed.

 

2774 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hearst Corp. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


204 Misc. 584; 123 N.Y.S.2d 816; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2047



June 3, 1953 



DISPOSITION: The motion is granted to the extent of dismissing the complaint on the ground that the plaintiffs should be left to the statutory remedy provided for in the Administrative Code.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was a motion filed by defendants, the city and others, to dismiss the complaint brought by plaintiff taxpayers in a declaratory judgment which sought a declaration that certain notices of determination issued by the comptroller assessing the taxpayers with sales taxes were unconstitutional and void, or in the alternative, declaring that a substantial portion of the taxes assessed were invalid.


OVERVIEW: Defendants contended that the court should have exercised its discretion in favor of relegating the taxpayers to the statutory remedy of administrative hearings before the comptroller with the right to review the comptroller's determination. In the court's opinion, the moving affidavit submitted by defendants in support of that branch of the motion that was made pursuant to N.Y. R. Civ. P. 212 showed that a trial of the present action would have necessarily involved litigation of a great number of factual issues relating to numerous transactions of the various taxpayers. The court held that a proper exercise of discretion required that the taxpayers be relegated to the exclusive statutory procedure prescribed by New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § N41-10.0. The taxpayers claimed that the comptroller lacked an adequate staff in order to provide the taxpayers with a timely hearing and thus interest and penalties would have been accruing during that time. The court held that that condition was common to taxpayers generally and was insufficient to justify the court in disregarding the express language of the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to the extent of dismissing the complaint on the ground that the taxpayers should have been left to the statutory remedy provided for in the administrative code.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City sales tax -- review -- (1) action for declaratory judgment that determinations of comptroller assessing sales taxes on plaintiffs unconstitutional; Administrative Code (§ N41-10.0) provides that remedy of hearing before comptroller and review thereof by proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act shall be exclusive remedy; on motion to dismiss complaint, affidavit shows existence of great number of factual issues relating to numerous transactions of various plaintiffs; complaint dismissed; plaintiffs relegated to exclusive statutory remedy prescribed by Administrative Code -- (2) that comptroller lacks adequate staff and that hearings before him may not be secured without long delay, during which interest and penalties will be incurred, insufficient to justify disregard of exclusive remedy provisions of law; plaintiffs' remedyis by way of order in nature of mandamus to compel comptroller to hear plaintiffs' objections within reasonable  [***2] time; until all remedies for purpose of procuring hearing before comptroller exhausted, plaintiffs cannot complain of violation of their constitutional rights.

1. An action seeks a declaration that determinations of the comptroller of the City of New York assessing plaintiffs with sales taxes are unconstitutional. Section N41-10.0 of the Administrative Code provides that the remedy of a hearing before the comptroller and a review by a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act shall be the exclusive remedy. On this motion to dismiss the complaint, the moving affidavit shows that a trial of the action would involve litigation of a great number of factual issues relating to numerous transactions of the various plaintiffs. The exclusive statutory remedy provided for in the Administrative Code may not be disregarded and an action for declaratory judgment maintained where complicated factual issues exist. Plaintiffs should be relegated to the exclusive statutory procedure prescribed by the Administrative Code. The complaint is, accordingly, dismissed.

2. That the comptroller lacks an adequate staff and that hearings may not be secured before him without years of delay [***3] during which interest and penalties are incurred by the taxpayers is insufficient to justify disregard of the exclusive remedy provisions of the law. The proper remedy of plaintiffs would appear to be an application for an order in the nature of mandamus to compel the comptroller to hear plaintiffs' objections to the notices of tax determination within a reasonable time. Until plaintiffs have exhausted all remedies for the purpose of procuring a hearing before the comptroller, they are not in a position to complain that they are being deprived of their property without due process of law or that other constitutional rights belonging to them are being violated.

 

2775 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Zenith-Godley Co. v. Wiley


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part V


121 N.Y.S.2d 795; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1789



May 21, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporations initiated an action against defendant traffic commission seeking a permanent injunction and for judgment declaring a section of the traffic regulations unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The corporations contended that the regulations were arbitrary, discriminatory, and oppressive and that the regulations denied them due process and equal protection of law because they were an undue limitation upon interstate commerce and the corporations' business delivering and transporting goods into the city. The court held that, in determining whether a regulation was to be upheld, it was required to consider the reasonableness of the regulation in light of the evidentiary facts. However, the court determined that ordinances passed in the exercise of the police power would not be declared unconstitutional unless their provisions were clearly arbitrary and unreasonable and had no relation to the public health, safety, morals, or public welfare. The court found that the evidence proved that the regulation was not unreasonable, that the original intendment was the regulation of traffic in the area, that it regulated such traffic, and that the regulation had not unconstitutionally deprived the corporations of their rights. The court granted judgment in favor of the commission.


OUTCOME: Judgment was granted in favor of the commission.

 

2776 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bauman v. Irondequoit


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Monroe County


204 Misc. 494; 122 N.Y.S.2d 47; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1809



May 15, 1953 



DISPOSITION: Motion is granted to the extent that the complaint is dismissed as against the defendant, Laurelton Fire District, but otherwise denied, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, town and fire district, sought a ruling on their motion to dismiss plaintiff widow's negligence suit under the Workmen's Compensation Law.


OVERVIEW: The widow's husband was killed while performing services as a volunteer fireman. She brought a negligence action against defendants to recover for her husband's death. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the suit, contending that her exclusive remedy was under the Workmen's Compensation Law. The court granted the motion as to the fire district, but denied it as to the town. The court held that the services performed as a volunteer fireman within the fire district were clearly performed for and on behalf of that district. The court held that the services were not performed for the town. The court held that because the town was liable for payment of benefits under the Workmen's Compensation Law pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205, the town was immune to the negligence suit as the Workmen's Compensation Law was the widow's exclusive remedy. The court held that the town was not immune because it was not the husband's employer, thus the widow could maintain her common law suit against the town.


OUTCOME: In the widow's negligence action, the court granted the motion to dismiss as to the fire district, but denied it as to the town under the Workmen's Compensation Law.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- volunteer fireman -- action for wrongful death -- (1) defendant town called on fire district within its borders to render assistance to men asphyxiated in sewer manhole; plaintiff's testate, volunteer fireman, answered call and also met his death in manhole by asphyxiation; in action for wrongful death complaint dismissed as against fire district but not as against town -- (2) Workmen's Compensation Law ( § 2, subds. 5, 9) defines employment to include service of volunteer firemen and defines wages of volunteer fireman as money rate applicable to his regular vocation; that plaintiff's testate received no salary immaterial; he was employee of fire district and was subject to orders of officers thereof; fact that call for assistance came from defendant town did not make plaintiff's testate employee of town -- (3) amendment to Workmen's Compensation Law governing volunteer firemen is constitutional -- (4) General Municipal Law ( § 205) imposed duty to make payment  [***2] to injured volunteer fireman upon taxpayers of fire district; since town not obligated under General Municipal Law, third-party action may properly be maintained against defendant town.

1. Defendant town called a fire district within its borders to render assistance to men who had been asphyxiated in a sewer manhole. Plaintiff's testate, a volunteer fireman of the fire district, was called and also met his death by asphyxiation. In this action for wrongful death the complaint should be dismissed as against defendant fire district but not as against defendant town.

2. Subdivision 5 of section 2 of the Workmen's Compensation Law defines "employment" as including service of a volunteer fireman performed for any fire district. Subdivision 9 defines "wages" in the case of a volunteer fireman as the money rate which applies to his regular vocation or the amount of his regular earnings in such vocation. It is immaterial therefore that plaintiff's testate received no salary. The services performed were performed for the fire district. The fire district comprises only a portion of the area of the entire town. The services were not performed for the town although the call for assistance [***3] camefrom defendant town. While rendering such assistance plaintiff's testate was performing services solely for the fire district and was subject solely to the orders and directions of the fire commissioners, employees, chief and assistant chief of that district and its fire department.

3. Volunteer firemen render service without direct compensation and the payments provided for them were intended to be in recognition of the moral obligation owed to such firemen by the community and hence as part compensation for the services gratuitously rendered. The Legislature elected to discharge a moral obligation of a subdivision of the State, and even though it placed an added burden on the taxpayers and was in that sense the taking of property, the legislation is nevertheless constitutional. Accordingly, the amendment to the Workmen's Compensation Law covering volunteer firemen is constitutional.

4. The benefits provided for volunteer firemen by the Workmen's Compensation Law are only in excess of those provided by section 205 of the General Municipal Law. While benefits provided by the latter statute appear to constitute the exclusive remedy against the municipality or district obligated [***4] to pay the same, the right of a fireman or his estate to maintain an action against a third party is clearly recognized. Accordingly, if the liability for making the payments provided for in section 205 rests solely upon the fire district, the benefits so provided would together with the benefits under the Workmen's Compensation Law constitute the exclusive remedy here available to plaintiff as against the fire district but would not preclude the maintenance of an action against defendant town. Section 205 specifies that where a member of a volunteer fire department was a member of a fire district, outside of a city or incorporated village, such sum should be a town charge and assessed upon the property in the fire district liable to taxation. Thus the statute by its express language places the liability for the payment of the benefits provided upon the taxable property in the fire district. Since section 205 of the General Municipal Law imposes no liability on defendant town, this action may properly be maintained against said town.

 

2777 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mallett v. Mamaroneck


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


123 N.Y.S.2d 249; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1952



May 13, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners brought an action against defendants, a village and a property owner, to enjoin the construction of any structures authorized by an amendment to a zoning ordinance. Plaintiffs contended that the amendment, under which defendant owner obtained a permit to build an apartment building, was invalid.


OVERVIEW: The village trustees amended a zoning ordinance to a residential area. Plaintiffs contended that the description contained in the proposed amendment was defective because it did not define, locate, or fix the boundaries of any ascertainable area. Defendants contended that the amendment sufficiently indicated the parcel intended and that any deficiency was overcome by a reasonable and fair construction. They also contended that plaintiffs were not allowed to attack the change because they acquired their title subsequent to the change and with knowledge. The description contained in the proposed amendment specified an ascertainable point of beginning and then defined a course running generally in a northerly direction along the westerly side of a street. The court granted relief to plaintiffs. The amendment failed to give any compass directions, incorrectly referred to a nonexistent street, and failed to specify the various directions of the courses. Thus, it never had the force of law, and no amount of knowledge on plaintiffs' part could have cured the fatal defects. Defendant owner acquired no vested rights in its permit because it was issued pursuant to an invalid ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court granted a judgment for plaintiffs.

 

2778 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Agliata v. D'Agostino


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County, Part I


124 N.Y.S.2d 212; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2134



May 5, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was a motion by plaintiff buyers for summary judgment in an action to recover a down payment. Also before the court was a cross-motion by defendant seller for leave to amend the counterclaim contained in his answer so as to allege that he had no adequate remedy at law and a cross motion for summary judgment in his favor.


OVERVIEW: The seller and the buyers entered into an agreement for the sale of a parcel of real property. At the closing the buyers rejected the title tendered by the seller as unmarketable. It was conceded that the premises described in the contract was located wholly within the bed of a proposed street as laid out on an official city map. The contract provided that the premises were being sold subject to any state of facts an accurate survey would show provided that title was not rendered unmarketable thereby. The seller contended that no proceedings had been taken to condemn the property, that any proposed street entirely encompassing his land and buildings deprived him of a substantial property right without just compensation, and that the statute under which the map accomplishing such a result was adopted was unconstitutional and could not have created an encumbrance. The court held that there had been no determination that the statute was unconstitutional and that the buyers could not have been required to accept a title that may have been perfected only by litigation. The buyers were entitled to summary judgment.


OUTCOME: The court granted the seller's cross-motion to the extent of permitting the amendment of the counterclaim and denied the balance of the cross-motion. The court granted the buyers' motion for summary judgment.

 

2779 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


National Steel Corp. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


1 Misc. 2d 1012; 121 N.Y.S.2d 61; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1425



April 28, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporation filed an action for declaratory judgment against defendant City of New York, New York, alleging that the General Business and Financial Tax Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ RR41-1.0 et seq, B46-1.0 et seq., was unconstitutional. The corporation also sought a money judgment for a refund of taxes paid to the City.


OVERVIEW: The corporation, engaged in the business of manufacturing and selling steel, maintained an office in the City from which salesmen worked to secure orders from customers throughout the surrounding states. When an order was received, it was forwarded to the corporation's home office in another state for acceptance. Once accepted, it was forwarded to plants in two additional states to be filled. The City assessed taxes against the corporation, which paid them under protest. The corporation filed a declaratory judgment action against the City and sought the refund of the taxes paid. The court entered judgment for the corporation and held that no part of the corporation's business could have been termed intrastate. The tax imposed upon the corporation constituted an attempt by the City to tax the privilege of soliciting interstate business and was on no better footing than a tax upon the privilege of doing interstate business. Such a tax constituted a violation of the commerce clause of the United States Constitution and was invalid. The court also held that the corporation's activities in the City were so related to interstate commerce as to be protected as an integral part thereof.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of the corporation and ordered the City to refund the taxes the corporation had paid, together with interest.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- interstate commerce -- New York City's Business and Financial Tax Law cannot constitutionally be applied to corporation which only solicits interstate business here; judgment granted for refund, despite failure to comply with refund procedure.

1. The New York City General Business and Financial Tax Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, § RR41-1.0 et seq.; § B46-1.0 et seq.) cannot constitutionally be applied to interstate commerce. Plaintiff, a Delaware corporation, manufactures steel in its plant in Ohio and its plant in West Virginia. Plaintiff has never had any plants, warehouses, inventories or stock in trade anywhere in the city or State of New York. It does maintain an office in the city of New York from which salesmen or solicitors go forth into New York State and parts of New Jersey and Connecticut. All orders procured must be and are forwarded to plaintiff's home office for acceptance or rejection. Accepted orders are shipped from either West Virginia or Ohio. Plaintiff's entire business is such manufacture and sale throughout the United States, f.o.b.  [***2] plaintiff's plants. This is wholly and exclusively interstate commerce. The city's tax is an unconstitutional imposition on the privilege of soliciting interstate commerce and constitutes a violation of the commerce clause of the United States Constitution, and is therefore declared invalid as to this plaintiff.

2. Plaintiff is also entitled to a money judgment for the taxes it has paid under such mistake of law, with interest.

3. Plaintiff, who challenges the constitutionality of this tax legislation, is not bound by the refund procedure set up in the law (§ RR41-6.0).

 

2780 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tatje


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court of New York, Borough of Queens, Municipal Term


203 Misc. 949; 121 N.Y.S.2d 147; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1718



April 28, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City of New York sought a conviction against defendant for violating New York City, N.Y., Bureau of Smoke Control R. 1.1.1.


OVERVIEW: An inspector for the New York City Bureau of Smoke Control observed dense black smoke coming from an apartment building for approximately 12 minutes. Defendant, the building superintendent, was observed coming from the boiler room and was charged with violating Rule 1.1.1. The court found defendant guilty as charged. The court held that the fact that dense smoke was being discharged from the stack of the premises under the control of defendant for a period of approximately 12 minutes was established beyond all reasonable doubt. The court determined that it was not necessary to prove the defendant wilfully discharged the smoke because there was no contention that the discharge was accidental or unavoidable. The court held that defendant failed to prove that Rule 1.1.1 was invalid or unreasonable, and thus the court upheld it. The court found that prior notice of the violation to defendant was not required as a prerequisite to his prosecution. The court determined that Rule 1.1.1 remained in effect notwithstanding the fact that the Bureau had been dissolved because the law dissolving the Bureau expressly so stated.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- smoke control -- (1) defendant superintendent caused dense smoke to be discharged from chimney of apartment house under his control; defendant found guilty of violating rule 1.1.1 of Rules and Regulations of New York City Bureau of Smoke Control -- (2) proof that defendant acted willfully in discharge of smoke unnecessary -- (3) prohibition against discharge of dense smoke reasonable and constitutional -- (4) rule 1.1.1 did not become extinct upon creation of department of air pollution control and elimination of bureau of smoke control since statute creating department provided that rules of former bureau be continued until repealed or amended; rule was neither repealed nor amended -- (5) no conflict exists between requirements of department of air pollution control and health departments of city -- (6) prior notice of violation to be served on defendant not condition precedent to prosecution.

1. A charge that defendant superintendent caused dense smoke to be discharged from the chimney of an apartment house under control of defendant for a period of approximately [***2] twelve minutes was established beyond a reasonable doubt. Accordingly, defendant is found guilty of violating rule 1.1.1 of the Rules and Regulations of the Bureau of Smoke Control of the City of New York.

2. Proof that defendant acted willfully in causing the emission of smoke was not necessary. The prohibition of dense smoke is a malum prohibitum, and discharge of smoke for the statutory time violates the law without regard to the elements of knowledge, intent or willfulness.

3. Regulation of smoke control and air pollution is reasonable and not unconstitutional. The presumption is in favor of the validity of such rule. The burden of showing unreasonableness is upon a defendant who attacks the legislation. Defendant having failed to come forward with such proof and the rule not being unreasonable on its face as a matter of law, the rule must be upheld as valid.

4. Rule 1.1.1 was enacted by the bureau of smoke control. Thereafter in September, 1952, a new department of air pollution control was created. A contention that rule 1.1.1 was not carried forward upon the creation of the new department should be overruled. The acts creating the new department of air pollution [***3] control (Local Laws, 1952, Nos. 114, 115 of City of New York) provided that the rules and regulations of the bureau of smoke control in force at the time the local laws took effect should continue until repealed or amended. Since the rule was neither repealed nor amended, it is applicable.

5. The claim that there is a conflict between the requirements of the department of air pollution control and the health department of the city should be overruled. Furnishing heat and hot water to tenants in accordance with the Penal Law and the regulations of the board of health did not require defendant to emit dense smoke from the fuel-burning equipment. There is nothing in the air pollution law or in its observance which conflicts with the sanitary code or the Penal Law.

6. It was not a condition to defendant's prosecution that prior notice of violation be served upon him.

 

2781 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Salzman v. Impellitteri


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


203 Misc. 486; 124 N.Y.S.2d 369; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2174



April 20, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed an action against defendant city officials for a declaratory judgment that legislative acts creating and funding the New York City Transit Authority were unconstitutional. Intervenor, state attorney general, was permitted to intervene.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer sought a declaratory judgment that the legislative acts creating and funding the New York City Transit Authority (authority) were unconstitutional. The court denied the taxpayer's motion for a temporary injunction, denied the city's motion for judgment on the pleadings, denied the attorney general's motion to dismiss, and granted the attorney general's motion for judgment on the pleadings declaring the legislative acts constitutional. The court held that the legislative acts did not violate the state constitutional provision prohibiting the city from making a loan to private entities or extending its credit to private or public entities. The court reasoned that funds borrowed by the city to reimburse the capital costs of the authority were borrowed for the city's own benefit. Thus, the court concluded, the authority would be acting as aquasi-trustee for the city.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayer's motion for a temporary injunction, denied the city's motion for judgment on the pleadings, denied the attorney general's motion to dismiss, and granted the attorney general's motion for judgment on the pleadings declaring the legislative acts constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional law -- validity of transfer of transit facilities to New York City Transit Authority -- (1) in taxpayer's action to declare chapters 200-208, inclusive, of Laws of 1953 unconstitutional, pleadings indicate existence of justiciable controversy -- (2) chapters 200 and 201 create New York City Transit Authority for purpose of acquiring and operating New York City's present transit facilities; chapter 201 provides that agreement of transfer, if made, should provide that capital costs should be paid by city; Constitution (art. VIII, § 1) provides that no city shall give or loan "money or property" in aid of "private corporation" and no city shall loan its "credit" in aid of "public corporation"; gift of moneys to public corporation for public purpose not forbidden; chapters 200 and 201 permit city to issue bonds and notes to raise funds to reimburse authority for capital costs; chapters further provide that, at end of term, properties transferred to transit authority should revert to city; in these circumstances, funds borrowed by city to reimburse authority for capital costs constitute borrowing for city's own benefit and not prohibited by Constitution -- (3) transit  [***2] authority not given power by chapter 200 to require levy of assessments prohibited by Constitution (art. VIII, § 3) -- (4) Constitution (art. X, § 5) not violated since city not liable for payment of obligations issued by authority -- (5) chapter 200 requires city to pay capital cost of $ 44,000,000 per year; minimum term of agreement between city and transit authority is ten years; city's constitutional debt margin is approximately $ 500,000,000; since city not compelled to contract with transit authority for more than ten years, act not unconstitutional on theory that city's constitutional debt incurring power exceeded -- (6) conditioning city's right to enact payroll tax and increase real estate tax rate upon city's entering into agreement with transit authority for transfer of its transit facilities not unconstitutional as giving authority right to grant or withhold taxing power -- (7) no proof offered that Legislature, in granting city taxing power conditionally, acted in bad faith and not to prevent abuses in taxation and assessments as required by Constitution (art. IX, § 9) -- (8) Legislature constitutionally directed appointment of officers of transit authority -- (9) chapters  [***3] 200 and 201 did not violate Constitution (art. IX, § 11) notwithstanding chapters were not passed upon request of city and upon concurrent action of two thirds of members of each house of Legislature; laws relating to rapid transit not included in phrase "property, affairs or government" of city within Constitution (art. IX, § 12); statutes do not deprive city of ownership of property without due process of law -- (10) chapters 204 and 205, in imposing condition upon power of city to raise real estate tax rate, did not interfere with city's right to home rule; request of city and approval by two thirds of each house of Legislature not required -- (11) Constitution (art. III, § 17) prohibiting passage of law relating to street railroad without consent of local authorities not violated; city's consent to transfer facilities to transit authority not given under "duress" -- (12) that chapter 200 provides that member of board of Port of New York Authority be member of transit authority does not constitute invalid modification of interstate laws creating Port of New York Authority -- (13) city's motion for judgment on pleadings declaring statutes unconstitutional is denied, and Attorney-General's  [***4] motion on pleadings declaring chapters 200-208, inclusive, constitutional is granted.

1. A taxpayer's action under section 51 of the General Municipal Law seeks a declaratory judgment that chapters 200-208, inclusive, of the Laws of 1953 are unconstitutional. An allegation in the amended complaint that the Mayor and the City of New York are about to avail themselves of the provisions of chapters 200 and 201 of the Laws of 1953 (adding and amending Public Authorities Law, art. 7, tit. 15, §§ 1800 through 1821, entitled "New York City Transit Authority") and to appoint some of the members of the New York City Transit Authority, therein created, as well as to arrange for the conveyance of the city's transit lines to the authority must be deemed true for the purpose of the motion of the Attorney-General, as intervening defendant, to dismiss the amended complaint. The answer of the Mayor and board of estimate of the city does not deny such allegation and is silent on the subject. In this state of the pleadings the court may not assume that the Attorney-General is correct in his claim that the city authorities do not intend to avail themselves of the new legislation. A justiciable [***5] controversy therefore does exist. (P. 492.)

2. Chapters 200 and 201 of the Laws of 1953 create the New York City Transit Authority for the purpose of acquiring and operating the facilities now operated by the board of transportation of the City of New York. The statutes authorize, but do not compel, the City of New York to enter into an agreement with the transit authority for the transfer to the latter of the city's transit facilities. Chapter 201 provides that the agreement, if made, should require the city to pay the capital costs of a nature not theretofore charged as operating expenses (§ 4, subd. 1, par. b). Chapters 202 and 203 authorize the City of New York to impose a payroll tax upon salaries received for work performed in the city of New York. Chapters 204 and 205 authorize the city to increase the real estate tax rate above the rate presently permitted. Chapter 208 authorizes the city to issue serial bonds in a prescribed maximum amount to provide for the city's pension contribution on behalf of transit employees during the fiscal years 1951-1952. Chapters 202, 203, 204, 205, and 208 are effective only on condition that the City of New York transfer its transit [***6] facilities to the transit authority prior to July 1, 1953. Section 1 of article VIII of the State Constitution provides that no city "shall give or loan any money or property to or in aid of any individual, or private corporation or association, or private undertaking * * * nor shall any * * * city give or loan its credit to or in aid of any individual, or public or private corporation or association, or private undertaking". By such constitutional provision a city is forbidden in the case of a private corporation to "give or loan any money or property", but in the case of a public corporation the city is forbidden only to "give or loan its credit" (italics supplied). There is therefore no prohibition against gifts of moneys to a public corporation for a public purpose, at least where the local unit does not borrow the money so given or loaned. Chapters 200 and 201, while permitting the city to issue bonds or notes to raise funds with which to reimburse the authority for capital costs incurred by the authority, do not compel or require the city to do so. The city could validly agree to pay the capital costs incurred by the transit authority where it is under no [***7] compulsion to "give or loan its credit", i.e., to borrow. Assuming, however, that such provision of chapter 201 so authorizing the city to issue bonds or notes is unconstitutional as a gift or loan of the city's credit in aid of a public corporation, the city could, should it elect to do so, waive this privilege, intended solely for its benefit, and agree to reimburse the authority without resorting to issuance of bonds or notes or other means of borrowing funds. Moreover, section 1821 of the Public Authorities Law provides that upon termination of the agreement of transfer, the city should succeed to the rights of the authority. Section 1806 of said law provides for a sale of the city's omnibus facilities by July 1, 1955, the proceeds thereof to be paid to the city.
