The essential nature of this transaction is a temporary transfer for a term of years with a reversion to the city. The capital costs incurred by the authority during the period of its possession of the facilities would enhance the value of the properties which the city would get back at the end of the term. In these circumstances, funds borrowed by the city for the purpose of reimbursing the authority for the [***8] capital costs incurred by the latter are actually and in substance being borrowed for the city's own benefit, since the transit authority's possession and control would be that of a quasilessee or trustee acting on behalf of and for the benefit of the city. Such borrowing is not the type of borrowing prohibited by the Constitution (art. VIII, § 1), for the Constitution seeks to forbid only borrowing by the local unit for the benefit of another without benefit to itself. (Pp. 493, 495-497, 499, 500.)

3. Section 3 of article VIII of the Constitution provides that "No municipal or other corporation * * * possessing the power (a) to contract indebtedness and (b) to levy taxes or benefit assessments upon real estate or to require the levy of such taxes or assessments, shall hereafter be established or created". Although the transit authority under section 1807 of the Public Authorities Law is given the power to "issue notes in anticipation of the receipt of revenues" and to sell the notes at public or private sale, it is not given the power to levy or to require the levy of taxes or assessments on real estate. It cannot compel the city to do so in its behalf. The city may, if it [***9] so elects, raise the funds necessary to discharge its obligations to the authority by taxes or measures which do not involve real estate taxes or assessments. Although some provisions of the Rapid Transit Law -- which have been continued by chapter 200 -- permit the transit authority in certain cases to require the levy of assessments upon real property, this requires the joint action of the authority and the board of estimate. Thus the power to require the city to levy assessments does not reside in the transit authority even in cases governed by the Rapid Transit Law. Consequently, the authority was not given the power to require the levy of assessments within the meaning of section 3 of article VIII of the Constitution. (P. 500.)

4.There is no provision in chapter 200, or in the agreement therein authorized, which would render the city liable for the payment of obligations issued by the authority. The incurring of debts for capital costs, which the city may be required by the authority to pay, is not the issuing of obligations which a public corporation may not do under section 5 of article X of the Constitution. (P. 501.)

5. The agreement provided for by chapter 200 would [***10] require the city to pay more than $ 44,000,000 per year to the transit authority to meet the capital costs to be incurred by the transit authority. The minimum term of the agreement is fixed at ten years. During this minimum period, the city would be obligating itself for more than $ 440,000,000. As of July 1, 1952, the amount of debt which the city was free to incur under section 4 of article VIII of the Constitution was approximately $ 46,000,000 and its debt-incurring margin under subdivision E of section 7 of article VIII was approximately $ 500,000,000. So the city's constitutional debt-incurring limit would not be exceeded if the term were only ten years. Since chapter 200 does not by its terms compel the city to enter into an agreement for a period of more than ten years, the statute may not be held unconstitutional on the theory that the city, if it accepts and complies with the statute, will be required to exceed its constitutional debt-incurring limit. (Pp. 501, 502.)

6. Chapters 202, 203, 204, and 205 empower the city to impose a payroll tax and to increase the real estate tax rate, but the privileges are made conditional upon (a) the city's entering into an agreement [***11] on or before June 1, 1953, with the transit authority for the transfer of the city's transit facilities to the authority and (b) completion of the transfer prior to July 1, 1953. It is possible that the terms insisted upon by the transit authority may be so onerous that the city and the authority may not reach agreement. Should this occur the city would lose the right to increase the real estate tax and to impose a payroll tax. It does not follow, however, that the Legislature has therefore conferred upon the transit authority the right to grant or withhold the taxing power and that the Legislature has thus acted unconstitutionally. The taxing power has not been vested in an appointive body. Since the Legislature was under no obligation to authorize the city to impose a payroll tax and to increase the real estate tax rate, it had a right to impose as a condition of conferring those powers the requirement that the city divest itself of its transit facilities and turn them over to a public authority. (Pp. 502, 503.)

7. A claim that the Legislature could restrict the power of taxation under section 9 of article IX of the Constitution only "so as to prevent abuses in taxation and [***12] assessments" and that what the Legislature did was for an "illegal" purpose "to unlawfully deprive the City of its property without due process of law" is rejected. Chapters 202-205, inclusive, did not further restrict the city's taxing powers, but instead lifted the restrictions upon those powers, though conditionally. Moreover, there is no proof that the Legislature was motivated by some improper purpose having no relation to the prevention of abuses in taxation and assessments. There is insufficient basis either in the record or in matters of which the court may take judicial notice to warrant a finding that the Legislature, in attempting to obtain the city's consent to a transfer of ownership and operation of its transit lines to an independent public authority, did not act in good faith and in the honest belief that this solution of the transit problem was in the public interest and would tend to prevent some abuses of taxation and assessments. (Pp. 503, 504.)

8. The Legislature constitutionally provided that the members of the transit authority should be appointed instead of elected (N. Y. Const., art. IX, § 8). (Pp. 504, 505.)

9. Chapters 200 and 201, in dealing with [***13] rapid transit in a city, do not concern the "property, affairs or government" of a city within the meaning of section 11 of article IX of the Constitution. Therefore it was not necessary that the statutes be passed upon the request of the Mayor, concurred in by the city council, or upon the request of two thirds of the elected members of the New York City Council, and be passed upon the concurrent action of two thirds of the members of each house of the Legislature. That section 12 of article IX of the Constitution authorizes a city to adopt local laws relating to "the ownership and the operation of its transit facilities" does not take from the State Legislature its constitutional right to enact laws relating to rapid transit in cities, for section 11 of article IX provides that the provisions of the article shall not be deemed to restrict the power of the Legislature to enact laws relating to matters "other than the property, affairs or government of cities". The amendments to the Constitution made in 1938 did not have the effect of withdrawing from the Legislature the right to enact special legislation for any city dealing with the subject of transit. The Constitution is unambiguous [***14] in providing that the Legislature might do so. Since it is only if the city voluntarily enters into an agreement with the transit authority that it may be deprived of its ownership of the transit lines, it is clear that the statutes do not violate due process of law. (Pp. 505-507, 509.)

10. The enactment of chapters 204 and 205, which impose a condition upon the power of the city to raise the real estate tax rate, does not interfere with the city's right to home rule, for the chapters do no more than lift, to a limited extent, theretofore existing restrictions upon such rate and do not force or compel the city to do anything. That the chapters could be taken advantage of by the city only upon condition that the city made an agreement with the transit authority did not change the legal situation and make necessary a request by the city and approval by two thirds of each house of the Legislature. (P. 510.)

11. The claim that chapter 200 violates section 17 of article III of the Constitution which prohibits the passage of a law authorizing construction or operation of a street railroad without the consent of the local authorities in control of the street, it being claimed that the [***15] city is compelled to give its consent to the transfer under "duress", should be rejected. A Legislature cannot be guilty of duress vitiating its enactments. The Legislature had a right in the public interest to attempt to persuade the city to transfer ownership and operation of the city's transit facilities to an independent public authority and to deny the city taxing powers -- which it could validly withhold -- unless the city should agree to the transfer. (Pp. 510, 511.)

12. Chapter 200, by providing for the appointment of the chairman or member of the Port of New York Authority as a member of the transit authority, did not constitute an invalid attempt by New York State, acting alone, to modify the interstatelaws pursuant to which the Port of New York Authority was created. No duties are imposed on the Port Authority itself or upon any of its members as such. That a member of the Port Authority may, in addition to his duties as such member, also serve as a member of the transit authority does not constitute a modification of or interference with the compact and the interstate laws creating the New York Port Authority. (P. 511.)

13. Accordingly, the city's motion [***16] for judgment on the pleadings declaring various chapters of the Laws of 1953 unconstitutional in whole or in part is denied, and the motion of the Attorney-General for judgment on the pleadings declaring chapters 200 to 208, inclusive, constitutional is granted. (P. 511.)

 

2782 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Raxor Corp. v. Goody


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part X


121 N.Y.S.2d 882; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1800



April 1, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a record manufacturer and an exclusive wholesale distributor, filed an action to enjoin defendant retailer from selling records at prices less than the minimum retail resale prices established by fair trade agreements between plaintiffs and other retailers.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer made record albums that the wholesaler sold to retailers. These record sales were in fair and open competition with others of the same general class, but were protected by fair-trade agreements in which other retailers agreed not to resell the records for less than a certain price. Plaintiffs filed an action against the retailer, who resold the records for lower prices despite these free-trade agreements. Plaintiffs sought an injunction against the retailer's practices pursuant to the Feld-Crawford Act, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 369 et seq. The court granted the plaintiffs' request for the injunction, despite the retailer's claims that the free-trade agreements were unlawful methods of competition under federal and state fair trade laws and violated the Sherman Antitrust Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1 et seq. The court ruled that nothing in the record indicated that plaintiffs' action was commenced either pursuant to or in furtherance of an illegal contract, agreement, or combination between plaintiffs and any other manufacturer or distributor. The court further found that the State was empowered to promulgate legislation and fair trade laws that affected interstate sales.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for plaintiffs, enjoining the retailer from selling records at lower prices that prescribed in plaintiffs' fair trade agreements.

 

2783 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Tropp v. Knickerbocker Village


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


205 Misc. 200; 122 N.Y.S.2d 350; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1850



March 24, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs public housing tenants brought a declaratory judgment action against defendants public housing landlords (landlords) and the Commissioner of Housing of the State of New York (Commissioner) seeking a declaration that the new rent schedules imposed under the provisions of N.Y. Pub. Hous. Law § 182 subd. 3 were unconstitutional. All parties sought judgment on the pleadings.


OVERVIEW: The tenants claimed that the rent increase provisions of § 182 subd. 3 were unconstitutional because they impaired the obligation of the tenants' contracts, deprived the tenants of property without due process, and constituted an unlawful delegation of authority. The court rejected these claims and held that § 182 subd. 3 was constitutional and that the schedule fixing rents proportionate to the tenants' ability to pay was not illegal or arbitrary. Thus, the court granted the motion for judgment on the pleadings in favor of the Commissioner and the landlords. The court held that N.Y. Const. art. XVIII, §§ 1 and 10 granted the legislature the power to provide low-income housing and that the delegation of power to the Commissioner to enforce rent increases was clearly defined and proper. The court also held that there was no denial of due process by applying the rent increases to all public housing tenants without a separate hearing for each tenant, which would be unduly burdensome to the Commissioner and the landlords. In addition, the court held that the statute did not exclude pre-existing housing projects from its scope and was properly applied to these tenants.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion for judgment on the pleadings in favor of the landlords and the Commissioner and denied the motion for judgment on the pleadings sought by the tenants.


HEADNOTES

Public housing -- limited-dividend housing -- (1) action by tenants in housing developments against respective landlords and State Commissioner of Housing for judgment declaring invalidity of provision of Public Housing Law ( § 182, subd. 3, par. [a], cl. [3], as amd. in 1951) permitting tenant whose income had risen above permitted maximum to remain in possession of apartment under certain contingencies, but upon payment of rental increased in proportion to ability to pay, as determined by company with approval of commissioner; provision not unconstitutional, even as applied to housing developments constructed before amendment and to tenants theretofore in possession -- (2) where all parties made similar motions on basis of complete pleadings, parties conceded no question of fact existed -- (3) where material facts admitted and only questions of law to be determined, motion for judgment on pleadings proper -- (4) Supreme Court not necessarily bound, because another remedy available, to decline to entertain action for declaratory judgment; remedy particularly appropriate where constitutional question involved and legality and meaning  [***2] of statute in question, and no issue of fact presented -- (5) statute will be declared unconstitutional only when shown beyond reasonable doubt to conflict with fundamental law -- (6) tenants acquired certain rights of occupancy by reason of applicable statutes and of tenancies pursuant thereto; those rights limited by statutes under which possession obtained in first instance, and under which, as amended from time to time, tenants continued in occupancy -- (7) limited-dividend, low-rent housing excluded from rent control under State Residential Rent Law; State justified in providing another scheme to protect landlord and tenant in developments during emergency -- (8) 1951 amendment to Public Housing Law, authorizing tenant disqualified by reason of increase in income to remain on payment of increased rent, conferred benefit on tenant rather than deprived him of property in violation of Constitution -- (9) formula set up by Legislature of rent-income ratio for fixation of maximum rents not violative of constitutional rights -- (10) Legislature may not delegate power to make law, but may confer discretion in execution of law -- (11) when delegation of discretionary powers to official  [***3] lawful, stated -- (12) provision of statute empowering housing company to increase rentals in proportion to tenant's ability to pay more, with approval of commissioner, not unconstitutional delegation of legislative functions -- (13) no unconstitutional delegation of judicial function to commissioner in promulgation of rent schedule -- (14) tenants not deprived of property without due process of law because no hearing afforded on question of rent increase -- (15) contention that restrictions under 1939 statute not applicable to plaintiffs because projects in which they resided constructed before 1939, and restrictions under 1949 statute inapplicable because not present when plaintiffs became tenants, untenable -- (16) no repeal of earlier statute resulted because 1939 statute referred to projects "hereafter constructed" and 1949 statute to projects "heretofore and hereafter" constructed -- (17) 1949 amendment to Public Housing Law manifested legislative intention to make low-income ratio provisions theretofore in use applicable generally by precise legislative enactment, rather than by statutory implication or regulatory procedure.

1. Tenants of limited-dividend housing corporations,  [***4] in an action against their respective landlords and the Commissioner of Housing of the State of New York, sought a judgment declaring the invalidity, as applied to them, of that provision of the Public Housing Law ( § 182, subd. 3, par. [a], cl. [3], as amd. in 1951) permitting a tenant whose income had risen above the specified ratio of income to rent, to remain in possession of his apartment under certain contingencies, but upon payment of a rental increased in proportion to his ability to pay, as determined by the company with the approval of the commissioner. The provision was not unconstitutional, even as applied to housing developments constructed before the enactment of such amendment and to tenants theretofore in possession.

2. Where all the parties in the action appeared, and, with the pleadings in complete form, each made similar motions on the basis of those pleadings, the parties thus conceded that there existed no question of fact, and that the issues presented to the court for decision were solely questions of law.

3. Where the material facts were admitted and only questions of law were to be determined, a motion for judgment on the pleadings under section 476 of [***5] the Civil Practice Act and rule 112 of the Rules of Civil Practice was properly made and could be entertained by the court in the exercise of its discretion.

4. While a court may, in the exercise of its discretion, refuse to proceed to a declaratory judgment when other remedies are available and adequate, when there exists a genuine controversy requiring a judicial determination, the Supreme Court is not bound, solely because another remedy is available, to decline to exercise the power conferred upon it with reference to the remedy of declaratory judgment (Civ. Prac. Act, § 473; Rules Civ. Prac., rule 212). The remedy of declaratory judgment was particularly appropriate where a constitutional question was involved, and the legality and meaning of a statute were in question, and where no issue of fact was presented.

5. Where a statute is attacked on constitutional grounds, the court's province is to take the measure of the statute's validity, not to weigh its desirability. A statute can be declared unconstitutional only when it can be shown beyond reasonable doubt that it conflicts with the fundamental law, and until every reasonable mode of reconciliation of the statute with the [***6] Constitution has been resorted to, and reconciliation has been found impossible, the statute will be upheld.

6. The right to establish rents is in the owner of the property, and is a matter for his sole determination, unless there exists some statutory or contractual limitation. There were no existing leases between the parties. The tenants, however, acquired certain rights of occupancy by reason of applicable statutes and of tenancies pursuant thereto, and those rights were limited by statutes under which possession was obtained in the first instance, and under which, as amended from time to time, the tenants continued in occupancy.

7. While limited-dividend, tax-exempt, low-rent housing projects were excluded from the control established by the State Residential Rent Law to apply to ordinary residential dwellings, the Legislature was empowered to establish, and was justified in providing for, another statutory scheme whereby protection might be afforded under the existing emergency in housing to landlord and tenant in developments constructed under the State Housing Law.

8. The Public Housing Law as amended in 1951 (§ 182, subd. 3, par. [a], cl. [3]) authorized the tenant,  [***7] in the event of inability to secure other safe and sanitary housing accommodations, or undue hardship, to remain as a tenant, even though by reason of increase in income he had become disqualified to continue as such. The statute, as amended, also provided for increased rentals commensurate with increased tenant incomes. The primary intention of the statute was to effectuate the policy and purpose of the State Constitution and the Public Housing Law, in the light of the existing housing emergency, to provide dwelling accommodations for persons of low income, and at the same time to prevent the hardship of eviction from affecting residents of such projects whose income had risen above the prescribed limits. As properly read and understood, the statute as amended conferred a benefit upon the tenants, rather than, as contended, deprived them of property in violation of the Constitution.

9. The Legislature was empowered to set up a formula of a rent-income ratio for the fixation of maximum rents on low-rent projects built and maintained by limited-dividend corporations. The formula adopted was not in any sense unreasonable or violative of any basic constitutional rights.

10. The Legislature [***8] may not delegate power to make a law, which necessarily involves a discretion as to what the law shall be, but it may confer discretion in its execution, to be exercised under and in pursuance of that law.

11. The Legislature does not abdicate its functions, in delegating authority, when it describes what job must be done, who must do it, and what is the scope of his authority. Where standards are provided which, though stated in general terms, are capable of a reasonable application and are sufficient to limit and define the administrative official's discretionary powers, the delegation of such powers to the administrative official is lawful.

12. The provision of the statute empowering the housing company to increase rentals in proportion to the tenant's ability to pay more, with the approval of the Commissioner of Housing, was a necessary and practical expedient and could not reasonably be construed as an unconstitutional delegation of legislative functions, where the Legislature itself declared and defined the manner in which the rents of the tenants, whose income exceeded the statutory ratio, should be increased.

13. Nor was there an unconstitutional delegation or unlawful exercise [***9] of a judicial function. That there were factual bases, consideration, deliberation and determination preceding the commissioner's promulgation of the challenged schedule, did not mean that there was impermissible exercise of a judicial duty.

14. The tenants were not deprived of property without due process of law because no hearing was afforded on the question of the rent increase. The formulas for rent increases as promulgated by the commissioner were practical and a fair compliance with the spirit and letter of the statute. The precise increase of the rent to be charged a particular tenant whose income had increased, in proportion to his ability to pay more as provided in the schedule, had been reduced to a ministerial function, and there was no legal necessity for a continuing and repeated computation and fixation of individual rentals.

15. An amendment in 1939 to the Public Housing Law ( § 182, subd. 3), enacted after completion of the projects involved but before plaintiffs' occupancy of their respective apartments, provided that dwellings in a housing company project "hereafter constructed" should be available for persons of restricted annual income. In 1949, after construction [***10] of the projects involved and occupancy by plaintiffs, that section was amended to make housing developments "heretofore and hereafter" constructed available for tenants whose incomes were not in excess of a prescribed maximum. The plaintiffs' contention that the 1939 restrictions did not apply to them because the projects in which they resided were constructed before 1939 and that the 1949 restrictions were not applicable to them because they imposed restrictions on continued occupancy not present when plaintiffs became tenants, was untenable.

16. No repeal of the earlier statute resulted from the circumstance that the 1939 statute referred to projects "hereafter constructed" and the 1949 statute to projects "heretofore and hereafter" constructed. There was clearly no express nullification and repeal by implication is not favored by the law.

17. The 1949 amendment to the Public Housing Law, making that law applicable in express statutory language to housing projects theretofore and thereafter constructed, manifested a legislative intention to make the low-income ratio provisions theretofore in use applicable generally by precise legislative enactment, rather than by statutory implication [***11] or regulatory procedure.

 

2784 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Vernon Park Realty, Inc. v. Mt. Vernon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


122 N.Y.S.2d 78; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1811



March 5, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff realty corporation sought a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief against the defendant City of Mount Vernon (city). The city had passed a zoning ordinance that barred the realty corporation from using the land for business development.


OVERVIEW: The realty corporation sought a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief against the city. The realty corporation sought a judgment declaring the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Mount Vernon, and amendments thereto, unconstitutional in so far as it affected its use of its property for business and commercial uses. The court determined the ordinance was unreasonable and arbitrary in character and amounted to a confiscation of the realty corporation's property without due process of law. The court held there was no basis for restricting the property to a residential use. The court stated the differential in valuation under the respective uses was so disproportionate as to amount to a confiscation of the realty corporation's property for an avowed public use without just compensation. The city contended the court should decline jurisdiction because the realty corporation had not shown good faith, and because the realty corporation could return the property to the Railroad Company in the event the zoning ordinance was not changed by the Common Council or by the Court. The court refused to impute bad faith to the realty corporation.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of the realty corporation finding that the ordinance at issue was unreasonable and arbitrary in character and amounted to a confiscation of the realty corporation's property without due process of law.

 

2785 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Schneiderman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrate's Court of New York, Borough of Queens, Municipal Term


203 Misc. 1064; 119 N.Y.S.2d 688; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1568



March 3, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant pet shop owner was charged with a violation of New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 327(5).


OVERVIEW: Defendant admitted possession for sale in his pet shop of horsemeat greater in dimension than one-half inch. He contended however that as applied to him, the code was unreasonable, arbitrary, oppressive, and capricious; an unlawful delegation of legislative power to administrative officers; and unconstitutional because it was discriminatory and denied him equal protection of the law. The curt held that because it was not contended that there was any provision of the Federal or State law with which the local law collided or was inconsistent, the board of health of the City of New York was not only acting within its power but in furtherance of the duties and responsibilities imposed upon it when it undertook to make reasonable rules and regulations for the disposition and sale within the city of New York of horsemeat. The provisions that horsemeat should be less than a certain size in every dimension so that it may not possibly be palmed off on an unsuspecting public as legitimate food fit for human consumption was neither unreasonable nor arbitrary. Accordingly, the validity of New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 327(5)was sustained, and defendant was found guilty.


OUTCOME: Defendant was found guilty.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- regulation of sale of horseflesh -- (1) defendant, owner of pet shop, having in his possession horsemeat greater in dimension than one-half inch guilty of violation of New York City Sanitary Code (§ 327, subd. 5) -- (2) board of health of City of New York acted within power in making reasonable rule for regulation of sale of horsemeat; provision that horsemeat be less than one-half inch in any dimension not arbitrary.

1. Subdivision 5 of section 327 of Sanitary Code of City of New York provides that horsemeat shall not be kept for sale or sold unless chopped so that no piece shall be greater than one-half inch in any dimension. Defendant, owner of a pet shop who had in his possession for sale horsemeat greater in dimension than one-half inch, is guilty of violating said section.

2. The board of health of the City of New York was acting within its power and in furtherance of the responsibilities imposed upon it when it undertook to make reasonable rules for the sale within the city of New York of horsemeat. The provision that horsemeat be of a certain size in every dimension, so that it might not [***2] be palmed off on an unsuspecting public as a legitimate food for human consumption, is neither unreasonable nor arbitrary. Subdivision 5 of section 327 is a valid enactment.

 

2786 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lunmor Homes, Inc. v. Johnson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


122 N.Y.S.2d 149; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1818



March 3, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowner instituted a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to compel respondent building inspector to issue certificates of occupancy.


OVERVIEW: The landowner appeared before a town board to obtain building permits for his property. The landowner agreed with the town board that if the permits were issued, certificates of occupancy would not be issued until improvements were made on the property. The town board subsequently required a performance bond. The improvements were not made within the specified time period and the town board brought suit. The landowner then filed a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to compel the building inspector to issue the certificates of occupancy. The court denied the landowner's petition. The court held that the town board was permitted to call for a bond and require performance of improvements under N.Y. Town Law §§ 276 and 277. The court found, however, that that the town board was not permitted to condition the award of the permits on improvements. The court reasoned that by conditioning the permit on the performance, the town board deprived the landowner of his right to challenge the denial of the permits directly to the Zoning Board of Appeals as set forth under N.Y. Town Law § 280-a. The court relegated the landowner to the position of being able to appeal the town board's decision.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landowner's petition to compel the building inspector to issue building permits and ordered that the landowner be permitted to challenge the denial of the permits to the Zoning Board of Appeals.

 

2787 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


General Electric Co. v. S. Klein-On-The-Square, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part IV


121 N.Y.S.2d 37; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1709



February 19, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff manufacturer brought an action to enjoin defendant retailer from selling appliances for less than the stipulated price.


OVERVIEW: The retailer sold appliances for less than the price stipulated by the manufacturer. The court granted an injunction to the manufacturer because the McGuire Act, 15 U.S.C.S. § 45, and the New York Fair Trade Law (Trade Law), N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§ 369a, 369b, 369c, 369d, 369e were valid and the manufacturer fulfilled the criteria of those statutes. There was a valid contract that stipulated a price even though a subsequent price list was issued pursuant to the provisions of the paper signed by the retailer. When the manufacturer was permitted by the contract to change the prices occasionally, the contract as changed was as completely voluntary, consensual, and cooperative as the original. The manufacturer was entitled to protection pursuant to the Trade Law and the McGuire Act even though the manufacturer sought to require price stipulation on only some products and the contract contained express provisions that excepted certain groups from the stipulated retail prices. The Trade Law was not invalid as a deprivation of liberty of property without due process. The McGuire Act was not an unlawful delegation to the states of the power of Congress to regulate interstate commerce.


OUTCOME: The court granted an injunction to the manufacturer that enjoined the retailer from selling appliances for less than the stipulated price.

 

2788 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Toth


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


120 N.Y.S.2d 807; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1691



February 17, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, a girl, brought a petition for a writ of habeas corpus, claiming that it was illegal to arraign, hear, and dispose of the matter at a term of the court that was held in a county and borough other than the county of her residence and in which the acts and conduct complained of took place. She argued that the creation and organization of one Girls' Term Court for the entire City of New York was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The girl and her father resided in the County and Borough of Bronx and the acts of the girl complained of and alleged to confer jurisdiction occurred in such county and borough. The girl was, however, brought before the girls' term so established and held in the Borough of Manhattan and the hearing held and order of disposition was rendered at such term. The court held that while the New York City Magistrates' Courts were inferior local courts of limited jurisdiction, the legislature had power to make the jurisdiction of a term of such courts city-wide. By virtue of the provisions of the N.Y. Const. art. 6, § 18, the jurisdiction of the magistrates' courts as local courts of criminal jurisdiction could be localized within the territorial limits of the City of New York. The court held that the legislature, by the Girls' Term Court Act 1951 N.Y. Laws 716, authorized the organization and holding of a girls' term in one borough to render an order of disposition of girls residing in other boroughs and involving moral delinquency and misconduct occurring in other boroughs. Accordingly, the Girls' Term of the City Magistrates' Court had jurisdiction of the girl.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the writ and remanded the girl to custody.

 

2789 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Skating Vanities Co. v. State


Claim No. 31012


Court of Claims of New York


203 Misc. 779; 119 N.Y.S.2d 184; 1953 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1521



February 14, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant insured brought an action against the State of New York to recover premiums from the New York State Insurance Fund (fund). The insured argued the fund improperly exacted premiums for workmen's compensation insurance policy issued to the claimant. The state urged that the claimant contracted to pay rates higher than those of the Compensation Insurance Rating Board (rating board) and could not recover.


OVERVIEW: The insured's business was covered through the fund. The fund increased his rates and he paid them. The insured brought an action for reimbursement. The court dismissed the claim. The claim challenged the fund's power to depart from the rating board rates and did not question whether the premiums charged were otherwise excessive, arbitrary or unreasonable. The court held that N.Y. Ins. Law § 89 was not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power and its reasonableness standard for determining premium rates was proper. The operation of the fund was not a delegation of legislative function because the fund was not empowered to fix the rates chargeable by private carriers. It was authorized merely to fix rates upon policies of insurance it issued. Even upon the assumption that there was a delegation of ratemaking authority, a sufficiently definite standard was embraced in the statute. The court further found that the fund was authorized to set premiums higher than the rates fixed by the rating board.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the insured's claim for reimbursement of insurance premiums from the state insurance fund.


HEADNOTES

Workmen's compensation -- rates of State Insurance Fund -- (1) claimant seeks recovery of premiums allegedly improperly exacted in respect to workmen's compensation insurance policy issued by State Insurance Fund; policy provided that rates would be unconditional 200% over "board rates"; Compensation Insurance Rating Board established "board rates"; State Insurance Fund is member of board, but is exempt by law from premiums established by board; policy issued to claimant made subject to retrospective rating plan calling for adjustment of premiums based on claimant's actual loss experience; State Fund empowered by Workmen's Compensation Law ( §§ 83, 89) to fix premium rates; claim dismissed -- (2) Workmen's Compensation Law ( § 89) does not delegate legislative power without proper standards in fixing of premium rates -- (3) State Fund had power to adopt rates 200% over "board rates" -- (4) State Fund did not adopt more than "a" system of merit rating -- (5) if premiums of 200% over board rates were in violation of law, claimant had right to recover overpayments -- (6) despite last payment  [***2] of premium on September 29, 1950, where adjustment of premium finally made on March 15, 1951, filing on April 11, 1951, of notice of intention to sue and of claim on October 29, 1951, timely -- (7) since governmental rate-making not involved, claimant not confined to proceeding to review; claim involves construction of contract of insurance between State agency and claimant of which Court of Claims has jurisdiction.

1. Claimant seeks recovery from the State Insurance Fund of premiums claimed to have been improperly exacted by the fund in connection with a renewal policy of workmen's compensation insurance issued to claimant. Prior to writing such policy, the fund advised claimant that its accident record during its latest insurance period was substandard and that the policy would be renewed "on the basis of unconditional 200% over Board Rates". The indorsement on the policy read "uncond. 200% B. R." and contained a clause that it was subject to a retrospective rating plan which provided for periodic adjustments of the premiums paid, based on the insured's actual loss experience during the insurance period. The State Insurance Fund was a member of the Compensation Insurance Rating [***3] Board which promulgated such "board rates". The State Fund, although a member of said rating board, is expressly exempted from the rates made by said board (Insurance Law, § 44, subd. 3; § 180 et seq.). The fund is empowered by section 83 of the Workmen's Compensation Law to fix premium rates, and section 89 provides that employments shall be divided into classes based upon differences in hazard for the purpose of establishing premium rates and for such purpose a system of merit rating may be employed to take account of the peculiar hazard of each individual risk. Section 89 then provides: "Premiums in the state fund shall be fixed at the lowest possible rates consistent with the maintenance of a solvent fund and of reasonable reserves and surplus". The claim should be dismissed.

2. Section 89 of the Workmen's Compensation Law does not delegate legislative power to the State Insurance Fund without proper standards to be followed in the fixing of premium rates. The standards of rate-making set forth in section 89 are sufficiently definite to guide the administrative agency. The Legislature was not required to fix the individual rates applicable to thousands of employers [***4] in many industries, but the fund was instructed by the statute to take into account all of the factors which affect the hazard of each risk and was further required to fix rates consistent with the maintenance of a solvent fund and of a reasonable reserve and surplus.

3. The State Fund had power to depart from "board rates" even though it had adopted the rates fixed by the rating board. Accordingly, it had power to establish a rate 200% over "board rates", subject to adjustment under the retrospective rating plan.

4. The contention that more than one merit system has been adopted in violation of section 89 of the Workmen's Compensation Law which authorizes the fund to adopt "a" system of merit rating is rejected. Such view is too literal and imposes an unduly restricted interpretation upon the language of section 89 of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

5. A contract of insurance in violation of the Insurance Law is against public policy and unenforcible, and so if premiums fixed at 200% over "board rates" were illegal, such payments made under a mistake of law could be recovered (Civ. Prac. Act, § 112-f).

6. The last premium payment was made on September 29, 1950. Since the rates [***5] were expressly made subject to adjustment after payment and were in fact revised on March 15, 1951, the notice of intention to sue filed on April 11, 1951, and the claim filed on October 29, 1951, were timely. Until March 15, 1951, claimant could not ascertain the amount, if any, of his damage.

7. Since governmental rate-making is not involved, claimant is not limited to a review under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act. The claim concerns the construction and validity of a contract of insurance entered into between a State agency and claimant, a matter expressly reserved to the jurisdiction of the Court of Claims (Court of Claims Act, §§ 8, 9).

 

2790 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Crone v. Brighton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


19 Misc. 2d 1023; 119 N.Y.S.2d 877; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1519



December 31, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners applied to respondent town for a permit to build and operate a service station on their property. After the town granted a temporary permit, a rehearing was held, based on a newly invoked prohibition in the zoning ordinance, and the landowners' application was denied. The landowners brought actions before a New York trial court, one seeking to declare the ordinance unconstitutional, and the other for a variance.


OVERVIEW: The court held first that the landowners had established a right to a variance in the zoning ordinance. They brought out essentially uncontradicted evidence that the land in question had no other purpose than use as a service station, therefore presenting a right to be granted a variance on the ground of "unnecessary hardship." Further, acknowledging that the court had limited power to substitute its judgment for that of the duly constituted authorities, it found that the decision to rescind the temporary permit and deny the landowners' application was arbitrary and capricious. The court held that the evidence indicated that the town took this action on a trumped-up excuse, fabricated after the temporary permit had been granted, and that it did not provide adequate notice of the objection to the permit to the landowners. On these findings, the court held that he landowners had the right to the temporary permit on a variance from the letter of the zoning ordinance. Having made this holding, it found that the question of the validity of the ordinance was no longer subject to determination.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the determination of the town's planning board denying the landowners' application, and issued a temporary permit. It denied the town's motion for a dismissal of the petition. It denied landowners' motion for judgment on the complaint to invalidate the ordinance, but granted the application for a variance.


HEADNOTES

 [**1] Municipal corporations -- zoning -- because of unique and unnecessary hardship, variance is ordered granted so as to permit gasoline service station for temporary term not exceeding five years -- plenary suit to adjudge zoning confiscatory and unconstitutional dismissed, since grant of variance is adequate remedy.

1. A town which had homes, some commercial areas, and practically no industrialization, adopted a zoning ordinance in which an area which was changing from residential uses to commercial uses was zoned as commercial. The ordinance defined "commercial" as excluding gasoline service stations, but provided that an application could be made for a permit for not exceeding five years for such a station, but that no such station could have an entrance or exit within 300 feet of the entrance or exit of an existing school or church. An owner of an irregularly shaped plot in said zone, on an arterial highway, tried for years in vain to sell or lease his plot for any residential or commercial purpose, and finally could lease it only to a national gasoline corporation for use as a modern gasoline service station. The owner's application for such a five-year variance was granted [**2] at first; but then, when some residential neighbors objected and a church suddenly placed a gate in the rear fence of its premises within 300 feet of the proposed gasoline station, the board reconsidered and denied the variance. In this review proceeding, the court finds that in fact the church gate has no real use, that a modern gasoline service station would not be detrimental to the residences in this area, that the owner has no other reasonable use of his property, and that therefore, by reason of his unique and unnecessary hardship and handicaps and the practical difficulties, he is entitled to a variance. Accordingly, the court directs the board to grant him a temporary permit for not exceeding five years for the operation of a motor vehicle supply station in accordance with his filed plans and specifications.

2. By a separate, plenary suit, which has been tried together with this review proceeding, the owner also seeks to have the zoning ordinance declared confiscatory and unconstitutional as to his property. However, since the above determination (headnote par. 1) gives him an adequate remedy, his suit is dismissed, without costs.

 

2791 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Port of New York Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


202 Misc. 1104; 118 N.Y.S.2d 11; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2101



December 17, 1952 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Order Affirmed February 17, 1953; See 281 App.Div. 818, 118 N.Y.S.2d 921 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant landowner brought a motion to dismiss a proceeding brought by plaintiff port authority for the condemnation of real property.


OVERVIEW: In connection with its action to condemn real property, the port authority filed a verified petition setting forth the assessed valuation of the property for the purposes of taxation for the preceding three years, as required by 1947 N.Y. Laws 819(1)(e)(3). The landowner sought dismissal of the action on the basis that such requirement was in contravention of the due process clauses of the federal and New York constitutions, U.S. Const. Amends. V, XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6, in that the assessed valuation was made the standard of just compensation. The court disagreed and denied the landowner's motion to dismiss. In so ruling, the court stated that there was nothing in 1947 N.Y. Laws 819(1)(e)(3) that provided that assessed valuations were the sole and fixed criterion of just compensation. Indeed, 1947 N.Y. Laws 819(1)(o) directed the court, after hearing the testimony and considering the proof, to ascertain and estimate the compensation which should justly be made by the port authority. Further, nothing in the statute precluded the landowner from rebutting and overcoming the assessed valuations by contradictory and better evidence.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landowner's motion to dismiss the port authority's proceeding for condemnation of real property.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- assessed valuation as element of value -- statute authorizing Port of New York Authority to take real property by eminent domain provides that petition shall state assessed valuation of property to be taken; owner of damage parcel claims that statute unconstitutional; statute does not make assessed valuation sole standard of value; value subject to proof; statute constitutional.

The Port of New York Authority applied by verified petition, pursuant to chapter 819 of the Laws of 1947, for an order condemning certain real property and directing that the compensation of the respective owners of the property be determined by the court without a jury. The statute required the Port Authority to set forth in its petition the assessed value of each parcel of real property for each of the three years preceding the date of the petition, which the Port Authority did set forth. The contention of the owner of one of the damage parcels on its motion to strike out the petition that the Port Authority is not entitled to any relief thereunder [***2] because the statements of assessed valuation therein render the pleadings unconstitutional should be rejected. The statute does not provide that the assessed valuation shall be admitted in evidence or that it shall operate as a presumption in determining just compensation or shall constitute prima facie evidence of just compensation; nor does it contain any direction to the court which, in any manner whatever, requires it to consider the element of assessed valuation; nor does it attempt to set up any guide to substitute for the court's judgment in evaluating the condemned property. The statute does not provide that the assessed valuations shall be the sole and fixed criterion of just compensation or shall constitute the sole and exclusive standard of just compensation. The statute does not arbitrarily fix a value of the property which it compels the owner to accept. Assuming that the provision as to assessed valuation creates a presumption of value and renders hearsay evidence admissible with respect thereto, this does not render such legislation unconstitutional or give rise to a claim of lack of procedural due process. The statute creates no positive or conclusive state of [***3] facts. It merely dispenses with formal proof of the assessed valuations, matters of public record. Nothing in the statute precludes the owner from rebutting them by contradictory and better evidence. The statute is constitutional.

 

2792 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Schell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Schenectady County


203 Misc. 689; 118 N.Y.S.2d 481; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2166



December 5, 1952 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of conviction reversed, information dismissed and the defendant discharged. Submit order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the Police Court of the City of Schenectady (New York) that was rendered upon a verdict convicting him of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 483(2) on the ground that the court was divested of jurisdiction to try him on a second information and that his constitutional rights were prejudiced in that he was not granted a speedy trial.


OVERVIEW: The evidence indicated that defendant was arrested without a warrant and before in information was filed. Upon his initial appearance and without advice of counsel, bail was fixed and defendant was remanded to jail. The police justice, on his own motion, adjourned the proceeding until a later date. The police justice subsequently ordered defendant to a state hospital for a mental examination. The matter was thereafter adjourned several more times, and defendant was discharged from custody on the ground that he was deprived of his rights in violation of U.S. Const. amend. VI. However, defendant was later arrested a second time on an identical information. Defendant was ultimately tried, found guilty by a jury, and sentenced to county jail. The court reversed the judgment of conviction, dismissed the information, and discharged defendant. The court held that the record failed to reveal any reason for the adjournments in the case, and that there was not even a substantial compliance with N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 756, which required the police justice to make a return to all matters stated in the affidavit and certify and cause the same to be filed with the county clerk.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's criminal conviction, dismissed the information against him, and discharged him from custody.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- right to speedy trial -- (1) more than five months elapsed between arrest and ultimate trial of defendant; adjournments taken by court; defendant obtained discharge from custody under writ of habeas corpus; defendant tried and found guilty under second information alleging same facts; defendant's conviction reversed and defendant discharged -- (2) Sixth Amendment to Federal Constitution guarantees to defendant accused of crime, right to speedy trial; Second Class Cities Law (§ 190) applicable to Police Court of Schenectady, in which defendant tried, provides for adjournment of not more than eight days from joining of issue unless parties consent to longer adjournment entered in minutes; minutes do not show any consent to adjournment; section 190 applicable and carries out constitutional right -- (3) failure of Police Justice to certify and file with  [***2] County Clerk proper return violated defendant's substantial rights.

1. Defendant was arrested without a warrant and before an information was filed, and the proceeding against him was adjourned to January 23, 1952. On the adjourned date an information was read to defendant and the proceeding was again adjourned. Other adjournments occurred -- the record showing no sufficient reason therefor -- until May 16, 1952, when the court fixed June 7, 1952, for trial of the complaint with a jury, and announced that a jury would be selected on May 28, 1952. Defendant's counsel objected to such a lengthy adjournment. Defendant then made application for a writ of habeas corpus based upon the violation of defendant's rights under the Sixth Amendment to the Federal Constitution. The court sustained the writ and discharged defendant from custody. On May 26, 1952, another information identical with the original information was filed and a warrant of arrest issued. After defendant was brought before the Police Justice, his attorney moved for dismissal of the information and discharge of defendant on the ground that the court lacked jurisdiction. Defendant entered a plea of not guilty and [***3] demanded a trial by jury. The court fixed June 4, 1952, as the date of trial. Apparently defendant was tried before a jury and found guilty and defendant appeals from such conviction. The conviction should be reversed and the information dismissed and defendant discharged.

2. The Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution provides that in all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy trial. Section 190 of the Second Class Cities Law which applies to the Police Court of the City of Schenectady, in which defendant was tried, provides that if defendant demands a trial by jury, the Police Justice shall adjourn the case not more than eight days from the joining of issue, unless the parties consent to a longer adjournment, which consent shall be entered in the minutes of the court. The minutes do not show any consent by defendant to an adjournment. Section 190 applies and carried out the purpose of the Sixth Amendment and brings to local jurisdictions the right of a defendant to a speedy trial.

3. The return of the Police Justice omits the minutes of the trial and contains only a certified copy of the record of conviction, together with minutes of [***4] adjournments and a stipulation by counsel. It does not appear that such stipulation was part of the record. There seems to be no authority for such stipulation as the minutes of the trial are the best record of the proceedings. Section 756 of the Code of Criminal Procedure requires that the magistrate or court rendering the judgment must make a return and cause the same to be filed in the office of the County Clerk within ten days after the service of the affidavit of appeal. Such requirement is mandatory and imposes on the Police Justice the duty to make the return himself, and he must under his own signature certify the return and cause the same to be filed with the County Clerk. There has not been even a substantial compliance with this section, and defendant's substantial rights have been denied thereby.

 

2793 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Berkowitz v. Wilson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


118 N.Y.S.2d 291; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2147



November 25, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff claimant filed an action against defendants, the Commissioner of Education and the Board of Regents, seeking a judgment declaring unconstitutional N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 7401-7412, as amended by 1952 N.Y. Laws 706. The claimant also sought a permanent injunction restraining the Commissioner and the Board from enforcing the statute. The parties filed cross motions for judgment on the pleadings.


OVERVIEW: The claimant, a non-certified accountant, sought a judgment declaring N.Y. Educ.. Law §§ 7401-7412, as amended by 1952 N.Y. Laws 706, unconstitutional. He also sought a permanent injunction restraining the commissioner from enforcing the statute. The claimant alleged that by placing high standards for certified public accountants and by providing for their being disciplined for infractions or violations of standards, the certified accountant was afforded appearance of being a member of a licensed regulated profession while stigmatizing the non-certified accountant as being of a lower degree of character, competency, and integrity. The claimant also alleged that the statute was unfair because no provision was made to regulate the non-certified accountant. The court granted the motion for judgment on the pleadings filed by the Commissioner and the Board, and held that the challenged statute was constitutional. According to the court, the right to be certified as a public accountant was something in the nature of a privilege, and the claimant could not complain because he was not given a status to which his qualifications did not entitle him.


OUTCOME: The court held that the amended statute regulating certification of public accountants was constitutional, denied the claimant's motion for judgment on the pleadings, and granted the motion for judgment on the pleadings filed by the Commissioner of Education and the Board of Regents.

 

2794 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Leonard v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Part III


118 N.Y.S.2d 170; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2126



November 17, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff union brought an action seeking a declaratory judgment as to the rights and legal relations of the union and defendant employer under a collective bargaining agreement and N.Y. Ins. Law §§ 213, 213-a. The union sought an injunction pendente lite to restrain defendant insurance commissioner from preventing the employer from paying its employees more than the amounts imposed by §§ 213, 213-a.


OVERVIEW: In a collective bargaining negotiation with the union, the employer, an insurance company, maintained that §§ 213, 213-a prevented it from increasing wages or benefits for its employees. The union sought a declaration of the parties' rights under §§ 213-213-a and further requested an injunction pendente lite to enjoin the insurance commissioner from enforcing the wage limitation in the statute. The trial court dismissed the complaint, noting that the union alleged that the employer would not negotiate because it had no funds out of which it could properly pay any wage or similar increase. The union was seeking to have the trial court pass on the effect and constitutionality of the statutes so that the employer's excuse for not proceeding could be tested against the statutory norm of good faith. A decision as to the employer's good faith was outside the trial court's jurisdiction. The trial court further held that no present justiciable controversy as to the effect or constitutionality of these statutes had been asserted, and thus, the union had had no direct interest in the question of the applicability of the statutes. Accordingly, an action for declaratory judgment would not lie.


OUTCOME: The trial court rendered judgment dismissing the complaint.

 

2795 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Jiffy Auto Laundry, Inc. v. Monaghan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County, Part I


118 N.Y.S.2d 189; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2129



November 17, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action to declare unlawful the acts of defendants, Police Commissioner of the City of New York (New York) and a police captain, in enforcing the Sabbath Law, N.Y. Penal Law § 2143, plaintiff proprietors sought a temporary injunction to restrain defendants from trespassing on their property and interfering with their business. The matter was before the trial court for decision.


OVERVIEW: The proprietors operated an auto laundry business. After they had been charged with violating § 2143 by operating on a Sunday, they were acquitted on the grounds that their business was within the statutory exception for "works of necessity." When they were later charged with another violation of § 2143, they brought an action to enjoin defendants from interfering with their business and sought a temporary injunction restraining defendants from trespassing on the business property or interfering with the conduct of the business. The trial court denied the motion, explaining that equity could not be used to prevent enforcement of the criminal law. The trial court noted that the proprietors could raise the issue of the constitutionality of a statute for whose violation they had been indicted either by motion to dismiss, by habeas corpus, or by plea.


OUTCOME: The trial court denied the motion for a temporary injunction.

 

2796 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


N. H. Lyons & Co. v. Corsi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


203 Misc. 160; 116 N.Y.S.2d 520; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1907; 22 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P67,188



October 10, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff owner filed a declaratory judgment action against defendant Industrial Commissioner of the State of New York seeking a declaration that an order governing minimum wage standards in the "hotel industry" promulgated by the commissioner was illegal and invalid and seeking an injunction to enjoin the enforcement of the order.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner promulgated an order governing minimum wage standards in the "hotel industry," which included any establishment that offered lodging accommodations for hire to the public, and providing that it applied to males 21 years of age or over, to women, and to minors. The owner of men's lodging houses alleged that the order was illegal and sought to enjoin its enforcement against men's lodging houses. The court held that: (1) the commissioner had authority to establish minimum wages for women and minors; (2) by N.Y. Lab. Law art. 19, § 563-a, which provided that when fixing the minimum wages for women and minors, it would be unlawful to pay to men in the same occupation a wage less than the minimum fixed for women and minors, a minimum wage for men was provided; (3) a statute prescribing minimum wages for men did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment; and (4) in including the owner's lodges in his definition of the "hotel industry," the commissioner did not exceed his jurisdiction because it was not illegal to treat bedmakers and clerks in the lodges as being engaged in the same class of work as chambermaids and waitresses in fine and expensive hostelries.


OUTCOME: The court found no invalidity in the commissioner's order and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Master and servant -- minimum wages -- (1) State Industrial Commissioner has power to establish minimum wages for women and minors -- (2) Labor Law (§ 663-a), providing that men employed in occupation, for which minimum fixed by commissioner for women and minors, shall be paid not less than minimum is constitutional -- (3) legislative finding of facts or declaration of policy unnecessary to validity of statute -- (4) commissioner's order fixing minimum wages for women in hotel industry which applies to lodging houses on Bowery is valid despite fact that women prohibited from being employed therein by law.

1. The State Industrial Commissioner has authority to establish minimum wages for women and minors.

2. Section 663-a of the Labor Law, contained in article 19 which deals with minimum wages for women and minors, provides that, to protect the minimum wage standards and rates provided for women and minors, no male shall be employed at less than the wages fixed for women and minors in the same occupation. While the Legislature has not fixed minimum wages for men, it has made it unlawful to pay men, in an occupation for which minimum [***2] wages have been fixed by the commissioner for women and minors, less than such minimum. In that sense and to that extent, the Legislature has provided a minimum wage for men, and such legislation is valid, since an act of Congress prescribing minimum wages for men was held not to violate the Fourteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

3. A legislative finding of facts or declaration of reasonableness of the relation of a statute to the end sought to be obtained is not essential to the validity of section 663-a. Validity depends upon the existence of such state of facts or of such reasonableness and not upon the presence or absence of a legislative finding upon the subject.

4. The Industrial Commissioner promulgated a mandatory order governing minimum wages in the "hotel industry" which was defined as including "any establishment which, as a whole or part of its business activities, offers lodging accommodations for hire to the public, to employees, or to members or guests of members." While lodging houses are not hotels under either the common-law conception of hotels or under the definitions contained in many statutes, the commissioner in including Bowery lodging houses,  [***3] such as those run by plaintiff, in his definition of "hotel industry", did not exceed his jurisdiction and did not act arbitrarily or capriciously. The commissioner was not bound to adopt the common-law conception or a statutory definition of a hotel. The word "occupation" contained in former section 552 (now § 652) of article 19 of the Labor Law (L. 1937, ch. 276) means "an industry, trade, business or class of work in which women or minors are gainfully employed". In section 663-a the word "occupation" means class of work, regardless of who is employed therein. If the bedmakers and clerks in Bowery lodging houses are in the same occupation as the women and minors employed as chambermaids, waitresses, clerks, etc. in fine hostelries, the order is valid despite the fact that lodging houses do not employ women or minors and are prohibited by law from so doing.

 

2797 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Matosin v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


203 Misc. 973; 117 N.Y.S.2d 532; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2044



October 9, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant City filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings in plaintiff restaurant owner's action for a declaratory judgment that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code ch. 46, tit. F was unconstitutional, invalid, and void. The enactment was a city tax on the privilege of selling liquor, wine, or beer at retail for on- or off-premises consumption.


OVERVIEW: The owner possessed a liquor license permitting the sale at retail of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption. He assailed New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code ch. 46, tit. F as being generally and constitutionally invalid, as being unfair, discriminatory. He claimed that it denied equal protection and due process of the laws in violation of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, that it was violative of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 22 in failing to state distinctly the object of the tax, and that it was violative of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law. He asserted that it was unreasonable and was multiple taxation. The court dismissed the complaint. The court held that it would serve no useful purpose to again enter upon a detailed discussion in upholding the validity of the local law as to do so would be merely to indulge in a repetitious disquisition.


OUTCOME: The court granted the City's motion for judgment on the pleadings dismissing the owner's complaint and made a declaration that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code ch. 46, tit. F was a valid and constitutional enactment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- local tax on retail liquor sales -- (1) New York City Local Law No. 58 for 1952 imposing tax for privilege of selling liquor, wine or beer at retail is constitutional -- (2) complaint in action for declaratory judgment that statute is unconstitutional dismissed, and statute declared constitutional.

1. New York City Local Law No. 58 for 1952 (Administrative Code of City of New York, ch. 46, tit. F) imposing a municipal tax equal to 25% of the license fees payable under the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law for the privilege of selling liquor, wine or beer at retail for on- or off-premises consumption in the city of New York is a valid and constitutional enactment.

2. Accordingly, the complaint in this action for a declaratory judgment that the statute is unconstitutional should be dismissed and a declaration is made that said local law is constitutional.

 

2798 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McLean Trucking Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


202 Misc. 604; 116 N.Y.S.2d 292; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1866



September 30, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff trucking companies brought an action against defendant Defendants City of New York challenging the validity of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code ch. 46, tit. E imposing use tax on commercial motor vehicles and seeking an injunction restraining its enforcement.


OVERVIEW: The companies claimed that the tax imposed by New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code ch. 46, tit. E was not one authorized by the legislature, that the tax violated tax limitations contained in N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 10 & 11(11), and N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 54, and that the tax was an unconstitutional regulation of or burden upon interstate commerce. The court dismissed the complaint. It was patently clear that the tax was precisely the tax the legislature authorized under 1947 N.Y. Laws ch. 278, § 3. The thing that determined the incidence of the tax was the use of commercial vehicles upon the City streets principally in connection with a business carried on within the City. The provisions N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 10 & 11, and N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 54 were so modified by 1947 N.Y. Laws ch. 278, § 3 that they no longer prohibited the tax imposed. So far as interstate commerce was concerned the tax was valid because it was not a tax on the privilege of engaging in interstate commerce but a tax on the use of streets or highways in the state and City. It did not in discriminate against interstate commerce and it did not constitute an unreasonable burden upon interstate commerce.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the complaint by the trucking companies that challenged the local tax on commercial vehicles and that sought injunctive relief, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- tax on commercial vehicles by city -- constitutional law -- use tax on commercial vehicles as interference with interstate commerce -- (1) by chapter 278 of Laws of 1947, city with population of million or more empowered to adopt local law imposing tax on use of commercial vehicles in connection with business carried on within city; Local Law, 1952, No. 59 of City of New York, imposes tax on use of commercial vehicles within city; such tax authorized by Legislature and local law valid -- (2) even though businesses of plaintiffs may be interstate, each picks up merchandise by motor carrier in city and uses streets of city for that purpose; each plaintiff subject to tax to extent to be determined by comptroller -- (3) claim that statute authorizes tax on use of motor vehicles while local law imposes tax on use of streets of city rejected -- (4) Vehicle and Traffic Law provides that registration fee should be in lieu of all taxes to which motor vehicles may be subject; such provision modified by chapter 278 for it provides for imposition of tax "Notwithstanding any  [***2] other provisions of law to the contrary"; tax not condemned by Vehicle and Traffic Law -- (5) although plaintiffs engaged in interstate commerce, tax does not burden interstate commerce and not invalid -- (6) question whether regulations of comptroller under which tax administered create inequity deferred for future consideration since at present time no discriminatory administration shown -- (7) no unlawful delegation of legislative power given by authorizing comptroller to make regulations to carry out law.

1. By chapter 278 of the Laws of 1947, a city having a population of one million or more was empowered to adopt local laws imposing in such city taxes on the use of trucks, buses, and other commercial vehicles used principally in connection with a business carried on within the city. The City of New York adopted Local Law No. 59 of 1952, which imposes a tax of $ 10 on the use of commercial vehicles in connection with a business carried on within the city. The tax imposed by the local law is precisely the tax authorized by the Legislature, and accordingly, the claim of plaintiffs, interstate motor carriers, that such local law is invalid should be rejected.

2. What determines [***3] the incidence of the tax is the use of commercial vehicles upon the streets of the city principally in connection with a business carried on within the city. Even assuming that plaintiffs' businesses are purely interstate, they all pick up and deliver merchandise in the city and use the streets of the city for that purpose; each plaintiff therefore is subject to the tax to an extent to be determined by the city comptroller.

3. A contention that the statute authorizes a tax on the use of motor vehicles, while the local law imposes a tax on the use of streets of the city, is rejected. The tax authorized, as well as the tax imposed, is a tax on the use of motor vehicles on the streets of the city.

4. The Vehicle and Traffic Law (§ 11, subd. 11) provides that registration fees should be in lieu of all taxes to which motor vehicles may be subject. Said subdivision was modified and superseded by chapter 278 of the Laws of 1947, for in section 3 it was provided that "Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary" any city with a population of one million or more was empowered to impose the tax here involved. Moreover, even if a 1951 amendment of the Vehicle and Traffic [***4] Law could be regarded as a reiteration, as of its date, of the general prohibition against local taxes, nevertheless the specific authorization of local taxes contained in chapter 278 of the Laws of 1947, would have to be given effect in preference to a general prohibition in the Vehicle and Traffic Law, upon the principle that the particular prevails over the general. In fact, however, the authorization of local taxes is reiterated in chapter 742 of the Laws of 1952, and that authorization is the latest legislative expression, and hence controlling. The tax does not violate the Vehicle and Traffic Law.

5. Plaintiffs, although engaged in interstate commerce, are bound by all local laws which, although affecting interstate commerce, do not unreasonably burden it. The tax herein is a tax on the use of the streets of the city and not a tax on the privilege of engaging in interstate commerce. It does not in any way discriminate against interstate commerce, and there is no evidence that it constitutes an unreasonable burden on interstate commerce.

6. The question whether the city comptroller has promulgated regulations under which the tax will be unequally and unfairly administered [***5] between persons in the same class should be saved for the future, for if there is discrimination it exists purely on paper in the form of regulations and does not yet exist in actual practice.

7. The local law, while permitting the comptroller to make rules and regulations, does not contain an unlawful delegation of legislative power. The rule-making power is limited to making regulations appropriate to the carrying out of the law.

 

2799 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Central Westchester Humane Soc. v. Hilleboe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Westchester County


202 Misc. 881; 116 N.Y.S.2d 403; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1888



September 22, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, humane society and two taxpayers, filed a complaint for a declaratory judgment declaring that N.Y. Public Health Law § 5-a was unconstitutional.
