Defendant Commissioner of Health of the State of New York field a motion to dismiss the first, fourth and fifth causes of action for insufficiency in law.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed a complaint for a declaratory judgment declaring that N.Y. Public Health Law § 5-a, commonly known as the "Metcalf-Hatch Act", was unconstitutional and for an injunction restraining the Commissioner from acting under the provisions of the statute. The Commissioner field a motion to dismiss the first, fourth and fifth causes of action for insufficiency in law claiming that the respective plaintiffs pleading said causes had no right of action and that said causes should be dismissed for insufficiency and for lack of capacity in plaintiffs to sue. On consideration, the court dismissed the first, fourth and fifth causes of action. The court held that the causes of action were insufficient in that they failed to show any right of relief in favor of the respective plaintiffs; thus, it was not necessary for the court to pass directly upon the points of constitutionality of the statute. Plaintiffs lacked standing to challenge the statute since there was no showing that any of the rights of the particular plaintiffs in animals owned or held by them, or other interests of plaintiffs had been or would be infringed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the first, fourth and fifth causes of action in plaintiffs' complaint.


HEADNOTES

Animals -- use of animals for medical research -- action for judgment declaring that Public Health Law (§ 5-a), which provides for use of stray animals in medical research, is unconstitutional; causes of action by humane society which maintains pound for animals and by individual owners of dogs and cats, dismissed for insufficiency where plaintiffs do not show infringement of their rights or likelihood of material injury.

In an action for judgment declaring that section 5-a of the Public Health Law, which permits use of stray animals for medical research, is unconstitutional, one cause of action on behalf of a humane society, which gives shelter to dumb animals and which had contracted with a city to impound animals running at large, and two causes of action in behalf of residents and taxpayers, who own pet cats and dogs, respectively, should be dismissed for insufficiency. Such causes of action fail to show any right of relief in favor of such plaintiffs. There is no showing that any of the rights of plaintiffs in animals owned or held by them, or other interests of plaintiffs, have been [***2] or will be infringed. There is no showing of actual or likely material injury. That plaintiffs are taxpayers does not give them any standing, in the absence of statute, to have the courts pass upon the constitutionality of a particular law. Allegations to the effect that animals owned or held by plaintiffs may be seized and eventually surrendered for scientific experiments against the desires of plaintiffs do not show an interest required for the maintenance of an action attacking the validity of the statute. Allegations that humane societies will discontinue their operations if required to surrender animals for experimental use and that as a result municipalities will be required to maintain pounds at public expense do not give plaintiffs standing to maintain the action. Moreover, plaintiff humane society whose contract with a city to collect stray animals expires June 30, 1952, will not have any animals seized or possessed on or after July 1, 1952, when section 5-a takes effect. The contention that animals now in possession of plaintiff society, as carried over on the expiration of the contract, may be seized and impounded and thereby brought within the class of animals subject [***3] to the law is too remote a possibility to afford a basis for action.

 

2800 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Yonko


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Magistrates' Courts, City of New York, Arrest Court, Borough of Bronx


115 N.Y.S.2d 560; 1952 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1713



September 3, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with engaging in a confidence game known as the "Gypsy Swindle," in violation of the amended provisions of N.Y. Penal Law § 722(6).


OVERVIEW: The addition of subdivision 6 to N.Y. Penal Law § 722 had been designed as a means of preventing the acts of swindlers who proposed, by their acts, to defraud innocent victims of property. As the facts did not reveal an attempt to obtain money by trick, artifice, swindle, or confidence game or an attempt to obtain money by a "Gypsy Swindle," the People contended that the facts did reveal an obtaining of money in an illegal manner, namely, "Fortune Telling" and that in consequence defendant came under the prohibition of the words in N.Y. Penal Law § 722(6), "or in any other illegal manner." The court noted that defendant's unsolicited approach to approximately 25 strangers, as well as the place and manner of the approach, the lack of previous acquaintance with those accosted and the repetition, and the systematic conduct of defendant reduced the likelihood of mistake or mere coincidence. The court found that such conduct was of a disorderly person tending to breach the peace and serenity of the public. In finding defendant guilty, the court concluded that where there was fortune telling for hire there was an obtaining of money in an illegal manner.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty of violating the cited statutory provision.
